column2: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 When major league club owners and general managers gather in the West for the World Series next week, one man they won't go out of their way to meet is Fred Haney. The feller might just talk 'em out of their store teeth.

Two key merchandising appointments at Macy's New York and Bamberger's New Jersey department stores were announced yesterday by Wheelock H. Bingham, president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., the parent company.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 24 Mr. and Mrs. William K. Allison have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Virginia Allison, to Robert Thayer Powers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Powers of Boston and East Orleans, Mass.
James R. Hoffa declared open war yesterday on the A.F.L.C.I.O. in New York State.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 The Soviet Union displayed today a new jet airliner designed to carry 182 passengers from Moscow to New York nonstop in about nine hours.
The Bank of Tokyo Trust Company, New York, an affiliate of the Bank of Tokyo, Ltd., yesterday opened a midtown branch at 320 Fifth Avenue at the northwest corner of 32d Street.

The Sarah Lawrence College Chorus, conducted by Harold Aks, presented a concert in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. It was the same program with which the group toured Europe, singing 13 concerts in six countries in 31 days.
To spread employment among its membership, which has dwindled from a maximum of 1,500 in 1939 to 250 at present, the Hebrew Actors Union is arranging for the presentation of various entertainments.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 24--Thomas E. Doremus, an executive of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for nearly 50 years before his retirement in 1941, died last night at his home here. He was 88 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 24 Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, will meet Chancellor Adenauer next Monday to discuss Britain's membership in the European Economic Community, or Common Market.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 Robert M. Morgenthau said today that local school districts badly needed more financial help from the state and that much more should be done to expand the State University.
FORT WORTH, Sept. 24 Eight young pianists performed today as the $10,000 Van Cliburn International Piano Competition got under way.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 The Soviet Government announced today that it was postponing scheduled income tax cuts to help pay for further economic development and increased defense preparedness.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24 Bartholomew Morris, driving Cardinal Return in the sixth race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, was thrown out of his sulky and dragged 300 feet when his trotter was put off stride approaching the stretch turn.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 24 "Some solid evidence" of Federal fiscal responsibility was called for today by Ladd Plumley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
BERLIN, Sept. 24 The Russians held up for more than two hours today an American Army convoy bringing new troops to the United States garrison in West Berlin across East Germany.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 The General Assembly formally approved tonight a 92-item agenda for its current 17th session.
An art quarterly devoted to drawings from the 14th century through the 19th will appear here in the spring.
ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 24 The effects of a dusk-to-dawn curfew and other security measures decreed by President Kwame Nkrumah for Accra, Ghana's Capital, disrupted normal life in the city today.
Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association rejected proposals by Federal mediators yesterday for a oneyear contract with the New York Shipping Association.
OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 24 Gov. Ross R. Barnett ordered today the imprisonment of any Federal official who sought to arrest or fine Mississippi officials for defying court desegregation decrees.
A theater party in behalf of the Menninger Foundation has been arranged at the Nov. 27 performance of "Lord Pengo" at the Royale Theater.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 24 The Long Island Sound team of International One-Design Class skippers, representing the United States, won the opening race of the 23d international series for the Amorita Cup today.

ELBA. IN the geography of high fashion, the road from Paris to Bangkok passed through Australia and Elba this month. As Queen Sirikit of Thailand was acclaimed for her elegance during her official visit to New Zealand and Australia, Pierre Balmain, the Paris couturier to the Queen, vacationed at his villa here.
A $100,000,000 redevelopment project for the central business district in Cincinnati has been awarded by the City Council to the Emery Knutson Development Corporation.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 AP--Alejandro Lavorante, Argentine heavyweight injured in a boxing match Friday, remained in a semi-coma today with slightly better than a 50-50 chance of living.
HELSINKI, Sept. 24 Premier Ahti Karjalainen defended today the secrecy that marked the recent talks and the agreement for leasing part of the Salmaa Canal to the Soviet Union.
Prices of world sugar futures continued to climb yesterday in moderately active trading, while the rest of the local commodity-futures market lumbered through a quiet and generalLy uneventful day.

NEWPORT, R.I. Sept. 24 The United States was not inclined to claim victory nor was Australia ready to concede defeat today as Weatherly and Gretel prepared to resume their exciting match for the America's Cup.
Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons was wearing a big grin at Aqueduct yesterday after the 18th running of the $29,250 Discovery Handicap before 30,126 fans.

PARIS, Sept. 24 A new play, "La Brigitta" by Jacques Audiberti, opened tonight at the Athenee Theater, and Mr. Audiberti, the 63-year-old enfant terrible of the French drama, has three plays running here, including one at the Comedie Francaise.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 25 A Swiss freighter rescued from the gale-swept Atlantic yesterday 48 of the 76 persons who had been aboard a chartered United States airliner that ditched Sunday night.

The Dallas Museum of Fine Arts announced yesterday the purchase of a painting by Andrew Wyeth for $58,000. This is believed to be the highest price ever paid by a museum for a painting by a living American artist. It surpassed by $23,000 the record set when the Philadelphia Museum of Art purchased the same artist's "Ground Hog Day" for $35,000 in 1959.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept.24 A Federal appeals court heard arguments here today on whether three Lynchburg judges ought to be defendants in a case aimed at ending racially segregated seating in their courtrooms.

Senator Jacob K. Javits went back to Washington Heights yesterday the area where he broke through Democratic supremacy in 1946 to become a four-term Representative in Congress for the official handshaking start of his Republican re-election campaign.
CHICAGO, Sept, 24 (AP) Manager Al Lopez, finishing his sixth season with the club, signed a two-year contract today to direct the Chicago White Sox in 1963 and 1964.
The Avco Corporation increased its earnings 41 per cent in the nine months ended Aug. 31 on a sales gain of 24 per cent.

The Radio Corporation of America has received a $12,000,000 Air Force contract for continued work on the Ballistic Missile Early Warning System. The company received a $4,500,000 award last Friday for similar work.
Casey Stengel announced yesterday, with appropriate softshoe steps, obscure rhetoric and calls for stronger wine, that he would manage tht New York Mets next season.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 24 The board of trustees of the University of Mississippi agreed in open court tonight to admit James H. Meredith, a Negro, to the university by 4 P.M. tomorrow.
How well "Mr. President" has mended its fences in Boston during the last four weeks will be assayed tonight in Washington, where fence-mending is a recognized art.

A 32-year-old car washer was held in $15,000 bail yesterday in Kew Gardens (Queens) Criminal Court on charges that he raped and robbed a woman late Sunday in the waiting room of the Long Island Rail Road station in St. Albans, Queens.
About 5,000 teamsters employed by 500 trucking companies went on strike yesterday, curtailing, the delivery of general merchandise in the city.
Harold H. Helm, chairman of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, has announced the election of John R. Burleigh Jr., Oliver M. Mendell and Francis W. Murray 3d as vice presidents.
Steel production increased 2 per cent last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Representative Charles A. Buckley was unanimously reelected Democratic leader of Bronx County last night at a post-primary meeting of district leaders.
BEACON, N.Y., Sept. 24 Valentine G. Gahnkin, who retired in 1953 as a turbineperformance engineer for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died today in his home. His age was 74.
VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 24 The United States team has clinched qualification for the twelve-team finals in the chess olympics.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) A strike by 1,900 maintenance and production workers halted production of equipment for defense, missile and space projects at the Westinghouse Defense Center today.

Four bricklayers were injured critically yesterday when they fell from some planking over a stairwell on the fifth story of an apartment house. The house is under construction on East 19th Street, betwen Cortelyou and Dorchester Roads, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has announced that the board of the bank had appointed George Garvy as economic adviser and Alan Holmes as vice president.
The chief acoustical engineer for Philharmonic Hall said yesterday that he was "not entirely satisfied" with the acoustics at Sunday night's gala premiere.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 Floyd Patterson and Charles (Sonny) Liston will meet tomorrow night for the world heavyweight championship in a battle that has been publicized as a multimillion-dollar morality play.
Old October cotton futures fell 40 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Other months rose 20 cents to $1.25.

The clamor for an overhaul of banking regulations is growing in intensity. The Advisory Committee on Banking, set up by James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, is the latest to call for revision in a study that makes 84 separate recommendations to liberalize and simplify existing laws and practices.

ADEN, Sept. 24 (Reuters) British troops and the police fought Arab rioters today as the Legislative Council began debating Britain's proposal to link this strategic British colony with the 11-state South Arabia Federation.
A slum landlord's "cruel and callous" treatment of tenants was no reason to order him into a hospital for psychiatric examination, Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy ruled yesterday.
The Board of Higher Education voted last night to ask the City Planning Commission for $5,000,000 more to shift a road on the Brooklyn College campus.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24--The up-and-down relations between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union hit a peak on the roller coaster today. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Union's titular chief of state, arrived in... Belgrade for an official visit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Treasury bill rates declined on today's sale of the regular weekly issues.
WITH the opening of the small-game season in New York two weeks off, the time for new hunters to take the mandatory four hours of hunter safety instruction is growing short.
THE pursuit of humor in uniform is being intensi fied in television this season, and from the evidence at hand the Pentagon may be disposed to regard Bilko and Hennesey with new affection.
The American Hotel was officially opened here yesterday with the good wishes of officials of the city and the United Nations and with the blessings of the three major faiths.

India and Communist China have now agreed to meet and talk about their Himalayan border dispute. However, differences between them are so sharp and extensive that there cannot be much prospect of progress toward a settlement. They not only disagree, to the extent of some 50,000 square miles, on where their common border is located but differ even on what their projected meetings are to be called.
Murray Levine, manager of the Greater New York Mutual Insurance Company's claim department, died of a heart attack Sunday in his home at 20 Park Avenue. He was 72 years old.
The wholesale commodity price index dropped to 80.4 Friday from 80.5 Thursday.
The Mississippi River Fuel Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a maximum of 1,200,000 common shares.

Needing only one victory or one loss for the Minnesota Twins the world-champion New York Yankees tonight will attempt to clinch their 27th American League pennant when they meet the Washington Senators at the Stadium.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 Heavy selling of cattle and hogs swept the Farm Belt today, midway in the fourth week of a "holding action" by the National Farmers Organization.

Edward L. Bernays, the public relations man, is in a state of transition these days. He is moving his base of operations from New York to Cambridge, Mass., where he plans to slacken his pace and write his memoirs.

Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund reported yesterday net assets of $511,467,489 on Aug. 31, end of the third quarter of the fiscal year. One year earlier net assets totaled $546,388,784. The share value of $7.07, compared with $9.13 a year ago. There were 72,373,499 shares outstanding on Aug. 31, against 59,834,556 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The New York Central Railroad received permission today to go ahead with a plan that would revamp its less-than-carload business.

BADDECK, N.S., Sept. 24 (Canadian Press) Mrs. Marian Bell Fairchild of Miami, widow of David Fairchild, noted plant explorer, and daughter of the telephone pioneer Alexander Graham Bell, died tonight at her summer home. She was 82 years old.
A teacher was stabbed in the thigh yesterday when he tried to escort a 16-year-old youth from an East Harlem schoolyard. The teacher was treated at Metropolitan Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Striking telegraphers and officials of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company, who have been on the verge of agreement for nearly a week, made more progress today but still had one or two items to wrap up.

IT was the turn of the Boston Symphony last night in Philharmonic Hall, and the concert took a more conventional aspect than it had at the Sunday evening opening. For one thing, there was no chorus. This meant that the orchestra was in its orthodox position on stage rather than pushed forward. This, in turn, meant that acoustics would be different. And so they were.

Tickets for the concert Monday of the French National Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall are still available, Mrs. Arthur Little has announced. She is chairman of the committee that has arranged the event as a benefit for the French Hospital here.
More than 40,000 of the 110,000 seats in the metropolitan area for the closed-circuit telecast of tonight's Floyd Patterson-Sonny Liston heavyweight title bout have been sold.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) Moderate early selling overcame a thin demand for grain futures today, and prices declined on the Board of Trade.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 24 Switzerland presented her case for a tariff-free association, but not full membership, to the European Economic Community today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 The storm of controversy whipped up by the Saxon report increased rather than diminished during the second-day sessions of the American Bankers Association's annual convention.

The Basic Books Publishing Company, publisher of text and technical books, has leased a floor in 404 Park Avenue South, at Twenty-eighth Street, through Leonard A. Lemlein of Gallant-Roth Co., broker. The book company, which also is in the literary subscription field, is headed by Arthur Rosenthal. The concern formerly had offices at 59 Fourth Avenue.
DUBLIN, Sept. 24 The Government of Premier Sean Lemass has taken the first step to lower tariff walls between the republic and Northern Ireland by making considerable...

Should Congress write into the statutes of this country a system of political censorship and screening of the mails? This is the real issue posed by one section of the new postal-rate and pay-raise bill reported out yesterday by the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee.
The American Theater Wing yesterday postponed the acceptance of Helen Menken's resignations as president and decided it would seek to persuade her to continue in office.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee approved today a $603,000,000 increase in postal rates. The increase was tied to a raise for 1,600,000 Government workers.
BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, Sept. 25--A threat of new trouble involving opposing military forces developed in Argentina late last night.

AURORA DOWNS, Ill., Sept. 24 As the tension increased today for tomorrow night's heavyweight title fight, Sonny Liston became a nervous wreck. For the first time in training, he showed all the signs of a frightened warrior.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 24 Carlos Masterson sailed Pride to two victories and a sixthplace-finish today as the first three races were completed in a series to select an Americanbuilt 5.5-meter yacht to defend the Seawanhaka Cup against Canada's representative starting this weekend.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Senate committee's version of the postal rate bill would revive a controversial program, ended by President Kennedy last year, of intercepting Communist propaganda in mail from abroad.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 24 In the opinion of a growing number of Africans, Joshua Nkomo has seriously damaged his position as Southern Rhodesia's African nationalist leader by his flight ...
JACKSON, Miss., Sept, 24 Following is the text of the executive order issued today by Gov. Ross R. Barnett:
MANTEO, N.C., Sept. 24 (AP) Alpheus W. Drinkwater, who telegraphed the Wright Brothers' message announcing the first airplane flight, died today at his home. He was 87 years old.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24 (UPI) Ernie Davis, the former allAmerica football halfback at Syracuse University who became ill two months ago with a blood disorder, hinted today that he "hopes" to be working out soon.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 The military forces that enabled Dr. Arturo Frondizi to become President legally in 1958 have reassumed power in Argentina.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 24 Foreign Minister Jesus Unda Murillo of Guatemala charged today that Moscow had converted Cuba into an unlucky Soviet satellite. He contended that Premier Fidel Castro was "no longer in charge" in Havana.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 24 (AP) The pilot of a Navy radar plane that guided rescuers to the scene of last night's crash in the Atlantic described the dramatic search for survivors in the pitch darkness today.
The "great globe" of yesteryear, dwindling by the minute as intrepid men press on into space, still...
THE card-playing world lost one of its best stu dents in the death Sept. 14 of William L. Gresham, a novelist, amateur conjurer, and expert on the history of playing cards.
A 35-year-old Negro revealed here yesterday that he attended the University of Mississippi as a full-time student in the 19451946 school year.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was doubling the warranty period on its 1963 models to 24 months or 24,000 miles, whichever comes first.
TYLER, Tex., Sept. 24 Billie Sol Estes went on trial today on state charges of theft, swindling and embezzlement. His attorneys protested that the courtroom was ...
MONGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 24 (AP) The Alabama Supreme Court denied a motion today to put the names of candidates defeated in run-off primaries on the general election ballot.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 The National Labor Relations Board ordered waterfront employers today to pay Philadelphia longshoremen for the work they lost during the 16-day shutdown of the port in 1959.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 24 Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Archibald Smith Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Converse Smith, to Richard Patrick de Layarde Liesching. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Raymond de Layarde Liesching of Grayshott, Hindhead, Surrey, England.

The New York Giants yesterday traded Bobby Gaiters, the halfback who was their No. 1 draft selection for 1961, to the San Francisco Forty-Niners. In exchange, the Giants received an end, Aaron Thomas, who is in his second year in the National Football League.
IN "Out of Africa" by Isak Dinesen--by the late Isak Dinesen, unfortunately--there is an amusing footnote to "The Merchant of Venice."
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 24--A program to improve commuter service in the New York metropolitan area was advanced today by Abraham A. Ribicoff.

MOST Americans prefer bright, sparkling colors in their homes because the sky in the United States is generally crystal clear, according to T.H.C. Worthington, director of Heal Fabrics, Ltd., of London.
A landlord of a tenement where a tenant was bitten by a rat was given a suspended sentence yesterday in an unusual decision in the housing part of Criminal Court.
A group of students, many of whom had not set foot in a classroom for 40 years, assembled here yesterday to take part in an experiment intended to benefit them and the nation at large.

A person's chances of being considered a mentally healthy employment prospect with sound he-man qualities increase if he likes snakes, chasing bandits in a sheriff's posse and reading detective stories and if he dislikes playing bridge, visiting art galleries and reading poetry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Project Mercury may end after only two more orbital flights, under a change of plans now being seriously considered by the space agency.
A proposal to settle the EastWest dispute over Berlin during a 10-year cooling-off period was put forward yesterday by James P. Warburg, economist and writer on international affairs.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 24 (UPI) The Kentucky Attorney General's office scolded the Frankfort City Board of Education today for its refusal to allow 26 Negro children to attend two city schools.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 Brig, Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, the temporary Commander in Chief of the Argentine Army, is a hard-riding cavalry officer who is referred to with respect by his colleagues as "the stubborn Basque," General Ongania, whose name is pronounced ...

PARIS, Sept. 24 Declarations by a man charged with leading a plot on the life of President de Gaulle, saying the church justified tyrannicide, have produced a dispute between the defendant's lawyers and Roman Catholic spokesmen here.

Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer denied a temporary injunction yesterday to Julius Monk, nightclub master of ceremonies, who has charged the twin cabarets on West 56th Street with illegally exploiting his name and his show material.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 24 Two hundred of this village's 1,400 Negro residents marched on Village Hall tonight to protest the "ghetto" confinement in which they charged they were forced to live.

In a move to improve its communications with the public, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday that in the future it planned to issue quarterly financial statements instead of annual reports as it has issued until now.

The Murchison Brothers of Dallas have been discussing a possible sale of their controlling interests in the Alleghany Corporation and in Alleghany's major investment, Investors Diversified Services, Inc.

LONDON, Sept. 23 Sugar Ray Robinson, an ex-middleweight champion of the world, will meet Terry Downes, an exmiddleweight of the world, at Wembley Pool tomorrow night in a fight counting for the championship of nothing.
ROME, Sept. 24 The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Roman joined Pope John XXIII today, "sorrowfully deploring" the physical attack on the church.

The world's accountants were told yesterday that they should defend the world against the tyranny of computers. The suggestion was made by Arthur. K. Watson, president of the IBM World Trade Corporation, a subsidiary of International Business Machines Corporation, the largest of the computer manufacturers.
RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24 The North Jersey Conference believes that ethics has a place in the bleachers as well as on the playing field.
Grayson - Robinson Stores, Inc., said in Federal Court yesterday that it expected to have a cash balance of more than $1,400,000 on Nov. 10 after paying all invoices due on that date.

The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that its board of directors had authorized the distribution to shareholders of all shares held by it in the Shell Oil Company of Canada, Ltd. These shares amount to 50 per cent of the Shell of Canada shares outstanding. The distribution will be made Nov. 1 to stockholders of record on Oct. 8.
THE "Telephone Hour" returned to television last night after its summer vacation and filled an hour with the performances of a varied selection of stars.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy praised five Brooklyn detectives yesterday for their work in halting what he termed "the depredations of a vicious rapist and murderer."
The sixth annual Salute to Fall will take place at 8 P.M. tomorrow on the steps of the New York Public Library.
CAPETOWN, Sept. 24 (UPI) Adm. Sir Herbert Annesley Packer, commander in chief of the South Atlantic Station from 1950 to 1952, died yesterday at the age of 67.
LONDON, Sept. 24 The stock market recorded sharply contrasting trends today. British Government bonds surged ahead, and industrial shares declined under the influence of Wall Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24--The Wells Fargo Bank has accepted the proposal of the Dillingham Corporation of Hawaii to construct San Francisco's largest commercial office building at a cost in excess of $20,000,000. It will be built on property owned by the bank in the heart of the city's financial district.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24 Frank E. Schoenfeld, a former New Jersey Assemblyman, died Saturday in Miami Beach, where he had lived in retirement for five years. He was 64 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) British exports to the European Common Market countries rose 8 per cent between March and August, the British Board of Trade announced today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 A Justice Department spokesman said tonight that plans were under way for the registration of James H. Meredith at the University of Mississippi.

Paul Seligson, a lawyer for the Civil Aeronautics Board, recommended yesterday that Northeast Airlines be allowed to continue service between New York and Florida. Northeast, which also serves New England, is seeking permanent certification on the Florida route.
SYOSSET, L.I, Sept. 24 Carlos A. Feliu, a traffic executive for the New York Telephone Company, died today in his home. His age was 64.
Red Cross bloodmobiles will call at four places in the city today to collect blood from volunteers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) An Executive order was suggested today as a short-cut way to end job discrimination against many women.

ATHENS, Sept. 24--Bonds of Greece's prewar foreign debt today reached their highest postwar price on the Athens stock market on reports of resumption of negotiations for debt settlement with United States holders.

A fresh round of sniping between rival candidates for Governor created doubt yesterday whether a television or radio debate between Governor Rockefeller and Robert M. Morgenthau, his Democratic-Liberal challenger, could be arranged.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 Eric H. Louw, Foreign Minister of South Africa, bitterly attacked the "new United Nations" today. He said that it had forsaken the ideals that prevailed when the Charter was written in 1945.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (UPI) Norm Siebern drove in two runs with a homer and a single and Ed Rakow pitched a five-hitter tonight in leading the Kansas City Athletics to a 5-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The crowd of 2,297 was the smallest in Memorial Stadium this season.

Four New York City savings banks announced yesterday an increase from 4 to 4 per cent in the interest paid on money on deposit over a year in the quarter beginning Oct. 1, 1962. The banks pay 3 per cent on shorter-term deposits.

KODIAK, Alaska, Sept. 24 (UPI) A ground search party of 21 marines reached the wreckage of a United States Navy twin-engined flying boat on Montague Island, about 150 miles southeast of Anchorage, today and reported there were no survivors.
Malcolm A. MacIntyre, president of Eastern Air Lines, said yesterday the company had "gone through a convulsion" and that a "complete shake-up in our sales system" had resulted.
TARANTO, ITALY, Sept. 24 Construction has begun in this seaport city on a giant steel mill whose initial production of 2,000,000 tonas a yea by 1965 may later be increased to 6,000,000 tons.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 24 Miss Roberta Spekin and Donald M. Wallach plan to be married here Oct. 21.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 24 Getting into the "right college" has become the newest American status symbol, an educators' conference was told here today.
DUBLIN, Sept. 24 "Stephen D.," the sole James Joyce play in the Dublin Theater Festival, was given a warm reception tonight at the Gate Theater.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Defense Department announced today it would start immediately to enroll Cuban refugee volunteers into special Spanish-speaking units to train for service in the United States army and navy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) The 1962-63 season of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra was assured tonight when the American Federation of Musicians and the Chicago Orchestral Association reached agreement on a three-year contract.
The decline in the stock market paved the way for a rise in the price of Government securities yesterday.
BONN, Sept. 24 Peter Fuhrmann, a former high official in the Defense Ministry, was sentenced today to ten years at hard labor on conviction of spying seven years for the Soviet Union.
Silver moved into the spotlight on the metals stage following word yesterday that Mexico had dropped out of the list of silver suppliers. Mexico is the world's largest...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. Senator Kenneth B. Keating accused a Texas electronics manufacturer today of "a brazen attempt to seduce New York business" to move out of the state.
Governor Rockefeller promised last night that he and his colleagues on the Republican ticket would wage a lively campaign for election.

ST. JAMES, L.I, Sept. 24 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Owen Wister, formerly of Richmond Hill Queens, New York, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Agnes Wister, to Warren Webster Bovie. He is the son of Warren Bovie of Albany and the late Mrs. Bovie.

ELGIN, Ill., Sept. 24 Floyd Patterson walked down the winding country road today past the cows and horses clustered behind rustic fences. Every now and then a farmer's voice from the green fields beyond would echo: "Good luck, Floyd. Hope you win, champ."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)--The Securities and Exchange Commission said today the father-and-son team of Gerard A. (Jerry) Re and Gerard F. Re defrauded the public of incalculable sums of money by illegally selling "many millions of dollars of securities" on the American Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Sept. 24 Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of Britain's Union Movement, was granted a United States visa today to make a political lecture Wednesday at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Justice Department is moving to bring new indictments against eight men whose convictions for contempt of Congress were set aside by the Supreme Court last spring.

The Standard Products Company should report better earnings for the year ending June 30, 1963, than fiscal 1962's net of $858,732, or $1.12 a share, James S. Reid, president, told to annual meeting yesterday in Cleveland.
Port Newark will become a steamship passenger embarkation and debarcation point under plans announced yesterday by Grace Line and the Port of New York Authority.

DA NANG, Vietnam, Sept. 24 The commanding South Vietnamese general here thinks the Communist guerrilla fighters have reorganized extensively during the last Year and built up from company to battalion and regimental units.
Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., sent a proxy solicitation letter to shareholders yesterday indicating that management would not relinquish control to a dissident group of shareowners.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) The production of 1963 model cars indicates that dealers probably will have available more standard-size models than compacts when they go on sale in the next few weeks.

The Slick Corporation, which is engaged in airline operations and the production of window shades, plans to begin manufacturing pulverizing machinery and grinders, granulators, dust collectors and pneumatic conveyors.

A NOVEL called "The Red Cock Flies to Heaven" has been attracting considerable attention in Europe. The au thor, Miodrag Bulatovic, is a Yugoslav and his book was first published two years ago in Zagreb. Now, we are told, it has appeared in "all the major European languages."

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Berg of Jamaica, Queens, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Berg's daughter, Miss Eleanor Ann Heumann, to Joseph Pugach Weinman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weinman of Malden, Mass.

PEKING, Tuesday, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Four more Chinese Communist soldiers were killed or wounded as fighting continued for the fourth day in the disputed area where India's Northeast Frontier meets Tibet, it was reported here today.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 24 The Suffolk Board of Supervisors appointed a new Police Commissioner today in a vote split along party lines.
The American predilections for the out-of-doors and for doing things for themselves were apparent yesterday at the opening of the 17th Annual National Hardware Show, in the New York Coliseum.

Cast as a suburban husband and wife (income $9,000) a year stars Eddie Bracken and Janet Blair of the movies find themselves with 4,500 tantalizing dollars in a joint savings account. In the background is a precocious son who is obviously college material.

Scientists reported yesterday they had succeeded in isolating for the first time an elusive encephalitis virus in mosquitoes trapped in St. Petersburg, Fla., where fourteen persons have died in an encephalitis epidemic.
The Sharp drop in stock prices accelerated in active trading yesterday. Losses were the heaviest in almost three months, pushing the market back to the early August level.
The Royal Ballroom of the new Americana Hotel will be the setting for the annual dinner dance of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts Nov. 18.
CAIRO, Sept. 24 President Gamal Abdel Nasser reorganized the Government tonight and named Ali Sabry Premier. The change in governmental structure emphasized "group leadership."
The junior committee of the Legal Aid Society's women's division has planned its supper dance for Oct. 26 in the ballroom of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at 42 West 44th Street.

Jim Brown, the Cleveland Browns' fullback, is off to a fine start in his bid to win the National Football League's rushing title for a record sixth straight year.
The punctuality of air travelers has been improved by fining those who miss flights, Alan Boyd, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, revealed yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25--Talks aimed at smoothing over some of the last remaining differences between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia began today in Belgrade.
A landlord who received a suspended sentence Monday because he had no previous record of violations in a tenement was fined $200 yesterday for violations in another tenement.
DREUX, France, Sept. 26-- The forces working to induce the continued flow of American manufacturing investment into Western Europe were perfectly illustrated in a new plant opened here today.
Albania's Communists, apparently with Chinese Communist approval, have publicly denounced the Soviet Union for supporting and helping to arm India.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Barry Lupino, a comedian and pantomimist, and member of a family active in the theater since the mid-seventeenth century, died yesterday in the Loyal Sussex County Hospital at Brighton. He was 80 years old.

Lee Grosscup, who believes he could have made it with the National Football League, will make his first appearance in New York as a first-string quarterback Sunday. But he will be making it with the American Football League, playing with the Titans against the Denver Broncos at the Polo Grounds.
Texas Instruments, Inc. has received a Federal Aviation Agency contract for more than $10,000,000 to construct airport surveillance radar systems.
Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second largest food chain, made a sharp increase in earnings in its third fiscal quarter. The company bettered its threequarter record of a year ago.
A Bronx County grand jury indicted a man and his wife and two other persons yesterday for allegedly obtaining rent increases through fraudulent means.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26--Horatio Alger used to write that there was only one road to success for a red-blooded American boy. He reached the top by hard work, clean living, strict observance of the laws of God and man, honesty and all the nobler virtues. But Sonny Liston jarred that theory last night as violently as he jarred Floyd Patterson. He seemed to prove that being a copfighter and labor goon also could bring rich rewards.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26--After the fight last night, Floyd Patterson apparently did what he said he would do if he lost.

Is it unrealistic, in the midst of this election campaign season, to suggest to Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner that there is a nonpolitical issue of tremendous importance to the state and city of New York that desperately needs their influential intervention?

Trucking concerns that deliver general merchandise in the city were called upon yesterday by their contract negotiating committee to shut down all operations. Industry spokesmen, confident of a favorable response, predicted that 1,400 employers would make no deliveries today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (UPI)--Harry Craft has signed to manage the Houston Colts for the 1963 season, the general manager, Paul Richards, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The tax bill that is finally inching its way to enactment provides a case history in how to win while losing. It represents a combination of victory and defeat for President Kennedy.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, the president of City College, has rejected charges of anti-Hispanic discrimination in the college's department of Romance Languages.

Congress should restate what it believes to be the proper objective for stockpile commodities, Simon D. Strauss, vice president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, told the American Mining Congress convention in San Francisco yesterday.

Former Deputy Police Inspector Richard J. Sheridan, who, was chief of police at the New York World's Fair in 1939-40, died yesterday in his home at 121 Malba Drive, Malba, Queens. He was 90 years old.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26-- A New York banker-economist warned here today that a policy of easy money would be dangerous in view of the nation's gold losses.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 26-- State highway patrolmen prevented a Federal marshal today from delivering a contempt citation to the office of Gov. Ross R. Barnett in the Capitol building.

"Crime Does Not Pay," a four-part French melodrama based on noted criminal cases, will be the next attraction at the Sutton Theater, following the current "Waltz of the Toreadors."

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Arsonists set eight fires, five in unoccupied houses, last night and early today in suburban Kinloch. The Negro community has been the scene of violence since an elderly policeman killed a young man Sunday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 26 (UPI)--The central Government accused Katangese forces today of having shot down a United Nations plane last week. Two of the 10 Swedish crew members were killed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Wes Covington's three-run homer powered the Phillies to their 18th victory in the last 23 games as Philadelphia rallied for a 6-5 conquest of the Chicago Cubs and Bob Buhl today.
The Department of Buildings reported yesterday that its special inspection squad had found 1,299 violations in 25 Harlem tenements.
Stock prices broke sharply yesterday under pressure from a wave of late selling.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The Government borrowed $3,000,000,000-plus today, at discounts averaging 2.616 per cent.
LONDON, Sept. 26--Prices moved aimlessly on the stock market today. Most changes were no more than a few pennies.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (UPI) --Wilber Stargell, a rookie, doubled home a run in the 11th inning tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 1-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

The Magnavox Company announced yesterday its commercial entry into the office systems field with a low-cost unit for graphic information storage and retrieval. The initial unit is called MEDIA for Magnavox Electronic Data Image Apparatus. It is said to be capable of selecting a single page out of any size file and delivering a full-size reproduction in less than a minute.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26--Philippe de Seynes, United Nations Under Secretary for Economic and Social Affairs, said today that the growing trend among nations to form trade blocs might eventually work toward unifying rather than dividing internanational trade.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26--Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi has rejected notice of a court order to appear in New Orleans Friday to answer civil contempt-of-court ...

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 26--The engagement of Miss Judith Gurton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Gurton, to Martin O. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Cohen of Brooklyn, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

BUFFALO, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Sir Oswald Mosley, once jailed in England as a Fascist, defended his political philosophy before an orderly but at times loud gathering of 1,500 persons at the University of Buffalo today.

From the first suit to the last ball gown shown this week at Elizabeth Arden's fall and winter collection, a stately elegance was the keynote. Most of the clothes have been designed for Miss Arden by French and Italian designers.
ORONO, Me., Sept. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Ford Campbell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Campbell, to Michael William, Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Murray of Washington.
FLORENCE, ITALY. COSMETICS, liqueurs and medicines made according to formulas devised by monks in the 17th century are the stock in trade of an elegant Florentine drugstore.
Three banking syndicates submitted bids yesterday for $30,000,000 of Commonwealth of Puerto Rico general purpose bonds due 1964-86.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 26--Peter Liberman of Detroit, who is wanted in the United States for passport fraud in leaving the country, was granted asylum here today.
DUBLIN, Ireland, Sept. 26-- "Dossers,"; a first play by William J. Murdock, a young Dublin-born actor, is one of the new productions at Dublin's Theater Festival this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--President Kennedy nominated A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., a Philadelphia attorney to the Federal Trade Commission today. Mr. Higginbotham, if confirmed by the Senate, will be the first Negro to serve on a Federal regulatory agency.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP)-- The Americas Oil Company announced today it had developed a new long-distance engine oil designed to function properly for at least 6,000 miles between chanegs.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Twelve members of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament sailed a 48-foot ketch down the Thames today on the first stage of a trip to protest in the Soviet Union against the nuclear arms race.
NEWARK, Sept. 26--Ilo Orleans, lawyer and author of books of verse for children, died today in St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 134 Vassar Avenue.

The wholesale commodity index was at 80.4 Tuesday for the third consecutive day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --President Kennedy signed a bill today doubling the Government's authority to contribute to a cooperative forestry program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Anger and concern mounted in Congressional and Government circles today over the Soviet Union's plans to build a fishing port in Cuba for its Atlantic trawler fleet.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26--Trade by developed nations to expand markets and patience by developing nations over the rate of decolonization were prescribed by New Zealand today as practical medicine for international ills.

PARIS, Sept. 26--The French Cabinet put the finishing touches today on the controversial proposal for election of the next President of the Republic by popular vote.

Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of the pre-war British Union of Fascists and its postwar successor organization, is in this country for a brief visit at the invitation of the Students Senate of New York State University in Buffalo. He is one of five speakers scheduled to lecture this semester on the major political ideologies that confront the world today--democracy, Socialism, Communism and Fascism.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 26--Dr. Maud Thompson, a teacher of Latin, Greek and history for nearly 40 years, died today in United Hospital at the age of 91.
MILWAUKEE; Sept. 26-- Shed another tear for the New York Mets, who bowed, 6--3, to the Braves tonight and wound up with exclusive rights to another record, asterisk, footnote and all.

MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 26 --Michael Edwards, composer of the hit song, "Once in a While," and other popular and instrumental music, died here today in his home at 6 Jean Court. His age was 69.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Sept. 26--Former Premier Francisco Brochado da Rocha died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 52. He was stricken Monday night while taking part in a Labor party election rally.
The Niels Bohr Library of the History of Physics was dedicated yesterday afternoon in the headquarters building of the American Institute of Physics at 335 East Forty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--President Kennedy visited the Pentagon today for what the White House described as a "routine command post exercise."
The directors of Fairbanks Whitney Corporation are expected to answer a stockholder soon named George C. Lessner, a lawyer and former director of the Pratt Whitney division of the company.
Gen. James M. Gavin, retiring United States Ambassador to France, returned last night from Paris en route to his home in Boston.

WASHINGTON. THE opening of Irving Berlin's musical "Mr. President" on Tuesday evening turned into one of Washington's biggest fashion shows to date. Many New York fashion luminaries flew down for the occasion. Joining forces with Washington's best-dressed, they dazzled a gaping crowd that stood 10 deep outside the National Theater to see what Mrs. John F. Kennedy and other women in the elegant audience were wearing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The combined bill to increase postal rates and raise Government pay was taken to the Senate floor today amid bipartisan pleas that it be adopted intact. It no sooner had arrived, however, when it was met by a flurry of amendments, some of which would drastically alter the dual program.

BONN, Sept. 26--The prosecutors general of Karlsruhe and Wiesbaden announced today the arrest of an official winetaster and a wine merchant in a scandal involving the import of at least 2,000,000 gallons of adulterated wine from Italy since 1959.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 --The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation announced a new fellowship program today that will provide graduate students with complete financial independence while they are completing requirements for a Ph.D.
Members of the committee Planning the dinner dance in behalf of the American Library in Paris have been meeting at the Plaza, where the event will take place Oct. 8.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Deacon Jones, a rookie, hit a two-run pinch double in a six run eighth inning and lifted Chicago toward an 9-3 victory over Boston today and helped Ray Herbert gain his 19th victory.
Earnings of the Southern Company this year may be as much as $2.20 a share, "perhaps a shade more," Harllee Branch Jr., president of the company, told the New York Security Analysts yesterday.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 26 (Canadian Press)--The battle was joined for the world's durum wheat markets today as Canada cut prices 16 cents a bushel to compete with Government-subsidized United States growers.

A property in Greenwich, Conn., which is occupied in its entirety on lease by the atomic research department of the American Machine Foundry Company, has been purchased by Allan Haymes, New York realty investor and builder. The buyer has taken title to the parcel, which is at 140 Greenwich Avenue.

Protectionism, it is clear, does not die easily. While the impending passage of the Trade Expansion Act can be described as the Administration's most impressive and important legislative victory so far, it is not yet a conclusive deathblow to protectionism. The bill does give the President greatly enhanced bargaining power to negotiate tariff concessions and expand trade. But it also includes a series of restrictions designed to remove certain items from negotiation.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 26 --Negro voting success has led even the police chief of embattled Albany, Ga., to bid for Negro support for office, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. asserted here today.
Columbia's varsity football team went through a two-hour drill yesterday in preparation for its opening game against Brown at Baker Field Saturday.

A merger of two proprietary nursing home groups was an nounced here yesterday. The New York City Nursing Home Association's 33 members joined with the 34 members of the Metropolitan Nursing Home Guild to form the Metropolitan New York Nursing Home Association.

With the pennant clinched by their 8--3 triumph behind Whitey Ford over the Washington Senators at the Stadium Tuesday night, the Yankees yesterday engaged the Nats once again in a game that obviously was meaningless.
The Republic of China (Taiwan) officially opened its Chinese Investment and Trade Office yesterday, at a reception honoring C.K. Yen, Minister of Finance.

Members of the committees arranging the junior auxiliary dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Infirmary were guests yesterday afternoon at a meeting and cocktail party at the infirmary at Stuyvesant Square East and 15th Street. The dance will be held at the St. Regis Roof on Oct. 5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--News to brood on when optimism threatens to surface:
ALGIERS, Sept. 26--The National Assembly called on Ahmed Ben Bella tonight to form the first regular government of independent Algeria.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP)--The Sigma VII spacecraft of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. was back atop its Atlas booster rocket today. Preparations were resumed for the launching of the astronaut into six orbits of the world, now set for Oct. 3.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP)--The British musical "Oliver" was given hearty approval today by Paul Speegle, critic of The News-Call Bulletin. He called it a "smasher."

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, reported yesterday that he had received written pledges from seamen's unions not to cross his union's picket lines in the event of a strike, which is almost certain to begin at midnight Sunday.
The Theater Guild has broken off negotiations with the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company on plans to televise guild productions free of charge in five cities.

MATAWAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 26--A youth caught driving 110 miles an hour will spend two nights in the emergency room of the Perth Amboy General Hospital this weekend, to learn what reckless driving may lead to.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Sept. 26 --Mr. and Mrs. Jerome T. Congleton Jr. have made known the engagement of Mr. Congleton's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Congleton, to John G. Fergusson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. W.B.B. Fergusson of Montclair, formerly of London.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York plans to build the nation's third largest hydroelectric power plant on the Hudson River, near Cornwall, N.Y.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 26 (AP)--The pupil placement system in Clarendon County, S.C., where the case that led to the historic desegregation decision of 1954 began, was challenged today before the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 26-- Robert Stack, the television star, is now confronted with the problem that eventually plagues any leading actor in an old television series.

A COLLECTION of miniature shoes is on display at the Union Dime Savings Bank, West 40th Street at Sixth Avenue. There are 139 pairs of shoes representing styles that were worn during 4,000 years of history.

The directors of the Erie Forge and Steel Corporation, producer of steel castings and ingots, omitted the dividend yesterday on the preferred stock. The previous payment was 15 cents a share in August, 1960.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 16--Liberalization in Communist-ruled Hungary has gone so far as to raise the question is some minds of who did win the 1956 revolt, after all.

Plans are being discussed to expand Joseph Papp's annual New York Shakespeare Festival in central Park by giving additional free performances in Brooklyn and the Bronx. Whatever is agreed on must be authorized by the Parks Department under whose jurisdiction the plays would be given.

Bonnie Parcell, soprano, gave a debut recital of challenging works at Town Hall last night. She proved skillful in handling the divergent styles, and although her singing was rarely thrilling, it was consistently charming.

Negro parents from the East Elmhurst-Corona area of Queens continued their boycott yesterday against the junior high school in Astoria to which their children have been assigned.

ROME, Sept. 26--For the first time the Basilica of St. Peter's will be closed to visitors and pilgrims for an extended period starting tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26--Boxing buffs searched today for the scowling, growling fist fighter they had known Sonny Liston to be. Instead they found a jovial, dignified talkative chap who might seem out of place in the ring.

A Toledo port delegation, denying an intent to "beard the lion in its den," told shippers here yesterday they, could save money by bypassing New York and shipping through the Ohio terminal on Lake Erie.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 26--Lynne A. Turner of Chicago won the second International Harp Contest in Jerusalem today.

THE troubles of educational television station WNDT have given way to the glow of superb accomplishment on the home screen. Rarely has the medium afforded such a stunning insight into the artistry and personality of a human being as the hour passed with Pablo Casals in his class for student cellists.
Brig. Gen. William A. Taylor, New York National Guard, retired, died Tuesday, in Valley Forge (Pa.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 8801 Shore Road in Brooklyn.
CLEVELAND. DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK, whose books on baby care have eased the worries of millions of mothers, has now turned his attention to the problems of parents.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26-- Argentina's battle of words and pressures involving the air force and navy continued today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 26--Mrs. Harrison F. Flippin of Douglassville, Pa., seeking to recapture a championship she held for five years, took a 4-stroke lead in the 37th United States senior women's Golf Association tournament today.

Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, will deliver the convocation address on "A Third Period in American Higher Education," at 1 P.M. today to open Barnard College's 74th academic year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, president of the American Red Cross and former Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, underwent surgery today for a lung inflammation at Walter Reed Army Hospital. The operation was described as a vein ligation, meaning a vein was tied off to prevent further spread of the trouble.
VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 25 --In the final round of the preliminaries of the Chess Olympics here last night the United States team defeated Puerto Rico, 4--0.

The appointment of Dr. Arnold S. Zentner as director of the Consultation Center for Alcoholism of the New York University. Medical Center was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP)--A Federal judge has ordered pretrial depositions taken at one time for all 1,800 civil suits filed against 29 electircal equipment manufacturers convicted of price-fixing.

ALBANY, Ga., Sept. 26 (AP ) --City officials took less than four hours today to present their defense in a Federal Court suit seeking desegregation of public facilities, including parks and libraries.
BELGRADE, Sept. 26--President Tito took a party of topranking Soviet visitors hunting today near the Hungarian border. What they hunted and how successful they were seemed to be state secrets.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara warned Senate leaders of both parties today that House cuts in foreign aid funds entailed "a serious military risk."

In Oxford, Miss., yesterday, James H. Meredith, supported by five carloads of United States marshals, again attempted to register at the University of Mississippi; and again he was rebuffed. There was a little scuffle in which no one was hurt; but the state of Mississippi, even in the absence of its Governor, who was belatedly hurrying to the scene like Sheridan at the battle of Cedar Creek, reasserted the fantastic doctrine known as "interposition."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--A home buzzer system for warning of nuclear attack may be delayed a year because of reductions in funds by Congress, an Assistant secretary of Defense said today.
The Dover Corporation has agreed to purchase the assets of De-Sta-Co Corporation, formerly Detroit Stamping Company, for about $7,200,000 cash.
A report from behind the Iron Curtain increased prices on cocoa and sugar futures in New York Yesterday. Other commodities traded here were moderately active and mixed.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 26 --Carole Fromm and J.E. Sedlmayr of Sands Point won the low-net award with an 83,11--72 in the Long Island Golf Association's mixed foursome championship, played at the North Shore Country Club today.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 26--Miss Carol Rose Levine and Arthur Ostrove plan to be married early next spring.

C.O. Bigelow Chemists, Inc., one of the oldest pharmacies in continuous operation in the country, has leased the store at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 53d Street in the new Americana hotel for a midtown branch. The main store is at 414 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), opposite the Jefferson Market Court. It has been a Greenwich Village landmark since 1837.
New York City combined its sixth annual "Salute to Fall" last night with a tribute to Richard Rodgers, the composer, as "a man of all seasons."
SEATTLE, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Gene Tunney today called the Sonny Liston-Floyd Patterson fight "a terrible hoax."
Philharmonic Hall's fourth program was an hour of gentle music from the 15th and 16th centuries.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday cuts of as much as 14 per cent in published prices for a wide range of aluminum sheet products used be the auto, appliance, utensil, and construction industries.

CONCEALING high fidelity equipment and television sets is a game most interior designers have been playing for years. More recently manufacturers of sight and sound equipment have scaled down the size and restyled the design of their products, making these sets less conspicuous and easier to accommodate in decor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Intervention by Mrs. John F. Kennedy has saved historic Lafayette Square from Washington's wrecking crews.
The "grand old lady" of Columbia University--the Alma Mater statue, which reigns in queenly splendor in front of Low Memorial Library on the campus--is wearing a new shade of make-up.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 26-- Joseph E. Morahan, deputy election commissioner of Westchester County, died early today in White Plains Hospital. He had fallen ill at his office at the Westchester County Board of Elections at 80 Grand Street. He was 61 years old and lived at 35 Pelton Street, Yonkers.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (UPI)--The Los Angeles Dodgers, faced with the prospect of having their league lead cut to one game if they lost, tonight unleashed their biggest bombardment in a month. With Frank Howard leading the attack, the Dodgers crushed the Houston Colts, 13-1.

OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 26-- Chief United States Marshal James P. McShane and Lieut. Gov. Paul B. Johnson scuffled repeatedly today near the main entrance to the University of Mississippi as state officials again prevented the registration of James H. Meredith, a Negro.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 26--A team of Long Island Sound International One-Design Class skippers returned the Amorita Cup to the United States today.
CAIRO, Sept. 26--The Russians and the Egyptians have taken steps to speed the construction of the Aswan High Dam.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy reiterated tonight that the Federal Government would do "whatever is necessary" to carry out court orders in Mississippi.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- President Kennedy signed legislation today authorizing construction of the world's largest atomic power plant at Hanford, Wash.

LONDON, Sept. 26--The Old Vic began tonight not only a new season with Ibsen's "Peer Gynt" but also a new phase in its checkered history. For from now on it will have to be regarded as the foundation company on which the National Theater will in due course be based.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26 (AP)--Dr. Eddie Anderson, starting his 37th year as a head football coach, was given a new contract by Holy Cross today.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (AP) --The Kansas City Athletics, after being shut out, 3--0, in the opener of tonight's doubleheader, defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 6--2.

The American musicians who take jazz to all parts of the world are not engaged in oneway traffic. They also bring back to this country music that has caught their fancies on their travels. Their most recent importation is a Brazilian variant of the samba called the bossa nova, which is spreading through American jazz circles like a prairie fire.
Jack Karlin, a restaurateur here for 30 years, died Sunday gt Irvington (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 393 Huguenot Avenue in Union, N.J.

ALBANY, Sept. 26--The Shirley Water Works Company in Suffolk County hopes to compensate for having provided 76 of its customers with rusty water last year by giving them clear water, free of charge, for a year.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 26 (UPI)--The British defender, Hellcat, gained her second victory in the series for the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy today when she beat the American challenger, Beverly, by 1 minute 5 seconds.

ATLANTA, Sept. 26 (UPI) --The Atlanta Crackers, playoff winners in the International League, continued their amazing post-season play tonight with a 5-1 victory over Louisville of the American Association.
WITHIN the last several years there has been a marked surge of interest in Chinese cuisine. This is true not only in the world of restaurants but also in the food prepared in the American home.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 26--President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan urged the small member countries of the United Nations today to use the might of their massed votes to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

Held coffee hour for Democratic Senators; signed a resolution for coinage of a medal honoring the late Speaker Rayburn; signed $1,319,118,500 appropriation for military construction; visited Defense Department for routine emergency communications test; nominated A. Leon Iiigginbotham Jr. for a seven-year term on the Federal Trade Commission; ...
ALBANY, Sept. 26--Governor Rockefeller has named the Mayor of Ardsley in Westchester County and the Mayor of Lockport in Niagara County to the Local Government Advisory Board.

The New Brunswick Electric Power Commission announced yesterday the private placement with institutional investors of $8,000,000 of 5 per cent, 25year sinking fund debentures. The issue is guaranteed by the ...
