WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- President Kennedy, said today that partisan political differences with business did not particularly bother him. But he said that he would like to see more amity and understanding of the hard problems of government.

The new board of governors of the American Stock Exchange took its first disciplinary action yesterday. The governors suspended James P. Gilligan and Albert Will, general partners in the stock specialist and brokerage firm of Gilligan, Will Co., from regular membership in the exchange.

Robert M. Morgenthau opened his campaign headquarters in the Commodore yesterday with a promise that he would work closely with President Kennedy to bolster New York's economy if he is elected Governor.

TO the air traveler who gazes down on suburbs, shopping centers, subdivisions and superhighways, man's works seem to be spreading across our planet like a malignant growth. If our population continues to expand at its present rate, before many generations have passed there will be no room on earth for life other than that needed to feed us.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 26--Mr. and Mrs. James E. McMahon have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Jean McMahon, to Cadet Wayne E. Morehead of the United States Military Academy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jordan A. Morehead of La Junta, Colo.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Sept. 26--Bamberger's of New Jersey opened the eighth store in its New Jersey chain today at ceremonies presided over by State highway Commissioner Dwight R.G. Palmer.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York started its 46th annual campaign yesterday with a record goal of $22,500,000 for maintaining its 116 affiliated medical and welfare institutions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The Supreme Court was asked again today to hold New York State's legislative districts as unconstitutional.
Ground was broken yesterday for a 1964 World's Fair exhibit that will offer both dramatic design and glimpses into the electronics industry.
DETROIT, Sept. 26--The rate of new car sales in the Sept. 11 to 20 period was 25.2 per cent above the daily average for the same period a year ago, Ward's Automotive Report said today.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26--Stephen Berrien of Upper Montclair took the lead today in the 41st annual New Jersey State Senior Golf Association championship by finishing his 36 holes with a 77, 81--158 at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

Many who paid as much as $7.50 to watch the closed-circuit telecast of the heavweight title fight Tuesday night found themselves looking at empty screens when Sonny Liston threw the punches that dethroned Floyd Patterson.
An increase of 504,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 26 (AP)--Mrs. Styles H. Bridges, defeated in an effort to succeed her late husband in the United States Senate, has asked the State Supreme Court to investigate "illegal political activity" during the primary campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--A Buffalo doctor's wife has told President Kennedy that her husband has been blacklisted to the brink of bankruptcy because he publicly supported the Administration's medical-care program.

ONE of the oldest openings on the chessboard, the Ruy Lopez, is still going strong in important tournaments. First advocated in 1561 by the Spanish Bishop after whom it was named, the opening is in many ways as modern as the newest variations of the king's Indian and Pirc defenses.
Senator Jacob K. Javits and his Democratic opponent, James B. Donovan, agreed yesterday on a television debate on Oct. 16.

PEOPLE who like paintings can now have them even underfoot, thanks to the special talent of a young New York artists. Marcia Weinman, who does non-objective, wallto-wall paintings on floors, is delighted to have her work walked on.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26-- Russell R. Kirby's Milford Hanover, driven by Robert Camper, scored his first victory of the season in the Westinghouse Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)--Acting to satisfy tax claims against the promoters, the Government today placed liens on the entire promotion proceeds from last night's Sonny Liston-Floyd Patterson fight.
LISBON, Sept. 26--A new Portuguese policy in Angola was widely expected here today following the dismissal last night of the civil and military chief of that African territory.
TRENTON, Sept. 26--The New Jersey Farm Bureau joined local farmers today in their war on blackbirds, starlings, grackles hand cowbirds. And the Audubon Society voiced no objection.

GENEVA, Sept. 26--Preparations were nearly completed here today for the entry into force on Monday of a five-year pact for regulating international trade in cotton textiles. This will replace the interim one-year pact now in effect.
Cotton futures were 30 cents a bale up to 25 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The creation of a Caribbean military organization to guard against Cuban-based aggression and subversion is under discussion here by Secretary of State Dean Rusk and foreign ministers from the Latin-American nations.
Educational television station WNDT and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists failed to sign a contract yesterday, but Channel 13 remained on the air.
The first Jewish encyclopedia compiled in this country in more than twenty-five years will be published by Behrman House on Oct. 31.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26--The Soviet Communist party called today for a more effective campaign against religion.
The long-delayed replacement of 47,000 parking meters at curbs here will begin next Wednesday night, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday.
The New York and American stock exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP)--A rookie, Tom Satriano, drilled four straight hits, including one of Los Angeles' three homers, as the Angels protected their hold on third place with an 8-5 victory over Detroit today.

CRANFORD, N.J., Sept. 26 --Allan S. Whitney, an executive of the Esso Standard Oil Company in Linden and an actor and director of theaters in New Jersey for 30 years, was found dead in his home today. He was apparently stricken with a heart attack in his sleep. His age was 53.
THE New York Conservation Department has pub lished its annual estimate of the prospects for small game this season. The following is a summary of their predictions:

Irving Brodsky, realty invesor, has purchased the 22-story office building at 445 Park Avenue from the Tishman Realty Construction Company and has taken title. The property occupies the blockfront on the east aide of the avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets.
The New York Knickerbockers' schedule of 34 games in Madison Square Garden during the 1962-63 National Basketball Association season was released yesterday.
The International Chamber of Shipping's opposition to a proposed boycott of shipping to Cuba was strongly attacked yesterday by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Sept. 27 (AP)--The former Premier of South Korea, Dr. John M. Chang, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison on charges that he had helped to finance a plot to overthrow Gen. Chung Hee Park.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26-- Most of the bystanders had departed early today but the men who had sailed for the America's Cup remained on station and still were sailing it--conversationally.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 (AP)--The International Atomic Energy Agency concluded its sixth general conference today. It pledged to improve East-West cooperation in the peaceful use of the atom for the benefit of developing countries.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 26 --Two thousand more armed Kurds have crossed from Iraq into Turkey, border guards reported today. The Kurds said they were fleeing Kurdish rebel forces headed by Mullah Mustafa Barzani.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Tessell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Rose Tessell, to Pvt. Harris A. Lefkon of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Lefkon.
Silver scored another twocent-an-ounce price advance yesterday, reaching $1.20 a troy ounce in New York, a 42-year high.
Ray Torgerson, well-known amateur golfer, died yesterday of cancer at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 54.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26--The Soviet Union portrayed today its decision to build a fishing port in Cuba as a routine agreement for economic and technical aid to the Castro regime.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --Senator Barry Goldwater said today the United States was in "far greater danger from the civilian theorist" than from military men with "proven knowledge and concern for our American institutions."
A proxy fight is shaping up for control of Natco Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based producer of clay building materials.

Candidates and their campaign committees in the Sept. 6 primary election filed reports with the Board of Elections yesterday on their expenditures, but there was doubt that those who exceeded the state's legal limits would be prosecuted.
Warren Lott Cruikshank, a fifth-generation descendent of the founder of Cruikshank Company, has been named executive vice president of the real estate concern, which had its beginning in 1794.
The markets for debt securities continued firm and active yesterday.

Sonotone Corporation, in a letter sent to stockholders, expressed "conplete surprise" at an offer of Servel, Inc., to buy 700,000 shares oil the company's stock but termed the cash price offered of $10 a share as "attractive."

Out of the jigsaw puzzle of strikes, lockouts and general chaos in the New York-New Jersey truck negotiations, James R. Hoffa hopes to emerge with another neat mosaic to fit into his master pattern for a nation-wide trucking compact.
VERSAILLES, France, Sept. 26 (UPI)--Warrington Dawson, a former United States foreign correspondent in Europe, died here Sunday. He was 85 years old.
Virgil E. Goodwin has been named vice president and general manager of the Refinery Supply Company, Tulsa, a subsidiary of the Cenco Instruments Corporation.
LONDON, Sept. 26--The establishment of a national authority that could supervise the orderly development of Britain's ports was recommended today by a government-appointed committee of inquiry.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 26 --George. L. Carlson, book and magazine illustrator and caricaturist, died today is his home here. He was 75 Years old.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (AP)--Edward T. Stone, managing editor of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, challenged editors at the Associated Press Managing Editors Association convention today to present more meaningful news and to keep readers alert to the dangers of an explosive world situation.
The good fortune that had been with Willie Shoemaker in surviving foul claims in two big stakes races this month deserted him yesterday at Aqueduct.
HAVANA, Thursday, Sept. 27 (AP)--Infomed sources said today that at least 75 persons had been executed since Sept. 1 for an alleged plot to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro and overthrow his regime.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --President Kennedy will campaign for Democratic candidates for Congress and governorships every weekend, starting next month, until Election Day.

The Bowery Savings Bank has made commitments for mortgage loans totaling $9,140,000 to the Atlantic Improvement Corporation's wholly owned subsidiaries for the first group of buildings in the community construction program now under way at Breezy Point, Queens.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 26 (AP)--Two German jet airliners en route to New York made emergency landings at Keflavik Airport in Iceland today. They reported that bombs were believed to have been put aboard.

DETROIT, Sept. 28--The Chevrolet and Pontiac divisions of the General Motors Corporation announced today that the factory list prices on their 1963 passenger cars would not be increased above those on 1962 models.
A funeral service will be held in Champaign, Ill., today for Nettie Hart, an industrial designer who was killed in an automobile accident in Spain last Friday.
Rosh ha-Shanah, opening the High Holy Days, will be observed by Jews beginning at sundown tomorrow. The day also marks the first in the Jewish calendar year 5723.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--A House subcommittee plans hearings soon on the Interstate Commerce Commission's refusal to turn over certain railroad loan files to a Congressional auditing agency.

Edward Padula has taken on a second musical project for Broadway late this season. It is "Bajour," based on Joseph Mitchell's New Yorker magazine stories about gypsy operations in the city. Ernest Kinoy is writing the book, and Walter Marks will provide the music and lyrics.
The Citizens Union gave high ratings yesterday to three Queens and two Brooklyn legislators who are seeking re-election Nov. 6.
Assemblyman Anthony J. Travia, minority leader of the Assembly, has been appointed as manager of this year's Democratic campaign in Brooklyn.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP) A tax cut next January would force a reduction in Federal spending, Ladd Plumley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27 Leonid I. Brezhnev, titular chief of state of the Soviet Union, repeated today a Moscow warning to Washington that any attack on Cuba could mean war.
GUILLAUME DESCHAPELLES, a Frenchman who died 115 years ago and was considered the best whist player in the world at that time, was spiritual father to the key play in this deal.
The conviction of Herbert Fields, a 32-year-old part-time postal employe, on robbery and assault charges last April was set aside in Supreme Court yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) Wheat prices fell to lows for the season in another unsettled session today on the Board of Trade.

BONN, Sept. 27 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said on his departure from West Germany tonight that he had been "impressed" by what he had seen during a two-day inspection tour of United States and West German troops.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Mrs. Lilly Lesin Schlesinger Kay, widow of Otto Kay and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moritz Schlesinger of Great Neck, L. I., became the bride at noon today of Edward Neighbor Waters. He is the son of Mrs. Charles Andrew Waters of Palmyra, N. Y., and the late Mr. Waters.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 Beatrice Foods Company announced today it had entered into an agreement to purchase the stock of Cie Lacsoons, S.A., Rotselaar, Belgium, one of the largest, most modern and diversified dairy operations in the European Economic Community.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 The Soviet Union launched today the ninth instrumented satellite in the Cosmos space study program that began last March.

The Erie County Medical Society denied yesterday that it had blacklisted Dr. Angelo S. D'Eloia of Buffalo for his espousal of President Kennedy's program of medical care for the aged under Social Security.
Production of lumber in the country totaled 238,518,000 board feet in the week ended Sept. 22, according to reports received yesterday from regional lumber associations.
ATLANTA, Sept. 27 (AP) The Louisville Colonels took advantage of Atlanta errors and handed the Crackers, a 3-1 defeat tonight in the Little World Series.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Rail and truck loadings of freight rose slightly last week. There were signs that the autumn peak loading season had started.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Vandals have defaced the white marble Lincoln Memorial, painting "nigger lover" in foot-high pink letters on the rear wall, the United States Park Police report.
MADRID, Sept. 27 The United States and a number of international organizations have offered assistance to Spain for the victims of the disastrous flash floods that struck the Barcelona area.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 Foy D. Kohler, the new United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, presented his credentials today to Nikolai N. Organov, Vice President of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet.
The marshals escorting James Meredith to Oxford, Miss., have been directed to return to Memphis without attempting to enter the University of Mississippi.
ALBANY, Sept. 27 Governor Rockefeller announced today that the state would furnish direct assistance in finding housing for persons displaced by projects of the State Public Works Department.
The merchant ships of nations allied with the United States have been the major carriers of oil and other important cargoes to Cuba in the last year.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27 Ethiopia and Liberia announced today that Ernest A. Gross, New York lawyer who was formerly a member of the United States delegation here, would press their cases on South-West Africa before the International Court of Justice at The Hague.
ALGIERS, Sept. 22 Ahmed Ben Bella, first Premier-designate of independent Algeria, is scheduled to present his cabinet and program to the National Assembly tomorrow.
Three pedestrians were injured yesterday when drenching rains and heavy winds buffeted the city.

Central bankers, who believe in orthodox monetary discipline, dislike changes. Yet the existing international monetary structure, which was so widely hailed at last week's meeting of the International Monetary Fund, is not a fixed and immutable system. On the contrary, it has been steadily reinforced and made more flexible through a series of innovations in international monetary cooperation.
PARIS, Sept. 27--Edith Piaf, frail, fragile and aging, returned to a Paris music hall stage tonight and was triumphantly received.

ADEN, Sept. 27 Broadcasts from the feudal Arab kingdom of Yemen reported tonight that Imam Ahmad, the 35-year-old monarch enthroned last week, was besieged in his palace and assassinated by a military faction, and a "free republic" was proclaimed.
James Robbins, retired yachting writer for The New York Times, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 145 East 52d Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27--The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, told the General Assembly today that member nations should make it clear to the Soviet Union that they expected Moscow to stop creating crises artificially in Berlin.
The appointment of Joseph F. Pesko as eastern regional sales manager of Airborne Freight Corporation was announced yesterday by John D. McPherson.
ATLANTA, Sept. 27 The Georgia General Assembly convened in special session today to reapportion the State Senate, as ordered by a Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) Five Mississippi Representatives asked the General Accounting Office today to investigate whether an Immigration and ..aturalization Service plane had been legally authorized to transport James H. Meredith between New Orleans and Memphis.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 John A. Scalzi Jr., president of the Scalzi Paint Store and a member of the City Park Commission, died today at United Hospital in Port Chester. He had been injured in an accident on the Cross-Westchester Expressway on Monday. His age was 55 and he lived at 21 Ralsey Road.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Izydor R. Modelski, who testified he was sent here as Polish military attache to establish a Communist spy ring in 1946, died Tuesday at the age of 74.

The production of a new miniaturized solid-state voltage generator was announced yesterday by Beckman Instruments, Inc. The component, called the Beckman Hall Effect Generator, is used to multiply electrical signals or sense a magnetic field.
LONDON, Sept. 27 The credit squeeze was further eased in Britain today and an expression of satisfaction was heard in the London Stock Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept, 27 Mrs. Eleanora Willing Patterson, vice president of the Philadelphia Society for the Preservation of Landmarks, died yesterday at the home of her son, A. Willing Patterson in Rosemont. She was 88 years old.

A science teaching program that will bring leading scientists and their latest experiments into the classroom will be pioneered next month by the Board of Education and the Radio Corporation of America.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 It appears that World Series games in New York will have to get along without Casey Stengel.
TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 27 (UPI) A Strategic Air Command RB-47 jet bomber crashed and burned on take-off here today, killing the four-man crew.
GENEVA, Sept. 27 The United States called on the Soviet Union today to abandon its policy of "constant retreat" at the three-power negotiations here for a nuclear test-ban treaty.

WHEELING, W. Va., Sept. 27 President Kennedy returned tonight to the state that started him toward the White House. He said Democratic policies had transformed West Virginia's "whole economic climate."

Four senior vice presidents and directors of Ted Bates Co. have been elected to the agency's executive committee, expanding its membership to 11. They are Jeremy Gury, J. Ross MacLennan, Richard A.R. Pinkham and Dan Rodgers.

The American Ballet Theater will visit nine New York cities next month in a two-week tour sponsored by the New York State Council on the Arts. The tour will open in Middletown next Monday and end on Saturday, Oct. 12, in Huntington, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that Lanolin Plus, Inc., of Newark, N. J. had made false therapeutic claims for Rybutol, a vitamin and mineral product.

If the Alberts are at all representative, then it appears that England's most modern cabaret satire is plunging swiftly ahead into the past. Three impish vaudevillians, they poke sly fun at the complicated absurdities of this gadget-minded era by carrying on as though time had stood still since 1900.
VANCOUVER, Sept. 27 (Canadian Press) Three British Columbia companies have reduced kraft pulp pries because of an oversupply in world markets, and a fourth is considering a price cut.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 Van Tat's Pride, driven by Del Insko, scored a three-length victory tonight over the favored Next Knight in the Jamaica pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway.
The Women's Auxiliary of the Presbyterian Hospital will hold a buffet luncheon in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club on Oct. 24 for the benefit of the hospital.

THE parade of American orchestras continued last night in Philharmonic Hall. So far, the New York Philharmonic, the Boston Symphony and the Philadelphia Orchestra have turned up. Last night the Cleveland Orchestra completed the cycle. (Too bad that the last of America's major orchestras, the Chicago Symphony, has not had a chance.)
VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 28 After the Completion of all preliminary round games in the Chess Olympics here last night, the pairings for the first round of the round-robin finals were drawn.

A director of the Deutsche Bank, A.G., Frankfurt, , Germany, Hermann J. Abs, will speak at the annual meeting Oct. 3 of the New York chapter of the Investment Bankers Association of America. The meeting will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
PATRICK DE BARENTZEN, the Italian couturier, said yesterday that he would not move his fashion house from Rome to Paris.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 Recent pressure from the Soviet Union for more influential United Nations posts has led to only a small increase in the number of Russians holding high-level jobs.
Pink roses and blue delphinium created a gardenlike setting for the 15th annual Blue Grass Ball in the ballroom of the Plaza last evening.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP) Alejandro Lavorante, the Argentine heavyweight, took a turn for the worse this afternoon when his temperature shot up perilously high. But doctors later reported that the danger had lessened and his temperature had declined.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 27 Gov. John Patterson of Alabama told President Kennedy today that if Federal troops or marshals were sent to Mississippi "your action would establish the Federal Government as a dictatorship of the foulest sort."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate passed today a bill to increase postal rates and raise the pay of 1,600,000 Government workers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 Miss Phyllis Eitingon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Eitingon of Kew Gardens, Queens, New York, was married here today to Dr. Victor Robert Grann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fenmor Grann of New London, Conn., and Miami, Fla. Rabbi Ralph Simon performed the ceremony at Rodfei Zedek Synagogue.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (UPI) Charles (Sonny) Liston arrived home today from Chicago, where he knocked out Floyd Patterson Tuesday night to win the world heavyweight boxing championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 27 The Justice Department abandoned tonight a fourth attempt to register James H. Meredith, a Negro, at the University of Mississippi.

LYNBROOK, L. I., Sept. 27 Residents of this noise-conscious community have won the first round in a fight to do away with the sounding of the morning and evening fire siren.

THE Off Broadway theater was insulted again last night when "Digging for Applea" opened at the Washington Square Theater. The new musical revue is ammunition for uptown philosophers who contend that anything can receive a hearing in Greenwich Village lofts, basements and decorated caves.

Some Rockettes from the Radio City Music Hall and some girls in the 3-to-6-yearold group, will test the ice in a pre-opening session at 1:45 P. M. today at the Rockefeller Plaza Outdoor Ice Skating Pond.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 27--In the excitement over a world championship heavyweight fight, the America's Cup yacht races and the Yankees' capture of the pennant, scant attention has been given to the college football offering coming up Saturday in New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The defeat for renomination of Representative James. C. Davis, conservative Georgia Democrat, focused the attention of politicians today on the role of the Federal courts in altering the nation's political landscape.

BUFFALO, N. Y. Sept. 27 Senator Walter J. Mahoney strongly condemned today the policy of state-supported institutions in allowing students to hear the views of those "who would overthrow the Government by force." He pledged to do all in his power to bar "insidious propaganda" from these institutions.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 27 (AP) Gov. Farris Bryant said today he did not think that "Armed Federal troops should be used against the Governor of Mississippi."

INCLEMENT weather failed to keep the fashion industry from honoring its own. Seven hundred persons in gala evening dress gathered last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to see Donald Brooks receive the Winnie trophy of the Coty American Fashion Critics' Award.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) Six directors of the Gabriel Company resigned at a company board meeting today as officers of the Maremont Corporation took control of the company with ownership of more than 50 per cent of the outstanding stock.

When it comes to profit margins the United Carbon Company, of Houston, Tex., does very nicely. It had earnings of $7,139,000 on sales of $59,563,000 last year. That's a healthy 12 per cent return, quite a bit better than many much larger companies can do.
Industry and union spokesmen differed widely yesterday in their reports on the effectiveness of a trucking shutdown.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 27 The Liberty Industrial Park, Jersey City's first major waterfront development in many years, was dedicated today.
Jews the world over will observe Rosh ha-Shanah at sundown today, marking the year 5723 on the Jewish calendar and the start of the High Holy Days.
TRY looking at Mitch with the sound turned out. At Mitch Miller, that is, whose television sing along begins a fresh season this evening.

A new five-year International Coffee Agreement designed to regulate trade in the key world commodity and keep prices at equitable levels will be approved formally here today, but without the adherence of at least four small Latin-American republics.

The General American Investors Company, general investments, has leased most of the 31st floor in the office building being constructed by the Uris Buildings Corporation at 60 Broad Street. Robert D. Murdock, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, was the broker. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., is the agent for the building.
THE Englishman's style of dress, long a symbol of prestige with American men, has been imported or copied down to the last cuff link in Bloomingdale's new Savile Row shop, which opens today.
Eager to add prestige to their forthcoming annual fall international trotting series, officials of Yonkers Raceway again took the rubber band off the track's bankroll yesterday.

Bank clearings in the nation's twenty-six leading cities declined in the week ended Sept. 26, but were above last year's levels, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Transactions totaled $31,720,392,000,
At Mayor Wagner's request, the Board of Elections has informally agreed to add two days to this year's voter registration period in New York City.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 27--Ogden R. Reid reported to the Westchester County Board of Elections here today that his personal expenditures in the Sept. 6 primary were $7,476.
WASHINGTON, Sept. , 27 President Kennedy signed new fair legislation today and expressed confidence it would "sustain prosperity, reduce burdens of surpluses, and maintain stable food prices."
Associated Press service within New York City, including Mackay Radio's broadcasting to the Middle East and Latin America, was interrupted for hours yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 The General Assembly's Social Committee agreed at its opening session today to give priority to the recent earthquake in Iran.

OTTAWA, Sept. 27 Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Conservative Government assured Canada's 25th Parliament today that it would seek to restore a balanced budget and to reduce the disbalance in trade.

ALBANY Sept. 27 Governor Rockefeller has called on the Federal Government to make surplus grain available for use as livestock feed by farmers in seven upstate counties stricken by the summer drought.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Senate investigators are trying to negotiate a peaceful settlement of a new dispute with George M. Humphrey, former Secretary of the Treasury.

ESTORIL, Portugal, Sept. 26 One of the rare meetings between Generalissimo Francisco Fracno and Don Juan. Count of Barcelona, the pretender to the Spanish throne, is expected to take place soon. The status of the pretender's son, Prince Juan Carlos, is to be the main topic at the proposed meeting.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 27 "It's nice to have you in Birmingham" is the slogan posted at the airport and elsewhere in this sprawling city in the Deep South.

Thirteen Negro parents in Queens who have charged the Board of Education with operating a segregated school system failed to appear yesterday for hearings at the Bureau of Attendance in Long Island City.
The Pennsylvania Railroad said yesterday that its new underground Pennsylvania Station would be airier and more convenient to travelers than the monumental marble building that is to be replaced.
CAIRO, Sept. 27 The United Arab Republic assumed a hands-off attitude today toward developments in Yemen and hinted broadly it expected other foreign powers to do the same.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The outgoing chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff argued tonight against changes in the chiefs' organizational setup that the new chairman, Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, has advocated.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 The newest trick in politics these days is the Telethon, in which the candidates take questions from the voters and answer them for hours over the television. It is a remarkable device, a little like the old rigged TV quiz shows, only now they give away states.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A bill to tighten drug laws passed the House today after four hours of spiritless debate.
Action was taken yesterday at two levels of government to help Long Island youth solve its problems.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 27 (UPI) Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that the Federal Government could not send troops to Mississippi to enforce its desegregation order without violating the Constitution and creating "a wasteland for the national Democratic party."
The directors of Bush Terminal Company, New York City, declared yesterday a stock dividend of 2 per cent on the common shares, payable on Dec. 3 to holders of record of Nov. 2.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27--The Soviet Union ridiculed today suggestions in the United States that a fishing port to be built in Cuba with Russian help would be used for military purposes.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP) Mrs. Dorothea Pratt, writer of articles on early American homes, was found dead last night in her home in Erwinna, upper Bucks County. She was 68 years old.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 (AP) Argentina's Roman Catholic Primate appealed today for national unity and a quick return to constitutional government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) President Kennedy announced today new steps by the Government to make it easier for tourists from other countries to obtain nonimmigrant visitors' visas. The move is designed to encourage foreign travel to the United States.
A labor official charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner's bill to establish a minimum hourly wage of $1.25 here was politically motivated in at mosphere of cynicism and deceit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) An advisory committee on training for the unemployed met for the first time today. It heard President Kennedy describe the program as one of the best pieces of social legislation passed this century.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) The Senate voted today to repeal the Communist disclaimer clause in the program of Federal loans for college students. No voice was raised in dissent.
The Federal Aviation Agency is "shooting for Nov. 19" as the date when Dulles International Airport will be ready for commercial operations, a spokesman in Washington said yesterday.

THE introduction of a bill that would earmark Fed eral taxes on marine fuel for the construction of boating facilities is anticipated for the next session of Congress by Bill Dyer. He is in the government relations department of the Outboard Boating Club of America.
In this time of crisis, I feel it appropriate for me to clarify my position as to my intention, my objectives, my hopes and my desires.
The defense in the incometax evasion trial of J. Truman Bidwell, former board chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, is expected to rest today in United States District Court.
The wholesale commodity index dropped to 80.3 Wednesday from 80.4 Tuesday, where it had been for three days.

The following is a listing of New York restaurants that are recommended on the basis of varying merits. Such a listing is published every Friday in The New York Times. Unless otherwise indicated, the restaurants are open seven days a week.
Republican efforts to invalidate Conservative party nominating petitions brought a sharp exchange between the Democratic and Republican state chairmen yesterday.
An association of American owners of Liberian and Panamanian ships has endorsed the United states effort to halt shipping to Cuba, it was announced yesterday.

Sonia Vargas, Peruvian pianist, gave her first recital here in two years at Town Hall last night. She reinforced the impression she made then that she is an appealing artist who does not force her tone or technique or the nature of the music she plays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The fact that racial desegregation in public education is under the compulsion of a new interpretation of the Constitution by the Federal judiciary, instead of a mandatory act of Congress, has its origin in the Supreme Court 1954 decision in Brown v. Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the 1961 week last year.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 Attorneys for James H. Meredith expressed strong disappointment tonight that the Federal Government had not moved more boldly to end the Mississippi crisis.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 Turkish shipowners have halted all cargo movements to Cuba in their vessels.
Wages and salaries for many workers here increased in the last year, Herbert Bienstock, middle Atlantic director of the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday.

A jammed rudder may have been responsible for the sinking of the tug Russell 18 in Newark Bay last week, the craft's chief engineer told a Coast Guard inquiry here yesterday. Three crew members were lost in the sinking.

The time may have come "when thought should be given to making the ownership of these international corporations also truly international." This idea was presented yesterday by Frederic G. Donner, chairman of General Motors Corporation, one of the largest international companies.

MIAMI, Sept. 27 (AP) The Revolutionary Junta, a new anti-Castro organization headed by a former underground leader, Manuel Ray, announced plans today for a sabotage and guerrilla campaign inside Cuba.
BONN, Sept. 27 Dr. Hans Kroll, former West German Ambassador to Moscow, said in an interview today that the Soviet Union was not happy with the wall dividing East and West Berlin.
It's a rare singer who knows his own voice, but this knowledge is the reason why Tito Schipa will give a concert in Town Hall next Wednesday night at the age of 73.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 27 (AP) Eighty-two passengers boarded a Varig airliner at Galeao International Airport for New York at midnight. Most slumped back in their seats and slept. The Boeing jet landed six hours later. The passengers awoke and got off at Galeao International Airport.

DACCA, Pakistan, Sept. 27 (Reuters) East Pakistani Government authorities said today that Indian troops entered East Pakistani territory last night, fired on a border patrol and were receiving reinforcements.

OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 27 A fourth attempt to enroll James H. Meredith in the University of Mississippi was canceled late today when it became evident that his life would be endangered. The 29-year-old Negro student and his escort of 25 deputy Federal marshals turned back to Memphis, Tenn., before reaching the campus in Oxford.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The Civil Rights Commission urged today that racial discrimination in housing be outlawed in the nation's capital.

Normally this would be nothing more than a period of patient waiting as the Yankees, their American League pennant safely tucked away, play out their final string of three games before moving into next week's World Series.
Douglas Imrie McKay, who served as Police Commissioner for about five months here in 1914, died last Monday in San Jose, Calif., at the age of 83.

REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 26 Economic planners believe that a bridge almost two miles long linking the Italian mainland to Sicily over the Strait of Messina is essential to the growth of the underdeveloped south.
LINDA THOMPSON was neither surprised nor at a loss for words when an advertising agency telephoned to ask for five houseflies for its fly-eating plants.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP)--The Houston Colts tonight kept Los Angeles from clinching at least a tie for the National League pennant by defeating the Dodgers, 8-6, by breaking a 6-6 tie with two runs in the seventh inning.

The extremely tight New York money market was reflected by the heavy borrowings at the Federal Reserve by member banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The Reserve also noted that the tightness extended across the nation.

HANDWOVEN fabrics were the highlight of a resort collection recently shown here to store buyers by Maskit of Israel, Ltd., an Israeli ready-towear concern.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 27 (AP) Former President Ei senhower told a news conference prior to a Pennsylvania Republican fund-raising dinner that he was positive the Kennedy Administration "will do something" to require the University of Mississippi to admit Mr. Meredith in accordance with Federal Court orders.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 27 Governor Rockefeller said today his Democratic opponent, Robert M. Morgenthau, was linked with New York City "bossism," which, he said, is trying to take over the state.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 27 Seven politicians went to college today to learn to be teachers. Their students will be 25 young men and 16 young women who want to teach about politics.

Massachusetts yesterday announced plans to sell $25,600,000 of bonds at competitive bidding on Oct. 16. The various-purpose bonds for different state agencies will bear maturities ranging up to 50 years. Of the issue, $15,000,000 will mature in 20 years.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 27 (UPI) Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. will photograph cloud formations during his orbiting flight to speed the development of a new weather satellite.

OTTAWA, Sept. 27 How to mesh increases in costs and prices, with profits and productivity, while asserting the national interest has become a critical economic problem of our time, according to Allan Sproul. Mr. Sproul, a former president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank was speaking before the Royal Commission on Banking and Finance today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Kennedy called on 400 experts in a dozen fields today to lay down guidelines for a new, comprehensive Federal narcotics program.

"Senate Shelves Transit Aid Bill." "2.6 Billion Allotted in States' Road Aid." These were two recent headlines on news dispatches from Washington that betray the Government's one-sided interest in highway construction for the automobile, to the almost total exclusion of any assistance to the financially stricken railroads.
The financial ills of the New Haven Railroad received an optimistic diagnosis last night from one of the road's three court-appointed trustees.
The State Medical Society recommended yesterday that the state pay all or part of the cost of health insurance for persons over 65 who cannot afford to pay.

Fred H. Hill, realty investor, has taken title for the third time to the three buildings at 1147 First Avenue and 342-44 East 63d Street. The property forms an "L" around the southwest corner of the two thor oughfares.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 A strike against the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad, which the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen had scheduled for tomorrow morning, was barred by a Federal judge today pending a further hearing on Monday.

ONE of the nicer things about the poor old human race is the ability of many people to fall deeply and permanently in love with places. The Governor and the state of Mississippi are now treating the world to the degrading spectacle of a university campus turned into a military encampment in order to bar a single mildmannered Negro from attending classes on a basis of equality with the white man.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) Dennis Bennett, a rookie lefthander, gave only five hits today and pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

ROME, Sept. 27 Pope John XXIII named two Roman princes as "custodians" of the Ecumenical Council and announced the names of 191 theological experts who will be available as advisers to council members. The meetiag opens Oct. 11.
Record sales and increased profits were achieved by Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., in the fiscal year ended July 31, the annual report of Samuel Bronfman, president, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) Senate Minority Leader Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois and Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, entered hospitals in Bethesda, Md., today.

Members of the motion picture industry voiced unanimous opposition yesterday to classification by the state of films suitable for children.
TORONTO, Sept. 27 Box-office receipts of the Stratford (Ont.) Shakespeare Festival have topped the million-dollar mark for the first time, it was announced today.
Seldom has a new football coach stepped into a less promising situation.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 27 Mrs. Harrison F. Flippin of Douglassville, Pa., scored 41-43 84 in the heavy rain and high, gusty winds of an easterly storm today and won the 37th United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship with a 36-hole aggregate of 160.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 27 Two members of Mississippi's House of Representatives praised today President Kennedy's "great strength" in dealing with the state's flouting of the Federal Courts.
Stocks sagged in quiet trading yesterday after drifting downward and then upward earlier in the day.

Robert M. Morgenthau charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was a "parttime Governor" who depended for advice upon employes of private business "not responsible to the people of the State of New York."
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association has asked President Kennedy to apply economic pressure on any country building merchant vessels for the Soviet Union.
Mayor Wagner's administration was denounced by one of its own members yesterday for seeking to "squander" $87,000 on another study of the city's youth problems, including juvenile delinquency.
PARIS, Sept. 27 Trains moving through Brittany were halted for hours today by aroused peasants, fishermen and tradesmen protesting against a projected increase in freight rates.
The first phase of a project designating buildings as "landmarks of New York" has been completed with financial support from the New York Community Trust.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that some parking rules would be suspended tomorrow and Oct. 8. Tomorrow is Rosh ha-Shanah and Oct. 8 is Yom Kippur.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 27 Mrs. Heinz Schultz has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Caroline Schultz, to Stephen E. Adler. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Adler of Danbury, Conn., and Brussels, Belgium.

The average rate of interest charged on short-term loans to business by New York City banks held steady between June and the first half of September,... the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The music season has now begun. There was a premiere of a work by William Sydeman at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
WARREN, Mich., Sept. 27 Broad shoulders; smaller fins and less chrome mark the Cadillacs for 1963.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 The Acting Secretary General, U Thant, has informed the General Assembly that estimated regular expenditures for 1962 will exceed appropriations by $2,727,480.
The North American Aviation, Inc., Downey, Calif., has received an Air Force contract totaling $45,640,000 for Minuteman missile guidance and control systems.
LONDON, Sept. 27 The stock market was quiet today. Most leading industrials dropped a few pennies.
The bond market was firm and moderately active yesterday.

A House subcommittee has uncovered "quite a number" of violations of the Clayton Antitrust Act in connection with mergers and consolidations of newspapers over the country, Representative Emanuel Celler said here last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27--The World Health Organization warned today that there had been a significant worldwide resurgence of syphilis. It urged international cooperation to control the disease.

Richard E. Hodges, vice president, general manager and a director of Appalachian Power Company of Roanoke, Va., died yesterday apparently of a heart attack on a train from Roanoke to New York. His age was 59.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (UPI) Royal Air Force helicopters removed from the Canadian aircraft carrier Bonaventure today four more injured and the 12 dead victims from the ditching of a Flying Tiger lines plane in the North Atlantic last Sunday night.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 27 (AP)--Darlene Hard of Los Angeles, seeking a third straight Pacific Coast tennis championship, today defeated Jane Albert of Pebble Beach, 8--6, 6--2.
GENEVA, Sept. 27 The sixnation European Common Mar ket will increase its quota for imports of low-cost cotton goods by 88 per cent over five years.
The British Motor Corporation showed its 1963 MG sports car designated the MGB at a press preview yesterday at the Americana hotel. It will sell here for $2,658.

After long hesitation and in response to urgent pleas, the United States has agreed to sell to Israel defensive short-range missiles to counter the massive armament the Soviet bloc is sending to the Arab states, in particular to the United Arab Republic. This is a reversal of the policy not to provide substantial American arms to any nation in the Middle East.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 Americans who visit the Soviet Union often remark in some wonderment about the warmth of their reception by Russians.

After four years at the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane, 39-year-old Victor Rosario became a free man yesterday, largely because he finally got someone to look into a fantastic story that he had tenaciously insisted was true.
The state announced yesterday that it was increasing its tests for radioactive iodine in milk as a result of the fallout from the current Soviet nuclear explosions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) A House Armed Services subcommittee declared today that unless the United States doubled its warship construction the fleet faced mass obsolescence, which could "have most disastrous consequences."

Governor Rockefeller urged the Port of New York Authority yesterday to approve the Pine Island area of New York's Orange County as the site for the new jetport that the agency has proposed for the metropolitan area. The site is south of Middletown, near the New Jersey border.
Cotton futures were 25 cents a bale up to 40 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. New October and new December were the weakest months.

In an action designed to test the constitutionality of the New York State film-censorship laws, "The Connection," a new film that had been denied a license for commercial showing, is scheduled to open here next week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP) Gene Oliver's three-run homer capped an early St. Louis Cardinal outburst today that stood up for a 7-4 victory over San Francisco. The defeat was a big jolt to the Giants's pennant hopes.
The Revlon International Corporation has elected two officers to new positions, Robert W. Armstrong, president of the wholly owned subsidiary of Revlon, Inc., announced yesterday.

A 28-year-old leader of the Committee For Non-Violent Action was sentenced to prison for nine months yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman for violating the Selective Service Act.

Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc., manufacturer of food and confectionery specialities, has purchased for cash all of the outstanding stock of the Bustelo Coffee Roasting Company, the Bronx, producer of a LatinAmerican type coffee.
The price of silver in New York added another 1 cents yesterday, reaching $1.21 per troy ounce, another new high since 1920.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)--Six American steel producers charged today that foreign steel wire rods were being dumped in United States markets by exporters from Japan, Germany, France, Belgium and Luxembourg.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (AP) Guy Hoff, a freelance artist whose work included magazine covers, died in Owings Mills today at the age of 73.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 28 (AP) A form of funeral service providing church services and burial in consecrated ground for suicides was recommended by a Church of England committee today.
LONDON, Sept. 27 Britain is contemplating no immediate political or military moves in the wake of the first reports today of an uprising in Yemen, a Foreign Office spokesman said.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 27 (UPI) Dick Powell, a successful singer and actor before becoming one of television's major producers, is suffering from cancer.

PARIS, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Talks at diplomatic level have begun between France and West Germany to fix details of closer cooperation between the two countries. They will settle matters agreed upon when President de Gaulle visited Germany earlier this month, official sources said tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 27 The Bounty, a 480-ton, threemasted stage prop used for a filmed version of the famous mutiny sailed into London port today.
It was sneaker day for the New York Giants yesterday. Coach Allie Sherman's National Football League club was scheduled for a full outdoor drill at Fordham University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) New Britain, Conn., lost today in a court effort to overturn an Atomic Energy Commission license to a trucking company to receive, store and dispose of low-level packaged radioactive wastes.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 David G. Taft, vice chairman of the board of directors of the Taft Broadcasting Company here, died of a heart attack today at Biddeford Pool, Me., where he and Mrs. Taft were on vacation. His age was 46.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a foreign aid program totaling $4,422,800,000 for the current fiscal year.
TRENTON, Sept. 27 The State Parole Board reported today it had denied a parole to Joseph V. (Newsboy) Moriarity and ordered that he serve his maximum sentence.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 27 Mrs. Lurietta de Kraft Livingston, concert pianist and music teacher, died Tuesday in her home on Clapboard Ridge Road. She was 85 years old and the widow of Frederick M. Livingston.

Listless trading in commodity futures on local exchanges ended yesterday with most prices down or narrowly irregular.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Administration has approved an Army plan to increase the size of its antiguerrilla forces to 6,650 over the next five years. This represents an expansion from the present force of 5,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) An advisory group met in closed session today to help the Social Security Administration plan a nationwide review of eligibility for aid to families with dependent children.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 27 J. Nelson Williams, retired vice president of the General Foods Corporation, with offices at 250 North Street in White Plains, died Tuesday at his home here, 2 Washington Square, at the age of 67.
