SIMSBURY, Conn., Sept. 27 Mrs. Eleanor Montgomery Ellsworth, wife of John S. Ellsworth, a cattle breeder and former chairman of the New York County Red Cross chapter, died today at her home. Her age was 82.
The Port of New York had its busiest day in at least five years yesterday as steamship lines hurried to move general cargo away from piers that may be struck at 12.01 A.M. Monday.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 27 (UPI) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said tonight that the University of Mississippi's refusal to admit James H. Meredith was "absolutely unconscionable and indefensible."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The State Department stressed today that the United States had no intention of attempting to maintain permanently a military balance in the Middle East.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kaminsky of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Kaminsky, to Nathaniel Paul Karush. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Karush of New Rochelle, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Operating revenues of the nation's interstate natural gas companies totaled $4,786,049,000 for 1961, up from $4,570,806,000 for 1960, the Federal Power Commission reported today.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 27 Israelis expect Hawk missiles to be obtained from the United States to end Arab superiority in the skies of the Middle East.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Victor H. Harrell Jr. to the newly created office of vice president in charge of sales.
The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that the Government could not control or censor television programs that are sent abroad by United States broadcasters.

Dr. and Mrs. Nathan L. Levine of New York and Neponsit, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Bonnie Levine, to Dr. Edwin Carl Olarsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Olarsch of Brooklyn.
ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 27 The Ghanaian Army and police stepped up today their hunt for a small but elusive secret army of terrorists who have killed 15 and wounded 250 in seven weeks of violence.
The State Commission for Human Rights ordered the New York office of the Arabian American Oil Company yesterday to stop refusing to hire Jews because of creed or ancestry.

Mrs. Josephine J. Cepek Wolf, who was active in the women's suffrage movement, died Wednesday in her home at 601 East 228th Street, the Bronx, at the age of 86. She was the widow of Julius Wolf, founder and former publisher of the American Slovak Gazette in Pittsburgh.

DA NANG, Vietnam, Sept. 26 In an effort to fit the aircraft to the terrain, the United States military command has replaced an army unit here with a marine squadron that has been flying faster and more powerful machines in the Mekong Delta.

THE venerable home furnishings concern of W Sloane is having its first official "at home" eight months after moving its house south on Fifth Avenue. Although the store has been open all along for business at its new address near 38th Street, it now feels sufficiently settled to celebrate.
Keyes, Madden Jones, Inc., and Post, Morr Gardner, Inc., two Chicago agencies, confirmed reports yesterday that they would merge, effective Jan. 1.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 The Ford division of the Ford Motor Company said today that prices on all but five of its 1963 passenger cars would remain unchanged.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 27 Three persons died and six children were rescued in a smoky fire that swept through an attic apartment in a twoand-one-half-story frame house at 448 Spring Street here shortly before noon today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Friday) (AP) A 110-man Army unit headed for Memphis, Tenn., early today to provide logistic support for the Federal marshals.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) The International Olympic Committee today banned from future Olympic Games all "state amateurs" subsidized by their governments and college athletes receiving scholarships based mainly on athletic ability.

EACH year at legislation time, as regularly as the leaves grow dead and sterile, laws further restricting a basic American right, the right to bear arms, are conceived. Most are stillborn to reappear in succeeding years in the same, or slightly changed, form.
TRENTON, Sept. 27 The police said tonight that what appeared to be a suicide note had been left by a Trenton dentist whose body and that of a woman were found in his office last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 Despite "modest alleviations"' of the tight Communist rule of Hungary, the regime there still rests on the support of Soviet forces, the United Nations special representative on Hungary reported today.
A $500,000 payment yesterday by Towers Marts International, Inc., to Grayson-Robinson, Inc., settled a dispute between the two companies.

Ending the parade of major orchestral talent across the stage of Philharmonic Hall last night was the Juilliard Orchestra. In some ways--particularly in the matter of mettlesome programing--it put its more illustrious colleagues to shame.

LONDON, Sept. 28 The leaves in London's miles of parks had a faint golden tone this week and a pallid sun was bathing the city with the copper glow of a British autumn. The fact that the sun shone at all was a conversation point for a people obsessed with the weather.
LISBON, Sept. 28 Portugal's Overseas Minister denounced today the "privileged sanctuary"" that he said terrorist raiders in Angola were finding in the Congo.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28(UPI) The Government of Israel has presented a Chicago corporation with a $25-million contract to construct a system of dikes in the Dead Sea for the processing of potash.

CRANSTON, R.I., Sept. 28 Miss Barbara Bromson and Stephen S. Rosenfeld are planning to be married on Oct. 28. Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Bromson have made known their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay C. Rosenfeld of Pittsfield, Mass.

Louis Skidmore, the architect who helped change the face of America and who waa a founding partner of Skidmore, Owings Merrill, died Thursday after a long illness at his home in Winter Raven, Fla. He was 65 years old.
GENEVA, Sept. 28 The 24nation Metals Trade Committee of the International Labor Organization urged today the drafting of a model code of safety regulations in shipyards.
Four mystery witnesses have been subpoenaed to testify before the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Boxing at a public hearing next Tuesday, it was learned yesterday.
A five-alarm fire swept out of control last night and early today on an Argentine cargopassenger ship tied to a Hudson River pier in lower Manhattan.
NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 28 Two power substations sixty miles apart, serving 8,482 customers, went out of service last night when rifle bullets struck insulators on high-tension lines.
Governor Rockefeller and Robert M. Morgenthau have agreed to make a joint appearance on television on Nov. 4, tvvo days before Election Day.
VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 28 In the first round of the finals of the world team championship of the Chess Olympics, the United States won one game, drew one and adjourned two against East Germany.

The Associates Investment Company filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed offering of $50,000,000 of debentures. The issue would mature in 1983 and proceeds would be used for working capital, O.C. Carmichael, chairman, said. Public offering of the issue would be made by an investment banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
An automobile skidded and mounted the sidewalk at East Tremont Avenue and Westchester Square in the Bronx yesterday and knocked down five school children.
Price reductions averaging 13 cents a pound for Orlon acrylic fiber have been announced by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. The cuts ranged from 4 to 16 cents a pound.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 Three of the 24 physicians whose licenses, were canceled last May by the State Board of Regents have taken new qualifying examinadons and have been fully restored to practice.

Miss Sarah Frothingham Mason, daughter of Mrs. Lester Ward of Walpole, N. H., and Harding Tremaine Mason of New York, was married yesterday to Harry Jackson, New York, painter and sculptor. He is the son of Mrs. Ellen Grace Jackson of Chicago.
SOMERS, N.Y., Sept. 28 Miss Julia Titus Emerson, a grandniece of Ralph Waldo Emerson, died yesterday at her home on Route 116. She was 85 years old.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk outlined the United States position on a wide range of world problems yesterday at an informal meeting with foreign ministers of the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO).
Investigations Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan announced yesterday that he had called on the city to order a refund of at least $250,000 in fraudulent rent increases in 100 buildings.

EVER since Russian education, with some assist- ance from German rocketeers, has been credited with Soviet triumphs in space, reports on Russian schools have been of supreme interest to Americans. The Soviet curriculum has been described, analyzed, admired, criticized and speculated about. It therefore made good sense for the American Broadcasting Company to take cameras into the Russian schools to let Americans see for themselves what goes on there.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 28 William Hyndman 4th of Abington, Pa., won the medal prize with a two-over-par 38-34 72 today in the qualifying round of the 38th annual golf tournament for the George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup at the Pine Valley Golf Club.
Henry Wolf, operator of the Skyway Garage opposite Pennsylvania Station, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital. His age was 77. He had been a resident of Miami Beach for the last ten years.
Sales of the General Tire and' Rubber Company in the nine months ended Aug. 31 increased 17.7 per cent to a record, but earnings declined 4.8 per cent from the 1961, reflecting competitive pressure.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Sept. 28--James N. Weeks, a director and former chairman and president of the Hanes Hosiery Mills Company, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home. His age was 70.

GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 28 (AP) Mississippi's state Democratic chairman, Bidwell Adam of Gulfport, told a cheerping crowd that he was through with the national Democratic party because of its stand in the University of Mississippi desegregation case.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Charges of cruelty, neglect and mistreatment in the use of research animals in United States laboratories were made today at a Congressional hearing.
William Walter Frankel, a lawyer who had been active in Democratic politics, died yesterday at his home, 355 Riverside Drive. His age was 72.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 A New York woman has been sentenced in East Germany to six years on a charge of espionage. She is Miss Gabrielle Hammerstein, a singer, who has been held incommunicado in East Germany since last January.
The offensive backfields of the New York Titans and the New York Giants received some encouraging news yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense, said today that the United States was ready to use nuclear arms in Germany if necessary to protect its vital interests in Berlin.
Walter Lippmann, whose news columns have been syndicated by The New York Herald Tribune since 1931, will be syndicated instead by The Washington Post beginning Jan. 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 Adam Rapacki, Poland's Foreign Minister, told the General Assembly today that West Germany was "the strongest power in the western part of the European Continent."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 28 (AP) Delegates of the Eighth General Assembly of the Atlantic Treaty Association called unanimously today for reduction of tariff barriers between the United States and Western Europe.

ADEN, Sept. 28 (Reuters) Ten former Government officials, including the former Foreign Minister, Hassan Bin Abrahim, were executed by the new rebel regime in Yemen today and a Premier and Cabinet were appointed, according to a broadcast from Sana, the nation's caiptal.
A new Museum of Early American Folk Arts, the latest addition to the city arts scene and the first of its kind here, will give an exhibition next Friday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 The National Farmers Organization's fight to raise livestock prices ended its fourth week today with plans to keep milk off the market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Agriculture Department predicted today that Americans would spend a record of $6,880,000,000 this year for cigarettes slightly more than five times the amount farmers got for last year's entire tobacco crop.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 28 Biggs Snow Prince, a 16month-old buff-colored cocker spaniel owned by Robert W. Biggs of Fairhaven, Mass., was best of breed at the Cocker Spaniel Club of Long Island's 30th annual specialty show today at the American Legion Hall.

Abdel Khalek Hassouna, Secretary General of the Arab League, said yesterday that the projected sale of United States missiles to Israel was ill-advised and a danger to the stability of the Middle East.
LONDON, Sept. 28 The Mississippi integration crisis dominated the front pages of European newspapers today.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph Curry Walker, former pastor of Madison Avenue Baptist Church, died yesterday of a heart attack in Neckargem nd, Germany, according to word received here at the office of the American Baptist Convention. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Soil-filled flowerpots, possibly aided by a piece of shirting, offer an emergency technique for purifying water contaminated by fallout from a nuclear attack, a Government scientist said today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28 Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi was found guilty today of civil contempt of Federal court orders against interfering with the desegregation of the University of Mississippi.

THE Chief United States Marshal, charged with carrying out the orders of the Federal Government in Mississippi, is a sweet-talking, tough-fibered man from the sidewalks of New York. He is James Joseph Patrick McShane, who won 12 citations for bravery in 21
CINCINNATI, Sept. 28(AP) The Cincinnati Reds collected 10 hits and seven runs in the first three innings tonight and beat Philadelphia, 7 3.
College football takes the center of the stage today and everybody gets into the act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 It has been a week of soft cold rain and lingering mists along the Potomac. The first tinge of gold is in the. maples, the smell of wood smoke in the air. The tourists are gone. Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy is back. It is autumn, the season of quiet when the Government's pulse beats weakly and Washington enjoys a few precious weeks of living with the pressure off.

TUCKED away in the northeast corner of Blooming dale's fifth floor is a roomful of Old World delicacies, including the famous Viennese Sachertorte, a very rich and moist chocolate cake. Supplies of the cake are being flown here from Austria especially for the current storewide presentation of European imports.

The 13-day strike at Channel 13 was settled yesterday. An agreement was signed by Richard D. Heffner, vice president and general manager of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, and Kenneth Groot, executive secretary of the New York local of the striking American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 28 United States marshals continued to arrive today at the Naval Air Station at Millington, Tenn., 18 miles from here.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 28(AP) Lear Siegler, Inc., said today that its instrument division had saved the prime contractor on the Bomarc missile one million dollars.
Preston L. Hickey, a motion picture public relations man, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at the Hotel Sheridan Lincoln in Indianapolis. He was 62 years old.
BIRMINGHAM, Sept. 28 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., apostle of nonviolence to achieve equal racial rights, was struck twice in the face today by self-styled member of the American Nazi party.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Sept. 28(AP) The captain or the airliner that ditched in the Atlantic last Sunday told today how a mental "inspiration" had sent him back into the plane's cabin for a flashlight that was to help save the 76 Americans aboard.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 28 Richard Schermerhorn Jr., a retired municipal planner and landscape architect, died yesterday. He was 84 years old and lived at 173 Orange Road, here.

Miss Martha Sykes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Ware Sykes of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Henry Lohmann Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Matthew Murray of New York and Lawrence, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced plans today to launch two huge Project Echo spheres.
James R. Hoffa claimed victory yesterday in his drive to impose an area-wide contract on New York and New Jersey trucking operations outside New York City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The first $1,000,000 Federal expenditure for the Fire Island dune erosion project was approved today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.
The wholesale commodity price index dropped to 80 Thursday from 80.3 the day before.

Like Henry Higgins, we've grown accustomed to her face. She is not simply his smudgefaced, sniveling, lower-class experiment but our explosive pet. He is not merely her splentic condescending mentor but our crotchety friend: "My Fair Lady" has become part of our lives.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 28 A clear and strong exchange of views on James H. Meredith is hard to find among the Negroes of Jackson, who make up about a third of the city's population of 160,000.
A driving northeaster raked the East Coast yesterday for the second day in a row.

New York's economy, just beginning to throw off the choking effects of a strike and lockout in trucking, faces the further squeeze at midnight tomorrow of a paralyzing dock strike. The threatened walkout by the International Longshoremen's Association would blockade every Atlantic and Gulf port from Maine to Texas. It is the latest in a series of crises that indicate the inadequacy of present bargaining procedures and labor laws in all branches of transportation.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (AP) Charlie James singled home the winning run with two out in the tenth inning tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Dodgers, 3 2, and cut the Los Angeles lead over second-place San Francisco to 1 games.
Offerings of fixed-interest debt issues next week are expected to exceed $118,000,000. This would compare with capital offerings of $138,000,000 scheduled this time last week.

The Citizens Budget Commission urged the City Planning Commission yesterday to reject the Transit Authority's proposal for a $200,000,000 highspeed, nonstop subway line between mid-Manhattan and the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Merck Co., Inc., has patented a new alloy, trademaked "ZMet," which it says will be an efficient material for thermoelectric cooling, the latest thing in refrigeration.

As Jews began the observance of Rosh ha-Shanah at sundown yesterday, marking the start of the High Holy Days, rabbis pleaded for a greater adherence to the values of Judaism and for greater attendance in temples and synagogues.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)An active speculative . trade drove wheat futures over a broad range on the Board of Trade today. The crop closed mixed.

THE PRESIDENT Heard report of President's committee on employment and unemployment statistics; received Keith J. Holyoake, Prime Minister of New Zealand; attended swearing in of Charles A. Horsky as adviser for national capital affairs; presented Distinguished Serv
Cotton futures fell 10 to 60 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28(AP) A Pittsburgh Pirate southpaw, Bob Veale, hurled 6 2/3 hitless innings against the Milwaukee Braves, but had to settle for a three-hitter and an 8-2 victory tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 Samuel Parke Rodgers, a director and former vice president of the Insurance Company of the State of Pennsylvania, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Wayne.

A $16,000,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in New York State Supreme Court against Dun Bradstreet, Inc., by De Jay Stores, Inc., a clothier concern, and three other organizations. They charged that "false, untrue and defamatory" reports had been made by the credit reporting agency.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28 The Rev. William J. Manning, assistant professor of philosophy at St. Peter's College, died today in St. Francis Hospital, after a short illness. His age was 53.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Kennedy announced tonight that the Chicago and North Western Railway and the Order of Railroad Telegraphers had reached agreement in their 30-day strike. He said that service would resume as soon as possible.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 28 Some state officials made a sober reappraisal today of this state's position in the crisis created by Gov. Ross R. Barnett's defiance of Federal authority.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) Members of a delegation of Jewish victims of Nazi tyranny were told by the Soviet Embassy today that Jews living in the Soviet Union might leave to join families abroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Jerome B. Wiesner, science adviser to the President, charged yesterday that the National Education Association was largely to blame for the defeat last week of the college aid bill.

The establishment of a unified European market of 300,000,000 people hinges on the success of negotiations between the European Economic Community (Common Market) and the European Free Trade Association, Frank Figgures, Secretary-General of Outer Seven, said in a speech here yesterday.

HONG KONG, Sept. 28 The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party said today that there had been a slight improvement in the economic situation this year. A communique also indicated changes would be made in bureaucratic appointments and referred to the "incompetence of some leading cadres."
Columbia will open its season today against a Brown squad that scored a surprising opening-game victory over Colgate. Game time for the Baker Field contest is 1:30 P.M.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 28 (AP) A resolution adopted by members of a three-state Baptist group urges Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi to "stand fast and die if necessary for what you believe to be right."

The third design clinic presented by the National Society of Interior Designers will be held next Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. in the National Design Center Auditorium, 415 East 53d Street. It will benefit the society's educational foundation for talented design students.

The Monsanto Chemical Company has acquired the half interest in the Plax Corporation held by the Emhart Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday. Monsanto has owned the other 50 per cent since 1957, when it was acquired from the Owens-Illinois Glass Company.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 Walden, W. Shaw, former operator of a taxi fleet, died yesterday in Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hospi-' tal. He was 83 years old.
ALGIERS, Sept. 28 Ahmed Ben Bella, Premier-designate of Algeria, announced tonight that Algeria would be Socialist in her economic organization but "neutralist and nonengaged" in foreign policy.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 28 A two-part complaint charging the Board of School Estimate with perpetuating racial discrimination by inaction has been filed with Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger, State Commissioner of Education.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 In a ceremony solemn enough to emphasize its symbolic character, the long-term International Coffee Agreement was opened for signature here today. Twenty-' three Governments signed immediately.

ATLANTA, Sept. 28 (AP) The Georgia Senate, in special session for court-ordered reapportionment, argued today whether Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi should be praised for his defiance of the Government.

Events today: Falla's "El Amor Brujo" and the first United States performance of his "Atlantida," presented by the Metropolitan Opera Company, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, duo pianists, Philharmonic Hall, 3 P.M.; September Vegen, a Hungarian musical evening, Town Hall, 8 P.M.

Floyd Patterson was so humiliated after the first-round knockout by Sonny Liston on Tuesday night in Chicago that he drove all the way back to New York disguised as a bearded beatnik. He had a beatnik beard glued to his chin, a thick mustache across his upper lip, dark glasses over his eyes, and a hat tilted forward on his head.

Patrolman Robert Hoover, who has been attached to the, Central Investigation Bureau of the Detective Division, was suspended yesterday on charges of associating with known gamblers. He .is scheduled to face a departmental trial.

ALGIERS, Sept. 28 (AP) "Our Jewish festive season will be a sad one this time," a leader of the Jewish community here said today as he watched elderly Jews lining up for their monthly free ration of flour, milk powder and vegetable oil.

Mrs. Violet Ketels of Merion Station, Pa., an occasional actress and teacher of English, has finished the dramatization of "Time of Hope," an early novel by Sir Charles P. Snow, published by Scribner's.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 28 Former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker continued today his efforts toward a march of civilians on Mississippi to help Gov Ross R. Barnett resist any Federal troops in the integration crisis.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has called for an increase in the so-called weight break points in the trans-Atlantic air-' lines' cargo rate scale.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 Alexander I. Ponomareff, a mechanical engineer and assistant to the vice president of the Westinghouse Company's steam division before his retirement in 1960, died Wednesday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Havertown.

ALBANY, Sept, 28 A Supreme Court hearing of an action brought by the City Club of New York to prevent former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh from collecting his state pension was postponed today to Oct. 26.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 28 (AP) Seven new directors were elected and three incumbents were re-elected today by the Associated Press Managing Editors Association.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 28 The Rev. Dr. William F. Frazier, retired treasurer of the Board of Home Missions of the Congregational Christian Churches, died of a heart attack today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.
The Aetna Life Affiliated Companies in Hartford, Conn., have elected John M. Meyer Jr. a director.

Two magnificent salary drives faltered in the stretch at Yankee Stadium last night. Early Wynn lost his bid to become baseball's 14th 300-game winner and Mickey Mantle went hitless in four appearances at bat.
CAIRO, Sept. 28 President Gamal Abdel Nasser established a 12-member Presidential Council today designed to reorganize the United Arab Republic Government on the basis of "group leadership."

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 28 An anonymous gift of $3,500,000 from an alumnus for construction of a new Amherst College library to be named the Robert Frost Library was announced today by Calvin H. Plimpton, president of the college.
Federal mediators were rebuffed last night in their efforts to avert a strike at midflight tomorrow by 90,000 longshoremen in ports from Maine to Texas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)--Democratic Congressmen revealed today that the farm bill signed by President Kennedy yesterday contained a provision that inadvertently discriminated against 300,000 small wheat growers.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28--Soviet newspapers declared today that a new dispute had arisen that might endanger the East-West agreement to create a neutral Laos.
PARIS, Sept. 28 The translation rights of Marcel Achard's new comedy "Turlututu" had already been sold for a number of foreign countries before the play opened here tonight at the Theatre Antoine.

Stylon Corporation, Boston ceramic tile manufacturer, announced yesterday that it is proposing a reverse split that would reduce its authorized common stock to 750,000 shares from 3,000,000. Outstanding would be reduced to 542,743 from 2,170,973.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28 Following is the text of an opinion of the United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals that today found Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi guilty of contempt of court:

GLENCOE, Ill., Sept. 28 Dr. and Mrs. Harold Laufman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dionne Laufman, to Dr. Wolfgang Weigert, a senior resident in psychiatry at the Yale University Medical School's Mental Health Clinic.
The Archbishop of Canterbury will arrive here Oct. 12 to begin a three-week visit in the United States, his first since he was enthroned.
A $750,000 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the widow of one of three men killed in a midtown restaurant last Friday by a car that crashed through the window.

St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katharine Ludington Murphey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Lambert Murphey of New York and Westhampton Beach, L. I., to Lieut. (jg.) Anthony D. M. S. Pell of the Naval Reserve.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 28(AP) The engine of the X-15 rocket ship got its longest workout aloft today, 2 minutes 7 seconds.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 28 The first American performance and the first English production anywhere of Friederich D rrenmatt's "An Angel Comes to Babylon" was staged here last night.

The Collins Radio Company has named John H. Boyle to vice president and general manager of the communication and data systems division; W.W. Roodhouse, vice president, was elected to fill an unexpired term as a director.
A new device installed at New York University allows teachers to write on a "blackboard" without turning their backs to their classes.
TRENTON, Sept. 28 Two North Jersey milk distributors renewed their two-year-old effort today to end state price controls on milk.
The first major glass tableware plant built in the United States in thirty-five years was dedicated yesterday at the City of Industry, Calif., twenty-five miles east of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 29 An American sailor was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last night in a New York suburb and charged with conspiring to pass defense secrets to the Soviet Union.

Bonds called in September for redemption before maturity totaled $115,239,000, more than double the $53,620,000 of the preceding month. Transactions were below July's $124,896,000 which is the highest volume so far this year. But prepayments were 189 per cent above the $39,843,000 recorded in the similar 1961 period.
Although it is a relatively new race, the $100,000 Woodward Stakes has grown into one of the most important contests on the national thoroughbred scene.
An 18th-century mathematician, irked at having been refused a life-insurance policy at the age of 46 because he was considered too old, formulated a plan that revolutionized the business.
VANDENBERG A.F.B., Calif., Sept. 28 (AP) A Canadian spacecraft roared aloft tonight toward a Polar orbit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) President Kennedy signed today a bill to establish an 81-mile-long Padre Island National Seashore park off the Gulf Coast of Texas. The isalnd extends for 113 miles from Corvus Christi almost to Mexico.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 28 United States sources reported that South Vietnamese Government troops routed two companies of Communist guerrillas in fighting today near the mouth of the Mekong River, south of here.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (UPI) Alejandro Lavorante tonight entered the second week of a full coma that resulted from a boxing knockout, and doctors said they were starting a series of electroencephalograms to evaluate damage to his brain.
DETROIT, Sept. 28(AP) Hank Bauer resigned tonight as manager of the Kansas City Athletics and Ed Lopat was named as his successor.

WINNETKA, Ill., Sept. 28 Dr. and Mrs. Wallace Dundas Mackenzie have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madeleine Mackenzie, to Bernard Christopher Nevill Jackson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Nevill Jackson of Ruxton, Md.

Stock prices dropped sharply this month. The New York Times combined average fell 17.80 points, and hit the lowest point since late July. This pushed the market back within striking dLstance of the year's low point, which was made on June 25, when the Times average touched 286.09.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Sept. 28 The last Dutch Governor left this island today after a day of farewells heavily tinged with sorrow and bitterness. The Governor, P.J. Platteel, left by air two days before Dutch

ROME, Sept. 28 (Reuters) Britain and Italy agreed today that "concrete prospects" exist for a favorable solution to the problems of Britain's entry into the European Common Market and the establishment of a European political union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) President Kennedy asked Congress today for $10,191,000 to help companies and workers injured by expanded imports under the new foreign trade bill.
The price of silver in New York dropped 1 cents a troy ounce to $1.19 yesterday, the first decline here since July 5.

Chief Judge Sylvester J. Ryan of United States District Court accepted yesterday pleas of no contest by five steelcompany executives accused of price-fixing and bid-rigging in sales of steel forgings.
TAPPAN, N.Y., Sept. 28 The Rockland County Historical Society will conduct its fourth annual tour of historic houses tomorrow.

MORE than 2,000 accessories from Italy are displayed on rows and rows of glass shelves at Piazza 65th Street, which will open today at 133 East 65th Street. Outside the shop is a wild orange, pink and red plaid awning that is in marked contrast to the chalk white walls that line the interior. The own
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $5,211,271,400 appropriation to continue the building and planning of public works projects this fiscal year.

Those managers who argue that concerts by string quartets do not sell might consider the fact that Philharmonic Hall had nearly a capacity audience yesterday for its second "twilight concert," which was by the Juilliard Quartet. And that was at an off-peak hour.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, published today a document by Lenin that said "victory over the bourgeoisie" must be won by economic means.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The index of wholesale primary market prices remained at 101 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Sept. 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

It seemed as if they could have danced all night after the tall, handsome young man sat down at the piano and led his orchestra in a rendition of "Make Someone Happy." Another Duchin was back in town.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income; for the eight and 12 months ended Aug. 31.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 28 (Reuters) The pilot of a Nationalist U-2 reconnaissance plane downed over Communist China early this month was credited today with having located and photographed more than half the new air bases on the Chinese mainland.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 28 Governor Rockefeller announced today that he would ask the next Legislature to liberalize the depreciation allowances for investments in industry and research.

ACCRA, Ghanna, Sept. 28 The Government imposed censorship today on all press dispatches leaving Ghana. This followed the expulsion of two British correspondents, Walter Partington of The London Daily Express and Richard Beeston of The Daily Telegraph.

CHATHAM, N. J., Sept. 28--Miss Susan Hooker Petersen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Oluf Andreas Petersen, became the bride this evening of Kent Hill Sabin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Alfred Sabin of Mansfield, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to President Kennedy today a compromise bill that would permit self-employed persons to set up tax-deductible pension funds.

ROME, Sept. 28 The stability of Premier Amintore Fanfani's center-left Government was endangered today. His Christian Democratic party called on the Left-Wing Socialists to clarify their relations with the Government and to undertake more clearly defined commitments in its support.
A solid advance in cocoa futures highlighted an otherwise mixed and generally quiet Friday, on the New York commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) United States marshals are the enforcement arm of the nation's Federal court system.
A part of the Lincoln Center repertory theater began its training program yesterday.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 28 A newspaper that circulates widely in Mississippi expressed opposition today to Gov. Ross R. Barnett's defiance of Federal Court desegregation orders, Two other newspapers supported him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) A House subcommittee chairman said today that several stewardesses and flight attendants had acknowledged they were allowed to take the controls of airliners during flights.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Kennedy promised Robert M. Morgenthau today to make at least two visits to New York State in the next five weeks in support of Mr. Morgenthau's campaign for Governor.
BLOOMINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The Minnesota Twins swept to an 11-5 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles today and assured themselves of at least a tie for second place in the, American League.

The Russians have always been superb horse trainers and riders. Probably the last great cavalry charges in history were those of the Cossacks against the German armies as they retreated westward across the Ukraine after the defeat at Stalingrad. Cossack cavalry "escorted" the battered German armies across the snowy steppes and swarmed down to the attack every time the retreating forces faltered. Riders and horses responded with remarkable discipline to the attack commands.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) President Kennedy named Representative Kathryn E. Granahan, Democrat of Pennsylvania, today to be Treasurer of the United States.
BONN, Sept. 28--West German car makers issued gloomy predictions today about their industry's future, despite signs that 1962 might turn into another record year.
Public bond offerings fell in September to their lowest level this year. The value of stock offerings decreased from that in the preceding month, but was above last year's level.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Department of Justice probably will test the intentions of Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Missis- sippi before the Tuesday-morning deadline set by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

Thirty-nine demonstrators were arrested at a Bronx hospital last night after participating in a day-long sit-in to protest a collective bargaining election. The police said they would be charged with "unlawful instrusion on real property."

Judge Daniel J. Donahoe of Chemung County was elected president of the statewide Family Court Judges Association yesterday at the close of the association's four-day annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel. He succeeds Judge Leonard E. Ruisi of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The Senate approved today a compromise version of an Administration bill that would prohibit the interstate shipment of gambling equipment.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 (AP) Mrs. John O. Burgwin's Shirley Jones heads a field of nine fillies and mares named for tomorrow's 11th running of the $29,250 Margate Handicap.

ANY new artist nowadays who can produce a central blob with four attachments that could be diagnosed as limbs is scrutinized as a possible new Donatello. Though, what he produces may appear as distantly human as Sonny Liston's public image, some are already willing to cheer, put down their money, and watch the latest esthetic contest: The Figure vs. The Rest.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP) The smallest crowd of the major league season 588 wet, shivering fans watched the Detroit Tigers defeat the Kansas City Athletics, 7 3, today. Rocky Colavito and Al Kaline hit tworun home runs.
BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 28 (AP) Leaders of the massive rescue operations in the wake of Barcelona's disastrous floods indicated today that the death toll might exceed 800.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Administration will submit a comprehensive, realistic narcotics program to the next session of Congress, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy announced today.
LONDON, Sept. 28 The ad vance by British Government bonds continued on the stock market today with further substantial gains among the shortdate issues.

A substantial drop in the number of passengers traveling aboard Argentine and American liners between here and ports along the east coast of South America has prompted the two steamship lines active in the trade to reduce fares.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Farm product prices advanced 2.5 per cent during the month ended Sept. 15.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 George E. Hill Sr., Republican leader and former vice president of N.E. Henderson Company, a local wholesale hardware firm, died today at the age of 84.

Salvatore M. Pino Sr. of 198 Bay 17th Street, Brooklyn, who served for a half-century with Il Progresso Italo-Americano, an Italian-language newspaper, died Thursday in Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases. His age was 73.
The National Maritime Union threatened temporarily yesterday to halt the sailing of a freighter bound for Scandinavia with a cargo of. chemicals for the Soviet Union.
Corporate debt securities were strong and active yesterday in the over-the-counter market. Government obligations continued to move ahead and state and municipal issues were firm.
The Board of Elections voted yesterday to add two days to this year's voter registration period in the city.

Scoring in the first three periods, Riverdale Country Day School defeated Poly Prep, 19 0, yesterday and stretched its unbeaten string to 31 games, including ties. The game, played at Poly Prep's field, opened the Ivy League prep football season for both teams.
Monti, the hairdresser who in the space of one year has made himself a fashion editors' favorite, has closed his salon and plans to leave for Paris on Oct. 15.

The World Bank and its affiliate, the International Development Association, are confronted with a serious problem. The bank has funds available, and can always borrow more, but it is running out of lendable projects, while IDA has no shortage of projects but is running out of funds.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 28 Stockholders approved today the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation's recapitalization plan. Dissenters critized the plan at the meeting here and one threatened a lawsuit.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 It was so quiet at Wrigley Field today, you could hear the Mets drop their 119th game. Only 595 fans saw the Cubs beat the New Yorkers, 3 2, in a meeting between two of the worst teams in baseball.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Telstar satellite has survived almost three months of radiation attack without losing its effectiveness, commercial operators of the communications experiment said today.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 28 (AP) The Atlantic Danville Railroad, in the trusteeship since 1960, was sold to the Norfolk Western Railway Company for $1,500,000 at a public auction today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 A Federal Communications Commissioner left office today with plans to act as a consultant to mayor broadcasting and electronics concerns.
The United States Steel Corporation has a second venture in Italy.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 128 The first service contract with a foreign company for production of oil was announced There today by the Venezuelan Government.

After two false starts in the past four years, the WarnerLambert Pharmaceutical Company moved toward diversification yesterday when stockholders voted, by a large margin, to approve a merger agreement with the American Chicle Company.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 Irving W. Berkemeyer's Su Mac Lad set a track record of 2 minutes in winning the Trader Horn trotting feature by 1 lengths tonight before 24,050 fans at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)--Drillers will start digging a 1,000-foot hole next week preliminary to a later attempt to pierce the earth's crust and sample the planet's unknown interior.

THE 40th annual dog show of the Westbury Kennel Association will be held today on the Phipps polo field, Post Avenue and Jericho Turnpike, Old Westbury, L.I. For the second year in a row, Westbury will have no best in show or variety groups.

A leading men's hat manufacturer, concerned about the trend to hatlessness among the nation's college men, came up with a new approach to the problem last week--a doit-yourself hat that can be rolled up and stowed away in the owners pocket when not being worn.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 29-- Williams College scored twice in the second period today and held on for a 13-to-0 victory over Trinity College before a near capacity crowd of 7,500 at the Trinity Field.

Pierre Atkinson, an accountant for the California-Texas Oil Company and an active memberexplorer of the Explorers Club, died of a heart attack Friday in his home at 1720 New Hyde Park Road, New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 63 years old.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va. --So successful was Vir ginia's first Autumn Pilgrimage last fall that this year it will be extended from three to nine days, Oct. 20 through 28. This permits the inclusion of many outstanding showplaces not visited last year.
CAIRO, Sept. 29--The United Arab Republic became today the first Arab country to recognize the new republic of Yemen.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22-- Despite predictions of dire consequences, the last vestige of segregation in the public schools of near-by Coatesville, Chester County, has been ended without incident.

PORTLAND, Oreg. Sept. 29-- Of all districts held by Oregon Republicans in the House of Representatives, the one that the Democrats believe most likely to fall into their hands this year is the Fourth District. It is now represented by Dr. Edwin R. Durno.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29-- Mrs. Hanna Cox Harris Johnson, wife of Vice Adm. Alfred W. Johnson, U.S.N., retired, died at her home today. She was 82 years old.
Prices of most stocks in-the over-the-counter market fell last week, with bank and insurance issues the biggest losers.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29-- Stephan Smith, Harold McGinnis's 6-year-old racer, won the $25,000 Nassau Pace a mile and half at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The odds-on favorite, Irvin Paul, carrying the hopes of Abe Wilsker of New York, finished last in the field of seven. This was the 105th and final night of racing of the year here and a crowd of 32,587 attended.

KUTAMA, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 29--African nationalists are moving to go underground in their struggle for political equality in Southern Rhodesia.
The Congress of Racial Equality suggested yesterday that President Kennedy personally escort James H. Meredith to classes at the University of Mississippi.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 29 (UPI)--Wisconsin routed New Mexico State today, 69--13, using 61 players to rack up a modern school scoring record before 40,495 fans.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29--White and Negro leaders here are concerned because the disorders in suburban Kinloch this week have been widely misinterpreted as race riots.

QUARRY HEIGHTS, C.Z., Sept. 24--A change in emphasis of the military assistance to Latin-American countries is is making itself felt here at the United States Caribbean Command headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)--Low-level, packaged radioactive wastes may be dumped at 40 locations on the Pacific Coast of the United States and Canada without endangering human or sea life, a panel of scientists said today.
ORONO, Me., Sept. 29 (UPI) --The University of Rhode Island scored two touchdowns in the final seven minutes today to defeat Maine, 14--7.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 29--Harmon Killebrew set one enviable and one unenviable record today as his 47th and 48th home runs helped the Minnesota Twins gain an 8-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The triumph clinched second place in the American League for the Twins.

NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 29 --Countess Catherine Genevieve Buxhoeveden, daughter of Mrs. Hans Kessler of Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I., and the late Count Alexander Buxhoeveden of Paris, was married here this afternoon to Hans Holzer. He is the son of Leo Holzer of New York and the late Mrs. Holzer.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 24--An upsurge of gambling fever in New Zealand has brought sharp warnings from two Bishops of the Church of England. They maintain that the trend poses a threat to society.

It is unlikely that the 18-yearold author of this astonishing little book will be subjected to the usual patronizing admonitions handed out by reviewers to very young writers of first novels ("she will no doubt improve with maturity," "she must learn to tighten up her writing," "if she ever masters dialogue.") Maturity, tight writing, brilliant dialogue are her distinguishing features. Imagination, too? We can only hope so.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--Parties in power that have felt required to make decisions which engendered highly emotional popular resentments have often been voted out of office. FOR THIS WEEK: Continue planting perennials; be sure that the soil is moist and free of heavy clods.... ANY number of reasons account for the slowness of Western appreciation of Indian art. Generations nurtured on Graeco-Roman traditions and Mediterranean esthetic ideals scorned it as embodying what Lord Macaulay called inelegant superstitions, and puritanical standards were repelled by its frank, and often gross, sensuality.

ON Christmas, 1943, there entered my house by way of Santa Claus a book that I have reread every second year ever since. Never in my life did I so resist a book I later came to love. I resisted it because it made a nonsense of all my pet social theories in 1943. I loved it because its author, over the years, became a stanch and intimate friend even though I never met him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)--Officials of several Federal agencies are working on plans for a new stand by program under which tightlycoordinated United States Government relief services could be rushed into action when natural disasters strike abroad.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 29 --Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Killian have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Page Killian, to Harold W. Clauss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clauss of Allentown, Pa.

JACKSON, Sept. 29--With attention focused elsewhere, Jacksonians went to the polls in small numbers today to defeat a proposal that would have increased the Mayor's salary from $12,500 to $20,000 a year and that of city commissioners from $10,000 to $15,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)--President Kennedy appointed Sylvester Garrett, a Pittsburgh arbitrator, today to be the neutral member of the three-man panel to arbitrate the Chicago North Western Railway dispute.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 29-- As the tide of racial change rolled slowly southward, many white Mississippians planted their feet in the sand and cried "never." The harsh message of Clinton, Tenn., Little Rock, Ark., and New Orleans went unheeded or unheard.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Powers Elliott of New York and Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Caroline Dommerich Elliott, to Pvt. Sydney Messer Williams 3d of the Army. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Peterborough, N.H.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goldberg of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sabine Goldberg, to Robert Breier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Breier of Rockville Centre, L.I.
SEATTLE, Sept. 29 (UPI)-- Willie Siler, a diminutive quarterback, threw a 31-yard touchdown pass, set up another and masterminded Washington to a 28-7 football victory today over Illinois.

Primary aluminum production in the United States in August totaled 168,086 tons, 8.7 per cent below the 184,106 tons of July, the Aluminum Association has reported. August output was lowered by brief strikes in several plants at the beginning of the month.

The new term of the Supreme Court, starting tomorrow, promises to be one of controversy, of testing, of change. There will be, for one thing, the unanswered questions left by last term's historic decision opening the Federal Courts to suits challenging the fairness of state legislative districting.
EXETER, N.H., Sept. 29-- Phillips Exeter Academy today scored a touchdown with four seconds remaining in the first half and made it stand up for a 6--0 victory over Brewster Academy.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 29 --Ralph Heinzerling's Jack Rabbit, a 24-foot Dolphin Class sloop that flies the burgee of the Manhasset Bay Y.C. of Port Washington, L.I., sailed off with Crusing honors for the second straight year today in the Tri-Club's Y.R.A. Last Chance Regatta.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 29 (UPI)--Missouri, unimpressed by tales of Minnesota football muscle, tied the 1962 Rose Bowl champions, 0-0, in an intersectional game today before 60,133.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 29-- President Kwame Nkrumah addressed graduating cadets at the Ghana Military Academy in Accra today, dispelling rumors that circulated in Europe yesterday that he had been assassinated.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29 --A quarterback, Mike Bassett, a highly versatile passer and runner, turned a fumbling Harvard team into a smooth-functioning machine midway in the second quarter today and the Crimson went on to defeat Lehigh, 27--7, in its season opener at Harvard Stadium.

Gerald Patton. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Clement McCune Brown of Colorado Springs and the late Mr. Brown.

WITH the publication of "The Kindly Ones," Anthony Powell's long novel, "The Music of Time," reaches its halfway mark. Insofar as this is a chronicle (and it is partly that), we come in this volume to the end of the uneasy decades between the wars.
ATHENS, Sept 23--Opposition parties in Greece have renewed their fight to force new elections.

In a gamble that paying customers will like what they see, the managers of Broadway's Criterion Theater have decided to charge $4.80 for a look--a record ceiling for regular weekend performances of a motion picture.

Millions of Soviet families suffered an unpleasant economic blow last week when the Moscow Government announced that the income tax reduction program begun in 1960 has been suspended. The practical meaning of this news is that more than 10,000,000 Soviet workers, who had expected increased take-home pay beginning next month, will have to make do with the same wages they have been getting.

THE little woman who started the great big pesticide war --Rachel Carson--has returned to the project she abandoned four and a half years ago in order to write "Silent Spring." It is a "little book" exploring nature for children, she says, and after a moment's thought adds, "and is a more peaceful subject."

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 29 --Charles Vanden Bulck, who was director of administration and special disbursing officer of the Manhattan Project, died today at Stamford Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 83 Morgan Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29-- The marriage of Miss Joan A. Wiegmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Wiegmann of Meadowbrook, to Charles E. Lane 3d took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Edgar Lane of Garden City, L.I.

AS manufacturers learn to make high fidelity equipment that reproduces sound with ever greater accuracy, so are they finding ways to make their products more unobtrusive and more compatible as home furnishings. This is one of the major themes of the seventh annual New York High Fidelity Music Show, which opens at the New York Trade Show Building on Wednesday afternoon and closes Saturday night.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 29--Mr. and Mrs. L. Emery Katzenbach 2d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Varick Katzenbach, to Nicholas Niles Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Niles of Mendham, N.J.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Sept 29--The United Nations, facing its first political test here, decided today that diplomacy was more important than a flag.

"A mixed bag ... On a high plateau ... Satisfactory but lacking zip." These were among the descriptions being made of the nation's economy as the important fourth quarter began. HISTORIANS of early America have lavished attention on two topics: the founding of the colonies in the seventeenth century and their revolt from England in the eighteenth. Few have probed the ideological connections between the two, in spite of the fact that the men who carried out the revolt constantly likened their own motives to those of their seventeenth-century forebears.

The home with a family signature is staging a revival in America. Gone is the too-perfect, over-coordinated, "decorated" look of pretentious anonymity. In its place is an individualism that reflects family interests and activities, with comfort and convenience valued above effect.

Columbia beat Brown, 22--20, at Baker Field yesterday as the Bruins just missed tying the score in the last eighteen seconds. The Yale Art Gallery has bought its first Rubens, "Hero and Leander," a work done by the painter when he was 28 years old. It is a smaller version of one in the Dresden Museum in East Germany.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30--Premier Khrushchev declared today that the grain situation in the Soviet Union this autumn would be better than it was last year. It was his first public statement on crop prospects since the harvest began.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30--Albert A. Young Jr. of the Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club sailed his International Class sloop, Wisp, to a 25-second victory over Whiff, skippered by James Manny of the Larchmont Yacht Club, in the 37th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta on Long Island Sound today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Sept. 30 --Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver of Georgia took vigorous exception today to the course followed by Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi in defying Federal Court orders to admit a Negro student to the state university.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)--Sen. Hubert H. Humphery, Democrat of Minnesota, accused the Republican National Committee today of engaging in a "deliberate and reckless attempt to turn farmers against consumers and city dwellers against rural America."

Edmond Basson, cellist, was heard last night at Carnegie Recital Hall in his debut recital, which showed that he is a man with interesting musical ideas but not quite enough technique to express them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Theodore C. Sorensen, the poet laureate of the New Frontier, picked this weekend, of all times, to be in the Bethesda Naval Hospital with an ulcer.

The British Government, in briefs submitted to the United States Supreme Court, has described attempts by the National Labor Relations Board to assume jurisdiction over foreign seamen on foreign-flag ships as "inimical to international trade."

CHICAGO, Sept. 30--It mattered not that the New York Mets won or lost, or even how they played the game today before 3,960 fans at Wrigley Field. For the record, though, the season's final, for which Casey Stengel asked and obtained volunteers, went to the Cubs, 5--1.
PARIS, Sept. 28--A string of ships will be placed across the Atlantic Ocean between Brazil and the Gulf of Guinea in an international survey of the ocean next year.
The Atlas Credit Corporation, a leading publicly owned finance company specializing in the home and building improvement field, has acquired the Colonial Mortgage Service Company.
Ten youths were injured last night in a gang fight in Queens that the police believe arose from a mistake in identity.

TWO of the New York pairs eligible for the next United States international team had a practice game Friday night--John R. Crawford and Tobias Stone against Philip Feldesman and Ira Rubin (who lives in Fair Lawn, N.J., but whose home club is the Cavendish Club in New York).

A record crowd of 84,009, the 24th gathering in a row to top 80,000 at the Buckeyes' home games, saw Ohio State roll in all its majesty in opening its football season with a 41-7 victory over North Carolina Saturday.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 30 (AP)--The American Can Company and the Continental Can Company signed new labor contracts today with the United Steelworkers of America providing improvements in benefits but no wage increase and no reopener over a two-year period.

A GOOD rule for chess play is this: Adopt the defense you know more about than your opponent does. Then as Black, you can reduce White's opening initiative to almost nil. For Black can choose the defense he has mastered with liberal doses of midnight oil.

Five years ago last week paratroopers with fixed bayonets escorted nine Negro pupils into Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., under Presidential orders deriving from the principle that the Federal Government has the "power to compel obedience to its laws."
CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP) --Mel McGaha, the rookie manager of Cleveland's sixth-place Indians, was dismissed today. He thus became the second American League manager in three days to lose his job.

A 17-year-old Liberty ship, converted into what American electronics engineers describe as the most advanced spacetracking ship in operation anywhere in the free world, plowed through Pacific waters yesterday to take up a position some 1,800 miles west-northwest of Honolulu.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 30-- Some American movie producers are demanding that actresses, as a condition of employment, appear before the camera in the nude.

Tax-sheltered pensions are tantalizingly close for the self-employed, after years of pursuit. A measure to provide these pensions was overwhelmingly approved by Congress last week and sent to the President for his signature. However, some of the bill's supporters are almost hoping that the President will veto it.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30-- Unable to check one of the most amazing crackups by a front runner in major league history, the Dodgers today plunged the National League pennant race into its fourth playoff series in 17 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)--Washington's fine passing combination of Norman Snead and Bobby Mitchell today paced the Redskins to a 24-14 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in a National Football League upset.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30-- The number of workers living in Nassau County increased by 81.5 per cent between 1950 and 1960, the County Planning Commission reported today.
LONDON, Sept. 30--The London stock market moved in two directions last week. Industrial shares experienced their sharpest decline in two months while Government securities continued to rise.

Leon Wormser, a renowned shirt-cutter who was a cofounder of A. Sulka Co., the celebrated tie and shirt emporium at 405 Park Avenue, died in Paris yesterday, according to word from his daughter, Mrs. Philippe Strich of Cincinnati. He would have been 90 years old on Oct. 19.

HARTFORD, Sept. 30 (UPI)--The Hartford Courant said today Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi raised such a disturbance because a Negro was eating in a restaurant with him 12 years ago that policemen marched him off to the station house.
John Henry Faulk, the radio and television entertainer who was kept off the air from 1957 until last June, when he won a $3,500,000 libel suit, has been signed to make his movie debut.

THE PHAKAVALI, a small company of dancers from Thailand, gave two performances at Hunter College Playhouse on Saturday under the auspices of the Asia Society Performing Arts Program. The eight dancers--six women and two men--were accompanied by four male players of exotic instruments.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (UPI)-- The San Francisco Giants whooped it up today for a putout they didn't even see. They let out a roar and started pounding one another on the backs when an an nouncer's voice on the radio said, "Jim Gilliam has popped up to Julian Javier and the ball game is over."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--President Kennedy appealed to the students and the people of Mississippi tonight to comply peacefully with Federal law and bring the desegregation crisis to an end. "The eyes of the nation and all the world are upon you and upon all of us," he said, "and the honor of your university and state are in the balance."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Congress moves into one of the busiest weeks of its session tomorrow, with leaders pressing for adjournment by Saturday night.
World business and industry have committed $l,000,000 to support an international management congress here Sept. 16 through Sept. 20, 1963.
OXFORD, Miss., Monday, Oct. 1--James H. Meredith, a 29year-old Negro, was admitted last night to the University of Mississippi campus and was scheduled to enroll today in the all-white institution.

PARIS, Sept. 30--Despite improvement on many fronts, there are signs that one important aspect of the United States balance of payments may get worse before it gets better. This is the flow of long-term capital.

"Spiritual power" transforms life and "the way of the early church is still the most effective to win men--by the personal testimony of one man to another," the Rev. Dr. Ralph Beryl Nesbitt said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.-- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor takes over responsibility as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff tomorrow in an unusual military comeback.

More than 500 government official, lawyers and judges gathered in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning to hear the 34th Red Mass, offered annually for the opening of the fall term of the state and city courts.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 30--Smith College is lending its prestige to a campaign to stimulate interest in the legitimate theater and make its town a favorite stop once again for touring Broadway shows.
MANILA, Sept. 30--Philippine claims to the British Crown Colony of North Borneo have threatened the stability of various anti-Communist alliances in Southeast Asia.
Longshoremen struck in all ports from Maine to Texas at 12:01 this morning as their three-year contract expired.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30--The Dodgers wore faces like thunderclouds today when they filed off the field into their dressing quarters after losing to the Cardinals.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30-- New orders for steel moved upward last week.
At least 10 of the nation's better known symphony orchestras are in a precarious position, and even the more secure orchestras are, without exception, in need of financial assistance.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30-- The New York Times began printing here tonight a Western edition for readers in thirteen Western states, including Alaska and Hawaii.

A Trans World Airlines' Boeing-707 jet will take off this morning for London on the first commercial trans-Atlantic flight navigated entirely by electronics. Doppler radar equipment operated by the pilot will replace the navigator.

Governor Barnett has chosen the course of honor and of wisdom in ending his rebellion against the constituted authority of the Federal Government. He would have condemned himself and the State of Mississippi to universal obloquy if he had pressed his defiance of Federal law to an extreme that compelled the exercise of military force.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 30-- Gov. Ross R. Barnett, declaring that his state had been "physically overpowered" by the Federal Government, gave up his fight tonight to keep a Negro out of the University of Mississippi.

CAIRO, Sept. 30--Mohsen el-Ainy, Foreign Minister of the new republic of Yemen, asserted here today that his Government was "firmly established." He appealed for international recognition and material help.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 30-- More than 2,000 Mississippians, shouting segregation slogans and waving Confederate banners, ringed the Governor's Executive Mansion this afternoon in downtown Jackson.
The Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company has shifted some $3,500,000 in billings from Lambert Feasley, Inc., to Lennen Newell, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 30-- Following are the votes of Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls during the week ended yesterday. There were no major roll-calls in the House of Representatives.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30--There were four score trophy winners at the Westbury Kennel Association's fixture today. But there wasn't a best in show. For the second year in a row Westbury decided to go along with the bred judging only:

The Amsterdam Stock Exchange ranks as the world's oldest securities market. An Interesting reminder of that comes every five years when the New York stock Exchange, a mere 170 years old, collects interest on what may be one of the oldest bonds in the world still paying interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--Tomorrow we celebrate the 54th birthday of the machine that moved the world. It was a tough, plain, black, oblong box mounted on wheels and it cost $850. Henry Ford cabled it the Model T.

LAST week while conducting a personal sociological survey I asked a friend of mine, aged 56, if he knew much about American women, upper-middle-class, welleducated variety. "Of course I do," he said. "I can't remember a time when I didn't know some prime examples of that group. When I was quite young I knew my mother. When...

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30-- California authorities will begin tomorrow a statewide effort to stamp out a dancingstudio racket. Stanley Mosk, the state's Attorney General, says it has probably reaped "many millions of dollars" from gullible persons throughout the country.

"My Fair Lady," the grande dame of the American musical theater, removed her make-up Saturday night for the last time. She graciously retired from Broadway after a fourhour party early yesterday morning.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30--Maury Wills can now discard his asterisks, presuming that the San Francisco Giants are not so unspeakably gauche as to knock off the Dodgers in their pennant play-off. This one time he can zing past Ty Cobb without either difficulty or question.
Union teamsters were set last night to strike today to force some over-the-road trucking companies to sign a new twoyear contract calling for a 37cent-an-hour package wage increase.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The statutes invoked by President Kennedy as authority for his military action in Mississippi date back to May 2, 1792.

President Kennedy's appearance on television and radio at 10 o'clock last night was the highlight of a hectic day for the broadcasting networks. Earlier they had turned down a bid by Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi for equal time.

The first commercial production from the Provincia field, a Colombian oil field now being developed, hsa started moving to market. The oil is being transported through a 33-mile pipe line which links the new field at Yariri with the National Andean pipeline running to the port of Cartagena, on the Caribbean.
James H. Meredith's attempt to enroll at the University of Mississippi spans 16 months of legal maneuvering in the Federal courts.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 30--Eleven hundred more soldiers were on their way here from Fort Benning, Ga., tonight, as the massive build-up of United States troops continued.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., Sept. 30 --A silent prayer suggested for use in the public schools was distributed to children and high school and college students at Trinity Lutheran Church here today.
WITH an uncomplicated formula based on old fashioned slapstick, the new comedy series "I'm Dickens . . . He's Fenster" could be a surprise success of the television season.
A new book publishing division--one that will see museum curators and literary editors teaming to produce books-- was announced yesterday by Doubleday Co., Inc.

The big New York City commercial banks, which supply a large portion of the commercial and industrial loans used by the national economy, are puzzled by apparently contradictory trends in their loans and deposits.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30 --Dr. George Drayton Strayer, teacher and educational consultant, died of a heart attack last night in his room at the Nassau Club. His age was 85. He was a former resident of Riverdale, the Bronx.
Good evening, my fellow citizens: The orders of the court in the case of Meredith v. Fair are beginning to be carried out.
The roots of racial strife in Mississippi may be found in the state's lingering tradition of white supremacy. But besides its troubles over segregation the state is hampered by a depressed economy.
ABBEVILLE, Miss., Sept. 30 --Army troops hurriedly erected a tent city near here today in the Holly Springs National Forest to house "several hundred" deputy United States marshals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- One of the most important midterm election campaigns in years is entering its last five weeks, with Cuba and the domestic policies of the Kennedy Administration emerging as the major national issues.
OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 30-- A white stucco courthouse three stories high, with a margin of grass and trees around it, occupies an island in the middle of the shopping center here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Premier Khrushchev has sent a private invitation to President Kennedy to visit the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened its own staff investigation of the mutual fund industry.
HONG KONG, Sept. 30--Premier Chou En-lai declared in Peking tonight that no one could force Communist China to change the "just stand it takes in international affairs."
The program of the People-toPeople sports Committee will be advanced on Oct.16 with the proceeds of the sixth annual Dinner of Champions in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 30 --Mortimer Hays, a leading trial lawyer, died today of a heart attack in Norwalk Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived on James Street.
Zoning laws that are more concerned with their impact on taxation than with proper use of the land were attacked yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.
The second major phase of a spreading state inquiry into fraud and other irregularities in road construction and other public works will begin today.
At least 600 Protestant children are in need of permanent foster homes here, a new study by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies reported yesterday.
Members of both factions of Broadway Presbyterian Church worshiped together yesterday morning in an hour-long truce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30-- Shortly before Robert Francis Kennedy became Attorney General, when the prospect of his taking office appalled many liberals, a lawyer known as a fighter for civil rights predicted that they might be surprised.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 1--The University of Mississippi campus was under military occupation today as James H. Meredith, its first Negro student, registered and attended two classes.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1--The Communist regime in China celebrated today its thirteen years in power in a show of optimism that did not obscure the economic difficulties confronting the country.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 1-- James H. Meredith, a Negro, enrolled in the University of Mississippi today and began classes as Federal troops, and federalized units of the Mississippi National Guard quelled a 15-hour riot.
Belmont Park again became a mise en scene for thoroughbred racing as the autumn season of 24-racing days opened there yesterday.
The medical profession is "doing little" about the quality of medical care in the metropolitan area, the state was told yesterday in an experts' report.
BUFFALO, Oct. 1--Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley charged in a press conference today that Governor Rockefeller's record on civil rights and desegregation was "very poor."

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP)--A chemical reaction once believed impossible has been achieved at nearby Argonne National Laboratory and has opened up a new area for the study of un- known compounds and chemical bonding.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1-- Well, sir, it was so quiet in the Dodgers' dressing room that you could have heard an expletive drop.

W. R. Grace Co. announced yesterday that its Dewey Almy chemical division had contracted to purchase the A. C. Horn building materials division of the Sun Chemical Corporation.

YONKERS, Oct. 1--Like lemmings marching inexorably into the sea, bettors of all denominations($2, $10 and $50) poured back into Yonkers Raceway tonight for the opening of the final harness racing meeting of the metropolitan season.

Supplying fuel to big jet aircraft is a problem in logistics of staggering proportions. O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, regarded as the busiest jet terminal in the world, is tackling the challenge with an intricate underground hydrant fueling system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- Washington is sad about the mess at Ole Miss, yet, paradoxically, President Kennedy's handling of the crisis has impressed the capital.

LUCILLE BALL is back in her first weekly series since "I Love Lucy," and she is as remarkable a gal as ever. Put her in the wildest half-hour of improbability, the sort of far-fetched doings that so regularly trip up may TV notables, and she makes it all seem not only quite likely but diverting fun in the bargain.
LOS ANGELES, OCt. 1--The best Brooklyn boy the Dodgers ever had--Tommy Davis--hopes to return to New York to show his stuff next Sunday in Yankee Stadium.
ADEN. Oct. 1--The Yemeni Government announced today over its radio that it intended to close its embassy in Saudi Arabia as a protest against hostile propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The foreign ministers of the member nations of the Organization of American States will open an informal conference on the Cuban situation here tomorrow.

Record third-quarter sales and earnings of the Hooker Chemical Corporation lifted results for the nine months ended Aug. 31 well above those of the prior year's period, the report disclosed yesterday.

A 19-year-old youth died yesterday in City Hospital at Elmhurst, Queens, as the result of a street fight Sunday night between two gangs in Long Island City, Queens. Three other youths were reported in fair condition in the same hospital.
Dorothy Lane, harpsichordist, and Harriet Le Jeune, flutist and recorder player, will be heard in Carnegie Recital Hall at 8:30 tonight.
Bond prices moved up in quiet steady trading yesterday.

Mrs. Frederick R. Moseley Jr. of Jericho, L.I., and James Knott of Old Westbury, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Kent Knott, to William Perry Welch. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. G. Harold Welch of Mount Carmel, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The Senate decided for the Administration today in preliminary votes on the foreign aid appropriation bill, due for passage tomorrow.
