NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1--Eighty per cent of Rutgers University's $50,000,000 building program either has been completed or is in the construction stage.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Oct. 1-- Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi was finding scant sympathy among his colleagues of the Southern Governors' Conference for his fight against and final capitulation to the supremacy of the Federal Government.

Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey yesterday dismissed a suit by minority stockholders of the Mahoning Coal Railroad Company involving "pooled Federal Income tax returns" made since 1958 by the New York Central.
"THE MADISON AVENUE COOK BOOK" by Alan Koehler (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, $2.95) is a delightful spoof, putting into proper perspective both cooking and advertising.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP)--The auto manufacturers started today on what promises to be their biggest October production total in history. The goal is at least 700,000 cars.
WASHINGTON, Oct.1--Two former stewardesses testified today that pilots had allowed them to fly airlines filled with passengers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1--A funny thing happened to the Dodgers on their way to the opening game of the World Series in Los Angeles. All of a sudden they found themselves in San Francisco. They still don't know how they got here or why. Just as they reached for the pennant, they were gripped by a dizzy spell and everything went blank. When they came to, they were in the Cave of the Winds.
ALGIERS, Oct. 1--Economic necessity is pushing Algeria toward continued dependence on France, despite the antipathy of revolutionaries for such dependence.
VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. 1--In the fourth-round match of the finals of the Chess Olympics here last night the United States won on the top board against Austria but lost on the second and third boards.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 1--President Francois Duvalier vowed today that Haiti would continue her development program by herself in the face of the reduction of United States aid.

Land on Baldwin Road in Parsippany-Troy Hills, N.J., has been bought by Baldwin Marior, Inc., from Frances W. Baldwin. It will be improved with seven buildings containing 240 apartments. The Camarota Gould Agency of East Orange has been appointed renting agents for the apartments,
Ludwig Bemelmana, satirist, humorist and artist, died yesterday of cancer of the pancreas at his studio apartment in the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South. He was 64 years old.

President Kennedy told Agence France Presse yesterday that he wanted to "express the dismay of the American people" over the death of Paul L. Guihard, the French news agency's reporter, who was killed Sunday night during the rioting on the campus of the University of Mississippi.

A mother and two children were rescued from the Upper Bay last night after she had thrown them and herself from the stern of a Staten Island ferryboat as it entered a slip at South Ferry. A third child was still missing and believed to have been drowned.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1-- The San Francisco Giants, who only 24 hours earlier had come whirling out of nowhere to toss the National League pennant race into a deadlock, were still rolling today.

The long-held expansion plans of the Museum of Modern Art will become a reality next month with the breaking of ground. About $18,000,000 has been raised by the museum to build and to endow expanded activities.

BONN, Oct. 1--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany sharply criticized the West German Government today for its failure to pass supplementary legislation to indemnify "hundreds of thousands" of Jewish victims of Nazism.

A TELEVISION set the size of a telephone was introduced yesterday by the Sony Corporation of America. The eight-pound TV has a five-inch picture tube that makes it, according to Sony, "the world's smallest and lightest all-transistorized television set."

A 57-family apartment building at 941-45 Leggett Avenue the Bronx, has been sold after an ownership of 23 years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The House bypassed its Rules Committee today and sent to conference instead the legislation to increase postal rates and increase government pay.

The disruption that was inevitable with the departure of the Dutch from West New Guinea has occurred. As the United Nations and the Indonesians take over, public utilities and communications are in disorder; schools have closed; administration has disappeared in many areas; some of the Papuans brought under the control of the former Dutch Government are returning to the primitive, tribal ways they previously followed.
The New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Boxing will hold a public hearing today on the alleged underworld affiliations of Sonny Liston, the world heavyweight champion.

HOLLANDIA, New Guines, Oct. 1--The Indonesian Government dramatically established its political presence in west New Guinea today less than seven hours after the Netherlands turned over control to the United Nations.

Proceedings against four brokerage firms and an employe of a fifth have been dropped by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In making the announcement yesterday the S. E. C. said it was making the move "without prejudice to the subsequent institution of new proceedings based on the same or other charges."
Futures trading on the New York commodity exchanges were slow and almost uneventful yesterday.

The Alliance for Progress will be the main subject of discussion at this week's meeting of economic experts brought together by the Organization of American States in Mexico City. Unfortunately, the Alliance can report relatively little progress, and in the all-important area of private investment there has been a retreat. South America has been experiencing a net outflow of capital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- United States propaganda agencies dealt frankly with the Mississippi desegregation crisis today, treating it as the most important story of the day and acknowledging the violence in Oxford.

Senator Jacob K. Javits declared Yesterday that President Kennedy should address the country on the gravity of the Cuban situation and also ask for an emergency meeting of the Organization of American States.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 1-- The 5.5-meter yacht Pride retained the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup for the United States today. Pride defeated Bibis II, the Canadian challenger, for the third straight time on Long Island Sound.
COLUMBUS, Ohio. Oct. 1 (AP)--Col. Arthur W. Copp, who formerly commanded New Jersey's 57th Infantry Brigade, died yesterday in Mt. Carmel Hospital.

ALBANY, Oct. 1--L. Judson Morhouse, the Republican state chairman, announced this afternoon that a Republican challenge to the validity of the Conservative party's petitions was being dropped.
Bank of America, the largest commercial bank in the world, is taking steps to increase its worldwide business.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (UPI)-- A Federal Judge today barred a trainmen's strike against the 13,000-mile Atchison. Topeka Santa Fe Railway for at least 20 days.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 1--Maximilian Schell assailed today photographers and reporters who invade the privacy of actors or other public figures. The Oscar-winning star declared that the laws of Europe and the United States were not adequate to preserve even a minimum of privacy.
The lessons that Little Rock taught must be learned again in Mississippi, Mrs. Daisy Bates said here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Ames Robbins of 655 Park Avenue and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Ames Robbins, to Richard Snowden Fahnestock, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bertron Fahnestock of Southport, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1-- President Kennedy took the first step today toward getting an injunction to end the Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshoremen's strike for 80 days.
DALLAS, Oct. 1--Apathy in the liberal wing of the longdominant Democratic party and a growing defection of ultraconservatives may give Texas its first Republican Governor since Reconstruction days.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1--The Soviet Union has decided to pursue its program of rapprochement with Yugoslavia even at the risk of a further deterioration in relations with Communist China.
Sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area rose last month by 7 per cent from the 1961 level, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

A careless reader might suppose that "the Anti-Digit Dialing League" of San Francisco was a group of persons who hated digits but loved to dial. This is not precisely the case. The fight these embattled Westerners are carrying on is against the telephone company's plans to get rid of the names that have been attached to exchanges. WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The Treasury sold its weekly issue of 91-day bills today at almost exactly the same discounts as last week's issue. Today's and last Monday's rates are the lowest since late June.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Machinists struck the Aerojet-General Corporation rocket plants in Sacramento and Azusa today. Union members began walking out of the plants at 12:45 P. M. after negotiations failed. About 8,000 workers are on strike.

The $2,000,000 Pioneer Memorial Theater on the campus of the University of Utah in Salt Lake City will be dedicated Wednesday by David O. McKay, President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 2--Governor Rockefeller, carrying his campaign for re-election into the Finger Lakes region today, accused his Democratic opponent. Robert M. Morgenthau, of making false statements on wages and unemployment.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 2--President Kwame Nkrumah declared today that's recent attempt to assassinate him was linked to enemies of Ghana.

A contract for the sale of all the assets of the United Carbon Company, a leading producer of carbon black, to the Ashland Oil and Refining Company, principally an independent petroleum refining organization, has been approved by the directors of each company, according to a joint announcement made yesterday.
One of the biggest--but safest --"fires" in town yesterday was on Welfare Island in the East River.

Frank Lovejoy, the stage, screen and television actor who two years ago made the role of a bigoted candidate in "The Best Man" one of the Broadway season's notable performances, was found dead in bed yesterday morning at the Warwick Hotel.
Governor Rockefeller paid tribute last night to the leaders of the Museum of Modern Art. He said the museum, at 11 West 53d Street, was "the product of devotion and sensitivity of many people."

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 2--Former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, a key figure in weekend rioting over admission of a Negro to the University of Mississippi, was ordered placed under psychiatric examination in a Federal prison today.
Modest advances in cocoa, cottonseed oil and world sugar futures highlighted a quiet day on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday.
The New York Yankees, rested but in the dark regarding their opponents in the World Series, changed their travel plans yesterday and headed for San Francisco instead of Los Angeles.

A maritime industry arbitrator has ordered a steamship company that sold its fourteen vessels to see to it that marine engineers employed in the past on the ships are continued in their jobs under the new owners.
Shares of International Business Machines Corporation, Polaroid Corporation and Xerox Corporation have become instant indicators of the stock market.
BONN, Oct. 2-A group of leading German scientists rejected today as utopian any thought that the population of Central Europe could be "thoroughly protected" against nuclear attack.
For ten minutes yesterday morning one could have heard a check drop in the board rooms -of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
Los ANGELES Oct. 2-The almost defunct Los Angeles Dodgers came to life with shrill war whoops of joy after their marathon conquest of the San Francisco Giants today.
A city wide reading test given to more than 71,000 sixthgrade pupils in public schools in 1961 showed a slight improvement over the previous year despite many "negative factors."

The Securities and Exchange Commission sought yesterday to bar a life insurance company from selling a contract the commission considers to be a security. The company contends it is an insurance policy.
DENVER, Oct. 2 (AP)-Lieut. Gen. Henry L. Larsen, a muchdecorated retired Marine Corps officer, died of a heart attack at his home today. He was 71 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2--Ethiopia urged U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, today to take "swift, decisive and swift enforcement action" to settle the Congo question.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2--The railroads set the stage today for a united effort to seize the initiative in labor negotiations.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Oct. 2-- Most Southern Governors concede regretfully that this week's tragic events in Mississippi do not mark a significant milepost, a turning point, in the bitter conflict between the old Confederacy and the Federal Government on the place of the Negro in contemporary society.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York had net operating earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30 of S37,172,216, or $4.93 a share.

ATHENS, Oct. 2--The United States is experiencing in Mississippi what is tantamount to its own form of decolonialization. For our colonialism, sociologically speaking, has been within the U.S.A. and not abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The United States appealed to the Soviet Union today not to conduct a nuclear test that might interfere with the launching of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr., which is scheduled for tomorrow morning.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2--Israel and the Arab States have received a new plan for resolving the thorny problem of the Palestinian Arab refugees.
LONDON, Oct. 2-Britain's gold and convertible currency reserves fell 20,000,000 ($56,000,000) last month, the Treasury announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2--The United States will press for prompt discussion of a nuclear test ban treaty and disarmament in the General Assembly.
Columbia Pictures has concluded an important agreement to have its foreign language and "art theater" films distributed exclusively by a new company heeded by Richard Davis.
The twenty-five New York City Republican candidates for the State Senate promised yesterday that if elected they would oppose any state tax increase for two years.
Bond prices held firm in moderate trading yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The Senate sent to President Kennedy today a tax revision bill containing the key feature he had asked--a $1,000,000,000 plant-modernization incentive to business.
A total of 1,138 persons were hurt in car accidents here last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. The figure was 112 more than in the comparable 1961 period.

Governor Rockefeller termed the Mississippi situation "deplorable" in a statement made from his office here yesterday. He said it was "sad" that the 100th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation should be marked by the riots there and the burning of churches in Georgia.
Stocks staged a brisk recovery yesterday, erasing most of Monday's losses. Attention continued to center on the wideswinging "glamour," special situation and electronic issues.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 2 -Albert Delmont Smith, a portrait painter and former director of the Heckscher Art Museum here, died today in his home at Lloyd Harbor. His age was 76.
LODI, Calif., Oct. 2--Premier Nikita Khrushchev's personal adviser on agriculture crossexamined California specialty crop growers today.

ROME, Oct. 2-Pope John XXIII, who will be 81 years old next month, will go Thursday on the longest journey any Pope has made in almost a century. He will visit the Marian shrine of Loreto and the Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
LONDON, Oct. 2--Store shares were strong on the stock market today. Leading stores rose as much as 1s6d (21 cents) on the announcement of a large increase in retail trade in August.
The Natco Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based producer of clay building materials, yesterday served notice it would fight attempts by a dissident group to win control of the company.
PARIS, Oct. 2--The foundations of an economic battle between the Government and France's labor unions were laid today by Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing.
James B. Donovan left for Havana yesterday to complete arrangements for the release of 1,179 Cubans captured in the unsuccessful invasion of Cuba in April, 1961.
James B. Donovan left for Havana yesterday to complete arrangements for the release of 1,179 Cubans captured in the unsuccessful invasion of Cuba in April, 1961.
Paul Guihard, reporter for Agence France Press who was killed in rioting at the University of Mississippi Sunday night, said in his last article that "the Civil War has never ended."

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 2-- Mississippi's Lieutenant-Governor declared today that he could not forsee any time when James H. Meredith, a Negro junior, could attend the state university without Federal guards.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 2-- Edward R. Dudley, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, completed his first upstate campaign tour here tonight. He said he was pleased with the reaction to him.
Drivers use city parkways more because of their beauty than because of their utility as highways, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris said yesterday.

AFTER enough advance publicity to kill a weaker show, the Guggenheim Museum's exhibition "Modern Sculpture from the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Collection" opens today. It is still alive, and not even tired, although it is a quieter show than one somehow expected.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 3 (UPI)--Attorneys for former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker asked the Senate Judiciary Committee today to investigate the former general's "political" confinement and orders for psychiatric examination at the United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners.
WALTER MARTY SCHIRRA JR., the latest United States astronaut to orbit the earth, is a gay and smiling sportsman.
The volume of oceangoing vessel traffic in and out of the Port of New York is continuing its decline.
Astronaut Walter Schirra yesterday became the first American to orbit more than three times around the earth.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3--Harvard and Princeton universities will apply for student loan funds on the elimination of the non-Communist disclaimer required of students, their presidents said today.
A PROMINENT non-Ivy League football coach has been credited with the facetious remark that a good team ought to have a university of which it could be proud.
The Museum of Modern Art is developing plans for a television festival that would be presented in its auditorium beginning early in 1963.

A fact-finding board, appointed under the Taft-Hartley Act to investigate the labor dispute that has paralyzed shipping in ports from Maine to Texas, sent its report to Washington at 2:30 P.M. yesterday.

The directors of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc. voted a stock dividend yesterday of 10 per cent on the common shares, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 37 cents a share. They are payable Nov. 14 to holders of record Oct. 15.
8:16 A.M. Eastern daylight time--This is Mercury Control. Astronaut Walter Schirra reports all systems are go. Fuel supply is O.K. His oxygen O.K. We observe the trajectory here as being on track.
BERLIN, Oct. 3--The East and West Berlin police exchanged tear-gas grenades and East German guards destroyed a tunnel dug to help East Berliners escape to the West today at Berlin's intracity border.

IT isn't everywhere that a woman can buy a fur coat in the shade of an apple tree. But in the heart of the wholesale fur district Leo Ritter has a flourishing garden on a terrace adjoining his salon. A customer is likely to be ushered outdoors to admire Mr. Ritter's borticultural skills along with his fur-designing talent.
MIAMI, Oct. 3 (UPI)--The tropical storm Daisy began building up to hurricane strength today and aimed its 70-mile-anhour winds toward the United States mainland.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) --Commercial exports from the United States dropped 4 percent in August to $1,651,600,000, the Census Bureau said today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 3--Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, has linked the crime of speculation in gold to the influence of the Moslem religion.
The satellite journey of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. gives the Project Mercury team a record of five successes in six attempts to orbit its space capsules.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3--Malaya accused Communist China today of genocide and the denial of fundamental human rights in Tibet.
Battle Joined showed himself to be fast and fit in taking the $57,300 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday.
LLANTWIT MAJOR, Wales, Sept. 28--An experiment in international education is beginning near here in a centrally heated castle overlooking the rugged south coast of Wales.
Wall Street has become increasingly blast about United States space shots.

The Americana Hotel gave a boxing luncheon yesterday for Emile Griffith and Don Fullmer, but despite breast of chicken marengo, pommes parisienne rissole and candlelight, the menu seemed incomplete. Somebody forgot the buttered encomiums.

The oldest locomotive in active service--"The General," of Civil War fame--has drawn up beside the world's newest locomotive at La Grange, Ill., for ceremonies there today marking a production milestone in the diesel locomotive industry.

That close watcher of economic trends, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, reports that "there is no evidence of significant weakness developing in the economy." By itself the statement would be good news because so many observers have been stressing potential weaknesses.
Bill Winter is likely to be back at the left linebacker spot for the New York Giants on Sunday when they meet the Cardinals in St. Louis. The return would be just in time.

The major domestic airlines have voted to extend their apparently successful "no-show" penalty plan with one modification trough Jan. 31, the Air Transport Association reported in Washington yesterday.
The Board of Estimate acted yesterday to expedite the purchase of 1,024 new subway cars by the Transit Authority.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., made a substantial improvement in earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30 over the previous year, despite write-offs of nearly $5,000,000 for currency depreciation. Sales soared to a record $502,422,195 from the $471,597,283 volume the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3--A woe-stricken band of Los Angeles Dodgers filed into their dressing room, muttering soft oaths and biting their lips.

Plans are nearing completion for the Nov. 1 theater party at "Mr. President" for the benefit of the Salvation Army Women's Auxiliary. The new Irving Berlin musical is scheduled to open at the St. James Theater on Oct. 20.
THERE are two new developments in intercol- legiate bridge, which seems to be very active in this part of the country at least.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 3 (Reuters)--Two notes on the smoldering Chinese-Indian border dispute issued here today indicated that India was attempting to force back Chinese Communist troops by cutting off their lines of communication.
Having barely emerged from the Algerian crisis, France is now in the throes of a constitutional crisis that has pitted President de Gaulle against all political parties except the Gaullists.
ONE of the less obvious differences between men and women is their clothes-shopping attitude. Most women enjoy shopping for clothes and are well-informed and educated about what they are buying.
PARIS, Oct. 2--Settlement of the crisis over Andorra has removed the threat of isolation from the rest of the world that hung over that tiny principality.

Robert Moses urged the Soviet Union yesterday not to withdraw from the 1964-65 New York World's Fair and said that the United States did not insist on a reciprocal right to stage a United States exhibit in the Soviet Union in the next few years.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3--Sol Hurok's suite at the Ambassador Hotel was probably the only inhabited area there that did not echo with televised or radio reports today of the final game of the Dodgers-Giants playoff. To Mr. Hurok the playoff was a catastrophe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The case of former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker has focused attention once again on career military officers, and many persons are asking the question: How does a man like Walker rise to two star rank in the Army?

FIELD trial time has come again. Owners of hunt- ing dogs, who have had to be content with fun trials during the summer months, now get down to the more serious part of the sport, with their dogs competing for championships.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3--One of the most dramatic and nerveracking pennant races in years came to an astounding end today when the San Francisco Giants vanquished the Dodgers, 6 to 4, in the third and deciding game of the National League playoff.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 3--University of Mississippi officials went ahead today with plans for a football game Saturday despite continuing unrest over the enrollment of James H. Meredith, a Negro.

HOLLANDIA, New Guinea, Oct. 3--The intricacies of international politics are transplanting professional infantrymen from the plains of the Pakistani Punjab to sweltering coastal villages in West New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3-- Investigators for two Senate committees have been sent to Oxford, Miss., to look into the situation created by the troopenforced admission of a Negro to the formerly all-white University of Mississippi.

Licking County, Ohio, borrowed yesterday $4,316,000 on hospital construction bonds due 1964-83. A group headed by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago was awarded the issue on a bid of 101.64 for a 3 per cent coupon. This set a net interest cost to the borrower of 2.85585 per cent. The bonds were reoffered to the public at prices scaled to yield from 1.70 to 3 per cent.

It was noon. The long accounting room of the New York Telephone Company's office on Broadway near the northern tip of Manhattan, sunny and pleasantly cool, was well filled with women, mostly young, at work.
ARNOLD J. TOYNBEE, the leading modern metaphysician of history, has one fixed idea he illustrates over and over again. It is that no tree, no matter how big, ever reaches the sky.

The Fire and Building Departments and the New York County District Attorney's office began immediate investigations yesterday of the boiler explosion in the New York Telephone Company building in upper Manhattan.

A State Supreme Court justice issued an injunction yesterday afternoon staying the exhibition of the unlicensed film "The Connection," which had opened here several hours earlier at the D.W. Griffith Theater on West 45th Street.
STARTING as a brave attempt to be fantasy with satirical overtones, "Stop the World--I Want to Get Off" ends by being commonplace and repetitious.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3-- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today that the strike at the Aerojet-General corporation's plants in two California cities "demonstrates a callous disregard of the national and public interest."

Deliveries of general merchandise in the city returned to normal yesterday in the wake of the capitulation of 1,400 trucking concerns to contract demands of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

MELINA MERCOURI, the movie acress who through her lusty performance in "Never On Sunday" may have done more to interest Americans in Greece than any woman since Helen of Troy, is in New York this week to prove that she is a high fashion personality, after all.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 3--One set of experiments potentially important to the future of United States manned space flight rode as a passive hitchhiker on Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr.'s capsule today.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 29--Politics and pepper--both hot--spice the autumnal air of the desert lands of the Southwest.
SEATTLE, Oct. 3--A maritime labor relations act patterned on the collective bargaining statute governing the railroads was urged before the American Merchant Marine Conference here today.

TITO SCHIPA was last heard here in 1947 when he gave a song recital in Carnegie Hall. Before that it was in 1941, the tenor's last year at the Metropolitan Opera. (He left to return to Italy for the rest of the war at the request of Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister.)

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 3--President Ramon Villeda Morales said today that he would seek to meet objections to a newly enacted agrarian reform law that have been advanced by the United Fruit Company.
A record total of 35,000, "armchair" acoustical engineers is expected to attend the seventh annual New York High Fidelity Music Show, which opened yesterday at the New York Trade Show building.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 (AP)--Whitey Ford will start for the New York Yankees against the San Francisco Giants in tomorrow's World Series opener.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 3-- Gov. Ross R. Barnett accused the Federal Government tonight of "pushing around" the people of Oxford at bayonet point and subjecting them to search without proper warrants.
A decline of 1,136,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Seven Negro parents who have kept their children out of school to protest their assignment to a junior high school in Astoria, Queens, failed to appear in Queens Family Court yesterday as they had been ordered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) --A Trans World Air Lines flight engineer told a House committee today of napping by pilots, hostesses sitting on their laps and a donkey running at large during a passenger flight.

IN certain quarters there is the opinion that the play- ing style of Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, who has won the right to play his countryman Mikhail Botvinnik for the world title, is too lacking in imagination and too uninspired to make a good fight of it.

THE perfect six-orbit flight of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. was reported from start to finish on radio and television as the networks coped for tire first time with a space flight that lasted almost 10 hours.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3--The ignominious crack-up of the Dodgers reached splintering force today, leaving shattered hopes behind. They had the pennant as good as won weeks ago and let themselves get tied by the Giants. They had the final playoff game as good as won in the final inning. They lost it, 6 to 4.
Edward Goodman, a playwright and producer-director of stage plays and motion pictures, died Tuesday at his home after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 50 Central Park West.
Cotton futures were 70 cents a bale down to 10 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--Collectors of legislative antiques will probably never be eble to display one that became a museum piece so quickly as the 1957 Senate excision from the Federal statutes of a Reconstruction Act for the enforcement of equal rights.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 3--Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. flew six orbits around the earth today, twice as far as the two Americans who had orbited before him.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 3--The commander of the first Regular Army unit to reach the embattled University of Mississippi gave a minute-by-minute account today of the operation in the racial outbreak there and of the events leading up to it.
When the impoverished medical student has completed his internship, he's probably in no position to ask a bank for money to set up his practice.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3--The Administration's attempts to open up the housing market to an increasing number of Americans and its fight against slums and discrimination were cited today by a battery of top-level Federal housing officials.
Ten prominent New York residents announced last night that they had joined in the effort to convert the Breezy Point area of the Rockaways, Queens, into a vast waterfront park.

LONDON, Oct. 3--An international inquiry committee reported today that the rioting and looting in British Guiana last February were brought on largely by resentment stirred up against Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan and by fear of the Communist tendencies of his Government.
The city moved closer yesterday to the transformation of a half-acre of open space in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn into a sitting park.

In their informal meeting held in Washington on Oct. 2 and 3, 1962, the foreign ministers and special representatives of the American republics discussed in a spirit of strong friendship and cooperation the serious problems that face the Western Hemisphere.

An official of the Hospital Association of New York State declared yesterday that savings to its 334 member institutions would be "significant" if more of them could buy an insurance plan that most insurance companies in the state cannot sell and are opposed to having others sell.
Governor Rockefeller proposed yesterday that the state pay up to half the cost of treating more than 10,000 children who suffer from any of eight chronic diseases.
LONDON, Oct. 3--Stock market prices advanced today although the turnover was small. Most of the gains were in pennies, but nearly all the important industrial sections gained.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3--Changing concepts of International aid to less developed countries are graphically apparent in six projects to which the United Nations Special Fund has committed $6,800,000 for the next five years.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 3 --A rooster crowing in the background heralded the opening of a 3 -mile section of the Long Island Expressway in Suffolk County today.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., Oct. 3-- Construction was started today on the first unit in the development of a 375-acre industrial park area in this North Shore township.

Substantial changes in regulations affecting common trusts probably will be proposed by the United States Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, later this year. A common trust is a pool of funds invested for separate participants under a bank's management.

LOUIS GOETTING JR. OF ACCOUNTING FIRM SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Oct. 3--Louis C. Goetting Jr., head of a certified public accounting firm bearing his name at 19 Rector Street, New York, died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 68 years old and lived at 24 Chestnut Ridge Road.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3--The United States said today that the developing nations of the world must not view economic aid as a "permanent crutch."

The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange has taken its second disciplinary action in two weeks. The governors suspended for two years James F. Rafferty, a stock specialist, from regular membership in the exchange.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 3--Following is the text of a statement issued today by the University of Mississippi Chapter of the American Association of University Professors:
ROME, Oct. 3--Pope John XXIII today asked all Catholics to join him in spirit tomorrow when he prays for the success of the Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church.

ALBANY, Oct. 3--The court of Appeals heard arguments today on Hulan E. Jack's appeal from his conviction on charges of conflict of interest and conspiracy to obstruct justice while he was Borough President of Manhattan.

The $200,000 that was given to Dave Beck, former labor leader, by two trucking company officials was an innocent loan that was repaid and was not intended as a gift or bribe, a defense lawyer said yesterday in Federal Court.
SEABROOK, Tex., Oct. 3 (UPI)--Mrs. Walter M. Schirra Jr. emerged calm and composed from her nine-hour vigil today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3--Police Chief Carmen Canastra of North Brunswick was convicted today of criminal contempt of court in connection with charges that he induced a subordinate to destroy a traffic ticket.
PARIS, Oct. 3--Opposition forces proclaimed confidence today in their ability to unseat Premier Georges Pompidou tomorrow in the first round of an all-out fight with President de Gaulle.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 1--The Kennedy Administration has come up with a $100,000,000 low-interest housing program for elderly persons.

A woman passenger was injured yesterday morning when a Staten Island ferryboat rammed into a Coast Guard pier at the Battery during a heavy fog. The thick mists slowed harbor and highway traffic and halted operations at New York International Airport for more than four hours.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3-- James W. Riddleberger, a career diplomat, will be appointed Ambassador to Austria, the White House announced today.
New Yorkers lived up to their reputation for being blase yesterday in their restrained response--as "old space hands"-- to the orbiting and successful recovery of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr.
A Supreme Court trial was interrupted for several hours yesterday morning because the jury foreman fell asleep in the jury box.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation, with a battery of Pacific Coast division mills plotted along the western rim of the United States, indicated yesterday that it would meet the $12-a-ton average price cuts posted by Kaiser Steel Corporation at Fontana, Calif.
The election of Edward H. Heinemann and Homward L. Richardson as vice presidents of the General Dynamics Corporation was announced yesterday by Roger Lewis, president.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 3--The space agency has started keeping permanent radiation-exposure records on the nation's astronauts--the first thoroughgoing subject being Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. during his orbital flight today.
Robert M. Morgenthau accused Governor Rockefeller last night of helping Republican legislative leaders to rig legislative and Congressional district lines.

"The Screens," written by Jean Genet, who has been dubbed "the enfant terrible of French literature," will be done in the off Broadway area next spring. Bernard Frechtman is responsible for the translation. The play will be produced by Aldo Bruzzichelli, who says it will take nearly four hours to run through the 17 scenes.
Unionized investigators for the voted last night to strike next Wednesday, thereby posing the threat of a shutdown of the department's social service operations.

ADEN, Oct. 3--A West German agriculturist who had been at or near Sana all through the successful military rebellion in Yemen came unexpectedly to Aden today and said that Imam Ahmad was still alive although he had been reported slain when tanks shelled his palace.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 3-- About sixty political opponents of the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement, Bolivia's ruling party, were sent to exile in Paraguay today.
The Government securities market moved ahead strongly yesterday, closing at its highs of the day.
HARTFORD, Oct. 3 (AP) --The Wadsworth Atheneum announced today the gifts of three Rembrandt paintings, each from a different donor. The Rembrandts were received last year, but the...

New York's latest musical pastime is--and will be for some time--racking up "firsts" for Philharmonic Hall. Last night was a first for jazz, a first for chamber music played after sunset and a first for a clarinet soloist, His name: Benny Goodman.

WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 3 (UPI)--James H. Meredith believes his native state of Mississippi may some day "blot out its blackened past" and take the lead in "an enlightened phase of race relations and human decency."
Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago said yesterday that the opponents of urban renewal left only the "continuing blight and decay of the city" as an alternative.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3--The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia warned today that any United States attempt to keep an armed conflict over Berlin localized would meet with failure. The paper declared that use of force by the Western powers in the dispute might lead to a world nuclear rocket war.

The Buttenheim Publishing Corporation, publisher of magazines in the heavy construction industry, municipal, appliance and educational fields, has leased a floor in the office building being constructed by the Durst Organization at 757 Third Avenue, northeast corner of 47th Street. The lease involves about 20,000 square feet of space and was negotiated by Joseph Bernstein, broker. The building now is more than 65 per cent rented.

Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Frankovich of London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michele Joel Frankovich, to Gerald John Fitzgerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Fitzgerald of Atherton, Calif.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 3 --Hugh Gaitskell ranged the British Labor party today against union with the rest of Europe on the terms now offered by the Common Market.
The New York State Athletic Commission decided yesterday to recognize Sonny Liston as the heavyweight boxing champion of the world, but added that he must "earn the right" to be licensed in New York.

The Bankers Trust Company reported yesterday an increase in earnings for the first nine months of 1962. The bank reported net operating earnings of $22,819,709, or $2.54 per share for the first three quarters compared to $22,496,835, or $2.51 per share in the corresponding period a year ago.
The Senate has now restored most of the cut in the foreign aid appropriations bill that was inflicted in the House on the President's original request for funds.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Andrew Baxter of 200 East 66th Street and Fairfield, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susan Dent Baxter, to Roy Sarles Durstine Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Durstine of 410 East 57th Street and East Hampton, L.I.

The fiscal year ended June 30 was "another good year" for the Tennessee Valley Authority, A.J. Wagner, chairman, told a press lunoheon here yesterday. Mr. Wagner and other officials commented on T.V.A.'s operations in conjunction with release of the authority's annual report.
Nostalgia billowed through Roseland Dance City Tuesday night as Ted Lewis and his orchestra opened a four-week engagement in the huge ballroom.

"It's painful, bu t at least it's not murderous." This is the comment of one magazine executive about the proposed postal rate increases that have been approved by Senate and House conferees. His reaction to the bill epitomizes that of most magazine and newspaper publishers, direct mail advertisers and other bulk users of the mails.
The chairman of the State Commission for Human Rights asserted yesterday that the agency could and did initiate its own informal investigations into areas of alleged racial diccrimination.
The capitulation of long-distance and local truck operators in the metropolitan area to union demands gives James R. Hoffa another victory in his sweep toward a uniform national trucking agreement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 (UPI)--A screaming mob of 50,000 broke through police lines at International Airport tonight while waiting to welcome home the San Francisco Giants. The surging mass disrupted air traffic and forced the team's plane to land a mile away at a maintenance base.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The United States has decided on drastic unilateral steps to try to prevent American, allied and neutral shipping from carrying Soviet-bloc supplies to Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following pricipal changes for the week ended Sept. 26:
Fairly heavy activity in world sugar pushed the market up to new highs for current contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3-- The Chinese Communists are believed here to have come through the worst of a grave economic crisis with a deep resentment of their Soviet allies and with a grim confidence that they can face a difficult future alone.

THOUGH most of the public knows what a strike- out is, probably very few know what a restrike is. A restrike is a print taken from an etched plate after the legitimate, signed editions have been completed. If the original printings have worn or weakened the plate, the restrike will be inferior in quality.

Stock prices drifted aimlessly in quiet trading yesterday. They closed with slight gains. The six-orbit space flight of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. had virtually no effect on the market, which one observer described as "a very quiet and dull affair."

ABOARD THE U. S. S. KEARSARGE AT SEA, Oct. 3 --Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr., after orbiting the earth six times in his one-ton capsule, returned safely to earth today with pin-point accuracy and was picked up by this 41,000ton aircraft carrier.

The City Commission on Human Rights has found that the president of Temple EmanuEl, one of the largest Jewish houses of worship in the world, has been denied the right to purchase a cooperative apartment on Park Avenue because of his religion.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 3--The three-platoon system that Paul Dietzel introduced at Louisiana State, helped Navy to install a year ago and brought to West Point as Army's new head coach has another convert in Yale.
PROBABLY no other state program of land acquisition for recreationconservation purposes is more aptly titled than New Jersey's "Greenacres" project.
LONDON, Oct. 3--Reginald Maudling, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a series of measures tonight to help stimulate the country's economy.
The disgraceful behavior of tug crews in the docking of the great British liner Queen Mary points up the cynicism of some elements of maritime labor in viewing its responsibilities to the public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The victory of the San Francisco Giants was not merely a sports event but a national event. For a few brief hours, at least, California diverted the attention of 30,000,000. Americans from Mississippi. After Governor Barnett in Jackson, Miss., Willie Mays in Chavez Ravine was a relief.
At least 21 persons were killed and 95 injured yesterday when a steam boiler exploded in a building of the New York Telephone Company at 213th Street and Broadway, Nineteen of the dead were women.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3--The champagne flowed like water tonight as the Giants celebrated their pennant-winning playoff victory over the Dodgers. Some of the bubbly stuff--but no Giants--got drunk. INSTANT INTERIORS, a new decorating concern designed to take the trauma out of moving, may be happy news to many homemakers in need of decorating advice this fall. The enterprise sells the services of a designer for one day; nothing is sold but imagination. The fee is $100.
THE ichthyologist who gave the scientific name to hali but was endowed with a sense of humor. He dubbed the poor fish hippoglossus hippoglossus, the name with which it is catalogued today.
An explosion "like 100,000 backfires all in one" signaled the disaster in the New York Telephone Company building to nearby residents of the Inwood section yesterday.
The Board of Education has begun its first nationwide drive to recruit teachers.

OTTAWA, Oct. 3--Prime Minister John Diefenbaker and his Conservative followers cleared the first hurdle in their bid to remain in power as a minority government when the Social Credit party's motion of no confidence was overwhelmingly defeated last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3--Yugoslavia has rejected Soviet overtures for a common policy on the German issue involving the possible signing of a separate peace treaty with East Germany, qualified sources said tonight.

A bitter attack in the United Nations the other day by Panama's Foreign Minister on the United States-Panamanian Canal Treaty is the latest manifestation of unrest in the isthmus.
Nine singers have joined the roster of the Metropolitan Opera, bringing the number of debuts scheduled for the coming season to 16.

LAST week the New York State Conservation Department came up with an optimistic report on the prospects of small-game hunting. Every district and region found the outlook for the season to be encouraging.
Ted Bates Co., Inc., is starting a new advertising agency in Frankfurt, Germany. The agency will be called Ted Bates Werbegesellschaft mbH and will have an initial staff of 35 people.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 4--Robert Wilke of the host Winged Foot Golf Club won the Macy Westchester Newspapers' ninth Westchester tournament of golf club champions today with a 36-hole score of 150.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- Rail and truck freight loadings in the week ended last Saturday rose slightly from the level of the preceding week.

The four-story building with offices, stores and a self-service elevator at 404 to 408 West 14th Street has been sold by the 14th Street Corporation. It was bought by the Transnation Realty Company for cash over mortgages amounting to $290,000.
A portable communicator, developed by the Santa Barbara, Calif., laboratory of Raytheon Company, permits two-way confidential conversations between two stations as far as ten miles apart.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--A bill to tighten the drug laws ended its tortuous journey through Congress today and went to the White House.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 4--Project Mercury's flight director said today that the chief significance of Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr.'s six-orbit flight was in showing the invaluable role of the human pilot in space missions.
For a building that has been experiencing major reconstruction for the last two years, the Pierpont Morgan Library today looks much like its old self, which is exactly what the library wanted.
Columbia plans a backfield realignment for tomorrow's game at Palmer Stadium against Princeton.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4-- Edwin Charles (Whitey) Ford won the first World series game he pitched in, as a 21year-old way back in 1950. Today's victory was the 10th Series triumph for the stocky blond southpaw of the Yankees, who doesn't look a day older now.
Edwin Mueller, one of the country's outstanding philatelic authorities and a specialist in European stamps, died yesterday in Park East Hospital. His age was 63.
HOLLANDIA, New Guinea, Oct. 4--On maps and in newspaper dispatches the name of this town still appears as Hollandia. Psychologically, it is Kotabaru.
A 90-minute filmed documentary showing East German men, women aund children escaping to West Berlin through a tunnel-under the wall will be televised this month by the National Broadcasting Company.
LONDON, Oct. 4--The Admiralty said today that eight Royal Navy volunteers had set a record by rising 260 feet from a submarine submerged near Malta.
BONN, Oct. 4--The West German Cabinet approved today a record budget for the fiscal year of 1963. It totals 56,814,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $14,200,000,000).
CENTRAL CITY, Neb., Oct. 3-There is little isolationism in the Middle West when it comes to Cuba, Castro and Khrushchev.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 4 (AP)--Attorneys for a Negro seeking to transfer to Clemson College told the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit today that he should be given a choice of entering now or in January.

BRIDGEPORT, W.Va., Oct. 4--U.S. 50 pretzel-bends its way into Bridgeport and twists some more along Main Street. In a one-chair barber shop, its open doorway flooded by the morning sunlight, the proprietor and two patrons talked about Cuba.

ADEN, Oct. 4 (Reuters)--The Yemeni radio broadcast tonight what appeared to be a general mobilization order to the armed forces as pro-royalist tribesmen were reported to be preparing a countrattack against the new rebel Government.

IT would seem that maternity styles as such are almost ob- solete. The dresses and costumes in Bonwit Teller's current collection would look as attractive if found in any dress department of the store.

Cotton futures were 5 cents a bale up to 50 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 4--Westchester officials are considering several plans for changes in the county's Playland amusement park here.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 5-- France's National Assembly, in revolt after four years of domination by President de Gaulle, voted the overthrow of the Gaullist Premier, Georges Pompidou, early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)--A dome of earth 600 to 800 feet across--greater in diameter than the length of two football fields--was hurled 2,000 feet into the air by a midget hydrogen bomb that was exploded underground in Nevada on July 6, it was revealed today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4--A prospective rise in housing starts, the continuing availability of mortgage money and the promise of a streamlining in the processing of loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration were discussed today at the concluding session of the Mortgage Bankers Association's annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--A Senate-House conference com- mittee agreed tonight on a foreign aid appropriation of $3,928,900,000 after Congress acted on an accumulation of other measures in a rush to adjourn this weekend.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The national unemployment rate remained at 5.8 per cent of the total labor force in September, the Labor Department reported today.

United States Steel Corporation's California mills yesterday posted new prices on several key items, extending into new product groups the Western price-cutting wave started earlier this week by Kaiser Steel Corporation.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP )-- Most soybean and grain futures were mixed in a narrow range on the Board of Trade today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4--U Thant sounded a new warning today on the financial difficulties confronting the United Nations.

Sixty thousand striking longshoremen were ordered yesterday to return to work in ports from Maine to Texas, which have been idle since Monday.

Directors of the R.R. Donnelley Company yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock, declared a stock dividend and increased the cash dividend.

SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3--The Cuban crisis is not yet political issue in this industrial city; but, carefully nurtured, it could become one. President Kennedy would be held responsible by the voters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--All United States military personnel will be withdrawn from Laos before Sunday night, as promised, officials said today. The withdrawal will leave a still seriously divided country with several thousand North Vietnamese troops camped there.

Activity in domestic sugar futures increased yesterday on the New York, Coffee and Sugar Exchange. At the close, of trading, domestic sugar prices were up 1 point (hundredths of a cent a pound) to unchanged on the sale of 7,050 tons.
BOSTON, Oct. 4--It is difficult to make a political swing around America these days without coming to the conclusion that the governors of the states, taken as a whole, are a poor lot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- The President's Advisory Com- mittee on Labor-Management Policy recommended today the establishment of voluntary labor-management committees to explore ways of expanding foreign trade.

LONDON, Oct. 4--Prices advanced on the stock market today. However, gains among the leaders were less than a shilling (14 cents).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) --Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy announced today that two white men had been charged with the burning of a Negro church near Leesburg, Ga., Aug. 15.

Emanuel Greenberg, a lawyer, a former judge of the State Court of Claims and a Jewish philanthropic leader, died yesterday in his home at 11 Fifth Avenue after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

The State Insurance Department offered congratulations and a word of caution yesterday to executives of the 45 commercial insurance companies that have developed a pool plan for health insurance for persons more than 65 years old.

The long--expected audit of the E.L. Bruce Company has been completed by Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co. and is in the hands or the Securities and Exchange commission.
Seven of the 10 works commissioned by the New York Philharmonic for its first season in Philharmonic Hall have been definitely scheduled for the orchestra's season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) --Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Anthony J. Celebrezze, said today he planned to make "a few changes in the organization" of his department.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct 4-- --A Labor party spokesman said today that a Labor government in Britain would establish a four-year plan to expand all production and end the "economy of stagnation" imposed by the Conservative party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) --A Government official challenged today former Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey's estimate of the cost of nickel sold to the Government by Mr. Humphrey's M. A. Hanna Company.

The conference version of the drug control bill, now well on its way to becoming law, substantially strengthens the hitherto inadequate safeguards which have surrounded the development, production, testing and sale of medicines for human use.
The Community Service Society of New York opened its eighth annual appeal for funds yesterday. Its goal is $2,000,000, and the drive will end Jan. 31.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by E.J. Korvette, Inc., for the year ended July 29.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) --The Senate passed by a voice vote today one of the last of President Kennedy's "must" bills remaining before adjournment. It was a highway financing measure, which now goes to conference with the House of Representatives.

Stock prices climbed in quiet trading yesterday. Volume continued on the low side, apparently because of the continuing weakness of public interest and the attraction of the opening day of the World Series.

The market for Government securities registered its first definite decline in three weeks yesterday. Municipal and corporate debt issues continued to rise in unusually active trading for a Friday.
BOSTON, Oct. 5--A socially prominent Boston girl was charged with first-degree murder today in the shooting of her suitor here Monday.

PARIS, Oct. 5--Despite a political crisis in Paris, President de Gaulle went to the Champagne country of eastern France today to preside over the opening phase of the most extensive military maneuvers on home territory since 1938. France's military...

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5-- "That was the best game I ever pitched," Jack Sanford, the San Francisco Giants' ace righthander, said today after shutting out the Yankees on three hits. "Everything seemed to be working--fast balls, sliders, curves."

An American sailor accused of transmitting defense secrets to the Soviet Union for $10,000 was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on espionage charges. He could receive the death penalty if convicted.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5--Frederick H. Prince Jr., sportsman, died here today in his home. His age was 76.

Fighting for its life, the Government of Prime Minister Diefenbaker of Canada won its first victories over the combined opposition when the House of Commons defeated two motions of noconfidence, thus enabling it to continue as a minority regime. It won these victories not because it was able to rally majority support behind itself, but because the opposition is so badly split that it was unable to unite.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 5 (AP)--Gov. Wesley Powell said today that he would bring action in Federal court against the National Broadcasting Company and David Brinkley, news commentator, unless the network retracts a statement made by Mr. Brinkley regarding dishonesty in the Federal road building program in New Hamshire.
ALBANY, Oct. 5--The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 928 of the 1,480 persons who took the bar examinations on July 10 and 11 had passed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--Administration spokesmen said today that President Kennedy was expected to sign a revision of the controversial loyalty oath and anti-Communist disclaimer provision of the Government's program for loans to college students.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 5-- The Minister of Industry, Prof. Fethi Celikbash, opened Turkey's large new oil refinery today at Mersin, the principal port in southern Turkey. It will rank as one of the largest oil refineries in the Mediterranean area.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) --Leaders of American and Japanese electrical unions with some 600,000 members announced plans today for possible joint strike action against common employers.
TORONTO, Oct. 5 (Canadian Press)--A talk after a party tonight produced one of the weirdest hockey stories of the year--a $1,000,000 National Hockey League player sale.

A small explosive charge or homemade bomb was thrown into a narrow passageway outside Cardinal Spellman's residence at about 1:45 A.M. today. Neither the Cardinal nor anyone else was injured, and damage was slight.

The Flying Tiger Line's new fleet of CL-44 cargo planes has almost doubled its volume of business and resulted in a net profit before taxes averaging $600,000 a month, Robert W. Prescott, president, said yesterday.
Most commodities traded on the New York exchanges showed rises yesterday in weekend evening-up operations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--The index of wholesale primary market prices declined one-fifth per cent to 100.8 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Oct. 2, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Next week's calendar of municipal and corporate fixed-interest offerings is expected to continue light. Scheduled dollar volume of more than $85,000,000 will mark the third consecutive decline.

DALLAS, Oct. 5 (AP)--The Murchison interests of Dallas announced the sale today of a large part of their Alleghany Corporation stock in a move to bring harmony to the $7,000,000,000 railroad and investment corporation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5--The nuclear power plant of the Yankee Atomic Electric Company at Rowe, Mass., commended in 1961 by the Atomic Energy Commission as the "success story of the year" on the basis of costs, has scored again. Its

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Oct. 5-- Richard L. Maloney, president of the New York Savings Bank, died in his sleep during the night, apparently of a heart attack, in his home on Cedar Swamp Road. His age was 57.

Ross Hunter, a producer who has founded his career on glamorized new versions of the tearful shopgirl romances of the nineteen-twenties and thirties, plans to film Alexandre Bisson's hardy old drama of mother love. "Madame X."

The seasons got a little mixed up at Belmont yesterday. At the crest of interest in the World Series, a colt bearing the name of Grid Iron Hero ran over the sloppy track fast enough to win the feature race.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5-- Robert F. Eaton, who served with the American Red Cross for almost 30 years and was director of its national convention office since 1954, died last night of a cerebral hemorrhage at the Arlington (Va.) Hospital. He was 54 years old.

MINEOLA, L.I. Oct. 5-- Supervisor Clinton G. Martin of North Hempstead said today that the town would sue to recover $25,000 that was paid to a contractor for work performed by town vehicles and personnel.

Tremendous steam pressure that developed in 37 minutes and an absence of "safety factors" were suggested by an official last night as the cause of the boiler explosion Wednesday that killed 21 telephone employes and injured 86 others.
ALTHOUGH many people have not banished their summer clothes from the closet, it is time to think of Christmas for those who plan to send Yuletide gifts to friends and relatives abroad.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP)--Safe Mission, a son of the triple crown winner, Scott Frost, swept the rich Kentucky Futurity in straight heats today while the heavily favored A.C.'s Viking failed to make a serious threat.

EARLY last month harvesting began in West Coast or chards on what promises to be one of the largest walnut crops on record. It is expected that by the time the last nut is shaken from the tree, which will probably be late in November.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5-- Premier Hermes Lima has assured Brazilian sympathizers of Premier Fidel Castro that Brazil will never support punitive measures against Cuba simply because it has a different regime from other American countries.
Ivy League games are the main football attractions in the East today with Penn State, Army, Pittsburgh and Navy heavily engaged elsewhere and Syracuse idle.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 5-- J. Stuart Wickens, the athletic director at Groton School for two decades, is as busy as a traffic policeman at a seven-corner intersection. A new gymnasium is about to be built and Wickens is now a student of architecture. Draped on one of the
Babies do just as well on cold bottles right out of the refrigerator as they do on bottles that have been warmed to body temperature, a Bellevue Hospital study suggests.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) --The Senate sent to President Kennedy today an Administration-opposed bill to double the tariff on middleweight bicycles imported into the United States.
An exceptionally wide range of export and investment opportunities in Israel was reported by an American trade mission yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.
Three Thursday-morning benefit lectures at the Cosmopolitan Club have been announces by the Council of Goodwill Industries. They will be held next week and on Oct. 18 and Oct. 25 at 11 A.M.

John Wallowitch made his debut as a pianist in a demanding program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. He handled the two large-scale works on his program--the Liszt Sonata in B minor and the Rachmaninoff B flat minor Sonata--with intelligence. The proportions of the two sprawling pieces were planned with care and finesse.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5-- Morse Salisbury, former director of public information for the Atomic Energy Commission, died today of a stroke at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He would have been 64 years old tomorrow.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 5 (AP)--Judy Kimball scored a 69 for 139 in the second round today to take a 4-stroke lead in the Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at the Stardust Country Club.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein yesterday upheld the right of John S. Kroese, owner of an electrical supply house in New York City, to inspect certain of the books and records of the Texas Pacific Land Trust.
ABOARD THE U.S.S. KEARSARGE, in the Pacific, Oct. 5-- Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. came back from orbit with this one complaint:
Jews over the world will begin the observance of the most sacred event on their religious calendar, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, at sundown tomorrow.
YONKERS, Oct. 5--Splitting the American Test into two divisions turned out to be fine for Clint Hodgins tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Two New York youths, being held in Burgaw, N.C., for theft and housebreaking, have admitted the slaying of a registered nurse whose body was found buried in a cellar here last Tuesday, the police said yesterday. One of the youths was a nephew of the dead woman.

ATHENS, Oct. 5--It is a striking paradox that while Soviet Russia becomes perceptibly stronger as a national power, Communism falters as an international force. No alarmism over Cuba should obscure this.

Bobby Short, a bright-eyed, gleaming singer whose vast collection of show tunes--some obscure and some nostalgically familiar--are usually heard in, as he says, "the small, dark, smoky rooms," moved into Carnegie Hall last night. The

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 5 --Mr. and Mrs. William E. Leidt have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Cadoo Leidt, to Eric Francis Hockings of Princeton, N.J. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. John R.E. Hockings of Farnham, Survey, England.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP)-- Liquidation by traders stopped a rally in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today, and some losses were registered.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5-- The inhabitants of this gay metropolis are back on Cloud Nine.

Hand-Weaving Exhibition Seventeen hangings, rugs and blankets, all woven by Alice Kagawa Parrott, are now on exhition in the Members' Gallery of the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53d Street, through Nov. 11. Mrs. Parrott, who lives in Sante Fe, N.M., has found her individual style among the indigenous Indian weavers of the southwestern United States.

President de Gaulle is now bent on carrying the battle between himself and Parliament directly to the French people. The lines were drawn when the National Assembly, submissive to his one-man rule for four years during the Algerian crisis, rebelled once this crisis was over. It has thrown out de Gaulle's hand-picked Premier Pompidou with a vote of censure that accused President de Gaulle himself of violating the Constitution and opening the doors to dictatorship.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct. 5 (AP) --A Federal judge ousted another crew from a United States missile-tracking vessel today but he ordered further hearings in a dispute that threatens to provoke a Congressional inquiry into the entire operation.
OTTAWA, Oct. 5--The minority Government of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker seemed assured today of remaining in power for some time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5--Maybe the Giants merely needed another night's sleep to shake off the aftereffects of their grueling playoff. It left them dull and listless yesterday. But they were so refreshed today that even their perception improved. They could see that the Yankees really didn't look any different from the Dodgers. So they went out and beat them.
Dock workers ignored yesterday a Federal Court order issued on Thursday instructing them to return to work "immediately" in all Atlantic and Gulf ports.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 5--While the change in the Eastern Command is described officially as a "normal administrative reorganization," it appears to confirm an impression that the Government is not satisfied with the performance of the military on the northeastern border in the last two weeks or so.
BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 5-- The possibility of producing protective antibodies against germs that do not yet exist was suggested here today at a conference of experts on virus disease.

Secretary of State Dean Rusk conferred yesterday with the Malayan Minister for Internal Security on the danger that Communist forces might stay in Laos beyond midnight tomorrow, the deadline for the withdrawal of all foreign forces.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 5 (AP) --The Federal Aviation Agency said today that photographs taken by flight engineers indicated that at least three airline pilots had been inattentive to duty during flights.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) --President Kennedy has written to Pope John XXIII that people everywhere hoped the forthcorming Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church would advance the cause of peace and understanding.
A somewhat different concept in folk-music programs, "The Traveling Hootenanny," left the Town Hall terminal last night before rolling out to the bustling campus circuit.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP)--Part of the $100,000 reward offered by Bririk's, Inc., in the $1,219,000 cash robbery of its Boston money express office a dozen years ago has been awarded, the reward committee announced today.
Robert M. Morgenthau declared yesterday that the state had run "deeper and deeper into debt" through the borrowing by autonomous state agencies under Governor Rockefeller's administration.

Emile Griffith, the welterweight champion of the world, will move up to the 160-pound (middleweight) division tonight when he fights Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, in a bout scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5-- Congress completed action today on the bill to increase postal rates and raise the pay of more than 1,600,000 Government employes.

PARIS, Oct. 5--The defeat of the Cabinet of Premier Georges Pompidou in the National Assembly early today marked the opening of a struggle that is likely to produce either the consolidation or the disappearance of President de Gaulle's regime.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, the President's parents, have joined the sponsors of the third annual Candlelight Ball of the Manhattanville College Alumnae Association, which will take place on Saturday at the Plaza.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5--An African spokesman praised the United States in the General Assembly today for the integration action taken this week in Mississippi.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5-- George Robert (Birdie) Tebbetts today signed a three-year contract to manage the Cleveland Indians. He accepted the terms offered by Gabe Paul, Cleveland's general manager, during today's World Series game here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) --The United States accused the Soviet Union today of forcibly detaining and "roughing up" its assistant naval attache in Moscow before ordering him to leave the country on a charge of espionage. The expulsion was termed retaliatory.
ATLANTA, Oct. 5--Gov. Ernest Vandiver signed into law today a bill that the Georgia Legislature believes will comply with Federal Court orders on legislative rapportionment.
The excursion fleet and goodwill of the old Hudson River Day Line has been sold to Circle Line interests headed by Francis J. Barry.
Lower sales and sharply reduced earnings were announced yesterday by the Grand Union Company for the 13 week and 26 week periods ended Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--The Sperry Gyroscope Company is patenting a distinct departure in gyroscopes--one that uses a liquid instead of a wheel as the spinning element.
PHILHARMONIC HALL had its first piano recital by a solo artist last night. Josh Iturbi was the artist, and the Spanish pianist confined himself to pieces by his compatriot Albeniz.
Stock prices continued to move into higher ground yesterday, strengthening gains made earlier in the week.

SEATTLE, Oct. 5--Modern technological supremacy is the single sure bulwark for the United States, Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover told the 800 conferees at the three-day American Merchant Marine Conference here today.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 5--A Justice Department official said today he could not understand why University of Mississippi authorities had taken no action against students involved in rioting Sunday night.
LONDON, Oct. 5--Industrial shares maintained their advance on the stock market today, despite heavy profit taking toward the end of trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) --A former official in the Truman Administration said today the Government's nickel deal with the Hanna Mining Company was "objectionable." But he called it the best that could be made in the pressure of the Korean War.

A proposal was discussed here yesterday for a sweeping reconstruction of the International Court of Justice. It was drafted in the hope of achieving world peace through the impartial administration of international justice.
VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. 5-- In the seventh round of the Chess Olympic finals here last night, the United States team, playing against West Germany, won two games, drew one and adjourned one.
Cotton futures were 15 cents a bale up to 55 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Oct. 5 --Frederick M. Atkins, retired New Jersey district manager for the Jacob Ruppert Brewing Company, died today at his home, 110 Union Avenue. His age was 66.

As the tempo of the undeclared war in South Vietnam quickens, the American-aided forces seem to be fighting now with more effectiveness. Administrative improvements by the Saigon Government, an increasing number of strategic hamlets and an anti-Vietcong shift among the tribesmen of the northern plateau are among the other new factors in the struggle against the Vietcong.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5-- Princeton's football team will send its ground game against Columbia's passing attack tomorrow at Palmer Stadium. A crowd of 20,000 is expected for the game, which will begin at 2 P.M.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel S. Leibowitz directed yesterday that a grand jury investigate possible perjury charges against a New York City policeman and his wife after they had testified in a Bedford-Stuyvesant mugging case.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 5--A new Frontier Corps has been created to defend the eastern sector of India's northern border against Chinese Communist incursions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5-- Senate and House negotiators finished work today on a compromise foreign aid appropriation of $3,928,900,000. They scheduled voting on it in the House tomorrow and in the Senate Monday.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 5--Five landlords and two contractors are under indictments here for allegedly conniving to inflate the cost of apartment house improvements so that cents could be raised.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Oct. 5 --The engagement of Miss Bernice S. Leader, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Leader, to Henry A. Selib, news editor of the Brandeis University office of public affairs, has been announced. Mr. Selib is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Mitchell S. Selib of Brookline.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday challenged an assertion by his Democratic-Liberal opponent that enrollment in the State University had declined during the Governor's term of office.
Buddy Rogers and Killer Kowalski found a new way to end a professional wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 5 --The seventh annual Indian Harbor Yacht Club-Stratford Shoal overnight race, the final long distance event of the Long Island Sound sailing season, began tonight in a 15-to-20-mile east-southeast wind that carried gusts of over 25 miles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--Congress completed action today on two programs designed to clean up financial problems left over from World War II.
Some sets of open-stand, reserved seats (near the rightfield bleachers) are available for the next three games of the World Series, which moves into Yankee Stadium tomorrow.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5-- The Off Broadway production of Dylan Thomas' "Under Miikwood" began a tour of some 25 college campuses tonight with a performance before an enthusiastic audience of 825 persons in McCarter Theater of Princeton University.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5-- Old 33 delivered for the Giants today. Jack Sanford, 33 years old, and wearing No. 33, pitched a three-hit shutout in his first World Series game. It had been a long time coming.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--The merged labor federation has in effect given the Seafarers International Union a license to take the rival National Maritime Union apart if it can.

AFTER leaving James Wines's exhibition of sculpture at the Otto Gerson Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, I was accosted by the blunt end of a concrete mixer at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 60th. The encounter, after seeing the exhibition, was awesome, for the concrete mixer impressed on one the absolute impersonality of the machine.

Business as usual was the order at City Center last night, as the New York City Opera Company presented its second performance of the season. The business: a lively, imaginative production of a valuable contemporary score, beautifully performed, and attended by far too small an audience.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 5--The possibility of a visit by Premier Khrushchev to the United Nations late next month is getting increasing attention in the Administration. The chances of such a visit are now widely considered as "likely."
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5-- Without being glum, the Yankee dressing room was a silent place today after the Bombers had been shut out on three hits by Jack Sanford of the Giants.

OMAHA, Sept. 29--In Kansas and Nebraska, which went overwhelmingly against John F. Kennedy in the Presidential election two years ago, Republicans seem assured of another near sweep of state and Congressional races this fall.
