CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 (AP)-- Ernie Davis of the Cleveland Browns, the nation's top collegiate football player of 1961, has leukemia, but it is in a "perfect state of remission," a physician said today, and Ernie is physically able to start workouts with the team.

Production of lumber in the country totaled 235,373,000 board feet in the week ended Sept. 29, according to reports received from regional lumber associations.

THE opening of Philharmonic Hall at Lincoln Center gives New York another lustrous landmark in a progression which for a century has been dazzling the world. It is one more demonstration of the city's vitality and the originality of its patterns. But also--significantly--the new hall is but the first unit of Lincoln Center. And Lincoln Center is but one of the many great prospects in the city's future.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6-- Nearly half of Brazil's 18,500,000 voters eligible to take part in tomorrow's Congressional and state elections will find their ballots a test of reading and writing ability.

WHEN a bridge expert is set six tricks or a child psy chologist has the worst brat in town, every one feels a mildly malicious satisfaction. And doubtless something similar happens when a professional critic writes a novel or a play or a symphony and himself gets trounced.
A treasure of marine fossils has been discovered and mined 7,000 feet up in the Ganoid Range of British Columbia in western Canada.

But in the past few months I've been noticing several outsize whodunits, culminating this week in two first novels by celebrities (a jockey and an actor) with no unusual ...

HONOLULU, Oct. 6--Hawaii's voters went to the polls in record numbers today to select nominees for a United States Senate post, two seats in the house and scores of state, county and school offices. It was the last primary election in the nation this year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6-- Columbia started bravely against Princeton in a scoreless first quarter and Archie Roberts, the Light Blue sophomore quarterback, passed like an all-American on the only scoring threat of the period.
PARIS, Oct. 6--President de Gaulle and France's traditional political leadership embarked this week on a collision course that threatened to smash one or the other irrevocably.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 6 (AP)-- Tennessee gambled and lost today and Mississippi State gained a 7-6 victory.

MAJOR improvements in its New York-Boston and Boston-New York Washington service will be made by the New Haven Railroad, effective Oct. 28. Faster running times, better equipment on some trains and more efficient scheduling will mark the new timetable.
Seven thousand dock workers went back to their piers yesterday under the terms of a restraining order that stopped their walkout.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 6 (UPI)--Wisconsin's sophomorestudded football team, with a flashy running attack added to the pass receiving of its AllAmerica end, Pat Richter, opened its Big Ten season today, by defeating Indiana, 30--6.
THE interest in pure-bred dogs continues to rise. The American Kennel Club registrations, for the first eight months of the year, announced last week, totaled 354,029.

WASHINGTON. AS Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, President Kennedy can summon a dazzling display of the nation's military musical might: any of several Marine jazz trios, the Navy's "Cocktail Combo." the Air Force's bagpipe outfit, the Army's Fife and Drum Corps. Each service has its famous bands.
PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 6-- The Bergen County Traffic Safety Committee was organized this week to combat the steadily rising accident toll in this corridor county.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 6 (AP)--Clarence Ewing Tuttle, a Baltimore industrialist, died in a hospital today at the age of 78.

WHEN U Thant of Burma was named acting Secretary General of the United Nations, a visiting newspaperman, listening to his acceptance speech, commented: "He couldn't swat a fly." The gentle, softspoken Burmese educator and diplomat did seem, at first glance, to be a puff of evanescent tumbleweed, likely to be tossed by the diplomatic winds. It is entirely possible that the Soviet Union, permitting him to be elected, made the same mistake.

AN unusually fine confluence, of art exhibitions in New York and around the country last week was mush more reassuring than the news on the front page. They offered some reaffirmations of the contention, sometimes so difficult to support, that art rises above the chaotic experience of life and eventually distills from the mess whatever good is compounded within it.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Oct. 6-- Miss Margaret A. Towne and Peter D'Albert, both of New York, were married here this afternoon in the Skinner Memorial Chapel (Congregational) The Rev. Dr. Oliver K. Black performed the ceremony.

YESTERDAY the Monroe Doctrine was all but forgotten; today it is a focus of national attention. So viet shipments of arms and personnel to Cuba have sounded an alarm across our land, and citizens, public and private, are marshaling themselves against the threat under the banner of the venerable declaration.

MIAMI, Oct. 6--"Miami is a nice city and the Americans are very kind but we only live for the day we can go home to Cuba," Alfonso Lopez, a 57-year-old Cuban refugee, said. The members of his family nodded in agreement.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6--The state of relations between the Soviet Union and Communist China is symbolized by what a visitor to the Soviet capital finds at Ulitsa Druzby, the Street of Friendship. There is situated the huge, ornate Chinese Communist Embassy. It dwarfs the other embassies, but a strange silence pervades the compound and few Chinese are seen about.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 6 (AP)--Kansas scored four touchdowns after a sluggish first half and defeated Colorado, 35-8, in a Big Fight Conference football game today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6-- Troops of at least four nations were reported today to be maneuvering on and near the Arabian peninsula, in efforts to influence the civil strife in Yemen.

ALTHOUGH not much is being written in the way of humor these days, the paperback publishers are helping to relieve the shortage by mingling reprints from more carefree times with what there is of modern vintage.

IN recent years the popularity of guest participation dishes has been growing. There are various theories as to where this form of dining originated. Some say Switzerland, the land of cheese fondue; others say Japan, the home of sukiyaki.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 1--A sense of political frustration unknown here since the days of the absolute dictatorship of Gen. Anastasio Somoza is beginning to settle over a large part of Nicaragua's population.
A serpentine mall, with Oriental landscaping and air-conditioning, will serve as the main pedestrian thoroughfare at the Walt Whitman Shopping Center, soon to be completed in South Huntington, L.I.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico-- The eighth Inter-American Travel Congress, at its recent 12-day meet ing in this gay and festive capital of the state of Jalisco, took a major step toward bolstering Latin America's lagging tourist industry, by recommending that tourism be included among the objectives of the Alliance for Progress.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 6--The last of 25 new generating units at the Niagara Power Project will begin commercial operation next Thursday. It will increase the capacity of the huge hydroelectric development here to 2,190,000 kilowatts.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 3--Haitian physicians, lawyers and teachers are seeking employment abroad. Their efforts are ironic testimony both to the effects of this country's underdevelopment and to the inability of the Government to marshal the few resources it does have.
PHILADELHIA, Oct. 6-- Sonny Liston was picked up by police in Fairmount Park last night and later released, the police disclosed today.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 6-- Miss Jane Elizabeth Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Winchester Chapman of Brooklyn and Brightwaters, was married here this morning to William Edward Keefe. He is the son of Mrs. William Keefe of Weymouth, Mass., and the late Mr. Keefe.

THE national anthems of Africa's newly independent countries are composed of basically the same ingredients as are the old patriotic hymns we know. They celebrate a nation's traditions and aspirations and-- of special concern to Africans --love of a unified mother country as opposed to attachments to the tribe.

THE notion that the Scotch are a dour, hard-bitten, gloomy lot dies hard, despite evidence to the contrary by Scotchmen from Burns to Compton Mackenzie, Eric Linklater and Hugh MacDiarmid. Now we have a report from an English schoolteacher who went to live in the Hebrides, not just for ...
CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 6-- Thousands of people thronged the centers of private and community worship today at the start of a four-day religious festival, the Durga Puja.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 6 (UPI)--Don Mellhany's 100-yard kickoff return for a touchdown with two seconds remaining gave Texas A. and M. a 7-3 victory over Texas Tech tonight.
Ten cents will get you a cup of coffee and culture at many American restaurants today.

WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY once noted: "Next to eating good dinners, a healthy man with a benevolent turn of mind must like, I think, to read about them." Although it was not intended as such, this is a remark to warm the heart of one whose livelihood --perhaps I should use the phrase daily bread--depends on the public's interest in gastronomy.
One of the most prominent landmarks in Queens, the 50year-old Forest Hills Inn and Apartments, has been sold for $2,700,000.

Imports of alcoholic beverages continue to increase. In the first eight months of this year, United States imports of every classification showed a rise over the same period of last year. Indications are that the total for the entire year will also be ahead of 1961.
A young harpist and a young flutist made impressive debuts yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Fecital Hall. They were Joyce Rosenfield and Harriet Edwards Wallack.

LONDON. SIR LAURENCE OLIVIER'S appointment as director of the new National Theater is nonetheless welcome for being expected. No one commands such universal respect and affection with both the public and the profession as he does. He, if anyone, will insure that the venture gets off to a good start.
A jurisdictional dispute involving eight to ten plumbers and carpenters is keeping 189 families from moving into their homes in the Penn Station South middle-income cooperative.

A NEGRO leader once told me that, other things being equal, genuinely "reconstructed Southerners" are the Negro's staunchest allies. That has been true since the time of the Grimke sisters' and James G. Birney'; Sarah Patton Boyle is a blazing modern example.
SEATTLE, Oct. 6--It was generally conceded during the three-day American Merchant Marine Conference here this week that American shipping was in dire circumstances.

In the year 1602, an English fisher man named Bartholomew Gosnold made the first commercial fishing voyage off the shores of Massachusetts. He was so impressed by what he saw that he named the land nearby Cape Cod.

The Hudson Guild Neighborhood House, which has served the Chelsea community of Manhattan for 67 years; will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 12 and Nov. 15 performances of "Night Life" at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. Carol Lawrence is starring in the play, which opens on Oct. 23.

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 6--Miss Alexandra Montgomery, daughter of R. Alexander Montgomery and Mrs. T.F. Dixon Wainwright, both of Villanova, to N. Victor Dial took place this afternoon in St. David's Protestant Episcopal Church. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Kenneth W. Hinks of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Lieut. Nathaniel Minter Dial, U.S.N., of Washington.
More than a score of fragments from the first vehicle launched in the Soviet man-inapace program have been recovered in Wisconsin.
Governor Rockefeller brought his re-election campaign back to the city yesterday with a promise that he would try to create 500,000 more jobs in the state.

In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Brenda Jane Haslam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Shaw Haslam of 235 East 57th Street, became the bride of Jonathan Winfred Windle. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Winfred Woodard Windle of Sutton, Mass.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 6-- On this dismal day brightened only by the multi-colored foliage that was barely visible through the mist, Dartmouth defeated Pennsylvania, 17--0, before 6,000 drenched spectators.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 6--Port Chester High stretched its undefeated football string to 19 games today by defeating Mount Vernon High 20-0, at Memorial Field.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla.-- About 400 years ago, on Sept. 20, 1565, a Spanish force of 500 men from St. Augustine attacked the French garrison at Fort Caroline, slaughtering 132 men and capturing about 50 women and children.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 6--St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here tonight for the marriage of Miss Lynn Marquez Cowell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Cowell, to Garrett Bell Hunter. He is a son of Mrs. Ralph W. Carson of Naples. Fla., and the late John W. Hunter. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harrold A. Murray.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP)-- Fred W. Hooper's Sky Gem won the $30,300 Hawthorne Juvenile race for 2-year-olds today, defcating Salesman Prior by three-quarters of a length in what proved to be a two-horse race.

PAUL MacKendrick, Professor of Classics at the University of Wisconsin, has a thrilling tale to tell in his "The Greek Stones Speak" that is similar to the one he told two years ago in his story of archeology in Italy, "The Mute Stones Speak."

The stock market dawdled along last week without making much progress. Any spurt of activity with rising prices soon brought profit taking. The baseball games and space orbit generated more interest than the prices printed on the ticker tape. Stock prices gained 4.87 points for the week and closed at 317.84. Most of the gain came on Thursday and Friday, with sales well below 3,000,000 shares each day.
BIMINI, The Bahamas, Sept. 28--The sea's secrets are described as being as scientifically unexplored as space.
The anxieties of apartment hunting are familiar to most New Yorkers, but a Greenwich Village couple reports that tenant-hunting has a few trials of its own.
YONKERS, Oct, 6--J.R. Rick's Royal Rick from New Castle, Pa., scored a 1 -length victory over Prince Gamaun tonight in the $15,000 class F.F.A. Monitor Pace before 28,034 at Yonkers Raceway.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct 6--A fraternity house on the University of Mississippi campus sits high above a terraced lawn behind breastworks of baled hay. Mock cannon bristle from the gunports and Confederate battle flags flutter overhead.
LONDON, Oct. 6--The British Chamber of Shipping will meet Thursday to discuss United States efforts to prevent shipments to Cuba.

LAST week the Robert Jofrey Ballet invited dancers, choreographers, the dance press and others closely associated with the inner workings of the dance world to an informal showing of six "ballets in progress." These were the ballets that were created at Watch Hill, R.I., during the summer under a munificent grant from the Rebekah Harkness Foundation.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago, if a reporter had been assigned to write an article on "New Trends in Education," he could hardly have done so without mentioning the experimental private schools of New York City-- schools such as City and Country, Lincoln, Walden, Dalton and Ethical Culture.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6--The Yugoslav Government expressed satisfaction today over the United States Congress's decision to give President Kennedy discretionary powers to continue aid to Communist-ruled Yugoslavia.

MANILA, Oct. 4--President Diosdado Macapagal said today that he regarded the current widespread criticism of his regime as an essential part of the kind of democracy he was trying to foster in the Philippines.

"Prices slightly higher west of the Rockies." This phrase, which is a familiar one in many catalogues, was dealt a blow in the steel business a few days ago when Kaiser Steel Corporation chopped an average $12 a ton from base prices on key products at its Fontana, Calif., works.

A code of recommended standards for the advertising of land for sale has been issued by the National Better Business Bureau. It prescribes candor, honesty and full disclosure of pertinent information about any property offered for purchase sight unseen.

Morris White, who made and sold, handbags off a pushcart and amassed more than $20,000,000 in business and real estate before the Depression of the nineteen-thirties, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 785 Park Avenue.
RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 3-- Morocco embarked on the final phase of modernizing her judiciary system today with the opening of the National Institute of Judicial Studies.
THE two main points that emerge from "The Affair," Ronald Millar's stage adaptation of C.P. Snow's novel, are admirable and worth reiterating.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 6 --On Wednesday Hugh Gaitskell arrayed the British Labor party against entry into the European Economic Community on any terms except those that now appear almost completely out of the Conservative Government's reach. This act, probably the most important of Mr. Gaitskell's leadership, will have significant effects on the future of European unity, Britain's political struggle and perhaps, in the end, the fate of the Labor party.

A miniature heating unit--14 inches square and 6 inches deep--has been developed for use in homes, apartment houses and commercial structures.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Oct. 6 --Oceanside High School snappped Lawrenre High's unbeaten football streak at 13 today with a 31-7 Division I South Shore League victory. Lawrence's last defeat was to Freeport on Oct. 22. 1960.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6--Mortgage bankers from all parts of the country gathered in Chicago this week to attend a sedate and well-mannered convention staged by their association.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 6--While Mississippi resisted in agony this week, Little Rock, where Federal troops last integrated a school, moved quietly along in its fifth year of public school desegregation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 6 --Despite a gloomy outlook caused by the threat of rain, the few sailing skippers who ventured onto Long Island Sound yesterday were rewarded with a steady northwest breeze and good racing.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 6 (AP) --Ada L. Rice's Try Cash won the $27,700 Quaker City Handicap by two lengths today. The favorite, Ogden Phipps' Hitting Away, was second.

Department store sales in the country for the week ended Sept. 29 were 3 per cent above the level of a year earlier, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. The volume in the preceding week was 5 per cent above that of a year ago.

ON Oct. 20, a week from next Saturday night, an audience will gather in the comfortable, steeply raked auditorium of the Donnell Library Center to listen to the music of Robert Middleton and Donald Waxman.

THOUGH there is no slackening in the flood of books being published on Africa, the character of these books shows signs of change. More of the volumes provide intensive examination of particular subjects.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.--Frost has already touched the hillsides in the Pocono country, and there is a change in the leaves that were a rich green during the summer. Autumn, with its riot of colors, is at hand.

The Stevens Institute of Technology, founded 93 years ago on the west bank of the Hudson River with an endowment of $650,000, has spent nearly $11,000,000 in recent years on new buildings and improvements to old ones.

THE alto saxist after whom Birdland is named flashed through the night skies of Negro-American music in the dislocated decade following World War II, burned himself out before he was 35 and left a legacy of such inspired improvisation that he helped launch a new era in jazz.
LONDON, Oct. 5--A will signed by Sir Francis Drake the day before he died will be sold here at auction next month.

The Toronto Maple Leafs, Stanley Cup champions, and the Chicago Black Hawks are regarded as strong threats to halt the Montreal Canadiens' bid for a sixth straight regular-season National Hockey League title this season.

THE title will hardly induce people to pick up this book for bedside reading, but it is not at all a dry-as-dust, clinical or statistical report, as one might expect. This is not to say that it is not disturbing, however, for it is.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6 --Favored Yale, making 6 the hard way--two 3's--settled for a 6-6 tie with Brown in the rain and mud today. Between them, the teams made another point--that football should not be played in the rain and mud.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 6--The eighth annual art exhibition and sale of the Essex County Section of the National Council of Jewish Women will be held Nov. 10 through Nov. 14 at Graulich's. Mrs. David Amster of Maplewood is chairman of the event, proceeds of which will aid the council's local and overseas charities.

Miss Judith Antoinette Woracek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony L. Woracek of Ridgewood, N.J., and Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Thomas Donald Barry. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Barry of Wayzata, Minn.
The New York City Central Labor Council has endorsed the current multimillion-dollar development program that will turn La Guardia Airport into a jetport by 1967.
CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 6--Harvard moved into the lead of the first official Ivy League sailing championships today on the Charles River Basin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6--President Kennedy is back on the campaign trail and once again he is in the sympathetic role of the boy on the burning deck.

LIFE has become just a little more complex for Paul Shyre. The youthful author-director-producer, now in Milwaukee, preparing a season at the Fred Miller Theater, has an additional assignment. For David O. Selznick he will render into stage form Jean Ariss's new novel. The Shattered Glass" (Knopf).

Miss Marian Elaine Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur N. Anderson of Plandome Manor, L.I., became the bride at noon yesterday of Thomas Robinson Cornwell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford G. Cornwell of Manhasset and Nassau Point, L.I. The Rev. August F. Bobzin performed the ceremony in the Lutheran Church of the Resurrection, Flushing, Queens.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 6 (AP)--Paul B. Fay Jr., the Under Secretary of the Navy, said today that the Navy's new nuclear-powered warship, the guided-missile frigate Bainbridge, could travel 20 times around the world without refueling.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6-- Pressure on the San Francisco Board of Education was intensified this week with the filing of a suit attacking the city's "neighborhood-school" student assignment practices as productive of racial segregation.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6--Prof. Neil W. Chamberlain, Yale University economist, has proposed that business executives make college a lifetime career.

GLADWYNE, Pa., Oct. 6--In St. Christopher's Protestant Episcopal Church this afternoon Miss Winifred Lee d'Olier became the bride of Anthony Coates Brown. NEW CANAAN, Conn, Oct. 6 --Mr. and Mrs. William DuBois have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Day DuBois, to Edward Franklyn Hutton. He is the son of Mrs. Edward Friendly of San Francisco and Curtis Wood Hutton of Santa Barbara, Calif.

TORONTO, Oct. 6--Frank Mahovlich, a star left wing for the Toronto Maple Leafs, became the center of a milliondollar trade offer today when James Norris, owner of the Chicago Black Hawks, sent a check to the Maple Leafs in a "hard offer" to purchase the National Hockey League scoring ace.

IT may not be very hard to become an addict of educational television station WNDT. By the test of its programs on the air, the noncommercial outlet in New York is quickly proving that the home screen is indeed susceptible of vast improvement in matters of substance.
SURPRISINGLY few gardens contain an adequate representation of the many fine but less common varieties of hardy bulbs. They add much to the attracttiveness of spring beds and borders.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 6 (AP) --Minnesota struck for touchdowns the first time it had the ball in each half, added another in the final two minutes and employed overpowering line play to crash Navy, 21-0, today before 64,364 fans in the first football meeting between the schools.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5--Divorce petitions from two of Canada's provinces will apparently plague this Parliament, as it did the last.

NO United States commemorative coins have been struck since 1954, and there are signs in Washington that there may be no more. There have been repeated proposals for commemoratives since the WashingtonCarver issue of 1954, but all have been sidetracked because Treasury and Mint officials frown on them.

CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio--This, town's 56th annual trib ute to the pumpkin, which Ohioans like to claim is the sixth largest festival in the United States, will be held here Oct. 17-20. The four-day Pumpkin Show is expected to attract 250,000 visitors from more than a dozen states.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico-- Most businessmen, taking the night train from Mexico City to this, the coun try's second city, arrive from the 12 -hour trip refreshed and relaxed. The train is superbly equipped, comfortable and, furthermore, has a reassuring sign posted in every car: "This Pullman train has had no accidents in 10 years."

Johnny Pesky, a former Boston Red Sox infielder, was named, manager of the Red Sox yesterday. Manager Mike Higgins was moved up to executive vicepresident, it was announced by club officials who are here for the World Series.

NEW IPSWICH, N.H., Oct. 7 (AP) Dwight. S. Simpson, a naval architect, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 79.

Victor Roth, who retired recently as director of subscription circulation of the Macfadden-Bartell Corporation, publishers, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital of Brooklyn. His age was 65. He lived at 1911 Dorchester Road in Brooklyn.
Two major public accounting firms, Lybrand, Ross Brothers Montgomery, and Scovell, Wellington Co., merged on Oct. 1. The merged practice will continue under the Lybrand, Ross Brothers name.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 7 (AP) Judy Kimball set a tournament record of 282 for 72 holes today in winning the $15,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association championship by four strokes. The old record of 285 was set by Louise Suggs in 1957.
The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale yesterday blamed "the sophisticated leaders" of the Protestant Church for the failure of a religious revival in the years since World War II.
The 100th anniversary of the founding of Robert College of Istanbul will be observed at a dinner Oct. 17 in the WaldorfAstoria.

The proposed Litho City Housing Development is expected to clear its first major hurdle tomorrow. The City Planning Commission is scheduled to approve the site as suitable for urban renewal.

HONOLULU, Oct. 7 William F. Quinn, Republican Governor of Hawaii, weathered a tough primary fight yesterday and will face a former Representative, John A. Burns, in the November election.

An unscheduled mystery guest appeared briefly on the television quiz show "What's My Line" last night. Just what his line was was not determined.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 7 New Jersey's First Congressional District has not been represented by a Democrat since 1885. Neil F. Deighan Jr., the party's nominee this year, hopes to end this tradition, but he is the first to concede the tremendous obstacles confronting him.

The Evangelical Dean of Berlin urged closer communication among Christians yesterday. He offered hope that the Roman Catholic Ecumenical Council, convening Thursday in Rome, will "widen the scope and range of brotherly conversation between the branches of Christianity."

IT takes thousands of marigold blossoms, black wal nuts, onion skins, peach leaves and small bugs to achieve some of the colors in the hand-woven wall hangings, rugs, blankets and pillow covers that now hang in the Museum of Contemporary Crafts. It is from these seemingly unusual sources that Alice Kagawa Parrott, a Hawaiian-born weaver who lives in Sante Fe, N.M., makes many of her dyes.

THANKS largely to the performance of the title role, the City Opera's third offering of the season, "Rigoletto," came off on Saturday night with scorching intensity. The mere part was taken by Louis Quilico. The cast also included Richard Verreau as the Duke, Nadja Witkowska as Gilda and Norman Treigle as Sparafucile.

Shrugging off the effects of a line drive that left him limping on a badly bruised leg, Bill Stafford yesterday hurled the New York Yankees to a 3-to-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants in the third game of the 1962 World Series.

After eight years of geological surveys, seismographic studies and soundings, the Italian Government is almost ready to invite bids for a two-mile bridge to connect the mainland with Sicily, that romantic but forlorn island of passion, poetry and violence.

The Institute of the Aerospace Sciences, Inc., has leased space for its editorial and research programs in 750 Third Avenue at 46th Street. Richard G. Dailey and Tom Brown of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., were the brokers. The Cross Brown Company is the agent for the building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --Dirk U. Stikker, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, underwent surgery at Walter Reed Hospital today. A portion of his colon, containing a tumor, was removed, the State Department said. "A moderately inflamed gall bladder" also was removed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --Five men reindicted for contempt of Congress after the Supreme Court overturned their convictions on a technicality have pleaded not guilty and made bond for trials.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., .Oct. 7-- Another running of the Kentucky Derby, this one political, is scheduled for Nov. 6, otherwise known as Election Day. And as they say in racing circles, President Kennedy has a bundle riding on the outcome of this one.

Chuck Hiller, the hero of yesterday's Giant's victory over the Yankees, did not succeed in baseball without trying. Chuck had to try very hard and suffered a lot of heartbreaks before he reached his current eminence.

THE names would look right putty on the doors" of a law office: "Haller and Hiller, Counselors at Law." They were rather persuasive pleaders for their clients, the San Francisco Giants, at Yankee Stadium yesterday. They didn't use high-powered oratory, though. They used high-powered bats.
WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 8--Taft School has a new football coach and a new style of attack. Judging from the way the Big Red eleven has started, the two changes have been agreeable.

Output of steel in the nation's mills decreased last week after three weeks of successive advances. The volume of metal poured in the seven days ended on Saturday receded from a total that had been the highest turned out since the week ended May 5.

The football Giants earned two days off this week and for three good reasons: They did well against the St. Louis Cardinals last Sunday; the high temperature during the game at St. Louis took its toll on the players, and the Pittsburgh Steelers, next on the schedule, are well enough known so that a day of practice could be skipped.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Ilija Choumenkovitch, former Yugoslav diplomat, died today in Mexico City, where he had been visiting his son, Milorad. He was 78 years old.

Mrs. Wilhelmina E. Hill, whose husband made a fortune building and repairing brewery wagons, left an estate of about $1,000,000, according to papers filed with her will yesterday in Bronx Surrogates Court.

High-scoring Texas, named the No. 3 major college football team a week ago, vaulted past Ohio State and Alabama yesterday into the top spot in the United Press International board of coaches' ratings.

Robert Pritchard gave a piano recital at Philharmonic Hall last night that confirmed the mixed impression he made in his debut in April, 1961. His playing combined a rhythmic musicality with a tonal insensitivity.

Republican voters in three Queens neighborhoods will find the polls open today for a special election of so little general interest that the police are not bothering to shut the local bars and liquor stores during voting hours.

First-quarter sales and earnings of Bloomfield Industries, Inc., are above comparable year-ago figures, Daniel Bloomfield, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday. Mr. Bloomfield said that in the three months ended Sept. 30, sales rose to about 1,575,000, from $1,335,339 in the preceding year. He gave no figures on how far earnings exceeded the $89,427, or 19 cents a share, reported a year ago.
Detectives last night arrested three men that they said had stolen hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of copper cable from building and utility construction sites in three states.

Registration for this year's state election starts today in New York City. It ended Saturday in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and several other counties using the permanent personal registration system.

The home run, long the hallmark of the New York Yankees' success, was turned on the Bombers yesterday with stunning effect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman hag set Oct. 15 to Dec. 14 as the period in which winter wheat farmers may sign up to reduce the acreage of this surplus crop under the Government's 1963 voluntary wheat program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--(AP) --The Army said today it will need about 19,400 officers this year.
Three confirmed cases of diphtheria and nine suspected cases among children in seven families in Brooklyn were reported yesterday by the City Health Department.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 8-- Richard D. Zanuck has been named the new head of production at the Twentieth CenturyFox Studio. The appointment was made last week in New York by the company's board of directors. His title is president's production representative.

LONDON, Oct. 8--The British Overseas Airways Corporation had a loss of 14,400,000 ($40,320,000) in the year that ended March 31, it was announced today, It was the largest deficit for any year in the airline's history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8, (AP) --The Supreme Court granted today a hearing to Marlo D. Green, a Negro who complains he had been discriminated against in his efforts to get a pilot's job with Continental Air Lines, Inc.
LONDON, Oct. 8--Miss Susan Dorothy Doughty, a ceramist whose works with birds have become collector's items in the United States, died yesterday in Truro Hospital at Cornwall Her age was 70.
DALLAS, Oct. 8 (UPI)-- --Former Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker will undergo psychiatric examination "either Thursday or Friday, probably Friday," one of his attorneys said today.
Supporters of the Austen Riggs Center in Stockbridge, Mass., are planning a benefit at the opening concert of the Leningrad Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall Oct. 21.
Fifty-seven Roman Catholic clergymen, including five Archbishops and 30 Bishops, left here by plane last night for Rome to attend the Ecumenical Council.
LONDON, Oct. 8--The British Foreign Office denied today that Britain was sending heavy arms into Yemen.
The Meadow Brook National Bank and the National Cash Register Company announced yesterday the installation of the NCR 315 automated banking system.
OSLO, Norway, Oct, 8--The Right Rev. Arne Fjellbu, retired Bishop of Trondheim and a prominent leader in the Church of Norway, died yesterday in a Frondheim hospital. He was 71 years old.
One Yankee pitcher--Whitey Ford--served up a home-run ball yesterday at the Stadium and didn't regret the pitch.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The Senate sent the compromise $3,928,000,000 foreign aid appropriation to the White House today.
WARSAW, Oct. 8--As winter approaches, rising prices and a tight food situation are exerting a heavy strain on Poland's overextended economy.
Robert Porterfield, founder and managing director of the Barter Theater of Abingdon, Va., announced yesterday the successful completion of a campaign to raise $30,000 in matching funds.

The 1962 research achieve ment award of the American Heart Association has been won by Dr. Maurice B. Visscher, Distinguished Service Professor and chairman of the physiology department at the University of Minnesota Medical School.
Top officers of the International Longshoremen's Association urged the association's 60,000 members in Atlantic and Gulf ports yesterday not to handle any cargo shipments to or from the Soviet Union.
Reiterated and insolent and insulting statements [about Cuba] have been made by Senators and Representatives of the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP)-- Health Minister Enoch Powell said today the British people did not seem to be very bright --they go right on smoking despite evidence that cigarettes cause lung cancer. Said Mr. Powell:
The CIBA Corporation has appointed Dr. Otto Neracher as a director and vice president, Dr. Victor Umbricht, president, announced yesterday.
A pioneer in the space systems and highly specialized communications equipment field makes a big move today.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (Reuters)-- The body of Dr. Robert A. Soblen will be cremated Thursday at Ruislip, near London. Soblen, a fugitive Soviet spy, died Sept. 11 after taking an overdose of drugs as he was about to be deported to the United States.
Joseph Curran made light yesterday of the merged labor movement's decision to permit the Seafarers International Union to raid his National Maritime Union.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Oct. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Ross Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Eliot Ross, to Richard Kithil Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kithil of Northford, Conn.

WHEN the Kinzua Dam in the Allegheny River floods the heartland of the Seneca Reservation in 1965, there is no reason to believe that the Indians will be adequately resettled. The engineering for the dam proceeds on an inexorable schedule, but there is no equivalent engineering for the victims.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused today to interfere with the large-scale tryout of pay television that began last June in Connecticut.
SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Oct. 8 (UPI)--The eight-and-a-halfyear dispute between the Kohler Company and the United Automobile Workers ended officially today.
Robert M. Morgenthau said last night that Governor Rockefeller was considering a state sales tax.

To get the most out of the current World Series a baseball fan really needs two media: a television set for for the pictorial scene of the San Francisco Giants and New York Yankees at work and a radio set to hear George Kell and Joe Garagiola explain the fine points of the game.
TAKOMA PARK, Md., Oct. 8 (AP)--Heber H, Votaw, superintendent of Federal prisons and chairman of the Federal Board of Parole from 1921 to 1925, died yesterday of cancer. His age was 81.

THE influx of foreign statesmen, businessmen and a growing number of tourists has made New York a city where the gift of tongues is a necessity, not a luxury. Many hotels have employes who can handle guests in their native idioms, and Sonia Verdonck of the Manhattan Hotel is dedicated solely to that purpose.
The City Rent and Rehabilitation Administration announced yesterday that the state and city had authorized it to hire 47 more rent inspectors at an annual cost of $228,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Agriculture Department has reported that the United States now leads the world in barring entry of unwanted plants, plant insects and pests.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8-- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower accused President Kennedy today of seeking "oneparty government" in his demands for more Democrats in Congress.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 8 --Barthelemy G. Lachelier, head of Lachelier Co., a New York concern representing French pharmaceutical companies, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital. He wad 64 years old.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 8--Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan said today that a recently issued report on riots here last February showed the "usual reluctance to attach blame to people of importance."
DAWN POWELL'S "The Golden Spur" is a murderously comic novel about avant-garde Bohemia's quaint and curious tribal ways.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Supreme Court granted Hawaii permission todaty to file a suit intended to give the state title to lands owned by the Federal Government in the islands if they were no longer needed for Federal purposes.

PARIS, Oct. 8--French industrial production has doubled in the last ten years and many Frenchmen are going to get pay increases as a result, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, Minister of Finances, said today.
HYANNIS, Mass., Oct. 8 (AP)--Officials of this Cape Cod town were called upon today to care for three new "reverse freedom riders" from the South, who arrived here penniless yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8--Two Federal deputy marshals, just back from Oxford, Miss., said today that Gov. Ross R. Barnett and the state police deserved all of the blame for last week's riots at the University of Mississippi over the admission of a Negro.
BONN, Oct. 8--The West German Government indicated today that it had dropped its objections to the establishment of an international authority to control access to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Oct.8 (AP)-- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision that workers were entitled to reemployment with full seniority rights when an employer moved his plant from one state to another.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Tuesday, Oct. 9--Uganda attained independence at midnight last night after 68 years under British rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The Supreme Court's affirmed today a Federal court's denial of a preliminary injunction that had been sought by two Negro couples against enforcement of new Congressional lines in Queens.
The unofficial "Mayor" of Harlem charged yesterday that Harlem was becoming "a dumping ground of rackets."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8-- Dr. Harold L. Goldburgh, a specialist in internal medicine, died Saturday in Jefferson Medical College Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old. His home and office were at 1932 Spruce Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) --Agriculture Department officials predict that lending by the Farmers Home Administration (F.H.A.) in fiscal 1963, will total about $782 million, to surpass substantially the fiscal 1962 record of $637 million.

The Robert Joffrey Ballet will make a 15-week tour of the Middle East and South Asia. The tour, which will be the company's first overseas trip, will be sponsored by the American National Theater and Academy as part of the Cultural Presentations Program of the United States.

WHAT molehill will they seek to convert into a musical mountain next? Some days ago the torrid epics of the South Sea paradises served as the butt of the joke. Last night at the Provincetown Playhouse the romantic, flagwaving musicals turned out by Hollywood in the forties were on the griddle.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8--Ah, victory, the divine inflatus. Having drunk deep of Fortune's happy cup last Saturday, the coaches and football gladiators of U.S.C. and U.C.L.A. were still in the clouds today over their triumphs over two of the Big Ten's best.

DETROIT, Oct. 8--Gov. John B. Swainson criticized George Romney, his Republican challerger tonight for failing to speak up last spring in support of a tax compromise program that the governor had worked out with a group of Republican moderates. Mr. Romney called for a citizen's revolution to capture control of the political process in Michigan, which, he said, was currently dominated by a labor union bloc.
The Mobilization for Youth campaign to curb juvenile delinquency will inaugurate its proposed $950,000 work program next Monday, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8--Ghana, urged today that the United Nations impose diplomatic and economic sanctions on South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8-- The Supreme Court agreed today to pass on the constitutionality of reciting the Lord's Prayer and verses from the Bible in public schools.
LENINGRAD, Oct. 8 (AP)-- Igor Stravinsky gave a lecture for more than 100 student composers today after a rehearsal with the Philharmonic Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that an employer might grant superseniority to replacements for strikers and to returning strikers if the purpose was to keep his plant operating.
HONOLULU, Oct. 8 (UPI)-- Secretary, of Defense Robert S. McNamara and two high Washington official's met with Pacific-area military commanders today to discuss the Communist drive in Southeast Asia.

A round-robin of imaginative speculation always is in order after a grand slam homer in the World Series. In fact, you may lose your membership in the Baseball Second Guessing Club if you can't readily explain why the usually reliable Marshall Bridges let Chuck Hitler knock in four runs with one swing of his bat in yesterday's game at the Stadium.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 8 --Earle Gatchell of High Point Road, a former partner of Hayden, Stone Co., stockbrokers in New York, died of a heart attack today while visiting relatives in Philadelphia. He was 71 years old.

Creation of the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center by the merger of the Bronx and Lebanon Hospitals was announced yesterday. The resulting institution has 610 beds, 94 bassinets and a staff of about 2,000 making it one of the city's largest voluntary hospitals.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 8-- Yemeni Royalist sources in Amman, Jordan, said today that Wadi Ahemd al-Siaghi had entered northern Yemen to join Prince al-Hassan, the claimant to the throne.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 8 (AP)--Secretary of State Dean Rusk accused the Soviet Union today of having sabotaged the original intent of the United Nations--a society of sovereign states cooperating in common interests and committed to world order.
ISOLISTI DI ZAGREB, one of Europe's finest small en sembles, gave a concert last night at Town Hall that was four parts baroque to one part modern.

A syndicate of New York realty investors has contracted to purchase the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 95 Christopher Street, northwest corner of Bleecker Street, in Greenwich Village. The deal was negotiated by the William K. Langfan Company, broker. The sale will be made for cash over mortgages amounting to $1,475,000.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

"Lola," a French-made romantic drama with Anouk Aimee and Marc Michel, will reopen the new D.W. Griffith Theater with its American premiere on Sunday. The theater's first tenant, "The Connection," was withdrawn under a court injunction when it opened there last Wednesday. The French import was written and directed by Jacques Demy and coproduced by Carlo Ponti and Georges de Beauregard. Films Around the World is the distributor.

Interest waned on the stock market yesterday, to bring trading to the lowest level in almost a year. Observance of Yom Kippur and the playing of the fourth game of the World Series were factors in helping depress sales on the New York Stock Exchange.
VARNA, Bulgaria, Oct. 8-- Bobby Fischer met the world chess champion, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Linion, last night in the Chess Olympics.

A November wedding is planned by Miss Rosemarie Rita Urbina and Louis Fernandez Jr. Mr. and Mrs. Albert Urbina of the Bronx have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernandez of Canton, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --Two Congressional investigations on the handling of applications for new drugs were taking shape today.
Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, was solemnly observed by Jews here and throughout the world yesterday.

SOME of the most popular ways to prepare potatoes, judging by the number of times they appear on restaurant menus, have a special appeal for home cooks. Delmonico, Lyonnaise and O'Brien potatoes all can be delicious when leftovers are used as their base.

SYNTHETIC fabrics have long been used by American man ufacturers of ready-to-wear. But many of the top designers remained aloof. Their attitude toward man-made fabrics has been like that of a French chef contemplating a frozen dinner. Now, however, even these designers have capitulated.
In Montclair, N.J., the other day, a housewife exclaimed angrily: "This thing has gotten all out of hand!"
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 8 (UPI)--James Walter Glenn, president of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company from 1946 to 1948, died at his home today of a heart attack. He was 80 years old.

MIAMI, Oct. 8--The food and medicine that will be delivered to the Cuban Government as ransom for the release of the 1,100 prisoners captured in the 1961 invasion will be shipped "in bulk did without labels," reports from Havana, said today.
From the standpoint of the family financial expert it is none too early to begin thinking about next year's taxes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Supreme Court struck down today a Virginia law that limited picketing during a strike to employes of the plant being picketed.
WASHINGTON, Oct., 8 (AP) --The Senate passed legislation today eliminating the fixed October filing date for the filing and publishing of annual reports by newspapers and magazines.
Construction will reach a rec ord high next year, it is forecast by the F.W. Dodge Corporation, construction news and marketing concern.
Governor Rockefeller continued his criticism yesterday of what he terms misstatements about the state government by Robert M. Morgenthau.
RAMSEY, N.J., Oct. 8-- Mahwah scored a 20-7 victory over Ramsey today and moved into a tie with River Dell for the Northern Bergen Interscholastic League lead.
THE ROYAL BOX, Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. Harry Belafonte, singer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --Twenty-two acres of the old Mitchel Air Force Base on Long Island may be made available as the site for a Catholic high school.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 8 --President Romulo Betancourt suspended constitutional guarantees today following a week of terrorist activity in this city and the interior.
CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 8-- The first letters bearing Bhutanese postage stamps will be cleared through the Himalayan kingdom's post offices at Paro and Funcholing on Wednesday.
Cardinal Spellman received a telegram yesterday from Pope John XXIII expressing relief that the Cardinal was safe after a bomb explosion at his residence last Saturday.
CARACAS, Oct. 8 (AP)-- President Romulo Betancourt, now in the fourth year of his five-year term, has frequently been forced to fight against threats to his Government, from leftists and rightists.
DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP)-- American automobile manufacturers plan to build 1,700,000 to 1,800,000 cars in the remaining weeks of 1962.

Uganda joins today the African countries that have achieved independence in recent years in swift succession. This green, sunlit land on the shores of Lake Victoria enters its new era of freedom with a good economy and a society and government based on democratic principles that should enable its 6,845,000 inhabitants to succeed in building a new nation.
DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 8 (AP.)--Dr. John W. McConnell, 54-year-old dean of Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, has been named president of the University of New Hampshire.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 8--Britain began a new round of difficult negotiations today for entry into the European Economics Community.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 8 (UPI)--Houdaille Industries, Inc., announced today it was asking stockholders to tender up to 200,000 shares of their common stock at a price of $18.75 a share.
The victim of a purse-snatching aided the police in capturing her assailant yesterday by luring him to a bowling alley in the Bronx on the pretext of going on a date.
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation announced yesterday the election of James M. Dunford as vice president in charge of nuclear construction for the Navy.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8-- (AP--Secretary of the Army Cyrus R. Vance said today the Army "will move strongly into the air" in the next 10 years.

ROME, Oct. 8--Pope John XXIII visited St. Peter's Basilica tonight and spent a half hour inspecting preparations in the hall where the 21st Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church will open Thursday.

With Willie Shoemaker riding four winners, including The Axe II in the first division of the Long Island Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, the crowd of 34,126 paid close attention, as indicated by the $3,178,467 they sent through the betting machines. But they were also mindful of the activities at Yankee Stadium.
Hans Sternik, former West Coast hotel executive, has been named managing director of the Madison Hotel, Washington's newest luxury hotel.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 8--Mrs. Rector T. Davol of Round Hill won the final one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association season today by shooting 38, 41--79 over the par-72 South course at Westchester Country Club. Mrs. J. Paul Sinnott of Wykagyl captured low net prize in the field of 76 with a score of 87--16--71.

SCARSDALE, N.Y. Oct. 8-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William A. Dolph of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Cynthia Dolph, to Bruce Arlen Kunkel. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Alton D. Kunkel of Newburyport, Mass.
ROME, Oct. 8--The violet and scarlet garb of prelates was conspicuous in the streets of Rome today as more and more ecclesiastics arrived for the Roman Catholic Church's Ecumenical Council.
ATLANTA, Oct. 8 (AP)-- The steady integration of Georgia colleges has spread to a fourth--Emory University, where an Atlanta Negro mother of four is enrolled in an adult class.
The combination of the World Series and a religious holiday diverted attention from the bond market yesterday.

For the first time the Patrolman's Benevolent Association has asked policemen to join a picket line. The policemen were urged to join in a demonstration at City Hall at 10 A.M. today to support the firemen's demand for higher pay and other benefits.

BOSTON, Oct. 8--"TchinTchin," a play by Sidney Michaels, based on a French play by Francois Billetdoux, began its tryout here Saturday night. The comedy-drama, which stars Margaret Leighton and Anthony Quinn, opens in New York on Oct. 29.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 8--The natural gas industry is keeping well ahead of the national economy. That was made clear here today in opening sessions of the forty-fourth annual convention of the American Gas Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --President Kennedy said today he was "most grieved" to learn of the death of Representative Miller in California.
The Light Opera Production Fund of the New York City Center was the beneficiary of the preview appearance by Harry Belafonte in the Royal Box at the Americana Hotel last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8--Anti-Castro demonstrators screamed denunciations today at President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado of Cuba in the General Assembly. Later, antiCastro and pro-Castro pickets clashed across the street from the Asembly Hall and 33 were arrested.
A United States Supreme Court action in Washington yesterday cleared the way for New York City to proceed with developing the projected $100,000,000 Flatlands Park in Brooklyn.

Chuck Hiller of the Giants, a downcast young man on Sunday after his weak double-play relay had let the Yankees score the winning run, happily heard the hero's accolade yesterday for having smashed the grandslam home run that evened the World Series.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 4-- In Indiana's senatorial campaign this fall there is more talk about Cuba than about the price of corn or the outlook for steel.
Stocks drifted down slightly yesterday in the slowest trading in almost a year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP)-- Corn futures declined, but soybeans rallied sharply in spirited trading today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --Senator John J. Williams said today that the Government entered into a contract for nickel, cobalt and copper in October, 1951, but did not insist on deliveries to the national stockpile when market prices for the materials advanced substantially.
Rumors of baseball changes were part of the World Series atmosphere as usual yesterday.
A State Supreme Court justice forbade the producers of "The Connection" yesterday to resume commercial showings of the unlicensed movie pending adjudication by the State Court of Appeals.

James J. Conway, president of New York Printing Pressmen's Union No. 51 from 1929 to 1933, died Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 3300 Pleasant Avenue, Weehawken, N.J.

WASHINGTON--Oct. 8--The Army started to withdraw regular troops from the Mississippi ahea today. The Pentagon also announced the release of a group of the National Guard that had been placed under Federal authority during the riots over integration at the University of Mississippi.

Bill Wright's 72-yard touchdown run with an intercepted pass earned the 225-pound Princeton senior tackle a spot on the weekly all-East major college football team released yesterday by the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

Theodore E. Plumridge Jr., an executive of A.M. Lerner Co, Inc., securities dealers at 15 William Street, and former professional football player, died Saturday night in his home at 9201 Shore Road, Brooklyn. He was 62 years old.
South Vietnam, where 20 American servicemen have died in defense of freedom, has become a battlefield proving ground for new weapons, tactics and equipment.
Improved demand for automotive equipment enabled the A.O. Smith Corporation to return to profitable operations in the fiscal year ended July 31, L.B. Smith, president, reported yesterday.

President Tito and Premier Khrushchev, two pragmatic Communists, have once again demonstrated how they can coexist without settling the fundamental problems that divide them. The formula seems to be: follow parallel paths toward those objectives on which we, as Marxists, can agree, and let us not quarrel too much about our disagreements.

America's "cultural explosion," a publicized phenomenon that has puzzled sociologists and disconcerted sybarites, will be the theme of "The Beauty Part," S.J. Perelman's first Broadway show in 19 years. It will open Dec. 26.

TRENTON, Oct. 8--Last year when Democrats talked of nominating Frank Thompson Jr. for Governor, President Kennedy let it be known that he considered the Representative too valuable to be spared from Congress.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that seven life insurance companies in the city had reaffirmed a policy of nondiscrimination in their executive-training programs.
AP MY DIEN, Vietnam, Oct. 7--"The enemy lives and fights like a swamp rat," said an American adviser to the Government forces here, "and there is only one way to fight him--the same way."
The October Ball, the first of a series of three subscription dances directed by Miss Audrey Winston, will take place Oct. 19 at the Sheraton-East.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8-- Prominent foreign authors, among them John Dos Passos, are exchanging views on modern writing here at the international conference of the Argentine P.E.N. Club.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 8 --King Mahendra, in a message to the nation today for the Hindu religious holiday of Dussrah, said the ancient friendly relations between Nepal and India might be hurt by the activities of Nepalese rebels who lived in India.
SANA, Yemen, Oct. 8--Yemen, a country veiled from the world and recently shaken by revolution, appears quiet now except in the far north.
LONDON, Oct. 8--British Government bonds fell sharply on the stock market today after an advance of several weeks.
A new 250-bed hospital is expected to be completed at Trujillo, Peru, next April, a Peruvian official on his way home said here yesterday.
Msgr. Anthony J. Rothlauf, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in the Yorkville section at 404 East 87th Street, died on Sunday at Columbus Hospital. His age was 78.
Arrangements were announced yesterday for the purchase by Korad Corporation of the physical assets of the applied physics laboratory department of Quantatron, Inc., Santa Monica, Calif.

Mrs. Barbour Walker Lyndon Hadley, former head of the Lyndon Service of Statistical Information on Advertising here, died Sunday in her home at 525 Park Avenue. She was 77 years old and the wife of Earl J. Hadley.

VIENNA, Oct. 8 (Reuters)-- Four Hungarian deputy ministers were sworn in today, the Hungarian press agency M.T.I. reported. The men and their departments are: Karoly Erdelyi, Foreign Affairs; Jeno Szilbereky, Justice; Janos Koeves, Food, and Laszlo Boros, Internal Trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) An examiner for the Federal Power Commission recommended today that the $190,600,000 Pacific Northwest Power Company be licensed to build its proposed High Mountain Sheep hydroelectric power plant on the Snake River between Idaho and Oregon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8--Once a flourishing kingdom under the Moors, Badajoz province in west central Spain had by 1952 achieved doubtful distinction as the country's most backward area. Since then, a $50,000,000 Government redevelopment program has wrought a metamorphosis.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Oct. 8-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Steinmetz of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce Marie Steinmetz, to Edwin N. Partikian. He is the son of Mrs. Nerses Partikian and the late Mr. Partikian.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 8-- Deputy Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach told students at the University of Mississippi Law School today "not to hope for a miracle" that would remove James H. Meredith from the campus.
Luncheon meeting, New York chapter, Society of Fire Protection Engineers, Masonic Club, 71 West Twenty-third Street, noon. "The Extinguishment of Fire," Walter M. Haessler.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8--President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado of Cuba called on the United Nations today to condemn the United States' "naval blockade" of Cuba.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 8--President Francois Duvalier replaced three Ministers and added the new post of Under Secretary of the Foreign Ministry today in reshuffling his sixteen-month old cabinet that submitted a collective resignation last night.

Women attending the Fan Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 9 will be expected to carry some type of fan, be it an heirloom, spectacular or unusual. The 13th annual event will benefit the Children's Cancer Fund of America.
Third-quarter profits of Radio Corporation of America rose 66 per cent this year as sales increased 12 per cent over the comparable 1961 period.

Twenty acres zoned for industrial use at New Durham and Talmadge Roads in Edison, N.J., have been purchased by New Durham Industrial Park, Inc., which will construct general manufacturing plants to specifications of tenants. The land was sold by the United Principal Investment Corporation, which was represented by Terrence Brenner. The Archie Schwartz Company of Newark was the broker.

Jewelry and a suit of clothes, with a total value of $2,000, were stolen Sunday from an automobile belonging to John D. Rockefeller 3d. The car was being driven by his son, John D. Rockefeller 4th, a nephew of Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The court order directing admission of James H. Meredith to the University of Mississippi was left standing today by the Supreme Court.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Oct. 8 (AP)--The suspension of three weekly newspapers with a combined circulation of 15,000 and a large volume of printing business was announced today by the Magee Publishing Company, here.
Edwin H. Zimmerman, a restaurateur for more than 40 years, died Sunday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived at 41-40 Denman Street, Elmhurst, Queens.
The player pool for the 1962 World Series amounted to $863,281.71, the third largest in the span of 59 Series.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Commerce Department says it will insist on balanced transportation planning before approving highway funds for urban areas.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 8 (AP)--Ricky, a German shepherd dog condemned to die for sheep killing, lost an appeal today in the state Supreme Court. The state's highest tribunal denied a rehearing of the appeal that resulted in a 4-3 decision upholding the sentence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Nearly a month ago Associate Justice Black ordered the University of Mississippi to enroll a Negro, James Meredith, at the opening of the current semester, on the general ground the justice knew as a fact the state's pending appeal to the Supreme Court for formal, final review of the issue would be dismissed without a hearing when his judicial brethren reassembled.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 (AP)--United States Commissioner Reginald H. Carter Jr. 69 years old, was found shot in his office today. He was in critical condition from a head wound which the police said apparently was self-inflicted.
Stirling Moss, the British racing driver, disclosed yesterday that he had received a summons for speeding while driving here from Watkins Glen, N.Y., Sunday night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8--Prof. George P. Baker has been named dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. He had been serving as acting dean since March following the retirement of Dean Stanley F. Teele.

BERLIN, Oct. 8--The United States, Britain and France protested to the Soviet Union today against the barring of a British military ambulance by East Berlin on Saturday. The Russians refused to accept the protest.
Nurses and members of the staff of St. Vincent's Hospital extinguished 125 imaginary fires yesterday to learn how to put out a real one.
Coach Jordan Olivar of Yale contends that three-platoon football creates better team spirit and permits more players to compete.

Watching economic statistics threatens to become as popular a pastime as following the baseball averages. What Willie Mays does with the hat and Whitey Ford with the ball can be computed with precision. But this does not apply to the Government's statistics on employment and unemployment. They are estimates derived from a sampling, and while extremely useful and reliable, they are still evaluations.

The observance of the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur and interest in the fourth game of the World Series combined yesterday to bring futures trading on New York commodity exchanges to a near standstill.
RICHMOND, Oct. 8 (AP)-- The Virginia Supreme Court upheld today the death sentence imposed on Melvin Davis Rees Jr.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The Labor Department has counted 452,000 more union members. It had known that they existed, but not how many.
A New York printer, Frank Strauss, decided in 1884 that theater programs held an interesting potential as an advertising medium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture estimated today the year's cotton crop at 14,675,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight.
ALL sorts of odd and totally absorbing information flows across the desk of an outdoors writer. It's usually buried like diamonds in a depressing bulk of dross.

DURING the last four weeks, Cassandra Human, 18 years old, of Amanzimtoti, South Africa, bought her first pair of Bermuda shorts and sneakers and has been accepting dates from boys her own age. Catherine Tarride, 17, of Bordeaux, has tried (and failed) to acquire a taste for milk, has earned her first baby-sitting fees and learned to make her bed and to set the table.

A high-speed machine said to be capable of closing metal cans at rates exceeding 1,300 emits a minute, 30 per cent faster than existing ones, was announced yesterday by the Canco division of the American Can Company.
The American Academy of Arts and Letters announced yesterday that it will terminate its literary fellowships to the American Academy in Rome when the terms of the present incumbents have expired.

YONKERS, Oct. 8--Su Mac Lad, the biggest money winning trotter in history with $522,849, today drew post position No. 2 and was made the 2-1 early favorite over seven other star United States trotters slated to race in the 13th $46,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway on Thursday.

The Studebaker Corporation yesterday completed its purchase of Trans International Airlines, Inc., Burlingame, Calif., a carrier of air freight and military personnel. The acquisition was made for an undisclosed amount of Studebaker stock, valued at around $10,000,000 in one trade source estimate.
MR. KENNETH, a wellknown hair stylist in this country, is now coiffing for charity.
ROME, Oct. 9 (UPI) A Protestant scholar from the United States said today the he believed the Ecumenical Council would lead toward "Common Market-type" ties between Roman Catholics and Protestants.
A total of 21,753 persons braved the rain yesterday to register at polling places. It was the first day of registration in the city for the Nov. 6 elections.

Bertin C. Gamble, a Minneapolis store chain operator, yesterday seated himself and an associate on the 10-man board of the Alleghany Corporation, and said he hoped to restore peace to the big railroad holding company.
Several of the eight supplemental airlines grounded by the Civil Aeronautics Board indicated yesterday that they would take their case to court.

MORE than 50 years ago the nullo bid was invent ed for bad card holders in bridge: A player with a bad hand could bid nullo as a contract to lost tricks. Every trick he contrived to make his opponents win counted as a trick for him.
YONKERS, Oct. 9--Julienne of Sweden and Ordeal of New Zealand were entered today in the $45,000 Transoceanic Trot at Yonkers Raceway Oct. 18.

PARIS. WOMEN who care for their personal beauty are likely to care about beautiful objects and furniture. It is on this premise that Le Grain de Beaute, a combination antiques shop and beauty salon, operates.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 9 Capt. Viola M. McDonough, United States Army Medical Corps, died last Wednesday in the United States Veterans Hospital in Martinsburg, W, Va. A lifelong resident of this city, she was 59 years old.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 9 Dr. Webster Stover, a retired college president, and his wife, Marion, were held in criminal contempt in State Supreme Court here today for not obeying an order to remove lines of old clothes from the front yard of their home in Rye.
The Citizen's Union gave its "highly qualified and preferred" rating yesterday to one Republican, one Liberal and three Democratic candidates for the State Supreme Court.
The New Haven Railroad has decided not to seek any more fare increases, according to William J. Kirk, one of the line's trustees.
WARSAW, Oct. 9--Poland and East Germany began economic talks today in preparation for a goodwill visit by Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist party chief, to East Berlin next week.

When the press agent for New York's Americana hotel hired a circus elephant not long ago to shower champagne upon the new structure, this Barnumesque act reflected a new trend in hotel advertising and promotion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today the United States would work for the economic and social development of "the oppressed people of Cuba" if they were freed from Communist rule.

The game of musical chairs between Alabama and Ohio State is over. It could be a long time before the highly touted Buckeyes again are in the running for the No. 1 spot in The Associated Press's weekly football poll.
LONDON, Oct. 9 Prices declined in nearly every section on the stock market today.
The city dedicated four rehabilitated brownstones on West 94th Street yesterday for low-rent, public housing.
KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro told a wildly applauding crowd in Havana tonight that Cuba would never break her ties with the Soviet Union.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 9 Apollo Milton Obote is usually photographed with a pipe in his mouth the image of a quiet, reflective statesman, a cool, almost elegant figure.
The rejection of all four bids on a contract for maintaining most of New York City's parking meters was announced last night by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.

Earnings of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., in the 26 weeks ended Aug. 25, declined 2.9 per cent from those of the corresponding half of the preceding fiscal year, according to the semi-annual report yesterday of Ralph W. Burger, president.
The Prudential Insurance Company has given new status to its 26 vice presidents and 34 second vice presidents, according to an announcement yesterday by Orville E. Beal, president since Oct. 1.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 9 (UPI) The American Legion today presented its highest award its distinguished service medal to retired Gen. Lucius D. Clay and the late Dr. Thomas A. Dooley.

Certainly no price is too high to pay for the right to enjoy full American citizenship. Yet, when it comes to forfeiting one particular right or privilege in order to receive another right or privilege, it is quite possible to get the bad end of the bargain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Sekou Toure, the President of Guinea, will come to Washing ton tomorrow to lunch with President Kennedy and to renew an acquaintance that began two years ago.

SHORTLY before the scheduled start of yesterday's fifth game of the World Series, Bill Dickey threw out what was to be the first ball for the benefit of photographers. It was the only ball tossed all day. The Yankee Hall of Famer advanced into the drizzle to make his symbolic peg and then returned to shelter. But the rain had nowhere to go except down. And down it came with relentless persistency.
Twenty-one of the 33 persons arrested on charges stemming from a riot outside the United Nations Monday appeared in Criminal Court yesterday.
About 2,500 to 3,000 off-duty policemen and firemen ringed City Hall Park yesterday in a picket line that marched in the rain for three and one-half hours.
LONDON, Oct. 9 A British Admiralty civil servant was quoted today as having said he had been blackmailed into passing secret documents to Soviet agents.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct 9 Africa's newest nation refused today to recognize South Africa and the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland and hinted similar diplomatic rejection of Portugal "very soon."
The wave of terrorism that has been sweeping over Caracas and other Venezuelan cities for some weeks has a dangerous political content and purpose.
Ray Dudley, a Canadian pianist who made his New York recital debut in Town Hall seven year's ago, appeared last night in Philharmonic Hall, offering an uncompromising program.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 9 (UPI) Three high school boys said today that they had tricked Secret Service guards, deceived Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and bluffed President Kennedy into greeting them as "German exchange students."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 Three of the largest oil companies in the nation were accused today of violating the Federal antitrust laws.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 9 (UPI) Southern School News reported today that nine public colleges in Southern and border states had voluntarily desegregated since May.
Cotton futures were unchanged to $3.20 a bale down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Many voices are clamoring for tax reform, but the only reform that most taxpayers seem to favor is a cut in taxes. Even on this issue there is considerable disagreement over the size and nature of any reduction.

The General Electric Company yesterday reported increased sales and earnings for the three-month and ninemonth periods ended Sept. 30, as compared with those of the previous year. Ralph J. Cordiner, board chairman, pointed out, however, that if the third quarters of the two years were compared, the 1962 increases were not as great as those for the full nine months.
The first break is expected within ten days in the investigation by a special grand jury into alleged bill-padding and other crimes in public construction jobs in the state.
Grants totaling $6,100,000 to strengthen nine professional nonprofit repertory theaters from coast to coast were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
Differences in heredity can produce profound differences in the way a person reacts to a drug, a speaker told a conference sponsored by the New York Acedemy of Sciences yesterday.

The widening of 36th and 37th Streets between Madison and 11th Avenues has enabled them to handle more traffic and cut travel time through the garment center, Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan reported yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 Yugoslav sources said today that a sharp struggle was under way in the Communist party of neighboring Bulgaria over deStalinization.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 The Soviet Union has stationed new twinengine fighter planes at a military field in East Germany close to a Berlin air lane.
Shipments of finished steel products direct from mills in the first eight months of 1962 came to 49,379,993 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
