PARIS, Oct. 9 Sylvia Beach, the bookshop owner who made literary history in 1922 when she became the first to publish James Joyce's "Ulysses," was found dead last Saturday in her apartment at 12 Rue de l'Odeon. She was 75 years old.

THERE are many reasons why the Rank Organisa tion and Paul Czinner can be proud of their film of "Der Rosenkavalier," but few of them have to do with the art of the motion picture as such. Nor, indeed, does it seem to have been their concern to create a work of cinematic art. They have created a superb document, one in which the artistic content of the original object overrides any other considerations.

The Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club will benefit from the Bourbon Ball, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 1. Mrs. William H. Woodward is honorary chairman for the third annual event, which is sponsored by the Bourbon Institute.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. Dr. C. Allaines of France yesterday described a series of operations in which the hearts had been removed from animals and later replaced without causing death to the animals.

WHEN Mrs. Benjamin Partridge cooks, she often gives only half her attention to the job at hand. As she works, her mind is busy on the plots of the children's novels that she writes under the name of Cora Cheney.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--Passage of the foreign aid bill means that the United States can join formally in the special 10-country agreement for enlarging the International Monetary Fund, and that the enlargement becomes a fact.
WASHINGTON. In the second session of the 87th Congress, one man in particular has emerged in a new significant light.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (UPI) Soybean futures declined today on the Board of Trade. Grains were mixed after rallying from an early downturn.

LONDON, Oct. 9--An inquest into the death of Dr. Robert A. Soblen, the convicted Soviet spy, concluded today that he had committed suicide by taking an overdose of barbiturate made in the United States.
BOSTON, Oct. 9 The supermarket system of distribution is the key to a higher standard of living for more Americans, a leader in the supermarket and discount store fields asserted here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 The United States is reporting to the United Nations all its launchings of what the Russians call "spy satellites."
Fifteen New Yorkers representing industry, labor, the professions and public agencies banded together yesterday to provide job advancement opportunities for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

The electric utilities have been gaining some outspokenly enthusiastic adherents among stock market analysts, for a reason quite different from the ones that used to be offered for buying their shares.
Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson, in a nonpartisan speech here last night, denounced politicians of the "hatred" school as extremists trying to divide the nation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had clamped down on illegal importations from Canada of a homemade "cure" for arthritis.
ON Feb. 24, 1809, Richard Brinsley Sheridan was called away from his seat in the House of Commons by the news that the Drury Lane Theater, which he owned, was on fire.
Three campaign debates of an hour each between major candidates for Congress in this area will be presented by WCBS-TV, it was announced here yesterday.

In Laos the Communists have resorted to the old, familiar stratagem of charging the opposition with the transgression of which they are guilty. Official Communist organs in Peking and Hanoi declare that the United States and its allies still surreptitiously maintain military personnel in Laos in violation of Geneva Conference commitments that all foreign military men were to be withdrawn from the kingdom by last Sunday.
Governor Rockefeller helped drive a pile into the ground at the New York World's Fair site yesterday, thus officially starting work on the proposed New York State pavilion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Executive branch of the Government served notice today that it would oppose the Na tional Labor Reltaions Board's effort to establish its jurisdiction over certain foreign-flag vessels.

Robert M. Morgenthau announced last night that Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson would make several campaign appearances in New York State later this month on behalf of Mr. Morgenthau himself and others on the Democratic state ticket.
BELGRADE, Oct. 9 (AP) Dr. Milan Vidmar, scientist and theoretician in electrotechnology, died today at Ljubljana. He was 77 years old.
ROME, Oct. 9 Vatican officials have not given up hope that the Russian Orthodox Church will send observers to the Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholia Church, which opens Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Congressional leaders, after meeting with President Kennedy today, set Thursday night as the new target date for adjournment.
TAIZ, Yemen, Oct. 9 Except for occasional tribesmen carrying transistor radios, Yemen might be said to be on the farside of the Middle Ages.
The world sugar market is in "a state of anarchy" and an effective new International Sugar Agreement must be reached, a leading spokesman for the industry declared here yesterday.
Channel 7 will televise an hour of news each weekday from 6 to 7 P.M. starting Oct. 22.

Stone and wooden sculpture and a selection of Chinese jades, bronzes and porcelain, dating from the sixth century through the Sung period, are on exhibit at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street.
The election of Dorsey Richardson as president of the Investment Company Institute, trade association of the mutual fund industry, is expected to be announced next week.
PARIS, Oct. 9 The Paris Opera, adrift in a sea of trouble, made its first new presentation of the season last night with a new director at the helm.
Paul van Zeeland, Belgian Minister of State, predicted yesterday that Britain would become a member of the European Economic Community.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 9 A 37-year-old lawyer who lost his first bid for public office last year to a Republican by a narrow margin is the Democrats' choice this year to unseat Representative Peter Frelinghuysen Jr. in New Jersey's Fifth Congressional District.
Frank Kenna returned to active control of the Queens County Republican organization last night with his election as chairman of the party's county executive committee.
Now that Darryl F. Zanuck has definitively documented the Army's European campaign on D-Day, Otto Preminger has decided to assume command of naval operations in the Pacific.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Cuba is now dividing not only the political parties within the nation but the nations within the Western alliance.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP)--Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. and Maj. L. Gordon Cooper Jr. flew here today and Commander Schirra told newsmen, "I hope soon to be working for Gordon."
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 9 A nine-passenger hydrofoil boat zipped around rains-spattered yachts moored in Oyster Bay Harbor this morning at speeds of more than 30 knots.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 A major build-up of Katanga's air power was reported today by Robert K.A. Gardiner, the chief United Nations officer in the Congo.

THE make-up goal for every woman should be her own individual and natural look, according to Mr. Francois of Revlon. The make-up expert has created morning, afternoon and evening versions of what is called a Nearly Natural Look for Henri Bendel, where it will be introduced on Monday.

John Bartlow Martin, United States Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, and Mrs. Martin of Santo Domingo have announced here the marriage of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Ann Martin, to Anthony Valentine Macdonald Campbell.
Cambodia's Mission to the Unites Nations has leased space in the office building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 845 Third Avenue, corner of 51st Street.
The market for state and municipal bonds reflected pent up demand yesterday and resulted in the strongest day for these issues in several months.
Three five-story apartment buildings in the Bronx at 1980 Prospect Avenue, 1777 Bryant Avenue and 2009 Bryant Avenue have been sold in a package deal by the 1980 Prospect Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Nicolae Malaxa's attorney said tonight the Government had investigated three times and found false accusations that the 69-year-old Rumanian had Nazi and later Communist connections in his native land.

CAIRO, Oct. 9 While otherneighbors of Yemen are standing aloof or striking hostile poses, the United Arab Republic is playing big brother to the country, which recently overthrew the monarchy and set up a republic.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 Plans to end all hard labor underground in the Soviet coal industry by mechanization and other modern methods were disclosed here today by a high Government official.
Informants planted in the Communist party by the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified here yesterday on their findings and pay.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 9 James H. Meredith charged today that Army units in the Oxford area had been "resegregated."

KAWANA, Japan, Oct. 9 (AP) The third world amateur golf tournament opens tomorrow. Talk of an American runaway has all but disappeared at this rugged, panormic golfresort spread out in the shadow of Mount Fuji on the shores of the Pacific.
A biologist, a Brooklyn mother and a chemist have learned to live with a disease that most people fear: cancer.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 9 The chairman of the Federal Power Commission predicted here today that consumers could expect "substantial stability for quite a while [in their gas rates]."
FOR some years now it has been known that the wild mountain lakes and rivers along the Argentine-Chilean border held trout of heroic size.
Dr. Ann Anthony, dean emeritus of students at Hunter College, died yesterday in her summer home at Stinson Lake, N.H. She was 76 years old and lived at 5 Stuyvesant Oval here.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 8 When Maryland's organization Democrats count their blessings these days, they start with the Republicans.
DETROIT, Oct. 9 George Romney, Republican nominee for Governor, and Gov. John B. Swanson, seeking re-election, engaged in a verbal wrangle tonight on whether Michigan was going forward or backward.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 9 Chancellor Adenauer implied today that West Germany would take no initiative on the Berlin question so long as the Soviet Union sticks to its hard policy.
ROME, Oct. 9 Most of the 240 members of the American hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church who will participate have arrived in Rome to await the opening Thursday of the Ecumenical Council.
Cocoa futures tumbled in active trading to highlight a genenally quiet and firm day on the New York Commodity Exchanges.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 9 The Conservative party assembled here tonight for its annual conference confident that it could win the next general election if Britain succeeded in gaining membership in the European Economic Community, or the Common Market. The conference opens tomorrow.

DALLAS, Oct. 1 Super-patriotic, militantly conservative groups still flourish in Texas despite an apparent decline in the John Birch Society and the sobering arrest of a leading activist, Edwin A. Walker, on charges of rebellion, insurrection and seditious conspiracy.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 The $17,500,000 Grace Line passenger-cargo ship Santa Maria was launched here today at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point shipyard.

PARIS, Oct. 9 Speeches by Christian Fouchet, Gaullist Minister of Information, and Gaston Monnerville, President of the Senate, unofficially opened today the French political battle that will reach its climax Oct. 28.
Governor Rockefeller accused Robert M. Morgenthau yesterday of waging a "mudslinging" campaign.
Marcel Pelletier, a heads-up goalie who will back up Lorne (Gump) Worsley of the New York Rangers this season, was most uncooperative last night as hockey returned to Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)--The French Foreign Minister, Maurice Couve de Murville, conferred for an hour and 15 minutes with President Kennedy today on the problems of Berlin, Laos, the Congo and Cuba.
The regional head of the Federal Aviation Agency refused yesterday to restore to a Queens area an air traffic pattern near Idlewild Airport that was recently shifted to a Brooklyn area.

Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union was quoted yesterday by one of India's elder statesmen as having said that the Russians could not "afford the expense" of underground nuclear testing.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 9 (AP) The Venezuelan Government seized two Leftist newspapers today and imposed censorship on the rest of the country's papers and televisionradio stations.

Low storm clouds threw a blanket of darkness over the city around 9 A.M. yesterday. The eerie gloom remained for most of the day. Thunder showers during the morning and an intermittent drizzle during the afternoon combined to wash out the fifth game of the World Series.
The fifth game of the World Series, scheduled to be played yesterday, was rained out.
LONDON, Oct. 9 Dame Edith Sitwell joined 3,000 admirers tonight in a formal celebration of her 75th birthday.
Coach Allie Sherrnan of the New York Giants predicted yesterday that "if we're lucky enough" the Giants would get into the National Football League championship game against the Green Bay Packers.

In 2 minutes 6 seconds Sonny Liston, a man with a past, became the world heavyweight boxing champion and it was all over but the investigations. Now Liston apparently is avoiding them as he did Floyd Patterson's hook.

THE average home kitchen may well benefit from the experimental research that is being conducted for handicapped persons at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York University Medical Center.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 9 State officials pigeonholed today plans for the collection of $1,800,000 a year in extra tolls on two parkways in Westchester County.

THE Kohon String Quartet embarked last night on a series of three concerts devoted to the string quartets of Antonin Dvorak at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Three works were played, and two of them were listed as first American performances.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP) References to Governor Rockefeller's former wife have been eliminated from an official history of the Executive Mansion. The history has been updated to cover a fire on the night of March 2 that destroyed the interior and to tell of the subsequent restoration.

ROME, Oct. 9 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox bodies, under the aegis of the World Council of Churches, have their own definition of "ecumenical." It is not to be confused with the "ecumenical councils" of the Roman Catholic Church, the 21st of which opens here Thursday.
OTTAWA, Oct. 9 The support of the Social Credit party enabled Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's minority Conservative Government to survive another challenge tonight from the Liberal Opposition.

INDIAN summer is everywhere in Manhattan, but a holiday mood pervades F.A.O. Schwarz, which will mark its 100th Christmas this year. For the event, the store has collected American and European antique toys, as well as many designs made exclusively for Schwarz.
A new trial was ordered yesterday to determine whether a man had the right to withdraw the entire balance from a Savings account he held jointly with his estranged wife.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 9 The Jordanian radio reported from Amman today that Royalist troops were "on the way to liberate Sana," the capital of Yemen.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 Premier Ahmed Ben Bella of Algeria told the General Assembly today that Algeria's primary aim was to help eliminate colonialism.
DETROIT, Oct. 9 The slow driver is a far greater menace than the fast driver, the American Automobile Association was told today.
Johnny Rotz was sharp leaving the starting gate with Vital Force in the second section of the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. This sharpness enabled him to break in front and stay there.

Disappointment was etched on thousands of rain-swept faces in Yankee Stadium yesterday and most conversations in the grandstand as well as in the dugouts dealt principally with the foul weather that postponed the next moment of truth in the World Series.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) Critics here gave rough handling to the musical "Fiorello!" and its British cast in its premiers last night.
John T. Fetherston, civil engineer and former Commis sioner of Street Cleaning, died yesterday at his home in Lewisburg, Pa. His age was 88.
BEHIND the practiced violence of football, which has as its first requirement a total disregard for bodily wellbeing, there must be successful strategy and tactics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Treasury sold $2,500,000,000 of one-year bills today at discounts averaging 2.969 per cent. The bills were sold to replace a $2,000,000,000 issue maturing Oct. 15. Thus, the Treasury raised $500,000,000 of new cash in the process.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 9 Dr. Charles Dane of 410 West End Road here, a physician and surgeon for half a century before he retired in 1961, died yesterday. He was 76 years old.
A detective and a policewoman pretending to be newlyweds eager to see a World Series game, arrested a suspected ticket scalper yesterday, it was reported at police headquarters.
A number of American businessmen are expected to make exploratory trips to Nigeria soon, according to Dr. M.I. Okpara, Premier of Eastern Nigeria.
VIENNA, Oct. 9 (AP) The Bulgarian Communist party has decided to grant its members "full freedom of opinion in all party matters," the party's major newspaper said in an issue received here today.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it had improved subway service, reduced costs and attracted more riders by its carpurchasing program.

A strike of social workers in the City Department of Welfare that had been scheduled to begin this morning was averted last night when most of the workers gave preliminary approval to a new offer by the city.
The Chase Manhattan Bank has filed applications with the New York State Banking Board and the Federal Reserve Board to open a second branch in the Dominican Republic.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 9 One firm prediction can be made about the outcome of the campaign in New Jersey's Sixth Congressional District a woman will be elected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) The president of the Hanna Mining Company testified today that Hanna's stockpile profits were larger, but "not a great deal larger," than its earnings on commercial sales.
A comedienne has been found for the central role in "The Unfair Sex." She is Carol Burnett, former hatcheck girl, who will attain stardom in her second local appearance.
PARIS, Oct. 9 One owner has rejected and one has accepted the challenge thrown down yesterday by Jack Price, the trainer of the American colt, Carry Back.
SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 9 (AP)--Somerset County prosecutor Arthur S. Meredith said today he had found a bit of evidence that might have important bearing on the famous Hall-Mills murder case.

SINCE television first came on the scene in the late nineteen-forties great improvements have been made in picture reception but the problems of the audio components have been blithely ignored by the manufacturers, for whom TV is fundamentally a visual medium.

Achieving color harmony between rooms that open into each other can be difficult for do-ityourself decorators. But there are a number of ways to handle this problem, according to the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association.
ROME, Oct. 9 Vatican and Italian police officials put final touches today on a citywide security plan due to go into effect tomorrow, the eve of the Roman Catholic Church's Ecumenical Council.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 9 Seven Western states have signed the Columbia Basin Interstate Compact. They hope through it to establish a framework for resolving common problems and developing the 1,200-mile Columbia River.
The retirement of Frank J. Starzel as general manager of The Associated Press was announced yesterday. He has been the chief executive officer of the news service for 14 years.

The current session of Congress, wearily moving toward adjournment this week, has flown some little noticed danger flags against further centralization in the Pentagon. McNamara.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Army reported in unusual detail today on its counterguerrilla warfare activities, noting both successes and failures.
The Port of New York Authority sold $25,000,000 of various purpose term bonds yesterday in competitive bidding.

ROME, Oct. 9 The traveler to Iznik, once called Nicaea and today a sleepy Turkish village, is invariably taken to the ruined basilica where Christendom's first Ecumenical Council was convened by the Emperor Constantine in A.D. 325.

Stocks struggled upward in late trading yesterday, erasing small declines that came earlier in the day.

Earnings of the American Electric Power Company in the 12 months ended Sept. 30 exceeded $60,000,000, equal to $2.75 a share, Donald C. Cook, president, reported to stock holders at a special meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 John H. Rubel, Assistant Secretary of Defense, replied today to complaints that the United States was not spending enough for military space activities.

David H. Jaquith, Conservative party candidate for Governor, criticized Governor Rockefeller's record on education last night. He accused Mr. Rockefeller of failing to properly supervise state educational expenditures.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 9 (AP) Tod Browning, who directed scores of Hollywood movies for many years until 1939, died Saturday. He was 80 years old.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 The New York City Ballet opened its eight-week tour of the Soviet Union here tonight at the Bolshoi Theater, and added at least two items to the history of that beautiful house with all its red and gold excitement.

Three persons, including a woman Internal Revenue Service supervisor, were under arrest yesterday on charges of filing fraudulent income tax returns that may have cost the Government more than $100,000 in tax refunds.
DENVER, Oct. 9 General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower turned his Western tour into a counterattack against the Administration today. He spoke disparagingly of its "callow youth."

The Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday reductions in the wholesale prices of ground coffees, touching off similar moves by other companies. The General Foods move cut its prices to the lowest levels in 13 years.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. Oct. 9 The engagement of Miss Emily Rebecca Alber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David O. Alber, to Peter A. Cerreta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emidio Cerreta, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A summer wedding is planned.

JIM HALL, the young Midland, Tex., star who had to sit out the Grand Prix of the United States at Watkins Glen, N.Y., last Sunday, is hoping for better luck the coming weekend in the Grand Prix for Sports Cars at Riverside, Calif.

The movement to make a 1,400-acre beachfront park of the western end of the Rockaway peninsula in Queens has, after a late start, picked up an astonishing array of influential people and civic organizations.

A total of 44,066 persons regsitered for the Nov. 6 election yesterday, bringing the twoday figure in the city to 65,819.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 10 --The picture was a fa miliar one as Hotchkiss School's football squad concentrated on defensive work today for its date with Trinity-Pawling next Saturday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 10-- Legislation dealing with noise abatement, reflective license plates, the use of seat belts in school buses and daylight saving time are expected to be introduced in the next session of the Legislature.
The Juilliard School will present Retrospective Festival made up of the music of 1912-13, in a four-concert series at its concert hall next February.

Progress has been made in the inspection by the city of tower cranes used at building sites, according to Paul R. Screvane, President of the City Council. He said the increasing height of the cranes and their involvement in fatal accidents had become the cause of considerable concern.

For stocks and bonds Brooklyn "offers a better field than Wall Street." So said The Brooklyn Daily Eagle on Sept. 25, 1892. In those days there was active trading on Brooklyn's Montague Street stock exchange.
Heavy loads of merchandise for the Christmas market arrived here by ship and air last month, sending monthly customs collections above $60,000,000 for the first time this year.

Attorney General Kennedy has just reiterated the Administration view that we are likely to "face a great crisis in Berlin in the weeks ahead." The Russians certainly give every indication of preparing for it. They hurl ever more dire threats of atomic annihilation against the West unless we get out of Berlin. They are building up their forces around Berlin. They are preparing their own public for a coming showdown.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Oct. 10-- The Gertz Department Store opened a new split-level branch here today for two days of private selling to charge customers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- Sekou Toure, President of the African Republic of Guinea, conferred with President Kennedy for two hours today in an atmosphere of unusual cordiality. Mr. Toure said later he had invited the United States to expand its aid and economic ...
The Country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday declined 920,000 barrels, accord ing to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute.
Samuel S. Flug, a partner in the investment management firm of Flug Strassler Associates, died yesterday at his home, 78 Exeter Street in Brooklyn, at the age of 57.

The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation has reduced the base price on certain grades of stainless steel sheets and plates from 1 to 1 cents, a pound. It also is cutting certain extra charges on sheets and plates.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 10--President Kennedy changed campaign tactics tonight by accentuating the positive, and virtually eliminating the negative record of the present Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--President Kennedy signed a new drug bill today that he said would help to provide safe and more effective drugs to the American people.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- Retail sales slipped in September for the second month in a row, the Commerce Department estimated today. It said that reduced sales of automobiles were the principal cause.
PARIS, Oct. 10--The $150,000 challenge race between Carry Back and five of the horses that beat him in the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe last Sunday will not take place.

The Soviet Union has proposed to the General Assembly of the United Nations that it consider the possibility of organizing a world trade conference. Seemingly a routine matter, the fundamental importance of this proposal was lost upon those who are immersed in the more spectacular and dramatic moves and countermoves in the East-West struggle.

ROSALYN TURECK was back at Town Hall last night, playing Bach's "Goldberg" Variations on the piano. The artist was at her best, and during the uninterrupted hour and 25 minutes that she spent unfolding the masterpiece, the auditorium was a sublime place to be.
A witness in a robbery case who declined to answer questions was held in contempt of court yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.

The Board of Estimate approved informally yesterday a proposal under which uniformed patrolmen and firemen would receive wage increases and other benefits totaling $650 that would make their top pay $7,980 a year.
A juror who allegedly tried to telephone a defendant in a case to tell him he was voting for an acquittal was indicted here yesterday.
The Kratter Corporation, a real estate and investment company, reported yesterday substantially larger profits in the first six months of this year in comparison with a year ago.
PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 10-- A Democratic lawyer who was elected to Congress after two unsuccessful campaigns is seeking a second term in this traditionally Republican district.

For many years rival advertising media have been waging a curious form of statistical warfare. Magazines, television network, newspapers and other media have flooded advertising agencies with a sea of statistics in an effort to prove their superiority over their competitors.
The city's parks and playgrounds were described yesterday as "50 years behind the times."
BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 10-- Governor Rockefeller hit hard today at the issue of state taxes in reply to his Democratic-Liberal opponent, Robert M. Morgenthau.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) --The civil aeronautics board said today that a crash of an Alaska Airlines DC-6A cargo plane in 1961 was caused by poor airport lighting and the failure of a ground controller to give the pilot sufficient guidance.
DETROIT, Oct. 10--The men who make cars and the people who drive them united today against a common enemy--those who would dictate to motorists when, where and how they should use their vehicles.
ONLOOKERS at the ring where Mrs. Corinne Camer on Allen was judging golden retrivers at the Westbury show on Long Island saw a rare sight. The winning dog, Goldendoor ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- The United States has asked the International Control Commission for Laos to investigate the presence of North Vietnamese troops in Laos.

Newport Associates, Inc., realty investors, have bought and taken title to the shopping center occupying the blockfront on the north side of 18th Avenue, between East Third and Fourth Streets, in Brooklyn. The property contains a Waldbaum supermarket, ten other stores and a parking lot.

LENINGRAD, Oct. 9--When Igor Stravinsky came to Leningrad this week, the intellectuals spoke of the visit as another manifestation of "podsherstok" in Soviet art. Podsherstok is the fine underhair of an animal's coat that sustains it in cold climates yet cannot be seen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-- President Kennedy signed a bill today for tax deductions on income invested in private pension plans by self-employed persons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 --Hollywood has extended its boycott of the San Francisco International Film Festival into its sixth year. The festival, which will run from Oct. 31 through Nov. 13, has still not received a feature-length entry from Hollywood.

At 11 P.M. tonight about 100 members of the Archives of American Art, art collectors and museum people from all over the country, will embark on a flight to Portugal and Spain aboard a KLM airliner for the benefit of the organization.
ROME, Oct. 10--Pope John XXIII has repeatedly made it clear that he considers the tasks of the Ecumenical Council of the Roman Catholic Church to be pastoral rather than doctrinal.

PARIS, Oct. 10--A warm welcome greeted "Baby-Foot," the first play by Robert Soulat, a 39-year-old novelist, when it was shown to the press at the Theatre de Poche (Pocket Theater) in Montparnasse tonight.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 10 --The investigatory committee sent here last month by the State Commissioner of Education to study racial imbalance in the elementary schools said today it found no evidence of designed segregation.

SOUTHFIELD, Mich., Oct. 10 --The third national religious art exhibition, containing about 300 works in painting, sculpture, mosaic, ceramics and other art forms, will open here tomorrow and run for 15 days.

Joshua Logan, director of "Mr. President," which will open here Oct. 20, is to stage Peter Feibleman's first drama, "A Place Without Twilight," based on the author's novel of the same name. Rehearsals for Mr. Feibleman's play will start on Nov. 5.
President Kennedy will lead the Columbus Day Parade up Fifth Avenue tomorrow from 59th Street to the reviewing stand five streets north.

Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., a store chain based in Minneapolis, will not exercise its option to acquire an additional 130,000 shares of the Channing Corporation, Bertin C. Gamble, chairman and president, said yesterday.

One grown man among the 63,165 World Series fans at the Stadium yesterday broke down and wept when Tom Tresh walloped the game-winning homer for the Yankees. But wouldn't you, if it was your son who, with one powerhouse swing of his bat, had put his team one up in the series?
IF Messrs. Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris can't find their lost skill at bashing home runs in this World Series, they should ask Tom Tresh, a new Yankee. He knows where the body is buried.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP).--William S. Richardson, who retired in 1957 after having been president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, for three years, died last night while on a visit from his home in Bal Harbour, Fla.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UPI)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 3--1, tonight as 11,744 Hawk fans booed their favorites.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10--The United States appealed to the Soviet Union today to accept either of the two Western proposals submitted in Geneva for the prohibition of nuclear tests.
SHOULD an unmarried man or woman who is self-supporting continue to live at home? Is there a point at which a single person in his 20's or 30's should leave hearth and home and go it alone?
WARSAW, Oct. 10--Armies of the Communist Warsaw Pact concluded their annual autumn maneuvers yesterday with a parade in the Oder River city of Szczecin (Stettin) near the East German frontier.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 10-- The Army completed tonight the first withdrawal of troops from the Oxford area.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 10-- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, tired but "deeply involved in this election," sharpened his attack on President Kennedy today.

MY THO, Vietnam, Oct. 9-- Since United States military aid starting arriving in this Mekong Delta region Jan. 1, Government forces are estimated to have killed about 5,000 Communist guerrillas. The Communists, in turn, have sent in about that number of replacements.
Robert M. Morgenthau challenged Governor Rockefeller yesterday on the issue of housing discrimination.
ROME, Oct. 10--Pope John XXIII will inaugurate the 21st Ecumenical, or universal, Council of the Roman Catholic Church tomorrow morning with the pomp and splendor worthy of a great occasion.
THE deal shown today was played at the Regency Club, and Sam Fry Jr. was South and declarer.
The market for state and municipal obligations continued strong yesterday. Government securities rallied and corporate debt issues were firm and inactive.
Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation, the big closed-end investment concern, was down sharply on Sept. 30, 1962, compared with the figure of a year earlier.
HAVANA, Oct. 10--Negotiations for the release of the 1,113 captives taken in the 1961 invasion of Cuba hit a snag tonight and hopes for their early release were dashed.
The head of Channel 13 offered suggestions yesterday on how to watch educational television programs.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 10--The trustees of Williams College announced plans today that would, in effect, eliminate the 129-year-old fraternity system at the college.
"That was the worst game we've played in a long time." Those were Alvin Dark's first words to newsmen yesterday following the Giants' 5-3 loss to the Yankees in the fifth World Series game.

DETROIT, Oct. 10--In an unusual gesture in behalf of the nation's art heritage, businessmen and industries in the metropolitan Detroit area have donated several hundred thousand dollars' worth of used machines and tools for an auction for the benefit of the Archives of American Art here.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 10 --The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church urged its church members in Mississippi today to support the integration colleges and public schools.

FIFTH Avenue stores do not sell, loan or give away their labels. The only legitimate way to come by these sewn-in status symbols is the hard way--by plunking down the cash for something with the label in it.

An autumn ritual, almost as old and revered in New York as the World Series, took place at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night. The Budapest Quartet began its concert series.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP)--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Donahue, in New York City last week to see the sights, decided to tour the ocean liner Queen Mary. Before long, they were on the roof of a battered cabin cruiser, riding into Halifax, N.S.
ROME, Oct. 10--Posters displaying a golden dove over the invocation "Come, Holy Ghost!" and slogans in black lettering saying "Death to Sodom and Gomorrah!" were side by side on Roman walls today.

New York Ranger fans are among the most loyal in the National Hockey League. They will be present in force tonight at 7:30 o'clock as their favorites open their thirty-seventh season against the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden.

Though the Yankees didn't put Ralph Terry ahead until the eighth inning of yesterday's game at the Stadium, the 6-foot-3-inch right-hander was in control all the way. He walked only one San Francisco batter in pitching the first World Series victory of his baseball career.
Alpha 66, a Cuban exile organization, announced here yesterday that its members staged a successful raid Monday on the northern coast of Cuba.
Eighty members of the Peace Corps ventured into the slums of New York yesterday. Until Nov. 3 they will attempt to help and understand those who dwell there. They will also be helping themselves.

When Tom Tresh struck the blow that beat the Giants yesterday, he did it as a left-handed swinger against the righthanded Jack Sanford. This is pointed out for the benefit of those not aware of the numerous Tresh talents, one of which is that he is a switch-hitter.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 10--The annual conference of the Conservative party got off to a rebellious start today when one of the first speakers shouted to the Chancellor of the Exchequer: "Stop dawdling, Maudling."
Honey Dear, C.V. Whitney's 4-year-old filly, made her first venture on a turf course an impressive one at Belmont Park yesterday, scoring a five-length victory in the $29,700 New York Handicap.

Watson Hall of the Brick Presbyterian Church again will be the setting for the annual fashion show and tea in behalf of missionary work and social services of the women's association. The event will take place there Tuesday afternoon.
THE PRESIDENT of the Vatican's Secretariat for the Union of Christians, Augustin Cardinal Bea, a key figure at the Ecumenical Council opening today, likes to describe himself as a "realist."
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday he would attempt to meet with Mayor Wagner to discuss what steps could be taken to insure proper administration of the Nov. 6 election.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10--Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen this week opened a belated drive for a third term. In a downstate swing he spiced his customary tranquilizing oratory with tart criticism of what he called the Kennedy Administration's "sorry record."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Not until Under Secretary of State McGhee returns from the Congo, and his report on his efforts to unify the factions there is published, can the puzzle created by the timing of a statement issued yesterday by the U.N. Secretariat be fully dispelled.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10--An international convention to protect the rights of women in marital questions was recommended today by the General Assembly's Social Committee.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10--The United States protested to the Soviet Union today against what it termed the illegal detention of and assault upon Comdr. Raymond D. Smith, an assistant naval attache of the embassy here.
LONDON, Oct. 10--During the first half of 1962 Britain's balance of payments continued to improve, showing a surplus of 96,000,000 ($268,800,000).
Chinatown, New York. A community of restaurants, quaint shops, narrow streets, goggling tourists--and potential danger.
Federal Judge John F.X. McGohey issued a temporary injunction yesterday, staving off until Dec. 23 a strike by 60,000 longshoremen in Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports.
Louisiana borrowed yesterday $20,000,000 on two issues of revenue bonds for teachers' salaries. A group headed by C.J. Devine Co. and Ira Haupt Co. submitted the best bid for both issues.
TRENTON, Oct. 10 (AP)-- The New Jersey division of Tax Appeals reduced today the city of New Brunswick's tax assessment on the Bishop Towers apartment building from $826,000 to $481,800.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Mariner 2 spacecraft, bound for a mid-December rendezvous with Venus, has discovered that there is a steady "wind" of charged particles blowing off the boiling surface of the sun into interplanetary space.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 10-- The Town of Hempstead will impose next year a tax for administrative purposes for the first time in 24 years, according to the 1963 budget made public today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday ordered suspension of trading in the shares of the Atlantic Research Corporation, charging that published financial statements of the company were "incomplete and inaccurate."
A decline in potato futures provided the New York commodity markets with their only spark of life yesterday.

Communist North Korea has recently been adopting a new approach to the South. Denunciations and appeals to the people against the military regime in Seoul have been dropped. Instead there is now a softer line toward the Park Government, accompanied by proposals for contacts between North and South aimed at peaceful reunification of Korea.
President Kennedy's actions in enforcing desegregation at the University of Mississippi were acclaimed yesterday at a rally of 10,000 persons in the garment district.

The Regional Plan Association has decided to find out whether the swarming new suburbanites really want to live in the sort of "spread-city" environment developing in the former potato fields and wooded areas surrounding New York City.
BOOKS could be written on the dining habits of opera singers. Almost all of them have a routine pertaining to food and drink before and after a performance.

Sales of Argus, Inc., in the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 exceeded $9,000,000, Herbert R. Leopold, president of the photographic equipment company, informed shareholders yesterday at their annual meeting.

ALTHOUGH several enormously talented people perform skillfully in "Angels of Anadarko," which opened last night at the York Theater, they can only intermittently enliven a script that has a static quality.

The Women's Auxiliary of the Lenox Hill Hospital is sponsoring two theater parties for the benefit of the hospital. They will be held at "Tchin-Tchin" on the evening of Dec. 5 and at "Lord Pengo" on Jan. 15.

Tom Tresh, the Yankees' rookie of the year throughout the pennant campaign, became their man of the hour yesterday. With one swish of his bat he enabled the Bombers to down the San Francisco Giants, 5 to 3, in the pivotal fifth game of the World Series before 63,165 at Yankee Stadium.
William A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, urged the airline industry yesterday to adopt a single class of service as both an economy and as a safety measure.
The Hudson Tubes suspended all service to its 33d Street terminal yesterday because excavation for a Sixth Avenue IND express route made rock conditions unsafe.
LONDON, Oct. 10--The surplus disclosed in today's balance of payments statistics for the first half of 1962 stimulated demand on the stock market.
The second phase of New York State's master plan for dealing with mental illness was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

RUPERT HOUSE, Que., Oct. 6--There isn't much to be found in these barren, subArctic reaches except an estimated million geese and ducks. Scattered around are some 4,500 Cree Indians and 18 white men.

Small-business men will soon turn their attention to taxes, and when they do there is likely to be a sizable rise in their spending for machinery and equipment. BOSTON, Oct. 10--An Administration spokesman told the Boston Conference on Distribution today that the state of the domestic economy required the Federal Government to take a more active role in stimulating United States business activity abroad.

PARIS, Oct. 10--Time is running out for Monaco in the tiny principality's dispute with France over taxes.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (UPI)--Lulu McConnell, panelist on the radio show "It Pays to Be Ignorant" in the late nineteen-thirties and forties, died yesterday. She was 80 years old.

Poisonous plant products and fungi may be causing a share of the liver disease that has generally been attributed to malnutrition throughout broad areas of the world, a doctor said yesterday at a conference on liver disorders.

Stock prices continued a recovery yesterday with brisk gains in the morning but lost most of the gains in lighter trading in the afternoon.

MONTREAL, Oct. 10--McGill University, reflecting the impact of aviation on the business community, has announced that it is establishing a research center to train personnel and conduct studies into all phases of airline administration.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 10 --Carl Albert Schneider, a retired electrical engineer, died today in Community Hospital here. He was 82 years old and lived at 10 Waterbury Road, Upper Montclair.

CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 10-- The election contest in the Third Congressional District of Tennessee is one of high importance to the Kennedy Administration.
The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30 set new highs.

The Second Vatican Council opening in Rome today will be the largest gathering of Roman Catholic prelates in history. It may also turn out to be the most important. Pope John XXIII has set an impressive goal for the council "fathers." In essence he has asked for a reform or renewal of the church that will bring it into closer accord with the needs and conditions of the modern world.

LONDON, Oct. 15--Prices of industrial shares fell after an early advance on the stock market today. Changes were small and mixed.

Julienne, a 4-year-old bay from Sweden, yesterday drew the No. 1 post position for the $45,000 Transoceanic Trot at Yonkers Raceway Thursday night. The race will be the first on an American track for foreign trotters.

WASHINGTON, Oct.16--The steering committee of New York's Congressional delegation protested today to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara against a persistent "inordinate massing" of military procurement contracts on the West Coast.
MOSCOW, Oct. 16 (AP)-- The newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya said today there was 88 Communist parties in the world, with 41,600,000 members.

A little more than an hour after the World Series was concluded, and with the football season just getting well under way, the National Basketball Association opened business for the year at Madison Square Garden last night.
A growing public interest in the arts was further evidenced yesterday in the announcement that all attendance records in the 92-year history of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were broken last year.

A citizens' and artists' group called on public officials yesterday to preserve the Brooklyn building, where Walt Whitman helped to set type and print the first edition of "Leaves of Grass" in 1855.

For the first time in eight years Rolls Royce has made a major styling change. The new British luxury car shown yesterday at a preview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, has a new front end dominated by dual headlamps that replace the long used single unit lamps.
TRENTON, Oct. 16--Five optional plans for ending racial imbalance in the public schools of Orange were submitted to the Orange School Board today by the State Commissioner of Education.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 --Yale gained 600 yards from scrimmage in its last two games but it scored only one touchdown in tying Brown, 6--6, and closing to Columbia, 14--10.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16-- The United States is planning to sell France an atomic-powered submarine in fulfillment of a promise made four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--An attempt at a high-altitude nuclear test over Johnston Island ended in failure today when difficulties developed in the Thor launching rocket. It was the fourth failure in the troubleplagued test series in the Pacific.

MENTION here yesterday of Mrs. Rixi Markus, the premiere woman player of Europe, who is visiting her daughter (married to an American) in New York, seems a proper introduction to a hand played by Mrs. Helen Sobel, the premiere player of this hemisphere.
LONDON, Oct. 16--Field Marshal Earl Alexander conceded today that he had altered his official dispatch about one of the key actions of the desert campaigns of World War II.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI)--President Kennedy signed a bill today to help small airlines finance purchases of new aircraft.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), at a meeting held yesterday in Chicago, declared a special dividend of one share of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) stock for each 115 shares of Indiana Standard outstanding. In addition, directors ordered the regular quarterly cash payment of 45 cents a share on the Indiana Standard stock.

HARTFORD, Oct. 16--Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit assailed the leaders of the Mississippi bar today for not protesting loudly the events that preceded the integration of the University of Mississippi.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16-- The Yankees, who are not wont to show exuberance at World Series success, acted out of character today after they had beaten the Giants.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that the atomic Energy Commission had transferred to New York State some licensing and regulatory authority over radioactive materials.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16 --President Kennedy appears to have pacified the country's dairy farmers, at least temporarily.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 16--Premier Cyrille Adoula introduced today the federal constitution he is proposing for the Congo. It would give the provinces considerable local autonomy, but would retain the central Government's control over the army, foreign policy and finances.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 16-- Gov. Ross R. Barnett said today he had not been in contempt of court in the James H. Meredith case, and would not apologize for his actions.

The New York Drama Critics Circle decided yesterday to change its procedure for the selection of the season's best works. By a vote of 9 to 8, the critics provided that from now on "there shall be one ballot cast for the best play--drama or musical--regardless of the country of its origin."

ATLANTA, Oct. 16--Georgians voted in primaries today for a reapportioned State Senate that ends years of rural legislative control. They also sent some other political precedents tumbling.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 17--The United States yesterday lost its third plane in two days in South Vietnam's central highlands, where two American planes were felled earlier by Communist ground gunners.
DETROIT, Oct. 16--Michigan's campaign for the governorship has taken a new turn.

EUGENE ORMANDY and the Philadelphia Orches tra opened their season last night in Philharmonic Hall by presenting "The Star-Spangled Banner." Everybody has, so far, but on this occasion there was a slight difference. Mr. Ormandy turned his back to the musicians and conducted the audience. This person-to-person relationship caused many to break into song.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages, unless otherwise noted.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner will be hostess at Gracie Mansion next Wednesday to the 400 volunteers who will solicit funds for the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association in 500 upper East Side apartment houses. Mrs. Wagner is a member of the board of directors of the association. The tea and cocktail party will open the annual apartment house appeal.
A school that can be mounted on wheels was placed on exhibit yesterday by the Board of Education.

The White Motor Company of Cleveland is negotiating a merger with Motec Industries, Inc., of Hopkins, Minn. Motec formerly was known as the Minneapolis-Moline Com pany. Both companies are engaged in the farm equipment business, although White Motor is primarily a truck manufacturer.
Plans to build a riding academy in Central Park will be discussed tomorrow at a City Planning Commission hearing on the city's capital budget.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 16--The tragedy of the integration struggle at the University of Mississippi is that it has distorted and vilified the South. And nothing illustrates the point better than a drive down U.S. Highway No. 1 from the Potomac River to the Savannah River on the Georgia-South Carolina border.

The Soviet Union men's and women's basketball teams will begin an eight-game tour of this country on Nov. 8 at Madison Square Garden, and the tour looked yesterday like a possible new source of contention between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. (UPI)--The State Department would consider as "highly undesirable" a proposed television broadcast about a Berlin escape tunnel, a department spokesman said today.

ROME, Oct. 16--The Roman Catholic Church's Ecumenical Council began today the election of commission members in the wake of assurances that representation of all major trends and national groups would be sought.
James B. Donovan, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, charged in a television debate last night that Senator Jacob K. Javits "works with" the Dixiecrats and conservative Republicans in Congress.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16--Baseball's longest season ended today with the New York Yankees still the world champions.

SID CAESAR, returning to television in a monthly series on Channel 7, was the recipient last night of hospitable assistance from his writers. Two out of the three sketches on the program had the tang of a fresh twist.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 --"I am a very lucky fellow and I certainly thank God for a second opportunity," said Ralph Willard Terry today after he had pitched the Yankees to a 1-0 victory over the Giants in the deciding game of the World Series.

U.S. Steel closed yesterday at a new low of 40, off , compared with a previous low of 40 1/8 and a high of 78 7/8 this year. Bethlehem, the second largest steel maker, closed at 29, off , compared with a range of 29 and 43 . Republic also reached a new low, closing

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16--A series of recommendations to rescue the Alliance for Progress from a "crisis" has been submitted to the Inter-American Economic and Social Council in the third and last week of its reviewing conference.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 16-- State Attorney General Joe T. Patterson declared today that students at the University of Mississippi had "the constitutional right to ignore and ostracize any undesirable student."

The stock market was on a roller-coaster yesterday. Prices opened higher, shaded and then firmed, dipped again and closed with a small loss on average. Volume perked up and amounted to 2,860,000 shares on the New York Stock Exchange, against 2,640,000 on Tuesday. It was an indecisive day, in
A biochemist and a virologist were named yesterday as winners of the 1962 Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards. Each will receive $10,000 for his contributions to basic and medical research.

Twenty-three year-old Thomas Walsh, one of the youngest hedge-hopping jockeys, brought the favored. Barnabys Bluff home first at Belmont Park yesterday in the Grand National Steeplechase Handicap, one of the oldest jumping events.
A three-man board appointed by President Kennedy to seek a solution in the Atlantic and Gulf coast longshoremen's dispute began "exploratory" talks yesterday with maritime employers.

Ed Sullivan, the television star and New York Daily News columnist, was the honored guest at the fifth annual dinner of the People-toPeople Sports Committee at the Hotel Astor last night. Sullivan was honored for his work in developing goodwill and understanding between Americans and the people of other lands.

The Alliance for Progress is failing not because of lack of money, but because it neglects the program's social objectives, a business executive declared yesterday. was made by Manuel G. Garcia, executive vice president of International Business Associates.

OYSTER BAY, L.I. Oct. 16-- The Christ Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the wedding of Miss Joan E. Ames, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Amyas Ames of Cold Spring Harbor and New York, and John A. Woodcock. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Woodcock of Lloyd Neck, Huntington.
Harvard University announced yesterday that it would re-examine its program of General Education for students at its undergraduate college and at Radcliffe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16, (UPI)--The State Department defended today the continued employment of Wililam A. Wieland, a Foreign Service officer. He was criticized yesterday by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee.

ONCE again New Yorkers are sniffing one of this city's nicest aromas--the blend of roasting chestnuts and charcoal smoke wafted from the pushcarts of chestnut venders. The men have been out on the streets since the recent arrival of the season's first boatload of chestnuts from Italy, which supplies about 99 per cent of the nuts sold here.
WASHINGTON, Oct.16--The Republican high command made it official today: Foreign policy, and Cuba in particular, is "the dominant issue of the 1962 campaign."
The City Planning Commission, which slashed the Board of Education's proposed budget for 1963-64, was accused yesterday of unrealistic planning and a failure to appreciate local needs for schools.
New York City has agreed for the first time to extend collective bargaining rights to the uniformed police force.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 16 (UPI)--Scientists postponed tonight their Ranger 5 shot at the moon for at least a month because of the threat of tropical storm Ella.
LONDON, Oct. 16--Many groups were firm on the stock market today, particularly the food and catering shares. But the general tone of industrials was dull, and prices fell slightly in quiet trading.

YOU'VE seen her a million times--on television, in magazines and prominently displayed on billboards--but you wouldn't recognize her if she asked you for a match. She is a hand and foot model, a specialist in an age of specialization, whose fingers, feet and legs are more famous than hers face and whose annual income can exceed $20,000.
"The Rise of Soviet Power," a British Broadcasting Corporation documentary written and narrated by Malcolm Muggeridge will be televised by Channel 5 from 8 to 9 P.M. Tuesday, Oct. 30.

The Canadian Government will be asked in Parliament today about the authenticity of many paintings in "The Controversial Century," an exhibition selected from the collection of Walter P. Chrysler Jr. The paintings are being shown at the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 16 --The inspirational presence of General of the Army Dwight D Eisenhower lent New Hampshire's warring Republicans at least the appearance of unity today.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 16--Scotland extended a glittering welcome today to King Olav V of Norway at the start of a three-day State visit. He is the first state visitor ever to come to Scotland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16--The Giants finally ran out of miracles today. The implausible heroics that had brought the one-time Polo Ground tenants into the World Series came to naught in the seventh game in the Candlestick Park wind tunnel. But they sure gave it a riffle in the closing inning. They set the stage for a dramatic closeout of unbelievable proportions.
ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (UPI)-- The State Board of Education approved today grants of state tuition funds totaling $206,640 for 1,148 students attending private, segregated schools.

The battle of the sexes is conducted on many levels, but nowhere is it waged with greater intensity than on Madison Avenue. When a male agency president and a female agency president decide to go after the same account at the same time, the sparks always fly.
WASHINGTON, Oct.16 (AP) --The National Aeronautics and Space Administratration lofted a 65-pound payload of scientific instruments today from its Wallops Island, Va., launching site.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16-- Banks may pay higher interest rates on deposits by foreign governments than they pay on deposits by Americans, effective today.

SAIGON, Oct. 16--The Air Force T-28 that was downed today was one of a squadron of United States fighters here whose activity is clothed in secrecy. Their base outside this city is strictly off limits.
OWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 16--Governor Rockefeller, carrying his campaign through three Southern Tier counties today, visited the home his grandfather occupied as a youth.

PARIS, Oct. 16--The implication of France's dispute with tiny Monaco is far more important than its comic opera appearance. The French, engaged in adjusting to Common Market economic levels, understandably dislike, the existence of a special Monegasque enclave for tax dodgers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) In a homey, relaxed fashion President Kennedy played host in his office today to Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr., the sixorbit astronaut's wife and, their two children.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the better of two bids for $26,652,000 of Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority revenue bonds.

The head of Federated Department Stores urged business leaders yesterday to start a drive against the "tens of thousands of modern economic ghettos" that he said were being created in both the cities and the suburbs.
BERLIN, Oct. 16--Wladyslaw Gomulka carried the message of Polish-East German friendship and Communist solidarity into the hinterlands today.

BILL KING, Dartmouth's quarterback and captain, played just 19 minutes and 36 seconds against Brown last Saturday, but in that short time his exploits were such as to earn him Ivy League back of the week honors.
World sugar and potato futures advanced and cocoa and copper declined in a generally quiet day on the New York commodity exchanges.
LARNED, Kan., Oct. 16 (UPI)--Mrs. Ralph Terry screamed, "Oh my goodness, it's fabulous," when her husband retired Willie McCovey today for the final out of the World Series.

With a possibly major crisis over Berlin drawing near, top-level consultations are getting under way in an effort to break the deadlock. Premier Khrushchev conferred with Ambassador Kohler for three hours in Moscow yesterday and President Kennedy will meet Soviet Ambassador Gromyko at the latter's request tomorrow.

THE big cock pheasant skulked in the grass. Per haps he thought for a few minutes about how easy it would be to avoid a lady hunter--he knew she and her friends were pressing him hard. He heard the dog, Duchess, snuffling through the grass.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has nearly 1,500 informants in the 8,500-member Communist party, according to a former agent who also made public a report criticizing the "autocratic" way the bureau is run.
An increase of 739,000 barrels in the country's gasoline stocks in the week ended Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
Senator Jacob K. Javits described yesterday as "preposterous and unconscionable" a charge that he worked with Dixiecrats and conservative Republicans in Congress.

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Oct. 17--Although Mount Hermon's varsity football squad is still seeking its first victory this season, Vit Piscuskas, the head coach, is surprisingly cheerful. He has taken the stand that victory comes "for him who waits."

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Oct. 17--Prime Minister Sir Edgar Whitehead is expected to dissolve Southern Rhodesia's Parliament in the next two weeks and call an early general election under the projected new constitution.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy flew here from Washington yesterday to accept a citation from New York University in honor of her "genuine concern for the fine arts and our American artistic inheritance."

A major re-examination of the Queens College curriculum is due in order to keep pace with changes in higher education since the college was founded 25 years ago, Harold W. Stoke, the president, has advised the Faculty Council.

THE techniques that manage ment uses to hire the right person for a job can be adapted by the housewife to select a baby nurse, maid, housekeeper, cook or caterer, according to Dr. Mortimer R. Feinberg. Dr. Feinberg is associate professor of industrial psychology at the Bernard M. Baruch School of the City College of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) --House Speaker John W. McCormack accused the Republicans today of having helped Fidel Castro take over Cuba.
LONDON, Oct. 17--The United States and Britain, officials said tonight, intend to warn the Soviet Union anew that any Russian or East German interference with access to West Berlin would lead to war.

The airline pilots' union denied yesterday an accusation by the flight engineers' union that pilots had cheated on Government tests to qualify them as engineers.

A group of New York realty investors headed by Simon and Stanley Rappoport has purchased La Vista Villas, a luxury apartment development in northeast Atlanta. The property consists of a complex of three buildings on a tract of ten acres. It was bought for cash over a mortgage of $1,900,000.
The Browning School at 52 East 62d Street will benefit from a theater party to Mr. President" on Oct. 29. The new Irving Berlin musical is scheduled to open at the St. James Theater on Saturday.

ALTHOUGH Elizabeth David is still in her early 40's, she has a gastronomic scope that is formidable. She is a resident of London and is widely published in England, both as a journalist and as a cookbook author. She has lived in France, Italy, Greece, Egypt and India, and her books on food reflect an admirable curiosity and comprehension of national cuisines.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 17--Nobel Prize time, a pulsestirring season that only Stock holm and Oslo know, is here again.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 17-- The Government's quandary over the establishment of guidelines on the radiation hazard from nuclear fallout was described at a scientific meeting here today.

Funds are being raised to bring Hal Holbrook back to New York in "Mark Twain Tonight!" This time Mr. Holbrook's goal is Broadway. His previous appearance in the offering was at an Off Broadway theater in 1959.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--India, faced with increasing Chinese Communist military pressure against her northern border, is understood to be making quiet, unofficial approaches on the possibility of obtaining military equipment in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- The indictment yesterday of a Maryland Representative running for re-election culminated a long series of scandals involving the savings and loan industry in that state.
Textbook publishers were notified yesterday that the Board of Education would not accept books on social studies and other instructional material that did not deal adequately with minority groups.

"Aida," which promises to be as eternal as the Nile, beside which it takes place, last night made its annual re-entry into the Metropolitan Opera season. For this initial performance, the scenery, now a dozen years old and overly familiar, seemed to have been freshened up.
The nation's two largest containerships designed for overseas commerce will be placed in service this month by the Grace Line, W.J. McNeil, president of the company, said yesterday.
A four-ton crate containing an X-ray machine with an element of radioactive cobalt 60 fell 30 feet into the hold of a ship in Brooklyn last night. Experts said there was no radiation hazard.

The Mead Corporation, one of the largest paper and paperboard companies in the country, has leased the 43d floor in the 59-story Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Terminal. The lease, which is for 20 years, involves 35,000 square feet of space.
BUFFALO, Oct. 17--A voter could easily get the impression here that John F. Kennedy is running against Nelson A. Rockefeller this year.

"THERE'S nothing wrong with some dogs but much wrong with others," said Dr. Leon F. Whitney of Orange, Conn., at the first meeting of the season of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club at Luchow's restaurant yesterday.

The New York Yacht Club said "no thanks" yesterday to a British challenge for the America's Cup in 1963. But there were indications that the club would be receptive to a 1964 challenge.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- Miss Margaret L. Plunkett became today the first woman United States labor attache.

Dr. John B. Grant, who represented the international health division of the Rockefeller Foundation in many countries from 1918 to 1960, died Tuesday at the Hospital Auxilio Mutuo in Hato Rey, P.R. His age was 72. He had been ill for several weeks after a heart attack.

DUBIOUS solace has come to the television viewer. His general impression that commercials sound louder than programs is not the product of an enfeebled ear; it has been confirmed. But his chance of aural relief appears as remote as ever.
A $50,000,000 debenture issue of the Associates Investments Company of South Bend, Ind., was said to be spoken for yesterday, when it was marketed at a price to yield the investor 4.45 per cent.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 (AP)--Blood serum contains a new-found substance that has anticancer activity, a surgeon reported today. Cancer patients have less of the substance than do healthy persons, he said.

L. Arnold Frye, a prominent lawyer, specializing for many years in bond issues, died yesterday at his home. He lived at 5 Northway in Bronxville, N.Y. and was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--A politically sensitive tariff case on imports of lumber has stirred an off-stage argument between the Tariff Commission and Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17-- Scientists and engineers were honored for a wide variety of outstanding achievements at the Franklin Institute's Medal Day ceremony tonight.
