United States newsprint consumption set records in September and the first nine months of the year, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
A young Long Island couple whose twin babies were born deformed have instituted a $2,200,000 suit against the West German manufacturer of thalidomide pills, which the wife took during pregnancy.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18.-- Yale University said today that it would resume its participation in the student loan program under the National Defense Education Act.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP)--Frank Chapot of the United States went after big stakes tonight and won in the "Gambler's Choice" international jumping event at the 17th Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
WHEN John Moors Cabot, a third, secretary in the Foreign Service, entered the embassy on his arrival in Rio de Janeiro in 1932, the Ambassador abruptly ordered him back to the street.
YONKERS, Oct. 18--Chances for the return of the Hambletonian, the rich and renowned classic for 3-year-old trotters, to Good Time Park at Goshen, N.Y., in 1964 were enhanced today.
Stock prices declined on a broad front yesterday with key market indicators showing the sharpest drop of the month.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 18 (AP)--Dr. Charles A. Stuart, retired professor of biology at Brown University, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old.
The sobs of thousands of sidewalk mourners and a prayer to God to bring peace to Brooklyn's streets marked the funeral here yesterday of a rabbi who had been beaten to death in an apparent mugging.
ROBBINSVILLE, N.C., Oct. 18--For all its monstrous unloveliness, the European boar has a fascinating allure to it.

Extracurricular activities have had much to do with the New York Rangers' disappointing record of one victory and three defeats in the National Hockey League this season, Muzz Patrick, their general manager and coach, believes. What's more, he blames himself for having permitted this.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct.18-- The Huntington Planning Board was told this week that traffic on the town's already congested highways would double by 1980.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18-- King Saud's decision to step down as Premier of Saudi Arabia and recall Prince Faisal to fill the post was viewed here as an effort by the King to strengthen his regime against the shock of the revolution in Yemen.

In Thomas Wolfe's lighthanded short story, "Only the Dead Know Brooklyn," a couple of characters argue about which line, the West End or Sea Beach, takes you to Bensonhurst. Suddenly one pulls out of his pocket a big map of Brooklyn "wit all duh different pahts.
The New York City Central Labor Council, representing 1,000,000 union members, voted overwhelmingly last night not to endorse any candidate for statewide office this year.

The Internal Revenue Service is revising tax forms to reflect a retroactive business measure in the Revenue Act of 1962 signed this week, and to correct an unsatisfactory situation in inventory reporting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--A major textile manufacturing combine was ordered today to pay back wages to 500 workers who host their jobs when an affiliated concern shut down after the workers had voted to be represented by a union.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18-- The Democratic state chairman accused Richard M. Nixon today of condoning the "dirtiest" gubernatorial campaign in California's recent history.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct, 18 (AP)--Paul Hornung, who has captured three straight National Football League scoring titles, has been knocked out of the Green Bay Packer line-up by an injury.

The award of the 1962 Nobel Prize for medicine to Dr. James D. Watson, an American, and his two British colleagues, Drs. Francis H.C. Crick and Maurice H.F. Wilkins, is a deserved and long overdue tribute to the men responsible for one of mankind's great scientific achievements. If, as seems likely, we are today at the

TOTAL turkey production this year is expected to work out at about one-half a bird for each United States citizen. This is about half a drumstick less for each 100 persons than was available last year. This, in turn, will mean Thanksgiving prices will be higher than last year, when they dropped to a 20-year low.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Iselin Jr. of 432 East 84th Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Cary Iselin, to James Madison Morrison. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. James G, Morrison of 14 Sutton Place South.
BINGHAMTON, Oct. 18-- Unusually large vote-switching in this year's state elections seems to be in the offing in the Southern Tier, the row of New York counties along the Pennsylvania border.
Dr. Willford I. King, professor of economics at New York University from 1927 to 1945, died Wednesday in his home at 28 Shore Road, Douglaston, Queens. He was 82 years old.

TIME appears to have had a wearing effect on gen iuses. Greece's Euripides, Rome's Seneca and France's Racine fashined the legend of Phaedra for the ages. That complex of sacred and profane love ending in searing tragedy

AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 18 --A trans-Atlantic telephone exchange via the United States communications satellite Telstar marked the opening today of ceremonies honoring Paul Julius Reuter, a pioneer in the news dissemination field.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18--Cyprus proposed today that President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev meet here next month to try to reach agreement on the prohibition of nuclear tests.
EVERYONE who has returned to childhood's faraway scenes will find in Wallace Stegner's probing, brooding mem oir, "Wolf Willow,"* some pleasurable shock of recognition.

J. Press, the clothing store that has become almost a club for Ivy Leaguers and their sartorial followers, moved downstairs and half a block away this week. The store's new location is just off Madison Avenue and across the street from Brooks Brothers.
ROME, Oct. 19--What is believed to be the oldest synagogue in Western Europe, and perhaps in all Europe, has been discovered in Ostia, the port of imperial Rome at the mouth of the Tiber.
LONDON, Oct. 19--"The Premise," an American revue based on topical improvisation, has again run foul of the Lord Chamberlain, Britain's theatrical censor. This time the dispute may end in court.
A state hearing on charges of "blockbusting" against three Long Island realty men came to an abrupt end yesterday when the lawyer for one of them rested his case without offering any defense.

AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 19 --A three-story red brick building here whose roof was sheared off by a British shell in World War II became today a monument to a man whose intelligence and stubbornness brought Europeans closer together 112 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--Seaboard World Airlines of New York City asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to defer acting on renewal of its trans-Atlantic airline certificates until action was taken on the possible merger of Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.
Laymen, not clergymen, will preach the sermons tomorrow is 100,000 Protestant churches over the country.
Additional committee members and patrons for the Anniversary Dinner Dance of the Children's Health Service, which will be held Nov. 8 in the Royal Ballroom of the Americana, have been announced.

DETROIT, Oct. 19--The American automobile industry, now completing what is expected to be the second best year in its History, will open an automobile show here tomorrow. More than 400 models of 1963 cars and trucks will be on view at Cobo Hall.

A 26-passenger bus that saw service as a mobile headquarters in a recent political campaign has been donated to a group that is leading a drive for the registration of Negroes as voters in southwest Georgia.
CAPE HATTERAS, N.C., Oct. 19 (AP)--Hurricane Ella, with winds up to 100 miles an hour resumed a slow northeasterly course today that posed its chief threat to shipping.
FARMVILLE, Va., Oct. 19 (AP)--Twenty Negro children of Prince Edward County, registered under a Virginia Teachers Association placement program, began classes this week in other localities.

Metropotitan New York's oldest uninterrupted college football rivalry will be staged for the 17th time today at Hofstra Field, Hempstead, L.I., between Hofstra College and the United States Merchant Marine Academy of Kings Point, L.I. Hofstra leads in the series, 12--4.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 19 (AP)--Three Federal judges refused today to block the election on Nov. 6 of state legislators as requested in a suit seeking immediate reapportionment of the Indiana General Assembly.

Fredell Lack,--Violinist, made her first New York appearance in five years last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, in a program that showed again this artist's sure command of instrument and music. Assisting her at the piano was Albert Hirsh, who was last heard here in 1959 in a recital with Zino Francescatti.

FUR FLYERS, according to Jimmi York, started out as a sightseeing venture into Manhattan's fur market. Miss York went there one day with a friend and soon found herself buying a second-hand raccoon coat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19-- Discouraged space officials ordered today a technical study of what went wrong with Ranger 5. The $15,000,000 craft fell silent in space and compounded the national embarrassment over being unable to reach the moon.
MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 19 --The course lap record was broken by the fiat four drivers to qualify today for Sunday's 200-mile Pacific Grand Prix for sports cars.

Today is the final day of the New York Antiques Fair at the 71st Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and 34th Street. The hours are from 1 to 6 P.M. In addition to every type of old furniture, there are home accessories of all kinds on exhibition and for sale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--In recent years autumn, after the Congress is gone and the Yankees have won the World Series, has become a hard season for small-bore worriers. It is traditionally the time for worrying about the traditional fall Berlin crisis, and Berlin crises, unfortunately, are impossible for lightweight worriers to savor to the full.
WASHINGTON, Oct.19 (AP) --Eleven paintings have been accepted by the White House, it was announced last night. Some of the works are gifts and some are on loan.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18-- Amid the twisted pines of the Monterey peninsula, a candidate peers ruefully at a callus on his thumb, caused by a death and 20,000 high-speed, handshakes. In San Diego a Congressman goes out of his district to campaign--for his brother. In the Heart of Los Angeles two men assure themselves that each will be the first Negro to go to the House of Representative from west of the Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Oct.19 (UPI) --The State Department criticized today the National Broadcasting Company's involvement in a tunnel-building project under the wall dividing Berlin. But the department said that the showing of a film on the tunnel probably would not endanger any lives.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) --The Internal Revenue Service liberalized tax depreciation rules today applying to the auto, aerospace and several other industries.
WATCHUNG, N.J., Oct. 19 --Fire swept through the Washington House Restaurant today, destroying the historic 225-year-old inn and an adjoining motel. No one was seriously injured.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 19 --Local issues such as the price of gas and the campaign for a City Council seat seem to be stirring more election interest here than the state and nation campaigns.
Gus Hall, the American Communist leader, acknowledged yesterday that "some" Federal Bureau of Investigation agents had infiltrated the party. But he contended that the identity of many was known.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., Oct. 18-- A candidate who is named in a criminal indictment midway in his campaign is likely to be somewhat disadvantaged.
MONTREAL, Oct. 19--A Canadian labor leader and a judge denounced plans of the Maritime Trades Department (A.F.L.-C.I.O.) today to meet here Monday on a Canadian inquiry into Great Lakes shipping.

Events today: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York City Opera Company, City Center, "The Marriage of Figaro," at 2:30 P.M, and "La Boh me" at 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Cecilia Valdes, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Concert of Canadian folk music, Town Hall, 8:30; Visvaldis Gedulis, bassbaritone, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
DALLAS, Ga., Oct. 19 (AP) --Six white men have been indicted on charges resulting from a night rider foray in which a white man was shot and killed by a Negro woman at her home.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI)-- The Santa Fe Railroad was granted a temporary injunction today restraining the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen from striking on this Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19-- The big foreign-policy question here today was not whether Premier Khrushchev was coming to the United States but why he would want to come.
The Child Study Association of America has arranged a benefit at the Nov. 16 preview of "Lord Pengo" in the Royale Theater.

The Christiana Securities Company announced yesterday that it would distribute more than four million shares of General Motors Corporation stock to its stockholders on Nov. 14. One-third share of General Motors will be given out for each share of Christiana held of record on Oct. 26.

Motec Industries, Inc., a farm equipment company, plans to become a corporate shell if the sale of its assets to the White Motor Companies is approved, Robert Rittmaster, Motec's chairman, said yesterday.

Kelso, the horse of the year for 1960 and 1961, will try today to extend his reign. The formidable 5-year-old, owned by Mrs. Richard C. du Pont's Bohemia Stable, will compete in the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park, with seven opposing him in the two-mile race.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 18 --Dr. Sterling M. McMurrin insisted today that he resigned as United States Commissioner of Education six weeks ago because "I wanted to live the life of a scholar.
RAPID CITY, S.D., Oct. 19-- George P. McGovern and the Kennedy Administration are engaged in an uphill battle to capture a Senate seat in this traditionally Republican prairie state.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--Tighter curbs on the interstate shipment of gambling devices, except to states where their use is legal, are provided in a bill signed today by President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) --A proposed merger between two upstate New York banks has the approval of a Federal banking official despite findings by three other Federal agencies that competition would be impaired.
MIAMI, Oct. 19--The white porpoise thrust her head out of the water of the tank and deftly snatched a fish from the hand of Adolf Frohn, director of animal training at the Miami Seaquarium.

FOR those who delight in handmade home accessories, a group of wares from Jamaica has arrived at the Barn at Ben Robyn, 143 East 62d Street. The imports include carved salad servers and miniature chests that make charming chair-side tables.
THE HARMONIE CLUB, 4 East 60th Street, held an "experts' night" Thursday, with eleven well-known players present to compete with 86 members of the club in a duplicate game.
Former Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and Harry S. Tru man will join Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as honorary co-chairman of one of her favorite charties--the Wiltwyck School for Boys at Esopus, N.Y.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 19 --The nation's selectmen of business and industry agreed today that the economy was in the doldrums. And it was their view that the Kennedy Administration was responsible.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Oct. 19--A 29-year-old stewardess fell 1,500 feet to her death tonight when she was swept through an emergency door that suddenly sprang open on an Allegheny Airlines plane. The craft was approaching Bradley Field here for a landing.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19 (AP) --Three state Circuit Court judges reserved decision today on an appeal from two officials of New Haven's Planned Parenthood League who early this year were found guilty of violating Connecticut's controversial law against giving information on birth control.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Oct. 19--George C. McGhee, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, left the Congo for Washington early today with the belief that efforts might yet succeed in bringing a peaceful end to the secession of Katanga province.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 --The United States Eques trian Team, having clinched the international jumping team championship last night, continued to pile up points by wincing the two-round Prix des Nations event of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
Potato futures declined sharply for the second day, highlighting a generally weaker commodity futures market in New York yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 19 --One of the largest operations against the Communists in recent years in the war in Vietnam came to a quiet close yesterday. It was, in the opinion of Americans here, a long and expensive but futile exercise.
Mike Hegan, the son of the New York Yankees' catching coach; Jim Bronstad and Curt Blefary yesterday were put on the world champions' roster.
"HAMLET," two hours and eight minutes without interruption, was last night's contribution of educational station WNDT to civilized viewing.

A model of a typical square in Curacao enticed guests at the Comeback to Curacao Ball last night in the Waldorf-Astoria. The event was a benefit for Comeback, Inc., a national agency supporting the social rehabilitation of the aging, the ill and the handicapped.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission said some officials of the Atlantic Research Corporation apparently used $3,900,000 of the...
Bond prices moved up sharply yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's action cutting reserve requirements against commercial bank time and savings deposits.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI)-- Corn futures set seasonal lows today on the Board of Trade. Oats and soybeans also declined, while wheat and rye rallied to gain.
Cocktail buffets and dinner parties were given by many subscribers last night before the October Ball, which was held in the ballroom of the SheratonEast.
A sharp increase in the number of new apartment buildings being erected in New York has led to "overproduction," the heads of some of the city's largest building concerns said yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 19--The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit enjoined the State of Mississippi and several of its officials today from taking any action to prevent James H. Meredith from continuing to attend the University of Mississippi.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 19--The Suffolk County leaders of both major parties urged voters in five western towns today to approve a district court system.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., Oct. 19-- The president of the Board of Education predicted today that a report on Levittown schools issued yesterday by the State Education Department would have "many beneficial results."
The New York Yacht Club took a reef in its sail yesterday by deciding to withhold comment on the stormy America's Cup situation until Monday.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 19.-- The Army ordered a reduction today of 3,500 troops in its forces here.
WLADYSLAW Gomulka, the Polish Communist chief, who said yesterday that an accord between East and West on the Berlin question was possible, is known as a man of both courage and obstinacy.
LONDON, Oct. 19--The demand for British Government bonds continued on the stock market today. Institutional and investment buying was reported as substantial.
The airlines and their pilots have apparently found little cause for concern in a recent Pentagon policy that imposed charges and tightened rules on emergency civil landings at military airports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The complexion of the American tanker fleet will change radically within the next decade, Joseph Andreae, assistant manager of the marine division of Humble Oil and Refining Company, predicted today.

Recent developments in Europe indicate that Britain may formally become a member of the European Economic Community as early as the beginning of 1964, Richard Miles, director of economic affairs for the British Information Services, said yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 19--Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist leader, said today that an East-West solution of the Berlin crisis was possible. But he insisted that a settlement must be based on recognition of East German sovereignty and an end of the occupation regime in West Berlin.

The future of the Long Island Ducks in Commack, L.I., appeared to be relatively secure yesterday after three bidders had offered to take over for a year the operation of the Long Island Arena, the home of the Eastern Hockey League team, at a hearing in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

The stock market reacted bearishly to the Federal Reserve Board's cut late Thursday in commercial bank reserve requirements, but most banking industry observers termed the action a "constructive" step.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19--A Soviet economist lashed out tonight against critics of his widely publicized profit-incentive proposals. If adopted, they would revolutionize the Soviet industrial economy.
James B. Donovan, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, said yesterday that the "myth" of his opponent's "invincibility is going to be shattered on election day."

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 19 (UPI)--The New Hampshire Supreme Court dismissed today suits brought by two defeated United States Senate candidates. The court called for tighter regulation of primary campaign funds.

The modern pirates of the Spanish Main are main twisting the tail of the British Lion. As those who fought against Drake of Devon discovered centuries ago, this can be a dangerous pastime. Britain today is not the sea power she was in the era of her maritime dominance.
YONKERS, Oct. 19--Horsemen from various sections of the country, and Europe were drifting into town today for a week of harness racing activity.
Two pairs of brothers and a father and son were sentenced yesterday in the Bronx on charges of staging fake accidents to bilk insurance compa
CHICAGO, Oct. 19--President Kennedy received a roaring welcome today as he swung into the heart of America for three days of campaigning in seven states.
Mayor Wagner directed Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy yesterday to "take every possible action" against street violence in the Williamsburg area of Brooklyn.

Three young dancers were seen in Judson Hall last night in place of the vocalists and instrumentalists who usually appear there. Robert Schwart's New York Dance Theatre presented "An Evening of New Ballets" as the first in a series of Friday evening dance events in the hall.

Robert Horton, who won prominence as the frontier scout Flint McCullough in the television series "Wagon Train," is set to play the male lead in the as yet untitled Richard RodgersAlan Jay Lerner musical.

Herbert P. Greenwood, a certified public accountant, suffered a heart attack Thursday at 151 William Street and was pronounced dead on arrival at Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 47 Troy Drive, Springfield, N.J.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 19 --Charles Reginald Fletcher Wickenden, a former New York lawyer specializing in banking and estate work, died here yesterday in his home. He was 67 years old.
THE latest in the steadily increasing list of imita tions of "Rififi" opened yesterday at the Embassy under the blatant title, "Riff Raff Girls."
BONN, Germany, Oct. 19-- Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroder said today that Western allies would not accept any weakening of their rights of access to West Berlin.

Jerry Tripoll tackled Lou Vega in the end zone with 20 seconds to play yesterday to give New Utrecht a 2-0 triumph over Tilden in a Public Schools Athtetic League game at the loser's field in Brooklyn. The victory, New Utrecht's 10th in a row, ended Tilden's eight-game winning streak.
Four landlords in the Bronx were arrested yesterday in that borough's investigation of rent gouging.

The Greek Government and the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., reached an agreement yesterday in New York on a plan for the resumption of interest and principal payments on Greek dollar bonds.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19 (AP) --The Rev. Fredrik A. Schiotz, president of the American Lutheran Church, voiced strong support of the World Council of Churches today.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 19-- Richard M. Nixon's Victory Special rode slowly through booming southern California today as its star passenger drummed away at proved political selling points.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19--Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Under Secretary for Political Affairs, is leaving Sunday for the Congo. He will supervise efforts to settle the long-standing crisis between the central Government and secessionist Katanga Province.
The preponderance of data collected by disinterested scientific observers contradicts the contentions of Carl M. Loeb Jr. in his letter published today on the British system of narcotics control.
EXHIBITIONS continued in full spate this week, con temporary work crowding out the past although the past made a few distinguished reappearances.

"The Pleasures of a Nonconformist," a volume of commentaries by Dr. Lin Yutang, will be published by World on Nov. 20. Some of the subjects Dr. Lin covers are the Peking warlords, Picasso, football, Adam, Santa Claus, Zen and the emotional life of Confucius.
Columbia and Harvard, last year's Ivy League football cochampions, will meet today at Baker Field, Broadway and 218th Street. Game time is 1:30 P.M.

Riding out in front of the parade ahead of displaced Alabama and Ohio State, the Texas Longhorns undergo probably their stiffest remaining challenge of the college football season tonight against Arkansas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19-- The Kennedy Administration believes that business will be better, not worse, as the year draws to a close.
ATLANTA, Oct. 19 (AP)--A three-judge Federal court said today that it would not decide how votes should be counted in the special primary election last Tuesday for the reapportioned Senate.

Robin Roberts, the former Philadelphia Phillies' pitching star for whom the trail had been downhill six years, was named the comeback player of of the year yesterday by the United Press International.

James J. Murphy, a former Representative from Staten Island and lower Manhattan, and a former City Councilman here, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in West New Brighton, S.I. He was 64 years old, and lived at 3 Park Lane in Grymes Hill, S.I.

GENERAL, recognition was just about to come to Morris Louis when he died suddenly last month at the age of 49. His last paintings, all done in 1962, are on view in the Andr Emmerich Gallery at 17 East 64th Street.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 19 --Can a man be sentenced to serve two consecutive life terms? That question was raised today in Union County Court by counsel for Joseph William Maxey.

Stocks declined again yesterday as trading quickened. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to the highest level in almost a month. It amounted to 4,654,670 shares, against 3,280,000 on Thursday. The previous high was 4,999,370 on Sept. 24.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19 (AP)--President Jos Maria Guido said today that the Alliance for Progress was being crippled by bureaucracy and delays.
Robert M. Morgenthau called yesterday for a complete overhaul and liberalization of the state's program of medical assistance for the aged.
Silver prices here moved up ward again yesterday, as expected. They reached $1.22 an ounce, up cent. At the same time, the price in London rose by the same amount to 104 pence, or $1.214.
Big Sam Horner sat in his corner, waiting a chance to play. Yesterday, he got it.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19--Thirty nations proposed today that the General Assembly call on nuclear powers to cease all nuclear weapons tests before Jan 1.

VIENNA, Oct, 18--The linden trees on the Ring strasse are still green despite the October chill. Most of the cafes no longer serve on their outdoor terraces; the habitu s have retreated to the warmth inside.
A $15,000,000 international student center being planned as part of a union-sponsored housing development is projected for an area west of Lincoln Center.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 19-- Floyd Dominy, United States Commissioner of Reclamation, criticized Gov. George D. Clyde of Utah today for attacking a major western reclamation project while also calling for the Western states to unite in support of reclamation.
The Department of Agriculture is already paying farmers for agreeing not to produce crops. Now it is compensating seed producers for not selling seed.

Magnet Mills, Inc. of Clinton, Tenn., has been sold to Prestige, Inc., of New York, it was announced jointly yesterday by A.D. Grenshaw, president of Magnet Mills, and Samuel I. Burd, president of Prestige. Trade sources estimate the amount of the transaction at about $5,000,000.
Isador Gusikoff, a first cellist under Leopold Stokowski and Arturo Toscanini for many years, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 124 East 176th Street. He was 61 years old.

An attach of the Czechoslovak mission to the United Nations who fled from the city Thursday after killing his wife, died yesterday in a Pennsylvania hospital from a self-inflicted bullet wound in the head.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 19 (UPI)--Five students at the all-Negro Florida A University filed a $1,000,000 damage Suit today. They contended they had been humiliated and shamed by their arrest last September in a bus station restaurant where they had been refused service.

Third-quarter profits of the Caterpillar Tractor Company dipped from those a year ago despite higher sales. Results for the nine months, however, exceeded those of the 1961 period, the manufacturer of heavy earthmoving equipment revealed in its report yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 19--A new secretariat of the entire Roman Catholic hierarchy in Africa started functioning today. It is an expression of what churchmen unofficially term the pan-African bloc at the Ecumenical Council.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 19 --Thirty-five cities, including New York, Washington and Pittsburgh, have enough shelters to take care of their entire populations says Steuart L. Pittman, assistant Secretary of Defense for Civil Defense. He made this point while addressing the convention of the United States Civil Defense Council, which closes here today.

CAIRO, Oct. 19 (AP)--Darkness ended a shootoff today for the world clay pigeon championship, with Maharajah Karin Singh of India and Valadimir Zimenko of the Soviet Union in a tie. They will resume competition tomorrow.
BALTIMORE, Oct.19 (AP) --The Baltimore Orioles completed their 1963 coaching staff today by signing Hank Bauer.

The ruling bishops of the Greek Orthodox Church issued their first formal statement yesterday on the Ecumenical Council in the Vatican. They rejected the Roman Catholic Church's invitation to send delegate-observers but expressed the hope that the Council would open the way to progress in Christian unity.
Capital offerings of fixed-interest municipal and corporate securities next week are expected to exceed $425,000,000. This would compare with about $300,000,000 placed on the market this past week.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 19-- One of the most baffling mysteries in the annals of medicine was put before a meeting of public health scientists that ended here today.
Fifty-four radio and television executives from 19 European countries will begin a series of meetings here on Monday with representatives of the American broadcasting industry.

Miss Margaret Windley Auge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore George Auge of Brooklyn, was married there last night to Robert Frederick Harvey. He is the son of Mrs. William Harvey of the Isle of Wight and the late Mr. Harvey.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 19--Senator Jacob K. Javits today accused his Democratic opponent. James B. Donovan, of dodging most of the issues in their Senate campaign and of twisting those he was willing to discuss.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19-- Private letters tucked away in a vault for 20 years show that advertising agencies had a hand in Presidential campaigns as far back as 1923.
PARIS, Oct. 19--France's Council of State declared illegal today the special military court set up by President de Gaulle to try terrorists of the terrorist Secret Army Organization.

PEKING, Saturday, Oct. 20 --Indian troops inflicted heavy casualties early today in a "large-scale frenzied attack" on Chinese Communist frontier guards in the Kechilang River area of the disputed border region, Peking's official press agency reported.
About 1,500 off-duty firemen and policemen picketed City Hall for about three hours yesterday as they continued their campaign for larger raises than the city wants to give them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--President Kennedy, bolstered by his new Trade Expansion Act, proposed today an international conference of ministers next year to seek ways to cut down obstacles to world trade.

AFTER football practice, after class or on any occasion when high school or college students gather informally, the call for refreshments is heard. The far-seeing hostess who remembers that cool days call for hearty fare and hot dishes will keep a stock of staples on hand for easily prepared snacks.
Cotton futures fell 5 to 50 cents a bal yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Now that the Brazilian elections are over (though the returns are still incomplete), President Joao Goulart has a free hand to carry out the badly needed economic and social reforms which he has neglected for a whole year. This was the year that he tenaciously fought his political battle to get back the presidential powers taken from him in August, 1961, when President Janio Quadros suddenly and capriciously resigned.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 19-- Millions of dollars is being spent by aircraft, passenger seat and seat belt manufacturers to give travelers every chance to survive plane crashes, a Federal Aviation Agency safety expert said today.

Madison Square Garden appears on the verge of losing its regular classification of a major disaster area as far as the New York Knickerbockers are concorned. Formidable evidence in support of that contention was presented last night by the Knicks as they upset the Los Angeles Lakers, 116--105.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19--The United States urged the General Assembly today to condemn South Africa's racial segregation as a policy that could lead to "bloodshed, war and disaster for all races."
A jurisdictional dispute between plumbers and carpenters that had prevented 189 families from moving into the Penn Station South middle-income cooperative since Oct. 4 has been settled.

Steve Cochran is one actorproducer who keeps moving. The energetic performer has arrived here for a brief visit, with a backlog of two films (one opens here next week), plans for a new one to be made in the Bahamas and also with three additional properties in the blueprint stage.
NEW HARTFORD, N.Y., Oct. 19--Archibald B. Chapin, a retired political cartoonist, died here today in the home of a daughter. He was 87 years old.

LONGVIEW, Tex., Oct. 22 (UPI)--A Gregg County grand jury returned 71 criminal indictments against 20 persons today, charging theft, bribery and conspiracy in connection with the scandals involving slanted oil wells in East Texas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--Whether the build-up of acute expectancy that preceded President Kennedy's announcement tonight of a new, positive Cuban policy was inevitable in the circumstances or was most artfully designed, its effect was that of a marvelous public relations job. Not only was the great secret kept to the moment of dramatic revelation: it also was so thoroughly identified in advance as a secret that the attention of the whole world was fixed upon it.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (UPI)-- Grain futures reacted to new international tensions by gaining sharply today on an active Board of Trade.

TYLER, Tex., Oct. 22 (UPI) --Billie Sol Estes, bankrupt financier must be tried immediately on state charges of theft and swindling, District Judge Otis T. Dunagan ruled today. He summoned a 150-member jury panel for tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22--Adlai E. Stevenson told the General Assembly today that Communist China's "naked aggression" against India was new proof that it was unfit for membership in the United Nations.

OTTAWA, Oct. 22 (Canadian Press)--Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said today that Canada would give the fullest consideration to any request by India for military assistance to repel Communist Chinese attacks.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Oct. 22--The scheduled amphibious landing on Vieques Island, east of Puerto Rico, was canceled today. It was to have been the high point of the United States naval maneuvers in the Caribbean.
PARIS, Oct. 22--In Great Britain today the axe hangs over grand prix car racing, some horse race courses and 10,000 bookmakers.

Eighty-five per cent of New York's streets were rated as clean yesterday in the 1962 block survey. This was the same percentage as last year, but there were some improvements.

The existing "political stalemate" between the executive and legislative branches of our government is analyzed by James MacGregor Burns in his forthcoming book "The Deadlock of Democracy: Four-Party Politics in America." MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24--The Alliance for Progress conference gave indications today of settling down to serious discussion after having been interrupted by the Cuban situation.
Weekly live radio broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera will begin Saturday, Dec. 1, at 8:15 P.M. with a performance of Verdi's "Ernani."
Dr. Calvin E. Gross, the city's new Superintendent of Schools, voiced confidence yesterday that the system would be able to meet its problems and fulfill its opportunities.
NASHVILLE, Oct. 24--Efforts to pick a jury in the conspiracy trial of James R. Hoffa proved unsuccessful today for the second day.

Unusual terms have gone to Edward Albee for his first Broadway play, the successful "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" An important factor acccounting for the generous arrangement was that he had established a following with Off Broadway's devotees.

Communist tanks, guns, missiles and other military supplies that have been delivered to Cuba within the last 19 months have given Premier Fidel Castro a position of strength, which, in the view of Pentagon strategists, constitutes an increasing threat to hemispheric security.
The Christiana Stable's Smart came along fast in the closing stages to win the Joe H. Palmer Handicap for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--The White House asked newspapers, news magazines, radio and television stations today to use "caution and discretion" in handling certain kinds of information regarded by the Defense Department as "vital" to national security during the Cuban crisis.
New York Democrats began distributing 100,000 copies of a "Rockefeller Coloring Card" yesterday lampooning, the Governor on campaign issues.

The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income for the September quarter of $15,761,000 or $1.14 a share. This was 11.2 per cent greater than the $14,172,000, or $1.08 a share in the 1961 period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--The White House asked newspapers, news magazines, radio and television stations today to use "caution and discretion" in handling certain kinds of information regarded by the Defense Department as "vital" to national security during the Cuban crisis.
New York Democrats began distributing 100,000 copies of a "Rockefeller Coloring Card" yesterday lampooning, the Governor on campaign issues.

The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income for the September quarter of $15,761,000 or $1.14 a share. This was 11.2 per cent greater than the $14,172,000, or $1.08 a share in the 1961 period.

WALTER O'MALLEY had choice seats for the 1962 World Series, the royal box in his Chavez Ravine stadium. For reasons slightly beyond his control, however, the California part of the festivities took place in San Francisco instead. So The O'Malley went hunting in Wyoming. He was on the prowl for elk, although most baseball men were convinced that if he ever found Walter Alston in his gunsights, he'd shoot him neatly below the antlers.
The city's largest, most expensive and most modern steam ship terminal was dedicated yesterday.
Standard Brands, Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased the quarterly dividend from 45 to 50 cents on its common stock. It is payable on Dec. 15, to stockholders of record of Nov. 15.
OMAHA, Oct. 25--Midwesterners got a closer look at the Cuba situation today as the Strategic Air Command's B-47 medium jet bombers arrived at various dispersal stations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--A major shake up in the Food and Drug Administration was demanded today by a citizens' advisory committee.
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company postponed yesterday an offering of $50,000,000 of first mortgage bonds.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25--Britain told the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today that there had been no change in her policy of not intervening in the affairs of Southern Rhodesia.

The consolidated net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, was estimated yesterday by M.J. Rathbone, president, at record of $641,000,000, or $2.96 each on the 216,530,000 shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Rail and truck loadings of freight in the week ended Oct. 20, were up from the preceding week it was reported today. Spokesmen noted that this was the period of peak loadings for the fall season.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Oct. 25 --J. Ruppert Schalk, a vice president of the Jacob Ruppert brewery in New York, died of a heart attack today while being driven by car from his home at Linwood Farms here, to Poughkeepsie, where he was to have undergone an eye examination. His age was 66.
WEST HEMISTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25--Richard V. Napoli, business agent of Local 55, of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association, died today in his home at 585 Gaynor Place. His age was 67.
New York commodity futures declined yesterday in a general retreat. Volume also was reduced.
Two 25-room mansions and six acres at 73 to 95 Cedar Avenue in the West End district of Long Branch, N.J., have been sold and will make way for a garden apartment building for 92 families.
ALBANY, Oct. 25--The Court of Appeals today upheld a ruling that a worker was entitled to take time off to vote with pay only to the extent necessary to go to the polls.
New York University installed Dr. James McNaughton Hester as its 11th and youngest president yesterday at a ceremony in Philharmonic Hall of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) --The Census Bureau reported today that 7,270,648 running bales of cotton from this year's cotton crop were ginned prior to Oct. 18. This compared with 5,605,725 ginned to the same date last year.

THE bane of every redblooded boy's mother's ex istence--the sneaker--is undergoing a quiet fashion change. The newest version of the last word in rubber-soled footwear has been described by one disconsolate "mom" as a sawedoff basketball sneaker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--Two aspects of the vast operation of Government that was initiated by President Kennedy's decision to blockade certain supply lines to Cuba and the measures to effect it may interest historians as much as the ultimate consequences. And these two aspect deserve not to be obscured in the concentration of the American people on the unfolding of the military drama in the Caribbean.
Yesterday, the analysts were busy grinding out market letters with the greatest show of enthusiasm in some time. Now, at last, there was something tangible to say--and do.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., which entered the synthetic-fiber field by producing rayon in 1920, announced yesterday that it was going out of the rayon business.

Heavy casualties have slowed the San Diego Chargers to a limp in the American Football League race and given an uncharacteristic aura to their game with the New York Titans at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. For the first time in eight meetings, the Titan eleven appears to have a real chance for success against the club that has ruled the Western Division since 1960.

YONKERS, Oct. 25--Elaine Rodney, a 25-to-1 shot who previously had shown no particular liking for an off track, reveled in the snow, sleet and slop tonight to score a smashing upset over Su Mac Lad in the $60,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

The names of 21-young women who will be presented at the sixth annual Mistletoe Debutante. Ball have been announced by the co-chairmen of the committee for the event, Mrs. Horace J. McAfee and Mrs. Walker G. Buckner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)--The Treasury announced plans today for an $11,000,000,000 refunding of bonds and notes coming due.

MISSOULA, Mont., Oct. 25 (UPI)--Lieut. Gen. Frank Mil-, burn, U.S.A., retired, a corps commander in World War II and twice Supreme Commander of United Nations forces in Korea, died here today at the age of 70.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25-- The Benjamin Franklin Bridge across the Delaware River, linking this city with Camden, N.J., was closed to pedestrians today for an indefinite period.
The National Council of Churches commended the Kennedy Administration yesterday for taking the Cuban crisis to the United Nations and the Organization of American States.
John Steinbeck turned on the television set in his home in Sag Harbor, L.I., for details about the Cuban crisis yesterday and learned that he had won the 1962 Nobel Prize for literature.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25 --Robert M. Morgenthau, declared today he would favor state aid for home fallout shelters if the Cuban situation worsens.
Louis L. Goldberg has chosen a tough assignment for his first venture into politics.

Four walk-up buildings of five and six stories with a total of 115 apartments at 170-78 Thompson Street, between Bleecker and West Houston Streets, have been sold by 17078 Thompsori Street Associates. The buyer was a corporation headed by Ben Fishbein. Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers in the sale. The property has a plot of 125 by 100 feet.
Special to The New York Times
Fourteen Negro students who have been boycotting a Queens junior high school appeared for classes yesterday in obedience to an order of Family Court.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 26--James B. Donovan, the DemocraticLiberal candidate for the Senate, said tonight that negotiations for the release of the Cuban invasion prisoners were continuing despite the current crisis.

American materials technology has never been better prepared to do its full share in time of crisis than it is now, Allan Ray Putnam, managing director of the American Society for Metals, said here yesterday in comments keyed to the Cuban crisis.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it would solicit bids about Nov. 1 for 250 air-conditioned cars for the former Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.

The United States Treasury's gold stock sustained a $50,000,000 loss during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The exchange of United States dollars for the monetary gold was said to be unrelated to the Cuban crisis.
Arthur Miller's new play will be the first production of the Lincoln Center repertory company next fall.

Meeting on "The Certification of Teachers in Science" under the auspices of the eastern region of the Association for the Education of Teachers in Science, Teachers College, 525 West 120th Street, 9:30 A.M. Afternoon session, 1:45 P.M. Continues tomorrow.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25--Nationalist Chinese commandos have carried out several raids against Communist positions along the mainland coast north of Hong Kong during the last two weeks, according to reports published here today.

This season Carnegie Hall is sponsoring four series of six events each in its Recital Hall. The first series, presenting solo artists, was started last night with a recital by Bethany Beardslee, soprano, and Robert Helps, pianist. If the rest of the four series has the distinction of this opening one--and on paper they promise as much --the musical scene will be well served by them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The United States arms blockade of Cuba has added to the woes of the maritime industry in various countries, particularly Greece, according to displomats here today.
Progress in medicine has often taken such dramatic forms that some of the very real achievements have gone almost unnoticed except by statisticians. One of these achievements is reflected in ...
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (AP)-- Yevgeny Yevtushenko, one of the most popular Soviet poets published verses today in Pravda, denouncing the United States blockade of arms shipments to Cuba.
Harry S. Dale, a senior vice president of Book-of-the-Month Club Inc., died Wednesday in Club, Inc., died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He lived at 300 East 57th Street.
Governors and Congressmen from eleven northeastern states learned of the interception of a Soviet tanker at a briefing yesterday on the Cuban crisis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25--President Kennedy agreed today to talks between the United States and U Thant, Acting Secretary General, on whether arrangements can be made for negotiations in the Cuban crisis. The blockade of Cuba will continue.

The American Home Products Corporation attained record sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the producer of pharmaceucal, vitamin, household specialties and food, disclosed yesterday.

Richter's Jewelers, Inc., has leased the store, mezzanine and basement in 730 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street for 15 years at an aggregate rental of more than $600,000. A Sheldon Jaffe was the broker. David Baldwin of the Charles F. Noyes Company acted as agent of the building. Richter's will move next spring from 589 Fifth Avenue where it has been for 35 years.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 25-- Southern members of Congress came out of a briefing here today voicing optimism about chances of avoiding war.
LONDON, Oct. 25--Share prices advanced strongly on the stock market today, erasing a substantial part of the heavy falls of the last two days.
The Board of Estimate moved yesterday to prepare the City Council for the vast powers it will acquire under the new City Charter, which becomes effective Jan. 1.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25-- A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that no question of missile bases on Turkish soil had been raised during talks between United States diplomats and Foreign Ministry officials.

A 39-year-old Brooklyn lawyer interrupted his trial in Supreme Court yesterday to plead guilty to charges of trying to bribe a patrolman to alter his testimony in a drunken-driving case of the lawyer's client.
It is 15 years since Representative Abraham J. Multer has bestirred himself for election in Brooklyn's 13th Congressional District to the extent that he is doing so this year.

Norris Schermerhorn Oliver, an investment counselor with Kidder, Peabody Co. at 10 East 45th Street, died yesterday morning at St. Luke's Hospital. He lived in the Williams Club at 24 East 39th Street. His age was 73.

Events today: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; "Madama Butterfly," presented by New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Eugene Istomin, pianist, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15; Boston Symphony Orchestra. Erich Leinsdorf, conductor, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Tamas Vasary, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
A leading discount-store merchant declared yesterday that discounting was being unjustly stigmatized as a result of the financial difficulties encountered recently by several companies in the field.

The scholarship fund of the Decorators Club, Inc., will benefit from an invitation luncheon to be given by the club next Wednesday at the Cafe in Philharmonic Hall, Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts.
The wholesale commodity index rose to 82 Wednesday from 81.3 Tuesday.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 25 (AP) --Votes for the eight positions on the board of directors of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., were cast today at the company's annual stockholders' meeting, but no decision was reached in the company's proxy fight.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25--The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association endorsed a resolution today to make the national president of the P.G.A. a salaried officer.
TYLER, Tex., Oct. 25 (UPI) --The defense accused District Judge Otis T. Dunagan today of assuming a role as prosecutor in Billie Sol Estes' trial for theft and swindling.

The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots will start talks with East Coast and Gulf Coast ship operators next week on a plan to increase the retirement pension benefits for ship officers from $150 to $300 a month.

AS October wanes, the supply of fall fruit swells. There will be an abundance of apples for dunking at Halloween and a plentiful supply of the squash family for decorations. There should be no shortage of applesauce for pork or cranberry sauce for turkey.

Two barmaids told a Congressional committee here yesterday that they had worked in Harlem taverns for as little as $35 for a 60-hour week and had been forced to consort with patrons and serve drinks to known gamblers and uniformed patrolmen.

PARIS, Oct. 25--France probably will defer to United States opinion on the proposal by U Thant, Acting Secretary General or the United Nations, for a cruce in the Cuban dispute, it was indicated here.

The Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation announced yesterday the election of F. Norman Hartmann as president and chief operating, officer. He succeeds Walter J. Bergman, who will continue to serve as chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Oct.25 (AP) --The United States Court of Appeals held today that Congress intended to nullify "hotcargo" labor agreements whether they were signed before or after Nov. 13, 1959.
The Board of Education received yesterday a gift of 2,000 sets of color-plate reproductions of French paintings for distribution among the city's 860 schools.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- The Defence Department reported today on the status of the nation's civil defense program. The report was an apparent response to inquiries prompted by the Cuban crisis.
Tom Tresh of the New York Yankees and Al Jackson of the New York Mets are at the opposite ends of baseball's social structure.
Communist China has now achieved military gains in the Himalayas that put her in a strong position to get what she wants both territorially and politically from India.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Voice of America officials said tonight it had succeeded in penetrating Soviet-bloc jamming transmitters with an eight-anda-half-hour broadcast barrage explaining the United States position on Cuba.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 25-- Policemen firing submachine guns broke up a protest march on the United States Embassy tonight by sympathizers of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

THE group of seven standard radio stations active ly assisting the Voice of America in reaching listeners in Cuba is performing an unusual public service that should not go unnoticed. Moreover, it is an example of imagination in broadcasting that apparently caught the Castro regime off, guard.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)--The United States has advised interested countries, including the Soviet Union, what to do if their submerged submarines encounter United States ships blockading Cuba.

A Jewish women's service and educational agency warned yesterday that private projects and other voluntary efforts were not sufficient to meet the "overwhelming needs of young people who are untrained and out of work."
The Chrysler Corporation had profitable operations in the third quarter, for the second time in five years.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 --The Continentals and Minutemen were on the alert today for an ambush by a party of invading Indians variously known as the Tomahawks and Savages.

RO CUARTO, Argentina, Oct. 25 (AP)--Cacho Ibarra, the Argentine race driver, died late tonight after his car overturned on a rain-washed stretch of road during the first lap of the 11-day Argentina Standard Grand Prix.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 25--The Chinese Communists captured the key town of Towang today. Towang, the first town to fall to the Chinese, is at the head of a 100-mile road to the Indian military base at Tezpur in the foothills of the state of Assam.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25-- Honey Hughes and her dolls were all tied in knots this morning 10 minutes before her mother's first press conference began.
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25--John Steinbeck has won, the 1962 Nobel Prize for Literature.
ROME, Oct. 25--One of the world's leading Roman Catholic liturgists predicted today that the church was about to break the bonds of four centuries of "mere devotionalism."
LONDON, Oct. 25--Bertrand Russell suggested tonight that the United States Government "pretends I do not exist" like "East Germany and China."
Prince Fulco de Bourbon, a member of the royal house of France, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 55 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Some of the closest and possibly most significant battles of this year's Congressional elections are being fought "head-to--head" by incumbent members of the House.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 25-- Thomas A. Keating, a lawyer and a Democratic leader here for more than 50 years, died last night in his home. He was 75 year's old.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP) --Former Lieut. Gov. Harold J. Powers, a Republican, accused Richard M. Nixon today of making "a cheap bid for votes" in the Cuban crisis.

WIMBLEDON, England, Oct. 25 (UPI)--The emphasis will be on tennis and not on panties, Wimbledon tennis officials decreed today. They said that only "all white" panties would be accepted for women's wear in the future.

WILTON, Conn., Oct. 25--A Dec. 8 wedding here has been planned by Miss Linda Mixsell Barber and Nelson H. Morgan. Mr. and Mrs. David Stoddart Barber of Wilton have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Thomas Morgan of Westport and the late Mr. Morgan.

LONDON, Oct. 25--Prime Minister Macmillan declared today that when the West moved, as he hoped, into "a wider field of negotiation" with the Soviet Union there must be independent verification of Soviet words and promises.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday elected Norman H. Strouse chairman. He is pres-- ident of the J. Walter Thompson Company advertising agency.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Water-buying housewives, tiredeyed Government officials and a big demand for transistor radios were the chief signs of crisis in Washington today.

In the crisis precipitated by Premier Khrushchev's reckless adventure in Cuba, a head-on collision has thus far been avoided by virtue of the fact that since imposition of the blockade both sides have been moving with caution. This is all to the goody. But the problems that have been raised are as far as ever from being solved.
HAVANA Oct. 28 (UPI)-- The first units of a 22-nation "International Combat Brigade" are in Cuba to defend her from any United States invasion, the Government newspaper Revolucion said today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 --More than 1,450 letters exchanged by Woodrow Wilson and his first wife were presented to Princeton University today by the Wilsons' daughter, Mrs. Eleanor Wilson McAdoo.
Five steel company executives were fined a total of $44,000 yesterday after having pleaded no contest to charges of fixing prices and rigging bids on steel forgings.
Ninety million, Americans will have a 25-hour day Sunday. Daylight saving time ends then.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused a second union today of discrimination against Negro employes and asked that it be stripped of its Federal certification as exclusive collective bargaining agent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25--Following are the texts of replies by President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev to proposals on Cuba by Acting Secretary General U Thant: I deeply appreciate the spirit which prompted your message of yesterday.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that it had cut its regular quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share as a direct result of last week's adverse rate decision by the Federal Power Commission. The company had previously paid quarterly dividends of 32 cents a share.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25-- Latin-American countries that have not made a "substantial advance" in agrarian reform in five years will have "difficulty" in getting aid from the Alliance for Progress, Teodoro Moscoso, the United States coordinator for the aid program, said today.

ALGIERS, Oct. 25--The decision taken yesterday in New York by Mohammed Khemisti, Algerian Foreign Minister, to halt aid talks with the United States leaves Algeria "alone with France" to seek a solution to her profound economic and technical problems.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25--The Sovviet missile sites under con struction in Cuba would have a capability of firing thirty-two to forty 2,000-mile missiles with nuclear warheads simultaneously, members of Congress reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Questions are being asked in Washington about how and why the Cuban crisis developed with so little warning.

The two major campaign groups working for Governor Rockefeller's re-election have spent more than four times as much money as the three principal campaign committees for Robert M. Morgenthau, his Democratic-Liberal opponent.

BONN, Oct. 25 (Reuters)-- The West German Bundestag (lower house) cleared Defense Minister Franz Jesef Strauss today of charges that he had misused his official position by recommending a private German building firm for a United States Army housing project.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25-- Heavy buying of groceries, touched off by an urgent statement by the city civil defense director, appeared to be tapering off today.
Production of lumber in the country totaled 217,952,000 board feet in the week ended Oct. 20, according to reports received yesterday from regional lumber associations.
A spokesman for the city's five county medical societies defended the quality of medical care here yesterday against recent criticism.
PRAGUE, Oct. 25--Thousands of shouting, screaming Czechs demonstrated in front of the United States Embassy here today to protest against the blockade of Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- A social blackout has been imposed at the White House because of the Cuban crisis.

PLANDOME MILLS, L.I., Oct. 25--John W. Frommer, president of L.K. Comstock Co., Inc., electrical contractors, at 155 East 44th Street in New York, died today of a heart ailment in his home at 107 Grist Mill Lane. His age was 58.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25--The Soviet Union urged India today to open talks with Communist China in an effort to settle them border differences.
A total of 7,892,002 New Yorkers have qualified to vote in the Nov. 6 election.
BERLIN, Oct. 25--The customers and the staff at the elegant beauty parlor off West Berlin's fashionable Kurfurstendamm had their heads bent low over the counter, poring over a large open map.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 25--A jury of seven women and five men was finally picked late today to try James R. Hoffa on charges of illegally taking $1,000,000 from an employer for whom he once settled a strike.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuters) --An American industrialist described Premier Khrushchev tonight as "very tired but very calm" at the height of the Cuban crisis.
THE pairings are now complete for the trials that will be played at Phoenix, Ariz., to select the 1963 North American international team.

Commerce broke Franklin's two-year hold on the Manhattan Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The victors topped 12 other schools with a lowpoint total of 23, giving Coach Marty Lewis a championship in his second year at the school.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--A Senate subcommittee has found that there was more shadow than substance to the charge that military leaders were being "muzzled" in their public discussions of Communism and the cold war.
SCARSDALE, N.Y, Oct. 25-- William G. Dryden, treasurer of Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturers of steam power plant equipment died today in his home at 19 Lebanon Road. He was 61 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The United States held firm today to its demand that the Soviet missile threat in Cuba be dispelled before there is any respite for East-West negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 20 were 1 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year. Only three of the 12 Federal distracts reporting showed gains for the period.
JERUSALEM, Israel Sector, Oct. 25--Small demonstrations against the United States blockade of Cuba took place this evening in Tel Aviv and here.
Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Sica of Jamaica, Queens, again are lending their home for a private concert in behalf of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation tomorrow evening.

Brandt Examines Coexistence During his recent visit to this country, Willy ,Brandt, Mayor of Berlin, delivered the manuscript of a book to Harvard University Press. Scheduled for publication early next year under the title "The Ordeal of Coexistence," the book deals with the opportunities, obligations and perils that coexistence presents for the free nations. The main sections are derived from the two Pollack lectures Mayor Brandt delivered at Harvard this month.
NEW England's top candidates for the Lambert Cup, which symbolizes Eastern small-college football leadership, will be heavily engaged tomorrow.
LIKE the jester in a fine, old play, "Tchin-Tchin" is outrageously comic and tenderly rueful.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 25 --Prince Souvanna Phouma, the neutralist Premier, returned today from a two-day visit Hanoi. He said that the North Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Pham Van Dong, had given "his assurance that there are no North Vietnamese troops in Laos."

The 1962 Peace Award of the Catholic Association for International Peace will be presented to George Meany, president of the merged labor federation, at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25--Uganda was unanimously approved today by the General Assembly as the 110th member of the United Nations.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuters)--Following is the text of a statement on Cuba by Prime Minister Macmillan in the House of Commons today:
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 25--The home of the Atlantic Fleet welcomed ashore today 2,432 women and children evacuated on Monday from the United States naval base at Guantanamo, Cuba.

NEWARK, Oct. 25--Thirteen persons, including two officials of a local printing plant, have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here in an alleged conspiracy involving $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 in counterfeit securities.

Rex Harrison has been signed to re-create his original role of Professor Higgins in the film version of "My Fair Lady." He will play opposite Audrey Hepburn in the Warner Brothers musical, which starts production in London early next year under the direction of George Cukor.
The Sante Fe Engineering Company and M.M. Sund Stolt, Los Angeles, have received a $16,280,069 Air Force contract to construct three test stands for engines at Edwards Air Force Base.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25--A leading Russian scientist has called for a fundamentally new system of prices in the Soviet economy that would accurately reflect actual labor and material costs of a given commodity.

MIAMI, Oct. 25--A telegram has been sent to President Kennedy from Miami in the name of 40,000 members of eight Cuban underground organizations in Cuba, declaring they will not accept any government "imposed" by the United States when Fidel Castro is overthrown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) --President Kennedy cleared his desk today of the last of the bills passed by the 87th Congress. Among the 11 final measures he signed were two money bills that completed record peacetime appropriations of $102,262,154,659.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25--Dr. Clifford G. Grulee Sr., a cofounder of the American Academy of Pediatrics in Evanston, died, last night while attending a dinner of the academy's executive board in the Orrington Hotel there. He was 82 years old.
It was back to normal on the stock exchange yesterday. Prices declined, but not drastically, as trading slackened following the sharp plunges and rallies in hectic trading earlier this week.
St. Philip's, the largest Protestant Episcopal Church in the country, announced last night that it had begun a drive to raise $850,000 for a Community Youth Center in Harlem.
The bond market grew quiet yesterday. Governments drifted off in extremely inactive trading as announcement of the Treasury's November-December refunding plans were awaited.
The State Tax Commission exerted its awesome power yesterday in a move to collect 80 cents from a Manhattan couple.
ROME, Oct. 25 (AP)--Following, in a translation from French supplied by the Vatican press offices, is the text of an appeal for peace today by Pope John XXIII:

BERLIN, Oct. 26--About 400 soldiers from the British garrison in West Berlin returned to the city prematurely today from exercises in West Germany to bring the Western allied forces here to full strength.
DETROIT, Oct. 25--Sales of new cars during the second ten days of October soared above the 200,000-unit mark for the second straight 10-day period.
A state Supreme Court justice was called upon yesterday to decide whether a husband was responsible for the support of a child born through artificial insemination.
The Board of Estimate unanimously denied yesterday an amended application filed by former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh of Brooklyn for retirement on a city pension.

AT the end of the third quarter of the basketball game between two Ohio schools, Prospect High and Elm City High, the hot-handed Bob Rodgers of Prospect was summoned to the sideliness by his coach, Fred McCumber.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba is combining caution with defiance in his reaction to the United States blockade of his nation.
LONDON, Oct. 25--Henry A. Barnes, New York City's Traffic Commissioner, said today that London was in urgent need of a separate traffic authority.
An agreement on a five-year contract covering 5,000 employes of 200 hotels and residence houses has been reached by Local 144 of the Building Service Employes Union and Associated Hotels, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 25-- Warner Brothers, whose "The Chapman Report" brought it trouble with the movie industry's censors and with the Legion of Decency, is planning to film "Sex and the Single Girl," the best seller by Helen Brown, as a comedy instead of a sociological drama.
ROME, Oct. 25--In a voice charged with emotion, Pope John XXIII implored the rulers of the world today to do everything in their power to save the peace.

Riding for the first time in competition in this country, Fred Winter piloted Pete Bostwick's Baby Prince to a record-breaking performance at Belmont Park yesterday. The leading jumper in England, Winter impressed a crowd of 16,013 in the $18,600 New York Turf Writers Cup.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 25-- Doug Ford, the Tam O'Shanter pro, and LaJunta White of Englewood, today gained the semi-final round of the Jack Moone Memorial golf tournament at the Dellwood Country Club.
Michael Langham, artistic director of the Stratford (Ont.) Shakespeare Festival, has been signed to stage "Andorra," the Max Frisch drama, which Cheryl Crawford and Roger Stevens are co-producing.

BONN, Oct. 25--By an overwhelming vote, the West German Trades Union Congress approved today the calling of a general strike if the Government "endangers" basic rights or "threatens" the independence of the unions.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 (AP)--New York City and southern California could have averted or postponed the need for huge water supply projects if they had not wasted so much water, an Indiana University professor asserted today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25-- Walter A. Ryan, an unfrocked priest who, was the central figure in a $2,375,000 suit in New York against the Roman Catholic. Church, died Saturday of cancer in Letterman General Hospital.

EVERYTHING was workmanlike about last night's New York Philharmonic concert in Philharmonic Hall. Leonard Bernstein led the orchestra in a well-delivered performance of Haydn's Symphony No. 102 in B flat. It is a work that he must like, for he directed it a few years ago with the Philharmonic.

ON Sept. 11, 1709, near the village of Malplaquet the allied armies commanded by the Duke of Marlborough defeated the French after inflictfng and suffering hideous casualties. A young ensign in the Saxon contingent, who was only a spectator of the action, was horrified by the slaughter. His name was Maurice de Saxe and he was only 12 years old.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's directors cut the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday to 37 cents a share from the 60 cents it had been paying since early 1957. The nation's second largest steel producer failed to earn even its newly-reduced dividend rate in the 1962 third quarter, netting 27 cents a common share.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25 --The State Public Utilities Commission granted permission to the New Haven Railroad today to trim its service within Connecticut, effective Sunday.
The State Supreme Court was asked yesterday to declare unconstitutional the minimium wage law signed Monday by Mayor Wagner.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 25 (AP)--Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., battled a cold wind and a formidable golf course today to win her third successive North and South senior title with a final-round 80, six over par, and a 54-hole total of 233.

PARIS, Oct. 25--The European Economic Community and 18 independent African states, mostly French-speaking, have agreed on an extension in new form of the association of the Africans with the community.

MARSEILLES, France, Oct. 25--Opposition leaders in Marseilles, France's second largest city, admit they are fighting a losing battle in their efforts to reject President de Gaulle's appeal for a vote of confidence.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The United Automobile Workers has suffered a surprising defeat in a union-shop vote among workers of North American Aviation, Inc.

The 1,000th performance of one of the longest-running one woman, shows in the city will be presented this week just a few blocks off Broadway. Although the show has no title, it has been called "Back in a Bank" and "The Sound of Music and Money."

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 (AP)--Gov. Richard J. Hughes' 5-month-old son, Thomas, will be operated on Nov. 9 for cataract in both eyes.

The New York Knickerbockers' National Basketball Association game with the Boston Celtics tonight will be preceded by the sixth annual Knicks' Old-Timers Game. The doubleheader at Madison Square Garden will start at 7 o'clock.
President Kennedy expressed his thanks to Governor Rockefeller yesterday for supporting the Presidential decision to impose an arms blockade on Cuba.
John Steinbeck has been compared to Mark Twain and Ernest Hemingway because of his preoccupation with the people and the land of America.

Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, proposed yesterday that United States and Canadian broadcasters establish a method for expediting the exchange of satellite television programs among continents.
ROME, Oct. 25 (AP)--The Nobel Foundation, which has given out more than 400 awards in more than 60 years, received a peace prize itself today.

THE hour that vanished from a great many American households last April is about to return. At 2 A.M. Sunday, Standard Time returns to many sections of the country and the ritual means that millions of clocks must be set back an hour.

HIGH-POINT, N.C. FURNITURE is big business in this state, which leads the nation in furniture production. Most of the manufacturers have their factories and showrooms near High Point, a slow-paced Southern town that is near Winston-Salem and Greensboro.These three towns share an airport and a large sign over the passenger entrance, welcomes the traveler to Furnitureland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The Defense Department announced today the first interception of a Soviet ship in the Cuban blockade. The ship, the oil tanker Bucharest, was not boarded and was allowed to continue after the Navy "ascertained" from its appearance that it had only petroleum aboard, a Pentagon spokesman said.

Cox is an old hunter.

THE essay writer occupies one of the more exposed of all literary positions. Most other writers, novelists and historians for example, can go about their business and keep their own personalities safely out of sight. The modern journalist is nearly always concealed behind some cover. And even lyric poets are able to work their trade and give away no more about their character, or lack of it, than they wish to.

President Charles de Gaulle's none-too-decisive victory in the national referendum leaves the political future of the French people still up in the air. THE French blame their livers for most of their ailments; yet they consume calves' liver with gusto. In the United States the liver is not blamed for every internal twinge--except those that may accompany the eating of it. Because calves' liver is consumed chiefly for its nutritious merits, its delicious merits are often either overlooked or lost through being overcooked.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 29--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made an urgent request to the United States today for military assistance against the Chinese Communists. He received an immediate pledge that weapons would be rushed to India.

PARIS, Oct. 29--The North Atlantic Treaty Organization decided today to keep its Commander in Chief in Europe, Gen. Lauris Norstad, in his post two months longer because of the crisis provoked by the dispute over Cuba.
The National Maritime Union yesterday became the exclusive bargaining representative for 3,000 unlicensed seamen aboard East Coast vessels of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.
HOUSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)-- Neil A. Armstrong and Elliot M. See will be paid $17,000 a year as the nations first two civilian astronauts, the manned spacecraft center said today.

An offer of about $40,000,000 by Samuel I. Newhouse for The Omaha World-Herald has been accepted by the directors of the company that operates the newspaper.
The International Longshoremen's Association succeeded yesterday in halting the delivery of two shiploads of gunny cloth from India to Cuba.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (Reuters)--Sophie Tucker stole the show at tonight's annual Royal Variety Performance, which was attended by Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday withdrew its official support of the controversial national letter of intent.
Formation of the "Alleghany Corporation Stockholders' Committee for Peace and Progress Within the Corporation" was announced yesterday.
