WASHINGTON, Oct. 29-- Would the boisterous comic successes of yesteryear be anything more than period pieces today? You get a lively opportunity to ponder this question at the Arena Stage, where the resident company's opening bill is Moss Hart's and George S. Kaufman's "Once in a Lifetime."

"IT was the finest exhibition of pin-point passing I've ever seen." So said Greasy Neale in the afterglow of the 49-34 smashing of the Redskins by the Giants on Sunday. Allie Sherman said the same thing but Greasy has at least 30 years coaching seniority on his youthful protege and therefore speaks with far more authority.
Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover trained verbal fire on American industrial management yesterday for "failure... to live up to the exacting standards of reactor technology."
PARIS, Oct. 29.--President de Gaulle ceased to be seven feet tall, politically speaking, at about 1:30 A.M. today.
It is virtually impossible for Negro actors to earn a steady livelihood in the American theater, movies or broadcasting, a Congressional hearing was told here yesterday.

Cars and express buses can do the best job of moving people into and out of big cities at less cost, according to a study made for the White House Conference on Civilian Technology.

THE objectives of the Writers' Stage are admirable: to discover and produce work by new American writers, to establish a theater in which writers, actors, directors and designers develop their craft and question their times, and to build a company with continuity.
Yesterday's 33 per cent cut in the common dividend of the United States Steel Corporation was the first dividend reduction by the nation's biggest steel company in nearly a quarter century.

Reform is the keynote of the campaign in the 20th Congressional District in Manhattan's hilly, apartment-crowded northwestern quarter.

A FEW weeks ago Dame Edith Sitwell celebrated her 75th birthday. A distinguished poet, a critic, an essayist and anthologist Dame Edith has all her life cultivated her eccentricities with imperial sang froid. One of the most colorful personalities of her age, she has long been fascinated by the personalities of a more colorful age, the 16th century.
The odds-on favorite to win election next Tuesday in the 21st Congressional District in the Bronx nearly lost the fight two months ago in the Democratic primary.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP)-- Initial reports indicate that biggame hunters in the state are finding their quarry plentiful, large and varied, the Conservation Department said today. The deer kill is running "from one-and-a-half to two times greater than previous years," the department said.

The directors of the United States Steel Corporation cut the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday. The new rate is 50 cents a share, compared with the 75 cents paid since the final period of 1956.

Despite the truce in the Cuban situation and the temporacy suspension of this country's blockade, the International Longshoremen's Association intends to continue its boycott of all ships and shiplines dealing with Cuba.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 30--A United Nations spokesman said tonight that the talks between Acting Secretary General Thant and Premier Castro today in Havana had been "very useful." He added that the talks would be continued at 10 A.M. tomorrow.
LONDON, Oct. 30--Industrial shares followed their large rises of yesterday by easing a penny or two today in quiet trading on the stock exchange.

PARIS, Oct. 30--The members of the European Economic Community will debate and probably decide on their first response to the new United States Trade Expansion Act within the next three months, it was reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Oct. 30--The General Assembly voted today to exclude Communist China from the United Nations for at least another year.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (AP) --John J. Dreyfus Jr., owner of Beau Purple, accepted an invitation today to run his colt in the $125,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course Nov. 12.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges proposed today that Congress act to cut taxes quickly next year and leave tax reform until later.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 30 (AP)--Mrs. Amy Otis Earhart, mother of Amelia Earhart, the aviator, died in a nursing home yesterday. Her age was 95.

OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 30 (AP) --A bottle was hurled into a car returning James H. Meredith to his dormitory at the University of Mississippi tonight. It shattered glass and injured a Federal marshal.

Three thousand city firemen led municipal officials, labor representatives and firefighters from this country and Canada yesterday in a tribute to the six men who died fighting a Queens fire last Friday.

The feasibility of establishing a central agency for predicting how high school students will perform in college will be studied by the College Entrance Examination Board in field trials over the next three years.

Boston borrowed $6,550,000 on various purpose bonds maturing from 1963 to 1982 at an interest cost of 2.7097 per cent. Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and Drexel Co. headed the group that bought the issue, and reoffered the securities priced to yield 1.60 to 3.30 per cent.

Harry Leibowitz and Milton Levin, have taken title to 52 acres of vacant land at New Dorp, S.I., acquired from the Astor estate. The Title Guarantee Company insured title. The property is zoned for commercial use.

Willie Shoemaker was an improved rider at Aqueduct yesterday, when he rode three winners in four races. The day before, on the opening day's program at the Big A, the country's leading jockey had only two winners in five attempts.

Tams-Witmark Music Library, Inc., supplier of Broadway musical shows for performance by amateur and professional groups, has leased a floor in the new building at 555 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of 56th Street. The concern will use the space for its world headquarters.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30--Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko conferred today for 45 minutes with Foy D. Kohler, the United States Ambassador.

Crown Drug Stores, Inc., has leased a store with 15,000 square feet of space for a branch in the Walt Whitman shopping center on Route 110, off Jericho Turnpike in Huntington, L.I. The development is being completed by the Winston-Muss Corporation.

The market for government securities yesterday reflected the further decline in yields at the latest sale of Treasury bills. Prices of state, municipal and corporate debt issues rose again in quiet trading.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30-- The International Association of Machinists has lost a unionshop election among workers of the Convair Division of the General Dynamics Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30-- Manufacturers' sales and new orders rose in September after having dipped in August, the Commerce Department reported today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 30 --Mrs. Santina Manganero Rossetto, an artist and art lecturer, and the widow of Joseph Rossetto, an architect, died yesterday in Oyster Bay Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived at 34 Hamilton Avenue.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 30-- Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Grogins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Grogins, to Robert J. Sallick, son of Mrs. Samuel Gloss of Norwalk and the late Abraham Sallick.

Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lambert of Riverdale, the Bronx and New Fairfield; Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Anne Lambert, to Charles Robb Steinberg. His parents are Dr. and Mrs. Israel Steinberg of Yonkers. A wedding in December is planned.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 30--Indian Army leaders and Government planners believe that the Chinese Communist invasion will deeply affect India militarily and economically for years.
Cotton futures were 15 cents a bale down to 40 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
LONDON, Oct. 30--Workmen on high scaffolding began today to remove the grime of centuries, some of it an inch thick, from St. Paul's Cathedral.

The Continental Telephone Company is expanding its operations in Illinois through the purchase of 75 per cent of the common stock of the Looking Glass Prairie Telephone Company, an independent firm at Mascoutah, Ill. The stock was acquired for an undisclosed amount of cash.

Jan Smeterlin, Polish pianist who lives in England, gave a recital last night at Philharmonic Hall. It was his first appearance here in almost a decade, and his program was devoted to a composer in whom he has always specialized, Chopin.

Investors Mutual, Inc., the nation's largest mutual fund, wound up its fiscal year on Sept. 30 with net assets of $1,719,389,253, equal to $9.95 on 172,739,901 shares outstanding. This compared with $1,843,492,415, or $11.58 a share on 159,255,201 shares outstanding, one year earlier.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UPI)-- A Roman Catholic priest shot and captured today a knifewielding burglar who had fatally stabbed the priest's housekeeper and wounded her sister.

Joseph L. Mankiewicz withdrew yesterday from the controversy over who would complete the editing of the film "Cleopatra." He disengaged himself from Darryl F. Zanuck's production plans at Twentieth Century-Fox.

The Southern California Edison Company borrowed yesterday $50,000,000 on first and refunding mortgage bonds with a 4 per cent coupon. Halsey, Stuart Co. Inc. and associates bid successfully for the twentyfive year issue at 99.68 per cent. The bonds were reoffered to the public priced to yield 4.225 per cent.
Mayor Wagner described Governor Rockefeller yesterday as "not a man of honor and not to be trusted."
FOR the second time this season the exploits of Gary Wood at quarterback have earned the Cornell junior the Ivy League's designation as back of the week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--It still hurts to laugh these days, but the Cuban negotiations are not without their amusing aspects.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Wednesday, Oct. 31--Sir Roy Welensky's supporters took an expected early lead this morning in Northern Rhodesia's elections.

EL CAJON, Calif., Oct. 28-- "Oh, I suppose things could be better," remarked the young service station attendant with an Ivy League crewcut and Ivy League assurance, "But there are jobs. I just got this one. You ought to see the caliber of people down there collecting unemployment insurance."
The City Council was called on yesterday to seek the rejection of the proposal to develop Breezy Point on the Rockaway Peninsula, Queens, into a vast waterfront park.
The Waterfront Commission warned the port's 2,000 pier and terminal watchmen yesterday that the agency's investigators would be keeping close checks on the guards' activities.

A newcomer to the ballot in the New York State election this year will be the Conservative party. Its candidate for Governor is David H. Jaquith of Syracuse; for United States Senator, Kieran 0'Doherty of New York. There are candidates also for the other state offices of Lieutenant Governor, Controller and Attorney General.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30-- President Adolfo Lopes Mateos has set off widespread speculation here with the publi cation today of a critical letter to President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado of Cuba.
Edward V. Rickenbacker announced yesterday the formation of a national organization to protest the terms upon which President Kennedy settled the Cuban dispute with Premier Khrushchev.

The New York City Park Department has in no phase of its jurisdiction applied the dead hand of the past so adamantly against imaginative and flexible experimentation as in playground design and equipment. Here the dreary repetition of such items as a concrete or asphalt base topped by swings, teeter-totters, slides and the like has for years resisted all modernization efforts.
Bill Rigney, who helped to raise the Los Angeles Angels from infancy to a pennant contender in two years, was named the American League manager of the year today by the United Press International.
SANA, Yemen, Oct. 30 (UPI) --Premier Abdullah al-Salel says Yemen will soon have a democratic parliamentary government.
LONDON, Oct. 30--Britain will provide whatever aid India asks in her fight against Communist China's "brutal and ruthless" pressure, Prime Minister Macmillan promised today.
HAVANA, Oct. 30 (AP)--Cuban newspapers gave prominent display today to photographs of Premier Fidel Castro inspecting long-barreled coastal defense guns and antiaircraft weapons.
Donald Spitzer and Lewis Frohlinger, realty investors and syndicators, have contracted to buy the leasehold on the 13story office and store building at 80 William Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Senator Vance Hartke, chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee, suggested today that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower ought to consider withdrawing from the election campaign of 1962.
ROME, Oct. 30--Some Protestant observers attending the Ecumenical Council are acquiring a new image of the Roman Catholic Church.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 30-- Premier Khrushchev's public acknowledgment of the preence of rockets in Cuba under the direct control of Soviet military men has had a stunning effect on the political Left in Brazil.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 30 (AP)--Premier Souvanna Phouma said today that it was necessary to verify whether foreign troops remained in Laos in violation of the Geneva accords providing for the country's neutrality.

"I Picked a Daisy" is the title of the new Richard Rodgers-Alan Jay Lerner musical, due April 4 at the Majestic. For the first time, the collaborators decided to give their fans a glimmering of what to expect. The subject is extrasensory perception in a contemporary New York setting.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31-- Princeton put on its best offensive display of the season against Cornell last Saturday, gaining 387 yards on the ground, but nevertheless lost the Ivy League game, 35-34.

A one-hour documentary dramatization about Charles Dickens is being prepared by the Columbia Broadcasting System. It is expected to be televised on a Wednesday from 7:30 to 8:30 P.M. in January or February.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- The White House announced tonight that the air surveillance of Soviet missile sites in Cuba would he resumed tomorrow, along with the naval quarantine to prevent offensive weapons from reaching Cuba.

The financial defenses of the free world have been put to the test by the crisis over Cuba. Stock prices gyrated wildly; the price of gold increased; and speculative activity in both commodities and foreign exchange has been heavy.
The market for Government securities was a dull affair yesterday, with prices down a shade where changed.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 31 --Two teams posted net bestball scores of 66 at Round Hill Club today to tie for honors's in the final pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association season.

ANDREW WYETH, the American painter who is the subject of a large exhibition opening tomorrow at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo, must be the most contradictory phenomenon in contemporary art.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31--Premier Khrushchev has instructed Anastas I. Mikoyan, one of his most trusted deputies, to fly to Cuba on an urgent mission.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase of 9.2 per cent in kilowatt hour sales of electricity during the first nine months. Revenues rose by 5.9 per cent in the same period.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31-- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, was the recipient tonight of the National Defense Transportation Association's award for 1961 accomplishments.

HONG KONG, Oct. 31--Communist China's hate campaign against the United States reached a peak today. Newspaper editorials and articles called for worldwide support of Cuba against "imperialist aggression" directed by President Kennedy.

YORK, Pa., Oct. 31--Mahlon N. Haines, who made a fortune as "Haines the Shoe Wizard" and who gave his chainstore business to his employes two years ago, died this morning in York Hospital. He was 87 years old.

ALBANY, Oct. 31--The Conservative party's candidate, for the United States Senate, Kieran O'Doherty, and the party's state chairman, J. Daniel Mahoney, have been salaried employes of the party since last April.
PARENTS can help their children with homework, in the opinion of the National Education Association. The danger, however, lies in the fact that some parents actually do their children's homework.
The national board of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. has been ordered to explain in State Supreme Court this morning its failure to renew the charter of the Donora, Pa., Girl Scout Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--It is in the 39 campaigns for seats in the United States Senate that the Democratic party has its best chance this year to crack the tradition that a party in power loses Congressional seats in midterm elections.
In the 22d Congressional District in the Bronx, the temptation is strong to appeal to voters on the basis of ethnic background.
MIAMI, Oct. 31--Ten Cuban exiles were arrested on board a 35-foot yacht at 3 A.M. today as they sailed down the Miami River for the open sea. Presumably the youths were headed for Cuba.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 31 --James Wilson Riley, whose career encompassed the military and business, died yesterday at his home on Dingletown Road. He was 79 years old.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was getting started on a $145,000,000 expansion and improvement program, plans for which the company had reported earlier.

What is there about Y.A. Tittle of the Giants that enabled him to complete seven touchdown passes against the Washington Redskins last weekend? How many scoring strikes is he likely to pitch against the St. Louis Cardinals here Sunday?

SYRACUSE, Oct. 31--A pledge of $13,000,000 from S.I. Newhouse, the newspaper publisher, and his wife for a mass communications center at Syracuse University was announced today by Chancellor William P. Tolley.

DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 31-- Envoys from the United States, Britain, India and the Soviet Union called on Foreign Minister Mohammed Ali today to deliver messages on the border fighting between India and Communist China and on the Cuban crisis.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York completed arrangements yesterday with the Bank of Canada for a reciprocal currency exchange, on a stand-by basis, of $125,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- The number of unemployed persons declined by 200,000 from September to October, lowering the national unemployment rate to 5.5 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.

Robert St. John, author of several books about Israel, has written two more about that country that are on publisher's schedules. One is "They Came From Everywhere: Twelve Who Helped Mold Modern Israel."
AMARILLO, Tex.-- This breezy city on the High Plains of west Texas is normally a nice place where people get along pretty well with each other.

LONDON, Oct. 31--An 11year study of English dialects, the first part of which was published this week, lends proof to a conclusion established by George Bernard Shaw: Within a relatively small area, one Englishman may not necessarily understand another.
HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 31--A folk song that Larry Adler heard in Korea in 1961 has become the theme music of his first job in Hollywood since he was blacklisted in the nineteenforties for political reasons.
Distribution was started yesterday of more than 750,000 pieces of literature urging the election of candidates endorsed by the Committee for Educational Freedom.
GENEVA, Oct. 31--The European Economic Community stressed today that its expanding economy was of increasing benefit to nonmember countries throughout the world.

Horses out of the Garden of Eden commingled with the flags of the international jumping teams competing at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden to provide the decor last night for a champagne and cocktail reception and supper dance in the Versailles Ballroom of the Astor.

The president of the College Entrance Examination Board disagreed yesterday with critics of education in this country who maintain that the schools in Europe and the Soviet Union are better than American schools.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Exports and imports spurted in September, the Department of Commerce reported today. In the three-month period, July through September, imports set a record pace, an annual rate of $16,800,000,000, allowing for normal seasonal development.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31--The United States told the United Nations today with new emphasis that it would not accept any moratorium on nuclear tests without on-site inspection of underground disturbances.
A strike by the Newspaper Guild of New York began at The New York Daily News at 12:01 A.M. today.

DETROIT, Oct. 31--Bert Olmstead, who has been one of the best players in the National Hockey League, may wear a New York Ranger uniform this season. Bill Jennings, the president of the Rangers, met with Olmstead today in New York.
The New York Post endorsed Robert M. Morgenthau for Governor yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 31-- Larry Goetz, who had been a baseball umpire in the National League for 22 years, died here this morning after a heart attack. His age was 67.
Large stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., yesterday announced plans to sell 1,725,000 shares of General Motors Corporation common stock.
BONN, Oct. 31--Minister of Justice Wolfgang Stammberger submitted his resignation to Chancellor Adenauer tonight.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday put the University of Dayton on probation for two years for violations of the basketball recruiting rules.

Jorge Bolet, the Cuban-born pianist who is now an American citizen, celebrated the 25th anniversary of his Carnegie Hall debut with a recital there last night. A large audience attended and greeted Mr. Bolet with cheers at many junctures.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)--The Government announced completion today of a campaign aimed at making certain that drugs used to treat dairy cattle are kept out of the milk.
In a striking coincidence, two companies announced independently yesterday the same scientific achievement, which, they said, promises to open the door to communication by light waves.

The Christmas mail rush will prevent the swift completion of the General Post Office building's first exterior cleaning since 1935. Since Aug. 6 a crew of 20 workmen has been steam-cleaning the structure on Eighth Avenue between 31st and 33d Streets.

BERLIN, Oct. 31--Mayor Willy Brandt left today for talks with British leaders. There were indications that the city government was seeking to win allied agreement on a new plan for access by Germans to Berlin ...
THIS deal was played at The Whist Club of New York by Charles Lochridge, who has an international reputation as a dummy player and justified it with his play of the South hand.

ALGIERS, Oct. 31--The newly independent Algerian regime has swung further to the left than Western diplomats anticipated a month ago.

MADRID, Oct. 31--A diplomatic source said today that at least 200 Chinese Communists recently arrived in Algiers. The Chinese were thought to be advisers to Algreian authorities in specialized fields.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (UPI)-- Most grain futures advanced today on the Board of Trade.

Minnesota's Golden Gophers, who have made futile the running attacks of five opponents, have put together the best defense against rushing in the last 15 college football seasons.

George D. Widener's 4-yearold Nasrullah gelding, Nakrokan, made the favorite by a crowd of 21,535 at Aqueduct yesterday, justified the support with a stirring stretch run that won the $7,500 Columbia Purse.

OUR Government is ruthlessly solicitous about farmers in general. It is always trying to help them till the soil--or make more money by not tilling it. But what, ladies and gentlemen, does it do for the typewriter ranchers of our bosks, our dells!

The Standard Oil Company of California had net income of $79,960,000, or $1.18 a common share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, R.G. Follis, chairman, reported yesterday. This was an increase of 16 per cent over the third quarter of 1961, when net income was $68,725,000, or $1.09 a share on the stock then outstanding.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 --The third day of the 24th annual Standardbred Horse Sales was highlighted by the vendue of 10 Adios yearlinys for $201,500. Thus far at the sale 221 colts and fillies have been auctioned for $907,850.
LONDON, Oct. 31--The British Government announced today that it would discuss with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru a Labor party proposal for lend-lease to sustain India in her struggle with Peking.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31--The General Assembly late today asked U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, to begin discussions with Britain and Southern Rhodesia for a halt in implementing a new Constitution for Southern Rhodesia.
The majority of New York commodity futures rose yesterday in the slowest trading since before the Cuban crisis.

OTTAWA, Oct. 31--Parliament was told today that the controversial art owned by Walter P. Chrysler Jr. was displayed at the National Gallery of Canada here despite a warning received last summer as to the authenticity of some of the paintings.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 31--The $41,000,000 bid by Samuel I. Newhouse for The Omaha World-Herald was rejected this morning by the newspaper's stockholders in favor of a dramatic, last-minute offer from an Omaha contractor.
The Air Reduction Company, Inc., has acquired the Pittsburgh Metallurgical Company in an exchange of stock valued at about $25,667,000.
ROME, Oct. 31--Pope John XXIII pushed a button here today, touching off an electric signal that officially started work in New York on the Vatican pavilion at the site of the 1961 World's Fair.
Laurence Harvey will depict Charles Lamb in "The Albatross." Written by Howard Koch, the plot tells the story of the British essayist-critic and his demented sister, Mary.

AN opening unknown in classical times but played frequently in tournaments these days is the Catalan opening. It combines salient points of the queen's gambit declined with features of the Reti system.
The stock market rally ran out of steam yesterday. Prices closed mixed, with a few more advances than declines.
Scandinavian Airlines System announced yesterday that it was prepared to veto the North Atlantic passenger fare structure agreed upon by the world's airlines.
ROME, Oct. 31--The Ecumenical Council, which ended the first three weeks of its sessions today, will be in recess until Monday.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that a representative of Governor Rockefeller had sought a letter from the Mayor praising the Governor and had offered state approval of a city tax bill in return.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--Additional restraints on news coverage at the Pentagon became known today, but a spokesman insisted that they would not inhibit the proper flow of information to the public.

Gladstone could once describe the United States Senate as "that remarkable body, the most remarkable of all the inventions of modern politics." The rapid growth of Federal power and the increasing complexity of world affairs have made the Senate's responsibilities even more fateful than in Gladstone's day.
Mayor Wagner praised Dr. Ray E. Trussell yesterday for "real toughness of mind and spirit" in raising the level of medical care in the city's hospitals.

The Orchestra National Francais, which opened its American tour at Philharmonic Hall on Oct. 1, returned there last night at tour's end. This time the program was all French and the conductor was Charles Munch.

THIS was supposed to be song week in New York, with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau on Tuesday night, Rita Streich last night and Gerard Souzay Saturday. Mr. FischerDieskau's illness unfortunately cut the festivities by a third. But Miss Streich sang last night in Town Hall as scheduled.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31-- An important California Democrat was asked in mid-summer: "If you had $10,000 to bet on the Senatorial election, would you lay it on Kuchel or Richards?"
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--A "flashing light" satellite known as Anna was placed in a 700mile high orbit today to help determine the size and shape of the earth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- India is expected to receive its first shipment of United States infantry weapons by Saturday under a new agreement designed to aid the Nehru Government in its border battle with the Chinese Communists.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31--Revised assessments by the international lead and zinc study group, which yesterday concluded a week's meeting in Geneva, indicate a considerable improvement in their markets over forecasts made last May. PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31-- Though most of Pennsylvania's unlicensed political diviners made their decisions weeks ago, not even the "winners" have paid attention. All the candidates, taking nothing for granted, were still running hard tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)--The Department of Justice announced the indictment today of six major manufacturers of aluminum conductor cable on charges of price-fixing.
Dr. Siegfried Schoenfeld, a physician, died at Lenox Hill Hospital Tuesday evening of a heart attack he suffered two weeks ago. His age was 77, and he lived at 1432 Lexington Avenue.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Oct. 31 (UPI)--Gustave Smith's Wise Flushing rallied from third place in the stretch today to upset the favored Polylad by a half-length in the $27,800 Narragansett Special at Narragansett Park.
The Cunard Line announced here yesterday that it had appointed Thomas Laird and Robert F. Taylor joint general managers in its headquarters at Liverpool, England.
LISBON, Oct. 31 (AP)--The Portuguese Government's Overseas Council voted today to give territories abroad more voice in administrative affairs and a greater measure of self-rule.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31--After nearly 20 years of research in the Philippines, a solution may be near concerning the source of cadang cadang--a blight that has killed some 10,000,000 coconut trees since 1927.

CAIRO, Oct. 31 (Reuters) --President Gamal Abdel Nasser has suggested a fourpoint plan for a peaceful settlement of the Chinese-Indian border dispute, the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

LENINGRAD, Oct. 31-- The New York City Bal let opened its two-week engagement here tonight at the Kirov Theater before an audience that, though largely official in character, was nevertheless warmly responsive from beginning to end. This was in marked contrast with the opening in Moscow when the same program was presented, but a reluctant audience had to be conquered.

PARIS, Oct. 31--President de Gaulle said today that he was satisfied with the results of Sunday's referendum approving his plan to elect the next President by popular vote.

Navy and Notre Dame officials took time out yesterday to honor the memory of Knute Rockne. The celebrated coach was credited with setting in motion the Navy-Notre Dame series that will have its 36th game on Saturday in Philadelphia.

Four prominent Broadway showmen yesterday questioned the validity of David Merrick's recent statement that an overabundance of funds existed here for backing shows. But a fifth implied support for Mr. Merrick's claim of easy investment money.

PARIS, Nov. 1 (Reuters)-- Policemen seeking elusive leaders of a Secret Army Organization network found three of them were security officials who met their agents and passed instructions in a public swimming pool here, it was disclosed today.
The United States Treasury gold stock fell $40,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Wintter Watts, composer of art songs, died yesterday in his home at 235 Adams Street in Brooklyn. He was 78 years old.

WHEREVER baseball men gathered, Larry Goetz was there. He went at his own expense to World Series, All-Star games and meetings because his devotion to the game was deep. He had come to regard such attendance partly as his duty but more as a labor of love. What made his faithfulness so noticeable was that virtually no one else connected with the sport, including those on expense accounts, appeared with such regularity.

ATHENS, Nov. 1--Stavros Niarchos threatened today to sell or dismantle his $22,000,000 Hellenic Shipyards near Athens if the Greek Government did not annul its license to rival investors to build an $8,000, 000 yard in the same area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)--James G. Cross, former president of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, was indicted today for embezzling his union's funds. He was accused of using the money in an attempt to fix his perjury trial in 1959, which ended in acquittal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) --The Federal Power Commission will attempt to discover how much of the natural gas rate refunds it ordered are passed along to the ultimate consumer.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1-- San Francisco opened its sixth annual international film festival last night with a pacifist movie and belligerent speeches against Hollywood.
Ned Brent's Polarcy's Joy survived a bumping match and a stewards' inquiry to win the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 1--An official of the United States Department of Labor said here today that a high school diploma now assured a youth of $40,000 extra lifetime earnings, and a college diploma of $150,000 more.

DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 1--A high ministerial source indicated today that the Pakistani Government was not prepared to risk accepting overtures by India "to secure her rear" with Pakistan while the Indians were fighting against Chinese Communist invaders.

Dave Beck, former head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was acquitted in Federal court here last night of charges that he had violated the law in accepting a $200,000 loan from members of the trucking industry.
Leading unions in the entertainment business were informally pledged yesterday to "use all legally coercive means" to abolish racial discrimination.

ALTHOUGH machines cannot think, they can assist the shopper who is in a quandary about what to give someone for Christmas. An IBM 1401 computer, which had been fed with thousands of gift suggestion's for all kinds of people, proved this yesterday at Gimbels.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 2--The rejection by Premier Fidel Castro of any form of inspection of the withdrawal of Soviet missiles from Cuba appeared early today to deepen the Cuban crisis.
Governor Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javits appear to be the beneficiaries of political cross-currents in New York City in this year's election.

Ever since the stock market break last spring swept away some unrealities, investors have been searching more eagerly for realities, such as earnings. Economists, too, are studying profit trends as a basic indicator.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 1--Joseph Merlot, Minister for Public Works, resigned from the government tonight in protest against a clause in a bill establishing, a "linguistic frontier" in Belgium.
OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 1-- Twenty-one students in St. John's University Law School toured Sing Sing Prison today in an effort, as they put it, "to find out what happens when you lose a client."
MOSCOW, Nov. 1--The Communist bloc appears to be laboring under strong internal strains.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1--Australia accused the Soviet Union today of practicing anti-Semitism and said that Jews should be permitted to leave the country if they could nod be accorded religious freedom.

Claiming diplomatic immunity, an emissary from the Oakland Raiders came to town yesterday and explained why the New York Titans would be wise to expect the unexpected in their American Football League skirmish with the West Coast club at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

Jorge Bolet, the Cuban-born pianist who is now an American citizen, celebrated the 25th anniversary of his Carnegie Hall debut with a recital there Wednesday night. A large audience attended and greeted Mr. Bolet with cheers at many junctures.
The City Planning Commission adopted and sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday a proposed capitals budget of $1,077,256,195 for the eighteen months beginning Jan 1.
OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 1-- University of Mississippi students were warned today by Chancellor J.D. Williams that further rowdy protests over desegregation could bring expulsion.
MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 2-- The Soviet Union announced early today that it had hurled a one-ton space probe toward Mars.

TURNIPS reach their peak of supply this month and add a pleasing change of vegetable pace. One excellent way of utilizing their sweet crispness is to slice them raw and use them with a sauce for an appetizer.
The Port of New York will bid farewell today to the 20,477 ton French Line passenger ship Flandre.
ALGIERS, Nov. 1--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella said tonight that Algeria was ready to send troops to Angola to fight "Portuguese fascism" as part of a continuing struggle against "imperialism" in Africa.
Sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area rose last month by 4 per cent over the level of October, 1961, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 1--Dave Marr of New Rochelle won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship today by defeating Doug Ford of Yonkers by three strokes in their 18-hole playoff at the Westchester Country Club.
The General Dynamics Corporation made a sharp recovery in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, the report of George Lewis, president, disclosed yesterday.
A one-man band from the West Coast in the person of Jesse (Lone Cat) Fuller is making its New York nightclub debut this week at Gerde's Folk City.

NO one has questioned the agility of Jean Cocteau's mind or the versatility of his talents. But in a play like "Intimate Relations," which opened last night at the Mermaid Theater, his changes of attitude and mood are so mercurial that an audience must find it impossible to keep up with him.
THIS was supposed to be song week in New York, with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau on Tuesday night, Rita Streich Wednesday night and Gerard Souzay Saturday.

THE Cavendish Club of New York, which estab lished a precedent three years ago with an invitational pair tournament open only to 22 of the nation's highest-ranking pairs, will conduct a similar invitational team-of-four tournament over a period of several months this fall and winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Government will sell $1,000,000000 of short-term securities next week in an effort to discourage an outflow of shortterm money to foreign financial centers that are paying higher rates of interest.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 1 (UPI)--West Coast lumbermen have concluded that their industry faces a "significant price decline" as soon as about $22,000,000 worth of timber knocked down by an Oct. 12 storm reaches the market.
A warrant for the arrest of Henry Miller was issued in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday because of the failure of the author of "Tropic of Cancer" to appear to face an obscenity charge.
FORT MYERS, Fla., Nov. 1 (AP)--Sam Bruton, horticulturist and citrus fruit authority, announced today the development of a citrus fruit crossing a pink grapefruit and an orange.

A tighter code for the city's proprietary nursing homes was proposed yesterday by the Department of Hospitals. A dozen health and welfare leaders acclaimed it at a two-hour public hearing of the department's headquarters, 125 Worth Street.

David H. Jaquith, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, declared yesterday that "no business man in his right mind would bring his business to New York in the face of policies fostered by Governor Rockefeller's administration."

YONKERS, Nov. 1--Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd S. Lloyd's Dark Sun, with Del Insko driving, won the Valhalla Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1--An Asian-African drive to consider the expulsion of South Africa from the United Nations unless it modified its racial policies won overwhelming support tonight.

Baruch, noting the rapid approach of an international crisis which might pose a supreme test of the essential coordination and strengths of the industrial economy and the military establishment of the United States, found what appeared to him to be structural weaknesses.

The bond market sagged early yesterday, but recouped most of its losses later in the day.

The purchaser of The Omaha World-Herald was "rebuffed" on his first approach to the paper's management, he indicated yesterday. When his bid was accepted it was about $400,000 over the $41,000,000 offered by Samuel I. Newhouse of New York.

But, as a sire of standard bred horses, 57 of whom have negotiated a mile in two minutes or less, the great stallion is far from finished.

Directors of the Standard Oil company (New Jersey) at a meeting held here yesterday declared a dividend of 70 cents a share for the last quarter. The dividend will be paid on Dec. 12 to stockholders of record of Nov. 13.
